fields.headline: Green bids for Storehouse
fields.trailText: Monaco-based entrepreneur Philip Green is understood to have made a late "take it or leave it" cash offer for all or part of Storehouse and given the directors of the struggling retail group until this morning to decide whether to recommend it to shareholders.
fields.body:
Monaco-based entrepreneur Philip Green is understood to have made a late "take it or leave it" cash offer for all or part of Storehouse and given the directors of the struggling retail group until this morning to decide whether to recommend it to shareholders.

Mr Green has told Storehouse directors he is ready to bid about 60p a share for the entire group or offer £150m to £200m for the Bhs clothing and homeware chain alone.

Storehouse directors, who met on Friday to discuss the various approaches the group has received, are thought to have been told that they have until early this morning to make a decision about Mr Green's offer or he will walk away from negotiations.

An announcement of Mr Green's interest is expected to be made to the stock exchange today. Storehouse shareholders are already mulling over a rival no-bid takeover from Stephen Tucker, another Monaco-based financier.

He plans to parachute a new management team into Storehouse. Led by former Kingfisher director Nigel Whittaker and former Tesco boss Lord MacLaurin, they would aim to extract more value from the group and then sell it on.

Storehouse shares have plummeted over the past two years and are now worth one-sixth of the level at which they were valued in June 1998.

Sources familiar with the talks said the chances of Mr Green's bid being accepted by shareholders depended on whether they were prepared to cut their losses and sell or had the patience to hold on and see if new management improved the group's fortunes.

"A lot of people have lost a lot of money in Storehouse," one said. "If Green comes up with a decent offer, the big investors might decide to sell. The company's value is so low now it's not a huge amount to write off in institutional terms."

Mr Green is in a strong position to seal a deal after two rival bidders, supermarket group Iceland and Brown & Jackson, owner of the Poundstretcher discount group, pulled out of talks with Storehouse last week.

Last month Mr Green abandoned an ambitious takeover for Marks & Spencer amid much acrimony.

But after his successful break-up of the Sears group Mr Green will not be short of backers prepared to fund a bid for Storehouse or only Bhs. However, he is unlikely to break up Bhs and is thought to be much more inclined to run it as a turnaround project.

Analysts say years of poor management, strategic errors and a downturn in the fortunes of the retail sector have left Storehouse heavily indebted. Shares in the group closed at 49p on Friday, valuing the group at £200m.

Last year it turned over £1.4bn but in the half year to November showed a loss before exceptionals of £15.7m.

A cash offer for Bhs would reduce debt considerably and allow management to concentrate on turning around its subsidiary, Mothercare.

fields.headline: Can snail-mail beat email?
fields.standfirst: Electronic messaging hasn't revolutionised the office yet.  Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: Electronic messaging hasn't revolutionised the office yet. Kate Hilpern reports.
fields.body:
Where's the utopian paperless office that the arrival of email promised us? Even the e-commerce minister, Patricia Hewitt, was last week reported to have become so fed up with her unreliable email that she has resorted to good old-fashioned paper. The same day, Tony Blair inadvertently revealed the extent of his technological proficiency, sending an email to Paddy Ashdown that read, "You will be amazed that I have now come into the modern world!" The message got lost in cyberspace.

Perhaps email hasn't quite revolutionised office communication just yet. According to communications analyst Richard Metcalf, some offices, far from missing out on the paperless dream, have witnessed an increase in paper as a result of email. "Email messages now flood computer screens in an avalanche of print. The speed by which these messages can be sent means that memos tend to be distributed in the hundreds. For those secretaries whose bosses ask them to print out all their messages and leave them in their in-trays, this means using up forests of trees every month."

Metcalf has found that because emails have a tendency to "disappear", PAs are increasingly likely to be asked by clients and colleagues to send documents both by email and fax or snail-mail. "This highlights a further potential problem of email in the millennial office - eating up time rather than saving it."

Email has its own rules - many of which make communication easier - but there is also more room for misinterpretation, confusion, deceit and abuse, says psychologist Dr David Lewis. "Email lacks the clues provided by body language in face-to-face communication and of voice tone in telephone communication. Much less consideration is afforded to emails than to letters or faxes where the sender will most likely print the document and re-read it before putting it in an envelope or on to the fax machine. The nature of the medium means that emails are often hasty, poorly composed and unclear. It's little wonder that misunderstandings are rife. It is something secretarial staff, who often act as the go-between for managers and clients, need to be particularly wary of."

More worrying still is the fact that more than half the respondents to a Novell survey claim to have received "flame-mail" - a derogatory, obscene or inappropriate email message. A quarter said they received them several times a week; half said they got them several times a month. Some even said they had left their jobs to avoid the abuse - and there is little doubt that flame mail is on the increase.

Sue Hadwell, 28, a PA from Buckinghamshire, felt she was being publicly humiliated when her manager used to reprimand her by email. "Why haven't you arranged a lunch for my clients on Tuesday? Are you capable of this or not, Sue? Sometimes I think I could do a better job myself." Each message, written entirely in capital letters, had been copied to the company's entire management team.

Email is the easiest outlet for workplace frustrations, believes Lewis. "The aggression displayed in electronic communications can be very overt indeed, both because it is so instant and because there is no chance of interruption. After all, if someone starts hurling abuse at you in the street, or even across an office, you have the chance to interrupt, walk away or even produce a fist. And if you're on the phone, you have the chance to hang up."

As a result of abusive flame-mails the West Yorkshire police were forced to sack an officer and NatWest Markets to dismiss three employees and to discipline 12 others. Anne-Marie Thompson, an expert in employment law at Eversheds in Birmingham, says, "We are increasingly approached by companies that discover employees are abusing the email system."

Even for those who refrain from overt abuse, there may be trouble in store. "People all too often make the mistake of thinking that the contents of an email, like things said over the phone, are private and not permanent. But it is not only possible for an employer to read all your emails and monitor every internet website you visit, it is also perfectly legal," explains Joanna Boag-Thompson, specialist in the internet.

Since email messages can be traced back to their origin for a period of at least two years, you might want to re-think emailing colleagues about irritating clients. Asda recently suffered the consequences of an internal email which suggested that a policeman who had made a complaint about some faulty goods was nothing but a fraud. Quite by chance, the policeman heard about the message. He sued Asda and won.

It goes without saying that email exists to make life easier and if used correctly is an invaluable tool for businesses of all sizes. But perhaps, for the time being, the fact that 70% of the world's business documents are still made of pulped wood is not such a bad thing after all.

fields.headline: Art of Noise
fields.standfirst:
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
* *
fields.trailText: Art of Noise have grasped that their music, such as it is, is merely the pretext for an "occasion". Their first live appearance in London for over a decade was duly packed with tourists and people taking notes on Palm Pilots. You might say it was the triumph of presentation over content, except that the presentation was largely incomprehensible.
fields.body:
Art of Noise have grasped that their music, such as it is, is merely the pretext for an "occasion". Their first live appearance in London for over a decade was duly packed with tourists and people taking notes on Palm Pilots. You might say it was the triumph of presentation over content, except that the presentation was largely incomprehensible.

For this evening, Art of Noise comprised Anne Dudley, Trevor Horn and MC Paul Morley, with Lol Crème on guitar and Amanda Boyd shrieking. One striking thing about the Noise is how quaint their notion of electronica is. While Morley ranted about information overload like a cyber-guru from 1975 ("Faxes! Emails! Pagers!"), the band pumped out the kind of stuff Cabaret Voltaire gave up decades ago.

What of Morley's claim that "it's about ideas"? Hard to say. The show was based around the act's fixation with Debussy, for whom they did few favours with last year's album, The Seduction of Claude Debussy. There were gauche assertions like "Debussy didn't believe in Beethoven, Wagner or the Beatles", while the machinery battered away in the middle distance. They took some pity on the crowd by throwing in "classics" like Moments in Love and Close (To the Edit), which were received with rapturous bemusement. In years to come, we will be able to say "I was there!" while wishing we hadn't been.

webTitle: BA plays down talk of board rift

fields.headline: BA plays down talk of board rift
fields.trailText: British Airways was yesterday attempting to pour cold water on reports of further unrest among its directors.
fields.body:
British Airways was yesterday attempting to pour cold water on reports of further unrest among its directors.

A spokeswoman for the airline said it was "not true" that the chairman and acting chief executive, Lord Marshall, and the deputy chairman, Sir Michael Angus, were battling for control of the troubled carrier. "Everything is as normal," she added.

However, insiders at the group insist that Sir Michael, 70, who is scheduled to step down from the board in July, is lobbying to be installed as chairman and stay on for another year. The conflict is said to be linked to the departure of chief executive Bob Ayling.

Mr Ayling left BA after criticism of the airline's poor financial figures, falling traffic figures and declining morale among its employees.

Sir Michael, who has been a director since 1988, is reported to want a wider overhaul of the board and believes Lord Marshall, as chairman during Mr Ayling's reign, should accept part of the responsibility for BA's troubles. Sir Michael was abroad yesterday and unavailable for comment.

Lord Marshall, who is leading BA's search for a new chief executive, is said to be angry about suggestions that it was Sir Michael and not he who decided Mr Ayling had to go.

Both men are now said to be seeking the support of other BA board members and of Lord King, the airline's father figure and former boss.

Numerous names have been mentioned as possible successors to Mr Ayling as chief executive. The latest is Rod Eddington, head of Ansett, the number two carrier in Australia. Stephen Wolf, executive chairman of USAir, has also been suggested as new chief but his appointment is thought unlikely.

Shares in BA have risen more than 10% since Mr Ayling's departure. However, Friday's close price of 349p is still only around half the price they were trading at 18 months ago.

fields.headline: Visions of Dionysus
fields.standfirst:
LSO/Riccardo Chailly
Barbican Hall, London
* * * *
fields.trailText: Kurt-Hans Goedicke's final Barbican concert as the LSO's principal timpanist ended with a fitting demonstration of his talents. Goedicke's involvement with the LSO stretches back to 1964, and among the countless historic performances to which he has contributed is an account of The Rite of Spring with Stravinsky himself conducting.
fields.body:
Kurt-Hans Goedicke's final Barbican concert as the LSO's principal timpanist ended with a fitting demonstration of his talents. Goedicke's involvement with the LSO stretches back to 1964, and among the countless historic performances to which he has contributed is an account of The Rite of Spring with Stravinsky himself conducting.

Riccardo Chailly's interpretation could hardly have been more opposed to Stravinsky's lean, calculated approach to his famous work. Chailly led a thrilling performance that allowed Goedicke, and the rest of the orchestra, to celebrate the limits of their expressive potential. Maybe some of the inner details of Stravinsky's superimposed textures were lost under the atavistic power of the LSO's brass, but these subtleties were sacrificed for an extrovert, Dionysian experience.

There was mysticism of a more rarefied kind in Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celeste. This is another piece were the timpanist becomes a soloist, especially in the creepily subsiding glissandos of the adagio. Chailly managed to be as demonstrative in Bartok's elusive visions of insect-haunted nocturnes as he was in Stravinsky's tour de force.

But the opening performance of Ives's The Unanswered Question provided the spiritual touchstone for the whole concert. Chailly stationed the strings offstage, and they shrouded the Barbican with a halo of slow chords: a brilliant realisation of Ives's casting of the strings as unchanging Druids. They became the cosmological constant onto which the trumpet player posed his questions and the flutes impatiently replied.

fields.headline: Opec heads for higher output
fields.trailText: Opec ministers will meet in Vienna today amid rising expectations of a deal to increase output and ease worries of an oil-price induced economic slowdown.
fields.body:
Opec ministers will meet in Vienna today amid rising expectations of a deal to increase output and ease worries of an oil-price induced economic slowdown.

They are expected to agree a 5% increase in crude oil production which they hope will bring the price back to between $20 and $25 a barrel.

A year-long curb on production levels has seen the price of oil recover from lows of $10 a barrel to a recent high of $34, raising fears that the price increase could feed inflation in industrialised economies and slow economic growth.

Concern about the outlook for the global economy has presented oil producers with a delicate balancing act: trying to maintain a price level which they regard as reasonable but which is also sustainable.

The dilemma for producers was highlighted by the Kuwaitis who warned at the weekend they would increase their output even if the other Opec members failed to reach a new agreement.

"It is not in Kuwait's interest that oil prices reach between $30 and $35 a barrel," said the foreign minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah.

Although there is disagreement about the extent to which output should be lifted a deal looks likely. Saudi Arabia wants an increase of 1.7m barrels a day but others seek to restrict the increase to around 1m barrels.

Algeria is among those concerned that increasing production too much would send the oil price - which has slipped to around $28 a barrel in recent days - still lower.

But yesterday after talks with his Algerian opposite number, the Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi said: "We and Algeria are agreed on a position."

Oil producers, including non-members of Opec, have come under heavy pressure, particularly from the US to raise output. One concern in the US is that stocks have already been depleted before the warmer weather brings motorists out onto the roads in even greater numbers, boosting the demand for petrol.

Last March Opec reached a deal to cut output levels by more than 4m barrels a day to 23m barrels in an attempt to revive the price. Despite expectations that producers would cheat on their output quotas, the restrictions held - forcing prices higher.

Now Opec is expected to agree an increase of up to 1.5m barrels a day - and Mexico, which is not a member of Opec but which cooperated with the earlier output curbs, has already said it will now lift production levels. Though the US would like to see production increased by 3m barrels a day President Clinton is under stood to be happy with Opec's gradual approach.

Britain last night urged Opec states to achieve market stability with a price of around $25. "We think somewhere in the mid $20s is an area around which an understanding between the oil producers and the oil users can actually come," said energy minister Richard Caborn.

Iraq, which is not a party to Opec decisions, also plans to raise oil sales in the next few weeks under the humanitarian exchange arrangements with the United Nations.

fields.headline: The Flying Dutchman
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
* *
fields.trailText: The inevitable question hanging over the Royal Opera's revival of The Flying Dutchman was whether Covent Garden's tricky computerised stage system would be up to the demands of Ian Judge's infamously hi-tech production. Apart from the occasional metallic creak, the first night actually went without a hitch, but at a price.
fields.body:
The inevitable question hanging over the Royal Opera's revival of The Flying Dutchman was whether Covent Garden's tricky computerised stage system would be up to the demands of Ian Judge's infamously hi-tech production. Apart from the occasional metallic creak, the first night actually went without a hitch, but at a price.

Judge's overwrought staging, a whirligig of swivelling platforms and staircases when unveiled in 1992, was originally geared to the fashionable, if unauthentic, one-act version of the score produced by Wagner's widow Cosima in 1901. (Wagner repeatedly toyed with the idea of running the opera as a continuous whole, but never put it into practice.) A lack of technical rehearsal time forced the Opera House to revert to Wagner's own final edition - the 1860 three-act version - which will doubtless displease some, but does spare us some of the more motion sickness-inducing movements of John Gunter's set.

The production's other flaws remain, however. Psychology is subordinate to spectacle: there's a queasy tilt towards symbolism throughout that renders the opera's depiction of the effect of the uncanny upon a bourgeois society unclear.

More worryingly, the performance itself is wretchedly uneven. The conductor is Simone Young, who drives the piece with a hard, unyielding ferocity, turning it into a Gothic horror story, although Wagner was after something more subtle. There is a lack of tenderness in her interpretation, and the playing is alarmingly coarse.

Bernd Weikl scrapes through the Dutchman's music with a tattered wreck of a voice, his former sexual charisma now conspicuous by its absence. Solveig Kringelborn acts her socks off as Senta, turning Wagner's heroine into a credible neurotic who belongs on Freud's couch - but vocally some of it is excruciatingly squally and she should not really be singing the role in the first place.

Kim Begley's Erik is finely lyrical, if at times effortful. The choral singing is fabulous and there's a definitive Daland from the wonderful Kurt Moll, but he can't redeem an evening that ranks as one of the messiest to be heard at Covent Garden for some time.
fields.bodyText: The inevitable question hanging over the Royal Opera's revival of The Flying Dutchman was whether Covent Garden's tricky computerised stage system would be up to the demands of Ian Judge's infamously hi-tech production. Apart from the occasional metallic creak, the first night actually went without a hitch, but at a price. Judge's overwrought staging, a whirligig of swivelling platforms and staircases when unveiled in 1992, was originally geared to the fashionable, if unauthentic, one-act version of the score produced by Wagner's widow Cosima in 1901. (Wagner repeatedly toyed with the idea of running the opera as a continuous whole, but never put it into practice.) A lack of technical rehearsal time forced the Opera House to revert to Wagner's own final edition - the 1860 three-act version - which will doubtless displease some, but does spare us some of the more motion sickness-inducing movements of John Gunter's set. The production's other flaws remain, however. Psychology is subordinate to spectacle: there's a queasy tilt towards symbolism throughout that renders the opera's depiction of the effect of the uncanny upon a bourgeois society unclear. More worryingly, the performance itself is wretchedly uneven. The conductor is Simone Young, who drives the piece with a hard, unyielding ferocity, turning it into a Gothic horror story, although Wagner was after something more subtle. There is a lack of tenderness in her interpretation, and the playing is alarmingly coarse. Bernd Weikl scrapes through the Dutchman's music with a tattered wreck of a voice, his former sexual charisma now conspicuous by its absence. Solveig Kringelborn acts her socks off as Senta, turning Wagner's heroine into a credible neurotic who belongs on Freud's couch - but vocally some of it is excruciatingly squally and she should not really be singing the role in the first place. Kim Begley's Erik is finely lyrical, if at times effortful. The choral singing is fabulous and there's a definitive Daland from the wonderful Kurt Moll, but he can't redeem an evening that ranks as one of the messiest to be heard at Covent Garden for some time.

fields.headline: M&S moves into virtual underwear
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is attempting to give its share price some dot.com fizz by taking a stake in an online lingerie company.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is attempting to give its share price some dot.com fizz by taking a stake in an online lingerie company.

As part of its efforts to shake off a dowdy image M&S is investing an undisclosed amount in Splendour.com, which will design and market luxury underwear online.

The company is the brainchild of Mark Pilkington, a former chief executive of Wonderbra manufacturer Gossard.

M&S Ventures will take a "major stake" in Splendour.com and supply the company with two board members. It will also give it a stake in a potential rival.

The British lingerie market is worth £1.5bn a year and M&S is its biggest player, with more than a third of total sales.

Splendour.com's first products, aimed at the upper end of the market - at present served mainly through specialist retail outlets - should be available over the internet by the summer.

Mr Pilkington said: "I believe that there is a real opportunity for a net-only premium brand providing luxury lingerie direct to the consumer.

"M&S's investment will help us achieve our goal of becoming Europe's leading online lingerie company."

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst:
Duchess of York, Leeds
* * * * *
fields.trailText: When Jim Morrison sang of an "unhappy girl... locked in the prison of her own device", he could have been prophesying Broadcast's Trish Keenan, clad in shapeless clothing, eyes firmly closed. Possibly the last time a singer was so lost in their own reverie it was the Lizard King himself.
fields.body:
When Jim Morrison sang of an "unhappy girl... locked in the prison of her own device", he could have been prophesying Broadcast's Trish Keenan, clad in shapeless clothing, eyes firmly closed. Possibly the last time a singer was so lost in their own reverie it was the Lizard King himself.

Keenan's voice seems to attack out of the darkness like some warning siren. She has the abandonment of Janis Joplin added to Nico's Teutonic stridency; I'm most reminded of Jefferson Airplane's Grace Slick, dreamy and jagged.

If Keenan's voice was all that was good about Broadcast, they'd still leave many bands standing, but there's much more. While their spiky pop songs and organ-frazzled soundscapes reek of Haight Ashbury, 1968, their synthesisers give them a modern, urban feel. Their music taps into the division between fantasy and reality and, more acutely, into the eerie abyss of childhood where right and wrong are not yet entirely separate. Their songs have both the innocence and darkness of nursery rhymes and playground chants.

When Keenan sings, something truly haunted comes out. Lines like "My room's too small for parties, so spacious when you're lonely" are so powerful they follow you home. When Geri Halliwell can become a superstar there's something deeply wrong with the world, but if it can produce bands like this I'm all for it.

 On tour and at Dingwalls, London NW1 (0171-267 1577), on Wednesday.

fields.headline: I'm stuck on you
fields.standfirst:
Cuckoos
Gate Theatre, London
* * * *
fields.trailText: There are many famous couples in world drama: Didi and Gogo, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. But I can't think of any pair so inseparably bonded as Tito and Beatrice in Giuseppe Manfridi's Cuckoos. They are permanently stuck in an act of anal intercourse in which there are endless comings and no goings.
fields.body:
There are many famous couples in world drama: Didi and Gogo, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. But I can't think of any pair so inseparably bonded as Tito and Beatrice in Giuseppe Manfridi's Cuckoos. They are permanently stuck in an act of anal intercourse in which there are endless comings and no goings.

It sounds spectacularly rude, and as we watch Tito's father, a hearty gynaecologist, turn up with a retractor to extricate his son's instrument, we are not far from the world of Carry On up the Khyber. But, as it progresses over the course of 80 minutes, Manfridi's play turns from sexual farce into domestic tragedy. It becomes a metaphor for a society riddled with hypocrisy - in family-worshipping Italy, Manfridi sets out to destroy the household gods.

You see the intention; making it work is another matter. But Colin Teevan's translation neatly combines English puns with Euro-absurdism. Peter Hall's production not only keeps the action moving - which is tricky when much of it takes place under a silk parachute - but also faultlessly captures the transition from sophomoric excess to Sophoclean pain and reminds us this play is about self-discovery as much as sex. Commendations for bravery and skill to Kelly Hunter as the long-suffering Beatrice, Paul Ready as the tumescent Tito and David Yelland as the pride-swollen medico. The play sounds sensational; in the end it is a savagely sombre work about the incestuous inwardness of the nuclear family.

 Until April 22. Box office: 0171-229 0706

fields.headline: Working holidays
fields.standfirst: How to stimulate your mind and wallet when a sabbatical's out of the question
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: How to stimulate your mind and wallet when a sabbatical's out of the question.
fields.body:
Sabbaticals are flavour of the year with companies. In what is seen as a touchy-feely kind of a move, staff are being seduced out of the workplace for months at a time to go in search of a little quality time to reflect and study their skills.

Break-taking has its obvious rewards but the staff are proving wary. Three months in current business culture is the equivalent to three years in the post-IT era. And the thought of six months of prescribed rest brings to mind words like pie and sky. Families create lists of home repairs and redecorating that can make eight hours in the office sound like tropical paradise. So if you're looking for mental stimulation and a trip along a new learning curve without the hassle of re-thatching the roof or damp-coursing the conservatory, why not just take on another job alongside the existing one? Relieve your boredom and make money at one and the same time with these second career options.

Net millionaire Study the stories in the press and you may find this career so easy it lacks challenge. Time-wise the advantages are obvious, though, as you can take all those moments spend gazing dully at the screen-saver and turn them into solid dosh. Create your own website, float it on the stock market and - bingo!

Qualifications: The ability to plug in a laptop, youth - anything above an embryo need not apply Advantages: You can start up during lunch breaks or when the boss isn't looking Disadvantages: Net millionaire are currently very high profile in papers and magazines. To avoid appearing in Hello and alerting the boss to your extra-curricular activities make sure you tick the no publicity box.

Best selling author: Every man and his dog seems to be writing books these days, so why not join the ranks of criminals and disgraced politicians and get scribbling? Offices are full of inspiration for the truly creative mind (for example Bridget Jones's Diary) and the pre-sales advances will make your eyes water.

Advantages: The tools are in front of you on your desk right now. Writing a novel looks almost exactly like writing a sales report, so the risks are minimal and your boss may even think you're working harder than normal. Disadvantages: Only when the boss wanders up to your screen and asks why it features details of a sustained orgasm, rather than an update of the firm's annual reports.

Sandwich supplier All companies seem to have acquired their own external catering supplier, in the shape of a puffed-looking person on a pushbike carrying a large wicker basket full of baguettes and Twix bars. Unless your firm is supplied by anyone boasting mafia connections why not up your order of sliced farmhouse granary and get flogging your own home-made sarnies before the bike arrives?

Advantages: Captive clientele, on-the-spot marketing trends research, potential for growth and expansion. Was this how Conran started? Disadvantages: Getting up at four am to slap margarine over three hundred slices of bread, bike tyre marks over the bonnet of your company car as the current caterer exacts his/her revenge, colleagues dying of starvation if you take a week's sickie.

Lap dancer These clubs are opening everywhere and - as the work tends to be evening only - you don't have to give up the day job, especially if you are an insomniac.

Qualifications: Ability to slide around poles in stilettos, cellulite-free thighs. Advantages: Complete change of culture for harassed desk -bound worker, lots of exercise, meet new people. Disadvantages: Bottom-wobbling may prove tedious or cause RSI, you may find yourself gyrating in front of your boss.

fields.headline: Net gains for job seekers
fields.standfirst: Online recruitment companies have welcomed cheaper internet use. Hilary Whitney reports on how it could revolutionise the search for work
fields.trailText: Online recruitment companies have welcomed cheaper internet use. Hilary Whitney reports on how it could revolutionise the search for work.
fields.body:
We're accustomed in the UK to being several years behind America, but when it comes to internet take-up, there is little doubt why. Our transatlantic cousins are accustomed to unmetered local telephone calls, allowing them to spend hours on the internet without worrying too much about cost. We Brits, on the other hand, have always had one eye on the clock and another on the bank balance when surfing the net - at least outside work.

So internet service provider AltaVista's offer last month to give free unmetered access to the net in return for a one-off payment of £30 was genuinely innovatory - and had other ISPs scrambling to react with similarly competitive schemes. The expense of going online has been one of the biggest deterrents for people using the internet, and any moves to make access cheaper have been welcomed by Tony Blair. The government is worried that, unless prices are reduced, Britain will fall behind as the internet develops.

Unsurprisingly, competitive net charges have been greeted enthusiastically by the growing number of free recruitment websites. These sites put firms directly in contact with jobseekers by using a database that matches applicants' skills to appropriate vacancies. The employers make contact with their chosen candidate by email and the process continues (as normal) from there. Kamal Sharma, managing director of InterviewMe.co.uk, says, "Not only can companies get their job details instantly displayed on-screen in front of potential employees up and down the country, they can now eliminate exorbitant agency commissions and put the money where it belongs - into attractive starting salaries and additional profits." And if candidates can take time to look around the site without worrying how much it will cost, so much the better.

Tempz.com, which claims to be the world's first online temp agency, has taken this one step further. Rather than just matching skills with jobs, it will offer a full temp agency service to employers without reflecting the costs of the traditional infrastructure and overheads. All transactions, including skills testing and administration, will happen online. Candidates will register via their own web page, where they can update their availability, skills, references and requirements. They can also visit employers' web pages to check out assignments and hours of work before accepting a job. Even the face-to-face interview will be replaced by a series of third-party endorsements, which chief executive Chris Leonard claims is a more objective assessment. In theory at least, temps should enjoy greater flexibility and more control over their careers, plus better rates of pay because of the agency's low margin.

But if online agencies are set to benefit from cheap internet deals, what does this mean for high street recruitment firms? The more established secretarial and temporary agencies have been quick to develop their own internet sites, where prospective employees can view the current vacancies and send in their CVs by email, and most claim not to be threatened by the new online agencies. One consultant argued that online skills testing was open to abuse as it would be impossible to prove that it genuinely was the candidate who had undertaken the test.

"Personality is incredibly important when you are trying to place someone who will be working as part of a team," says Holly Wells, a senior consultant at Tate Appointments, insisting that the ideal employee can be identified only by a face-to-face interview and personal contact. But with internet access booming - and now at next to no cost - traditional recruitment agencies will be nervously counting on candidates continuing to require their services.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A love story set in turn of the century Egypt that was short-listed fir the Booker, plus Remembrance Day, An Intimate History of Killing, Pilate and The World's Smallest Unicorn
fields.body:
The Map of Love
Ahdaf Soueif
Bloomsbury £6.99, pp529
Buy it at BOL

Short-listed for the 1999 Booker Prize, Soueif's beautiful and intricate novel has at its centre a love story set in Egypt at the turn of the last century, but is equally concerned with the history, politics, and culture of the country itself.

Recently widowed, Lady Anna Winterbourne travels to British occupied Egypt in 1900 and falls in love with Sharif, a passionate Egyptian nationalist. A hundred years later, her great granddaughter Isabel becomes obsessed with Omar, an Americanised Egyptian musician, and enlists the aid of his sister Amal to piece together Anna and Sharif's story from old notebooks and letters.

Rich in both character and scope, Soueif's narrative adeptly weaves together past and present, and demonstrates the truth in the saying that the more things change, the more they remain the same.

Remembrance Day
Henry Porter
Orion £5.99, pp482
Buy it at BOL

When a London bus is blown up by a terrorist bomb, suspicion falls on Con Lindow, a young Irish biologist recently returned from America, and his elder brother Eamonn.

Determined to prove their innocence, Con's discovery of a cryptic message in Eamonn's flat leads him to realise that perhaps big brother wasn't the simple librarian he seemed, and the hunt is on for the real bomber. The question is will it be in time to prevent one final, audacious atrocity?

The terrorist's hi-tech methods are ingenious and frighteningly credible, and with the SAS, IRA, FBI and Whitehall shenanigans thrown into the pot, Porter's debut thriller doesn't let the tension slacken, from the literally explosive start to the edge-of-your-seat climax.

An Intimate History of Killing
Joanna Bourke

Granta £9.99, pp564
Buy it at BOL

'What the hell else is war than killing people?' asked William L. Calley, the American lieutenant who oversaw the My Lai massacre during the Vietnam war, in which 500 unarmed men, women and children were slaughtered by US troops.

Joanna Bourke uses memoirs and reports from veterans of the First and Second World Wars as well as the Vietnam War to remind us that behind the stories of glory and comradeship, the primary business of war is killing, and she argues that, far from being hell, for many men (and women) sanctioned bloodletting was, in fact, deeply satisfying.

Unconventional as some of its conclusions are, Bourke's fascinating study is so well sourced it's hard to refute, even though it's likely to upset anyone who believes in either the nobility of war or the fundamental decency of mankind.

Piliate: The Biography of an Invented Man
Ann Wroe
Vintage £7.99, pp400
Buy it at BOL

Beginning, bizarrely enough, in Blackpool in 1870, Ann Wroe performs an impressive feat of a biography on Pontius Pilate, about whom very little is actually known but an awful lot seems to have been made up.

Pilate: the Biography of an Invented Man's success lies in the fact that Wroe makes no attempt to settle on a 'true' version, but instead presents what little hard information exists alongside all the conflicting theories and myths, from the Gospels' accounts of Pontius Pilate's role in the crucifixion to the legend of his ghost haunting a lake in Lucerne.

Wroe vividly recreates the everyday background of Pilate's life, down to the minutiae of shaving, and handles her historical material with such humour and skill that we feel able to glimpse the real man behind two millennia of obfuscation and fantasy.

The World's Smallest Unicorn
Shena Mackay
Vintage £6.99, pp223
Buy it at BOL

Retirement homes for clowns, failed playwrights in trees, unwashed uncles and families from hell.

The manifold horrors of suburbia feature large in Shena Mackay's collection of short stories, which are sometimes as abrupt as a snapshot but so acutely observed that it's impossible not to wince - or laugh - at times in recognition.

Mackay gives an absurdist touch to the mundane and everyday, with an occasional foray into the downright surreal (such as the travel writer who ingests Marble Arch in 'The Wilderness Club'), revealing her characters' secrets, passions and flaws with a wit and descriptive flare that's as mercilessly illuminating as a flashbulb going off in a darkened room.

The World's Smallest Unicorn Shena Mackay Vintage £6.99, pp223 Buy it at BOL Retirement homes for clowns, failed playwrights in trees, unwashed uncles and families from hell. The manifold horrors of suburbia feature large in Shena Mackay's collection of short stories, which are sometimes as abrupt as a snapshot but so acutely observed that it's impossible not to wince - or laugh - at times in recognition. Mackay gives an absurdist touch to the mundane and everyday, with an occasional foray into the downright surreal (such as the travel writer who ingests Marble Arch in 'The Wilderness Club'), revealing her characters' secrets, passions and flaws with a wit and descriptive flare that's as mercilessly illuminating as a flashbulb going off in a darkened room.

fields.headline: Ghostly writing
fields.standfirst: David Mitchell weaves a rich narrative tapestry in Ghostwritten
fields.trailText: David Mitchell's ambitious first novel, Ghostwritten, is wide-reaching and multi-layered
fields.body:
Ghostwritten
David Mitchell
Sceptre £6.99, pp436
Buy it at BOL

David Mitchell's ambitious first novel was greeted with effusive reviews on its hardback publication; A.S.Byatt requested to read with him at London's literary festival last year. The accolades are well deserved.

Ghostwritten is a wide-reaching, multi-layered novel built from 10 subtly-linked stories, each with a different setting and voice. Land- and cityscapes are skilfully drawn, clearly from experience - Japan, Hong Kong, London, St Petersburg - with strong outlines and a shrewd eye for detail.

The story begins with the narrative of Quasar, initiate of a sect that perpetrates a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway. His story blends into that of a teenage assistant in a record store, who in turn enters the life of a dodgy-dealing Hong Kong lawyer who believes his apartment to be haunted. From there we move to an old woman on Holy Mountain, then to Mongolia, then to St Petersburg, where characters from earlier episodes recur, as the author blends crisp dialogue with varied but altogether convincing narrative voices. He also shifts genre with ease.

But Mitchell also captures a tenderness, a yearning for something deeper, just below what often appears in as a bleak and cheerless surface. One such moment occurs when Neal - the hard-living lawyer caught up in illegal dealing - wanders into a part of Hong Kong Westerners rarely see. 'Two old people in a room devoid of furniture... I wish I could go into their room and sit down. I'd give my Rolex for that. I wish they would smile, and pour me a cup of jasmine tea. I wish the world was like that.'

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Albert Camus's seminal essay on the Absurd has become, since its publication in 1942, one of the most influential discussions of atheism of this century.
fields.body:
The Myth of Sisyphus
Albert Camus
Penguin Classics £6.99, pp 192
Buy it at BOL

Albert Camus's seminal essay on the Absurd has become, since its publication in 1942, one of the most influential discussions of atheism of this century.

At the centre of his argument is the image of the Titan Sisyphus, condemned by the gods forever to push a boulder up a mountain, only to have it roll down again as it reaches the top, forcing him to begin again. In Sisyphus, Camus sees a picture of man's existence - essentially meaningless, with death as the only ultimate certainty; an existence fleshed out in the figure of a man condemned to death in his novel L'Etranger.

The two obvious responses to this reality - suicide and religious belief - are examples of what Camus calls 'the leap'; an escape from the certainty of death and a refusal to see life purely in its own terms. Instead he proposes 'absurd freedom'; what James Wood describes in his accessible introduction to this edition as 'an extension of life in life itself, a kind of aeration of life'. Camus concludes by saying: 'One must imagine Sisyphus happy.'

This edition also includes five shorter essays, including Summer in Algiers and The Artist and his Time.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: An abridged version of Nicci French's tale of abuse leaves out none of the suspense
fields.body:
Killing Me Softly
Nicci French
Read by Emilia Fox
Running time 3 hours

Penguin Audiobooks £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Nicci French likes to deal with contentious subjects. Her first novel examined false memory syndrome; this, her third, gatecrashes the addictive world of abused women. Addictive in the sense that French makes a successful attempt to explain why women find it hard to leave men who abuse them.

Alice Loudon is an attractive young scientist with a loving boyfriend. They have a comfortable lifestyle, a 'crew' of friends and plans for the future. But one morning on her way to work, Alice passes a man with 'startling blue' eyes who holds her gaze by sheer strength of will and lures her into his strange and dangerous world.

From the moment Adam Tallis reaches out and touches Alice, to the moment he first exerts his violent power over her, she is possessed, so totally in love with him that even though she comes to suspect him of terrible crimes, she cannot leave him.

Killing Me Softly has been abridged for this audiobook. It is a shame, because in the full-length version, French finely tunes the build-up of possession and entrapment, luring the reader into Tallis's arms and making it possible to judge Alice's actions as totally credible.

Having said that, none of the suspense is lost. Emilia Fox is spot-on as Alice, sounding intelligent but gullible (her interpretation of how journalists speak - a little bit of Cockney thrown in with hard-nosed nonchalance - is endearing). As she sweetly describes the climactic closing moments, I could hear my pulse thudding in my temples.

fields.headline: A not so great Gatsby
fields.standfirst: A late draft of F Scott Fitzgerald's masterpiece brings nothing new to the party
fields.trailText: A late draft of F Scott Fitzgerald's masterpiece brings nothing new to the party
fields.body:
Trimalchio

F Scott Fitzgerald
Edited by James LW West III
Cambridge University Press £30, pp192

Buy it at BOL

Books Unlimited author page

The word 'early' in this book's subtitle - 'An Early Version of The Great Gatsby' - is supremely misleading, attached as it is to a very late version of a slowly evolving masterpiece. This was the text set up in galley proofs in late 1924 and sent to F Scott Fitzgerald in Europe for his usual (but in this case unusually successful) tinkerings.

Yes, technically Trimalchio predates the published book, since proofs by definition predate the book that results from them, but only by a couple of months. The real tortuous labour was in the past by then, labour that had seen a novel first proposed in 1922 lose its nineteenth-century setting and its planned Catholic element, while 'Dud' and 'Ada' became Nick Carraway the narrator and Daisy the object of Jay Gatsby's obsession.

It's convenient to give the late version printed here its own title, but Trimalchio (or Trimalchio in West Egg) never struck Fitzgerald as a wholly satisfactory candidate. Other discarded possibilities included Under the Red, White and Blue, Among the Ash Heaps and Millionaires, and The High-Bouncing Lover.

Trimalchio is an unsatisfactory title both because it is portentously classical (Trimalchio was the nouveau riche partygiver in Petronius's Satyricon) and because it is inaccurate. Gatsby hardly joins in the revels he lays on and, of course, it turns out the whole performance is to impress a single person. He is a romantic destroyed by his dream, and an upstart much worthier than those he seeks to impress.

Though Scribners, the publishers of The Great Gatsby, used the caption 'F Scott Fitzgerald, Satirist' on one of their advertisements, the genre indication is not helpful. If the publicity department didn't quite know how to market what they had, editorial was more on the ball.

This edition reprints Maxwell Perkins's well-known letters of response to the Trimalchio version, in which he voices mild reservations about structure and tension in a couple of chapters. Perkins made no detailed suggestions, and was indeed only confirming doubts already expressed by Fitzgerald.

It's likely that the book's fate would have been much the same without the revisions (largely of the timing of disclosures about Gatsby's history) done at this stage. A few distinctive jewels were added, and a few dropped out of the published text, like the moment when Gatsby asks Daisy for the name of her hairdresser, which a celebrity party guest wants to know. Gatsby imagines that Daisy will be flattered by the request, when actually she's reluctant to share the secrets of her look.

The divide between the two of them is marked by his parvenu eagerness and her patrician resistance, and occasions Nick's melancholy observation that there existed 'no such intimacy' as would allow for the criticising of each other's friends.

There are moments of jaunty drollery in both versions that bring the book oddly close to PG Wodehouse territory, as when a party of drunken party guests try to explain to an unfortunate motorist 'that wheel and car were no longer joined by any physical bond'.

The true Gatsby note (though perhaps closer to a chord than a note) is half-lyrical and half-disenchanted. The most memorable moments are either ripe to the point of self-parody ('the abortive sorrows and unjustified elations of men', or 'a persistent organ sound' after a party 'as the full bellows of the Earth blew the frogs full of life') or else oddly analytical, like a sentence that begins: 'If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures...'. Fitzgerald builds up the exquisite surface of his novel with alternating layers of a rich varnish and a mildly caustic wash.

The Great Gatsby has an undeserved reputation as a lucky book, both in terms of its composition and reception. John Updike, reviewing a biography of Fitzgerald in 1994, quoted Wright Morris about this being one of the few books to have come into the world 'with the perfection of a bird's egg', and referred to it himself as 'superbly fortunate'.

Yet the Cambridge Edition (of which this Trimalchio is a later product) had already demonstrated in 1991 how much labour went into the enamelling of this bird's egg. Updike describes Fitzgerald as 'an author one should read when young' and comments that 'everything works' in Gatsby because the author has split himself in two between narrator and hero - as if this was a rather unsporting way of overcoming his immaturity.

The Great Gatsby was described as 'about the best American novel ever written' as early as 1924 - but that was Fitzgerald himself in one of his boisterous moods, before the manuscript was even finished. The book's reviews were mixed and sales disappointing. Copies of the second printing (a run of 3,000, in August 1925) were still in the warehouse when Fitzgerald died in 1940, and the 1934 Modern Library reprint was discontinued for lack of sales.

Some revivals of literary reputation are accomplished by critics, some by publishers and some by mere readers. In the 1940s, The Great Gatsby began to be widely available and popular; the critics caught up only a decade later. It's understandable that the academic establishment should seek to make amends for so sluggish a consecration of classic status. But as for giving separate publication to a late draft that shares almost almost all its material with the established text - that's closer to fetishism than act of atonement.

fields.headline: Jottings from the hard shoulder
fields.standfirst: Jack Kerouac's letters reflect his shambolic life and predictable death
fields.trailText: Jack Kerouac's letters reflect his shambolic life and predictable death
fields.body:
Jack Kerouac: Selected Letters

Edited by Ann Charters
Viking £25, pp514

Buy it at BOL

Books Unlimited author page

'On The Road,' William Burroughs once wrote, 'sold a trillion Levis and a million espresso machines, and also sent countless kids on the road.' From Easy Rider to the lyrics of Bruce Springsteen, American popular culture still stands in the shadow of Sal Paradise, this primordial literary hero.

As well as blue jeans and coffee bars, it has also been Jack Kerouac's fate to be associated with a variety of existential states, from alienation to restlessness, adolescent dissatisfaction to downright teenage revolt. His inspired exploration of these conditions has sometimes obscured the fact that Kerouac was the master of what he called 'spontaneous' American prose (it was anything but) and the author of several Beat Generation masterpieces - Big Sur, Desolation Angels, The Dharma Bums and Lonesome Traveler, of which On the Road is justly the most famous.

Kerouac was the descendant of Breton Canadians who had married with Mohawk and Caughnawaga Indians and celebrated what Hanif Kureishi has called an 'unfastidious relish for life', but he was also a highly self-conscious literary craftsman. When Anne Charters, a lifelong Kerouac scholar, was first invited by the author to inspect his archive, she did not stumble, as you might imagine, into a room full of smelly old sleeping bags, half-empty whisky bottles and cigarette butts, but was shown 'folders of letters... filed carefully away'. Later on, Kerouac, now in a terrible alcoholic decline, went through the carbons he had kept of his own typed letters to his friends and provided annotations.

Cyril Connolly, once the literary editor of The Observer, used to delight in the conundrum: 'What is the book that takes a lifetime to write and which the author will never read? His collected letters.' If ever there was a writer who put the unread book of his life into his correspondence, it was Jean Louis Lebris de Kerouac.

This, the second of two indispensable volumes, opens in the year of the publication of On the Road and ends the day before his death at the age of 47. It demonstrates in pitiless detail how successful American writers can be destroyed by the evils of celebrity, how they become the dancing bears of newspaper columns and television chat shows, and how, finally, they are destroyed by creative exhaustion. More specifically, it narrates how Kerouac was literally destroyed by the hostile critical response to his work.

When this volume opens, all this is yet to come. We find the struggling writer dispatching inspired 'spontaneous' riffs to friends like Allen Ginsberg, William Burroughs, Gregory Corso, Gary Snyder and Laurence Ferlinghetti and debating with his literary agent whether he should not, after all, change the title of his forthcoming novel to Rock and Roll Road to 'double the sales'. He need not have worried. Like Byron, Kerouac woke up on the day after publication, 5 September 1957, to find himself famous.

He, alone, was probably not surprised. He had already written that he would 'rather die than betray my faith in my work' and elsewhere boasted that: 'Hemingway has nothing over me when it comes to pernicketiness about craft.' And, like Hemingway, he soon became 'fat, dejected, ashamed, bored, pestered and shot. I must get a cabin or die...'

Having described himself to a friend as 'the great quitter', he died of severe abdominal haemorrhaging brought on by rampant alcoholism.

fields.headline: Amazonitis
fields.trailText: I was having lunch the other day with a well-known contemporary novelist when it became clear to me that he was suffering from an acute form of that debilitating millennial condition known as Amazonitis.
fields.body:
I was having lunch the other day with a well-known contemporary novelist when it became clear to me that he was suffering from an acute form of that debilitating millennial condition known as Amazonitis.

The first, unmistakable symptom of this condition is the sufferer's compulsive need to allude repeatedly to the sales of his book, as they are measured on the Internet by Amazon.com, and to regret that he couldn't log on with his laptop right there at the table to demonstrate what he was talking about.

In the bad old days, before Internet bookselling became a fact of everyday life, the biggest commercial excitement an author could get was to discover that his/her book was a bestseller. Quite quickly, the thrill of this would wear off when you discovered that, in order to achieve the dubious sobriquet 'national bestseller', your modest fiction (or whatever) had only to sell an equally modest 200 or 300 copies in the week after publication.

Now, with Amazon, you can discover that not only you are No 4,065 (after John Grisham and assorted Horse Whisperers), but also that you have risen to that dizzy height in the course of a morning. Or, you can find out that your highly acclaimed backlist prizewinner is currently No 27,975 in the Amazon charts. And you can drive yourself to the edge of reason in the quest for your current rating.

Intrigued by the identification of what I considered to be a rare and as yet unrecognised condition, I decided to devise a questionnaire to elicit from various writer friends, on conditions of strictest anonymity, the nature and extent of this new malady. Shorn of its awesome psephological jargon, my questionnaire boiled down to two fundamental questions: 1) How often in the course of a day do you, as a professional writer, find yourself checking the sales of your most recent volume on the Internet? and 2) Have you ever become sufficiently interested in your book's fate to read what Amazon's unofficial reviewers are saying about your work and, if so, do you admit to drafting an authorial riposte?

I dispatched these questions to about 20 English and American writers of my acquaintance and waited for a response. The results have been gratifying. Of my core sample, some 14 admitted to being fairly regular Amazon browsers. 'I sit at my desk all day, five days a week, so of course I can't resist going on to the Internet; it's the hi-tech equivalent of gazing out of the window,' wrote one.

By contrast, five (four of them women) said they were too busy and/or technologically challenged even to contemplate such a thing. One Luddite soul asked what was I on about. But it was the answers to my second question (Do you worry about Internet reviews?) which produced the most interesting replies.

'This,' replied H from Berkshire, 'is potentially a vision of endless hell. Once upon a time, the emotionally strenuous business of being reviewed used to last about a fortnight; after that, like a trip to the dentist, it was over. Now it appears it's destined to go on forever. I realised to my horror, a couple of months ago, that I could be as irritated by a bad review from sadcase@nowheresville.com [likely to be read by a few hundred] as I could be by one from a prominent critic in the Daily Telegraph. At that point, I stopped bothering to take them seriously; the alternative is madness.'

Actually, the alternative is that Amazon will go bust. A cursory reading of Amazon.Com: Get Big Fast by Robert Spector (Random House £18.99, pp272) suggests that though Amazon has yet to make a cent's worth of profit (and before last Christmas it posted the biggest quarterly loss in its short history), there is no shortage of venture capitalists out there to take up the torch.

So there you have it. Amazon is here to stay. And next time you see a friend eyeing the Internet don't call a doctor; remind him instead of Somerset Maugham's advice to writers: 'Don't read your reviews, dear boy, measure them.'

Now, with Amazon, you can discover that not only you are No 4,065 (after John Grisham and assorted Horse Whisperers), but also that you have risen to that dizzy height in the course of a morning. Or, you can find out that your highly acclaimed backlist prizewinner is currently No 27,975 in the Amazon charts. And you can drive yourself to the edge of reason in the quest for your current rating. Intrigued by the identification of what I considered to be a rare and as yet unrecognised condition, I decided to devise a questionnaire to elicit from various writer friends, on conditions of strictest anonymity, the nature and extent of this new malady. Shorn of its awesome psephological jargon, my questionnaire boiled down to two fundamental questions: 1) How often in the course of a day do you, as a professional writer, find yourself checking the sales of your most recent volume on the Internet? and 2) Have you ever become sufficiently interested in your book's fate to read what Amazon's unofficial reviewers are saying about your work and, if so, do you admit to drafting an authorial riposte? I dispatched these questions to about 20 English and American writers of my acquaintance and waited for a response. The results have been gratifying. Of my core sample, some 14 admitted to being fairly regular Amazon browsers. 'I sit at my desk all day, five days a week, so of course I can't resist going on to the Internet; it's the hi-tech equivalent of gazing out of the window,' wrote one. By contrast, five (four of them women) said they were too busy and/or technologically challenged even to contemplate such a thing. One Luddite soul asked what was I on about. But it was the answers to my second question (Do you worry about Internet reviews?) which produced the most interesting replies. 'This,' replied H from Berkshire, 'is potentially a vision of endless hell. Once upon a time, the emotionally strenuous business of being reviewed used to last about a fortnight; after that, like a trip to the dentist, it was over. Now it appears it's destined to go on forever. I realised to my horror, a couple of months ago, that I could be as irritated by a bad review from sadcase@nowheresville.com [likely to be read by a few hundred] as I could be by one from a prominent critic in the Daily Telegraph. At that point, I stopped bothering to take them seriously; the alternative is madness.' Actually, the alternative is that Amazon will go bust. A cursory reading of Amazon.Com: Get Big Fast by Robert Spector (Random House £18.99, pp272) suggests that though Amazon has yet to make a cent's worth of profit (and before last Christmas it posted the biggest quarterly loss in its short history), there is no shortage of venture capitalists out there to take up the torch. So there you have it. Amazon is here to stay. And next time you see a friend eyeing the Internet don't call a doctor; remind him instead of Somerset Maugham's advice to writers: 'Don't read your reviews, dear boy, measure them.' robert mcrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Ra ra Rasputin, still being sold as a love machine

fields.headline: Ra ra Rasputin, still being sold as a love machine
fields.standfirst: Edvard Radzinsky reveals new evidence on the 'holy peasant' - but can it really be the last word?
fields.trailText: Edvard Radzinsky reveals new evidence on the 'holy peasant' - but can it really be the last word?
fields.body:
Rasputin: the Last Word

Edvard Radzinsky

Weidenfeld & Nicolson £20, pp524
Buy it at BOL

In 1995, in a scene worthy of the opening of a thriller, Sotheby's put on sale a thick file of documents compiled in Russia in March 1917. The file, part of an investigation by the revolutionary government into the 'dark forces' that had supposedly controlled the tsarist regime, contained the original interrogation reports of roughly three dozen individuals - society ladies, clergymen, courtiers, ministers, maids and manservants - who had either met, or been under the spell of, Grigory Efimovich Rasputin, the Siberian 'holy peasant', who had been sensationally murdered three months earlier.

In a second thrillerish scene, the successful bidder for the Sotheby's file turned out to be none other than the world-famous Russian cellist, Mstislav Rostropovich, who carried his purchase back to his Paris apartment ('draped with Winter Palace curtains emblazoned with the tsarist coat of arms') and presented it, under the 'inexpressibly sad' gaze of a portrait of Tsar Nicholas II, to his friend, the playwright and historian, Edvard Radzinsky.

'It was the File,' writes Radzinsky, breathlessly, 'the one [for which] I had been looking for so long!' Precisely where The File - as he insists on capitalising it - had lain for the previous 78 years, or how it found its way to a London sale-room, or whether it has been authenticated, are questions he does not answer.

Radzinsky occupies a curious position in Russian literary life, for which there is no adequate analogy in the West. The author of two highly regarded biographies, of Nicholas II and Stalin, he is also, according to his blurb, 'the most frequently staged playwright after Chekhov' and 'the host of the popular Russian television programme, The Enigmas of History'. It is as if Harold Pinter divided his time between the Public Record Office, the National Theatre and presenting Timewatch.

Rasputin: the Last Word exhibits all the strengths and weaknesses one would expect of such a multi-talented hybrid. The first 37 years of Rasputin's life - his birth in a Siberian village, his reputation for thievery and womanising, his religious mania, his wanderings as an impoverished 'holy fool' - are skipped over in barely as many pages.

Radzinsky gets into his stride only when he reaches October 1906, when Rasputin, by now transmogrified into the fashionable mystic, 'Father Grigory', manages to worm his way into an audience with the tsar and tsarina. 'He made a remarkably strong impression on Her Majesty and me,' the tsar noted, 'and instead of five minutes, our conversation lasted well over an hour.'

From then on, thanks chiefly to his apparent ability to control the heir to the throne's haemophiliac attacks, Rasputin's power and fame grew, until he became a mythic figure. What is the truth about his role? His influence over the autocratic tsarina seems to have been absolute; over the tsar, less so.

Rasputin opposed Russia's entry into the war in 1914, but was in Siberia during the crucial period, recovering from an assasination attempt; Radzinsky suggests he might have changed history had he been fully fit, but advances little evidence. He also hints that Rasputin may have had sexual relations with the tsarina, but again has no proof. More than once, reading the tsarina's pleas to the tsar, for example not to take any military decisions until he had brushed his hair with Rasputin's comb, I found myself reminded of nothing so much as the relationship between Ronald and Nancy Reagan and Nancy Reagan's astrologer.

What Radzinsky does have that is new and indisputable is The File. Here is a huge amount of colourful, if disjointed, detail from Rasputin's inner circle, who used regularly to congregate at his St Petersburg apartment (No3 English Avenue, telephone number - he would answer it himself - 64646).

These previously unpublished eyewitness accounts, collected within months of his death, provide fresh evidence of the nature of his hold over dozens of fashionable St Petersburg ladies. Vera Dzhanumova, the wife of a wealthy merchant, describes how they would gather at teatime to watch his frenzied preaching and dancing, how he 'embraced each one and kissed her on the lips', and how, as they took their leave, 'they whispered to the maid, asking for the father's dirty linen - and with his sweat if possible'.

Frequently, of course, it went further than mere laundry collection. Rasputin's close friend, the publisher, Filippov, once saw him literally beating off an admirer, Madame Lokhtina: she 'was holding on to his member, while shouting, "You are God!" '

Rumours of his debauchery and drunkenness reached the Russian press, and, inevitably, as the war began to go badly, the German-born tsarina and her sinister-looking 'holy father' were blamed. The rest of the story is familiar (told and retold in at least four biographies published in the past decade).

In an attempt to save the monarchy, the decadent bisexual aristocrat, Felix Yusupov, formed a plan to murder Rasputin, luring him to the Yusupov Palace at midnight on 16 December 1916, on the promise that there would be some young ladies present in urgent need of spiritual guidance. Rasputin turned up, the poisoned wine proved too weak, so Rasputin was shot.

The conspirators retired upstairs to celebrate and returned to discover Rasputin crawling across the snowy courtyard towards the gate. He was shot again, in the back and head, and his body was driven away and dumped in the river Malaya Nevka. Radzinsky claims the fatal shots were fired not by Yusupov but by Grand Duke Dmitry Pavlovich, and that the facts were covered up.

Radzinsky also prints the police photographs of Rasputin's corpse, taken shortly after it was pulled from the water on 19 December. His hands are upraised. 'It was clear,' writes Radzinsky, 'that this powerful man, although still breathing in the car, had concealed the fact, hoping to loosen his fetters in the water. But his human strength had failed him.'

Actually, this is not 'clear' at all, and proves, on closer inspection, simply to be another sensational assertion for which Radzinsky offers insufficient evidence. Thus Rasputin: the Last Word ends as it has proceeded: gruesome, dramatic, engrossing and irritatingly tendentious.

fields.headline: Tubular belles
fields.standfirst: Tamara de Lempicka's life was sensational... so are her biographer Laura Claridge's claims for her art
fields.trailText: Tamara de Lempicka's life was sensational... so are her biographer Laura Claridge's claims for her art
fields.body:
Tamara de Lempicka: A Life of Deco and Decadence
Laura Claridge
Bloomsbury £25, pp436
Buy it at BOL

There is a nude by Tamara de Lempicka, now owned by Jack Nicholson, that summarises her deco style in one metallic sweep. It's a painting of an odalisque, reclining in narcissistic rapture, one arm casually flung behind her head. The pose is traditional, but the arm is a polished tube, the body a gleaming auto with haunches like fenders and hubcaps for breasts.

Run your eyes over this model, the picture leers, note that streamlined bodywork, those red enamel lips. No artist has ever made the equation between cars and women quite so explicit. Soft porn, hard chrome - that's the Lempicka nude.

La Belle Rafaela is described by Laura Claridge as the supreme example of Lempicka's 'painterly genius'. Claridge is a hardcore fan, along with collectors like Nicholson, Madonna and Luther Vandross, and her biography is a strategic campaign to restore Lempicka as 'one of the twentieth century's most important artists'.

Since she believes that Lempicka's art has been overshadowed by the story of her life, you might think that a biography of this astonishingly vainglorious socialite was not the place to start. But Claridge is no fool. In America, where this book was first published, the only way to get art history on to the nightstands of Hollywood and Manhattan is to wrap it up in a sensational life.

Tamara de Lempicka was born in Moscow around 1895 - she preferred Warsaw in 1902 - to a family of Polish-Russian aristocrats. In 1916, she married the rich tsarist Tadeusz Lempicki and they might have lived an entire life of sybaritic leisure if the Bolshevik Revolution hadn't exiled them to Paris the following year. But communism, as Claridge notes, was the making of Lempicka, who discovered everything she needed for her art in Paris - Italian masterpieces in the Louvre, modernism, art deco, ritzy fashion. La Belle Rafaela is the typical composite: lighting by Caravaggio, tubism by Fernand Leger, lipstick by Chanel.

Lempicka's 1929 self-portrait as a vamp in a green Bugatti is generally considered to epitomise the jazz-age woman; it was later used on the cover of Aldous Huxley's Point Counter Point. Forget likeness: Lempicka looks like every other one of her tubular belles. But there is a rapacity in those hooded eyes that seems to sum up the real woman, who could never have enough sex, cash, food or fame.

In Paris, Lempicka slept with actresses, prostitutes, ambassadors and sailors. She drank gin fizzes with deposed royals, threw colossal parties where naked girls were hired as human caviare dishes and worked at least as hard on her media profile as her art. When Lempicki left her, she replaced him with a Hungarian millionaire who doled out the money and asked nothing.

Baron Kuffner arranged her second escape, to America in 1939, where they hired King Vidor's former home in Beverly Hills before settling in a palatial duplex on New York's Fifth Avenue. Lempicka took to Manhattan with extraordinary glee, getting her name in all the gossip columns as the 'Baroness with the Brush'. Until abstract expressionism conquered the market in the Fifties, her machine-age style still held good among the rich and famous subjects of her portraits. As a social climber, her only rival was Andy Warhol, with whom she later claimed a friendship.

It wasn't true, of course, any more than her 'relationship' with Greta Garbo or her singlehanded invention of art deco. Lempicka was a dreadful liar, pretending for years that her daughter was her sister so she could fib about her age. Sometimes, she denied the child's existence: 'I have no children; my children are my paintings.' Kizette Lempicka was ignored, rebuked or kicked by her mother even into middle age.

Claridge has had a rough time with Lempicka, too. There are very few letters, no journals and only a handful of living sources, most of them creepy roués or crawling dealers. Claridge is a meticulous, scholarly and sympathetic biographer who would love to find evidence of Lempicka's grief when Kuffner died but is reduced to naming the florist for the funeral. Indeed, Lempicka only comes into focus at the end of the book and then, I'm afraid, in the words of a journalist who interviewed this still-glamorous termagant at her final home in Mexico.

But Lempicka's art is the true justification for this biography and here Claridge is ecstatic in her estimation. She raves about Lempicka's dodgy drawing, compares her with Hopper and Rivera, speaks of her in the same breath as Bellini and Vermeer. Lempicka's undeniable gift for graphic illustration is continuously downplayed in the rush to emphasise the dubious originality of her painting.

Claridge even proposes that the history of modernism be revised to accommodate the uniqueness of her genius. Here the biographer outflanks the subject. Not even Lempicka herself would have made quite such extravagant claims for her art.

webTitle: Come friendly bombs and fall on Pevsner

fields.headline: Come friendly bombs and fall on Pevsner
fields.standfirst: Timothy Mowl's Stylistic Cold Wars examines the prickly relationship between John Betjeman and Nikolaus Pevsner, but was there ever real conflict?
fields.trailText: Timothy Mowl's Stylistic Cold Wars examines the prickly relationship between John Betjeman and Nikolaus Pevsner, but was there ever real conflict?
fields.body:
Stylistic Cold Wars: Betjeman versus Pevsner
Timothy Mowl
John Murray £14.99, pp169
Buy it at BOL

On the penultimate page of this garrulous oddity, it is grudgingly acknowledged that, according to Candi Green, her father John Betjeman and architectural historian Nikolaus Pevsner were on reasonably good terms in their later years. Timothy Mowl then adds: 'I prefer to emphasise their conflict as that was more real.' Well of course you do, old son, because without that 'conflict', you'd have no book, and even with it generous wads of padding are required to bring it up to 50,000 words.

It is both short and rambling. Not that it much matters: indeed, it is the doggedly irrelevant cul-de-sacs that give the exercise its appeal. In this very method, Mowl reveals himself as a devotee of Betjeman (whose grave he visits every year) rather than of Pevsner. A page-long description of Arthur Bliss's house on the Wiltshire/ Dorset/ Somerset border, which Betjeman never visited and may not even have heard of, is included on the grounds that it might have fascinated him.

It is certainly true that for much of their lives, the two men enjoyed a less than cordial relationship. Most of the bitching came from Betjeman who, in the way of his generation, was liable to poke fun at foreigners, especially Jews. What was acceptable then is not acceptable now, and poking fun was, as often as not, an expression of spiteful malice. Pevsner would reply with a mild attack on Betjeman's inability to disentangle the aesthetic and the religious. Betjeman also disliked 'Herr-Professor-Doktor' Pevsner's method, his application of a quasi-scientific taxonomy to buildings and his refusal to acknowledge that they were more than bricks and style.

Now, Betjeman and Pevsner, for all the former's playground animosity, can hardly have been said to have feuded and their relationship would be of little moment were it not for Mowl's questionable assertion that had Betjeman's (and John Piper's) Shell Guides properly established themselves, then Pevsner's Buildings of England might never have gained their impersonal authority and Pevsner himself might not have been in a position to dictate the architectural fate of England in the third quarter of the twentieth century.

As Mowl puts it: 'Should a man with no English social background have been encouraged so quickly to a position where he could exert an unwise, and, in a very real sense, an "alien" influence?' The ugliness of the sentiment apart, does Mowl not realise that the migration of scholars and artists was one of the defining characteristics of the age? And the ascription to Pevsner of responsibility (or culpability) for what was built is both ludicrous and paranoiac.

It echoes Tom Wolfe's ignorant From Bauhaus To Our House, which blamed German émigrés for all America's architectural woes. If failed tower blocks are Pevsner's legacy, then by the same truly absurd reduction, the horrible estates of executive houses which disfigure much of England are Betjeman's. And that's simply not the case.
