And that's simply not the case.

webTitle: A woman of many parts, all unconvincing

fields.headline: A woman of many parts, all unconvincing
fields.standfirst: Linda Grant gives a colourful account of post-war Palestine in When I Lived In Modern Times
fields.trailText: Linda Grant gives a colourful account of post-war Palestine in When I Lived In Modern Times
fields.body:
When I Lived in Modern Times
Linda Grant
Granta £15.99, pp261

Buy it at BOL

'Scratch a Jew and you've got a story,' remarks the elderly Evelyn Sert recalling her younger self - or rather, selves - in Linda Grant's engaging, if ultimately frustrating, novel. By birth, Evelyn is the daughter of an exquisite Jewess of Latvian heritage and an anonymous, absent American. By design, she is variously a terrorist's accomplice, a would-be artist, a devout Christian, the British wife of an officer, an orthodox Jewish lady from Paris and, ultimately, her mother's true daughter.

Her childhood, played out against the seedy backdrop of London's Soho, ends suddenly with the advent of the Second World War and her parents' death. On the suggestion of her surrogate father, she joins the tide of immigrants flooding Palestine in the late Forties, less a religious pilgrim drawn to the promised land than an awkward girl on the cusp of maturity embarking on an introspective odyssey.

Lacking a vocation that might assist practically in the building of the new 'Jewish national home', Evelyn joins a kibbutz in Galilee. Ignorant of Hebrew, intolerant of the blistering sun and harsh working conditions, disappointed in love, she flees this supposed Utopia after six weeks for the modern Bauhaus city of Tel Aviv. En route, she meets Johnny, a demobbed soldier whose identity is as elastic as her own; the two become lovers. Evasive and incurious, Johnny is alternately Levi Aharoni or Efraim, terrorist or freedom fighter, tailor or soldier, depending on circumstance.

Most importantly, he is a catalyst, not that he spurs Evelyn to action, but he certainly ups the tempo of this ponderous story. Unlike Evelyn, he is pragmatic and politicised, determined not merely to witness but to effect 'the decline and fall of the British Empire' through direct action. Though Evelyn's attitude towards Britain is ambivalent - it is simultaneously the colonial oppressor of the Jewish people, among whose number she attempts to locate herself, and the societal model which determines her own modus vivendi - she chooses British company over that of the multitudinous immigrant 'beings' converging on Palestine. Tel Aviv, with its crowd of cafés, prostitutes, neon lights and gateaux, reminds her of Soho.

She conceals her looks, dyeing her hair platinum blonde, shaving her dark eyebrows, assuming a distinctively English pseudonym and inventing a British husband for herself. By day, she works at a hairdressing salon; by night, she betrays her expatriate clients and acquaintances in providing Johnny with their names and addresses.

Finally, a little dramatic tension colours the plot as various Jewish factions antagonise the British. Evelyn, as may be expected, remains distanced, occupying the position of peripheral spectator, uncertain of where her allegiance lies. For a while, pregnant with Johnny's child, she is hidden by Irgun, the terrorist organisation to which he belongs, but she does not belong with them, nor with the British, nor with Jews.

Ultimately, she leaves Palestine, returning 50 years later to confront her youthful self in a neat, somewhat fanciful conclusion, enacted on the balcony of her old apartment.

'Always I have edited my life, leaving out whole sections or changing or embroidering details,' admits Evelyn. A mistress of artifice, a pawn or puppet in the machinations of others, experiencing life vicariously, she is a difficult, slippery choice of heroine who never really evolves beyond the 'preliminary sketch' of her youth. Evelyn functions as a token character grafted on to Linda Grant's evocative study of this momentous period in history, implicated by default in order to lend a human angle.

Despite the use of the first person, the descriptive narrative offers an objective rather than personal perspective. What redeems the book are sporadic passages of spirited intellectual debate, the vivid sense of place that emerges from Grant's writing, and the stories of the Jewish immigrants which accentuate the premise of this fiction - that a consciousness of the past is vital in articulating a conceivable future.

fields.headline: Secrets and lies
fields.standfirst: Stephen Dorril reveals everything you wanted to know about British Intelligence but were afraid to ask in MI6
fields.trailText: Stephen Dorril reveals everything you wanted to know about British Intelligence but were afraid to ask in MI6
fields.body:
MI6: Fifty Years of Special Operations
Stephen Dorril
Fourth Estate £25, pp907
Buy it at BOL

There is a telling acknowledgment at the beginning of this timely and entertaining book. It could not have been written, says Stephen Dorril, 'without the sterling and greatly appreciated efforts of the staff of Huddersfield library'. He continues: 'They managed to make available through the British Library lending system hundreds of books from around the world, as well as many obscure articles. Institutions such as this are a precious local resource that should be nurtured and properly funded.'

Dorril is a voracious reader and tireless researcher. Though there is new material - especially about what MI6 appears to have been up to in recent times - much of what is here has appeared elsewhere. The usefulness of this long book, containing a great deal of information, soberly presented, is that it has been collected in one volume. It captures the feel, the flavour of what Sir Colin McColl, a former C - for 'Chief', as the head of MI6 is known - once described as the 'soft-shoe service'.

It is a kind of alternative history of Britain's Secret Intelligence Service, to give MI6 its formal title. It is a refreshing antidote to the officially-sanctioned and, for the most part, self-serving accounts such as those written by Christopher Andrew with KGB defectors, including Oleg Gordievsky and Vasili Mitrokhin.

Dorril sheds light on how MI6, principally through Maurice Oldfield, its liaison officer in Washington in the 1960s (and later appointed C), persuaded Harold Wilson and the US that Britain should not send British troops to fight alongside the Americans in the Vietnam war. MI6 was rightly sceptical about the US 'domino theory' and about allegations of direct Chinese communist involvement in the war, and - unlike the CIA who thought it a ruse - correctly judged the Sino-Soviet rift as genuine.

But MI6 did help the US in the special ways open to it. Dorril describes how Daphne (now Lady) Park, its station chief in Hanoi during the war, provided Washington with intelligence reports, as did the GCHQ base at Little Sai Wan in Hong Kong. Park, who was to become a governor of the BBC, once recalled that one of MI6's successful ploys was to 'set people very discreetly against one another. They destroy each other. You don't destroy them.'

Elsewhere, MI6 worked closely with the CIA in helping to oust Indonesia's President Sukarno in the 1960s. It helped to subvert nationalist regimes in the Middle East (though they briefly fell out during the Suez crisis and Whitehall ploys to assassinate Egypt's President Nasser).

Dorril reminds us that MI6 failed to foresee the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and the Argentine invasion of the Falklands in 1982. MI6 was not always entirely at fault. Concern about upsetting the sensitivities of the Shah - as well as ignoring what it did not want to hear 'cognitive dissonance' as it is called in the trade - meant it did not foresee his fall in 1979. MI6 warnings about the build-up of tanks in Basra prior to the invasion of Kuwait in 1990 were dismissed by Thatcher's advisers in the Cabinet Office intelligence bureaucracy.

The trouble with this book, particularly when it covers more recent events, is that it is difficult to distinguish between what is hearsay or gossip and what has come from first-hand sources. Even then, it is hard to know what to believe.

Dorril gives a more complete account than has appeared so far of allegations emanating from the renegade former MI6 officer, Richard Tomlinson. Some of it is true - just as it is now clear that a lot of what his MI5 counterpart, David Shayler, has alleged is turning out to have substance. The way, for example, MI6 targets Britain's EU partners. Some of it seems implausible. For example, Dorril throws in a line that Nelson Mandela was an 'MI6 catch', suggesting he was recruited by British secret agents. It is a claim backed up by no evidence and understandably dismissed last week by Ismail Ayob, Mandela's personal lawyer and former fellow prisoner.

Anyone writing about Britain's security and intelligence agencies, cloaked as they are in a thick fabric of secrecy and disinformation, has to rely more than most on judgment and healthy scepticism. There are few available and reliable sources. The further back in time, the more there are, though official papers even about MI6's pre-Second World War activities are only now beginning to trickle through to the public record office, and even so in a haphazard trickle.

This book will not be welcomed by MI6, not least because it names names, though they have all appeared one way or another on the Internet. But it serves many purposes, not least - one lives in hope - by bringing Britain's Secret Intelligence Service down from its exotic pedestal. Spying, after all, is a dirty game.

And Ministers do not know what they have been up to. In April 1988, in a Mansion House speech, Robin Cook said MI6 'cannot speak for themselves' because 'the nature of what they do means that we cannot shout about their achievements if we want them to remain effective. But let me say I have been struck by the range and quality of the work.' He might like to read this book.

webTitle: Saint Hughes to kick-start stalled career

fields.headline: Saint Hughes to kick-start stalled career
fields.trailText: Not many Premiership footballers issue a come and get me call through the pages of The Observer. More fool them.
fields.body:
Not many Premiership footballers issue a come and get me call through the pages of The Observer. More fool them. Last August, Paul Hughes, the Chelsea midfielder, was training on his own. He had no squad number and no shirt. He had slipped off the back of the programme.

Understandably unhappy, he announced in these pages that 'people honestly think I'm quite happy at Chelsea - happy to be pottering along. But I'm desperate to get away and prove how good I am.'

On Thursday - a mere seven months later - his call was answered as Glenn Hoddle, the manager who had given him his first pro contract at Chelsea, signed him on a free transfer for Southampton.

'A Premiership team, a manager like Glenn Hoddle. It's perfect. A dream,' he said after the deal was done. As well he might for what had he preceded it had been turning into a nightmare. Not picked for the reserves by Chelsea he had only played two competitive games in the last year and only a handful of first team games - on loan at Stockport and Norwich - in the year before that.

'At 23, I've still plenty of time but it is a shame that, through no fault of my own, I've had two years of non-progression. It's made me more and more determined that it shouldn't break me and ruin my career. I've grown up tenfold. The best thing is that when your in real dire straits you find out about yourself and I'm happy with what I've found.'

He is mentally strong, but physically unfit. 'It'll take 10 to 12 games to get match fit and I'd be very shocked if I played in the first team by the end of the season.'

Which is more than would ever be on offer at Chelsea where 'I was in a Catch 22 situation,' says Hughes. 'The perception was that there must be something wrong with me because I hadn't moved. And then because I've enjoyed the best football education, along with Man U, that is on offer I was almost too well-qualified. It's like getting a first-class degree and possible employers thinking you may be a bit too academic.'

We wish him well, and under Hoddle's guidance he has the skill, intelligence and determination to succeed, but the precedents are not good. Three English players left Chelsea in the week that Hughes issued his come and get me call. Eddie Newton, who Ruud Gullit once reckoned should be in the England Squad - make of that what you will, moved to Birmingham City but was released last week. Andy Myers moved to Bradford and was last week sold to Portsmouth. Michael Duberry went to Leeds and has had some success without ever showing the form that once suggested he might one day play for England.

Chelsea receive criticism for not playing their home-grown players but the evidence suggests that many of them simply aren't good enough to merit selection at the very highest level. In the meantime those that are good enough to be picked regularly - Wise, Le Saux, Morris - benefit from playing alongside such good players and against the best opposition.

Wise has blossomed in the last two years. He has on outside chance of being Player of the Year and a better than even money chance of being in Keegan's side for the European Championships. If fit, Le Saux will probably line-up alongside him.

The critics say that foreigners at Chelsea are ruining the prospects for the national side but the last time two players from Chelsea represented England in a major international tournament was.....never.

webTitle: Step forward Roy Keane  - United's new hairdryer

fields.headline: Step forward Roy Keane  - United's new hairdryer
fields.trailText: Why look abroad or to exiled old boys when Sir Alex Ferguson's successor is already on the payroll?
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson still has two years left at Manchester United, but the succession question is already the liveliest debate in football. Martin Edwards has admitted the matter is under discussion within the club; last week two Sunday newspapers exclusively predicted two different managers to take over from Ferguson (David O'Leary and Louis van Gaal); and eavesdrop any pub conversation on the subject and you cannot fail to be impressed by the depth of the field and the ingenuity of some of the theories.

Perhaps because the situation is such an unusual one in English football - a long-serving and ultra-successful manager making way while his own reputation and that of his club are almost too bright for ordinary mortals to contemplate - the betting odds are all over the place. The field supplied by William Hill resembles the starting line at a particularly unruly Grand National, with selling-platers in with the Classic winners, some no-hopers at the front and several of the fancied runners still facing the wrong way.

Granted, any betting show reflects the suppositions of the punters rather than any inside knowledge of the bookmaker, but even so, what has Arsène Wenger done to find himself a rank outsider, sandwiched comically between Paul Ince and George Best? Surely on his record in English football alone, the Arsenal manager ought to be a better bet than Ruud Gullit, Roy Hodgson and Lou Macari, all priced more flatteringly. Surely just by virtue of being a manager, leaving aside the not inconsiderable feat of winning the double a couple of years ago, Wenger should have a slight edge on qualification-free candidates like Eric Cantona, Denis Irwin and Gary Pallister (none of whom has yet demonstrated even an inclination towards management), but clearly the United connection is paramount. The names heading the list are the ones people imagine would jump at the chance to manage United, whatever they might say at the moment, whereas Wenger is evidently considered Arsenal through and through, unlikely to be asked and unlikely to accept.

All of which may be true, but how likely is it that Steve Bruce, Gordon Strachan and Bryan Robson will be asked, regardless of whether they would accept? The assumption seems to be that Manchester United will be seeking to replicate Ferguson by following the processes they went through in 1986. Wanted: a promising young(ish) manager with a track record behind him but still something to prove, an Old Trafford old boy if possible but failing that someone with a solid reputation who would fit into the club's traditions and make a name for himself. On this basis, Strachan, O'Leary and Martin O'Neill must be leading candidates, with Alan Curbishley and Peter Reid as outside chances. Bruce is simply unproven, while Robson has made the odd mistake at Middlesbrough and probably lacks the media-savvy necessary to front the monster that Manchester United has become.

Because, and this is the crucial point, Manchester United have changed massively since 1986. Nothing about the Old Trafford operation is remotely recognisable from the time Ferguson walked in 14 years ago, and just as the world's first billion-pound football plc would no longer consider selling out to Michael Knighton for £10 million, nor would they contemplate installing a manager, no matter how young and bright, who needed to learn on the job or time to find his feet in European football. In short, if the plc is looking to replicate Ferguson, they want a clone of the manager he is now, not the one who was not even the club's first choice in 1986. United will not necessarily demand a treble in the first season, but the days when Ferguson bought himself time with a solitary FA Cup success after four years are gone. This season United did not even enter the FA Cup, and it is a sobering thought for supporters of the home-based managers mentioned above that not one of them has managed even an FA Cup win with his own club. By the time Ferguson came to England he had ended Old Firm dominance in Cup and League in Scotland, and won the European Cup Winners Cup with Aberdeen.

The obvious answer might appear to be to look abroad and hire one of the self-styled super coaches like Van Gaal or Marcello Lippi. Big names, big ideas, big salaries; possibly wouldn't fancy Sunderland on a wet Wednesday night or exchanging their Mediterranean lifestyles for an altogether more austere existence at Carrington Moss. It is debatable whether Manchester United are a bigger football club than Barcelona anyway, though if English clubs continue to flourish in European competitions leading managers will gravitate to the Premiership. Until that happens, however, the element of culture shock (think of Roy Hodgson at Blackburn) will always place a question mark against even the best qualified foreign candidates, which is why the assimilated and already successful Wenger might not be such a long shot after all.

Foreign coaches also tend to bring in foreign players, which worked out well for Wenger at Arsenal, yet still causes resentment for Van Gaal at Barcelona. If stability and continuity are United's goals, anything potentially disruptive is to be avoided. It is one thing for a foreign 'guru' (Ferguson's word, not entirely approving) to walk into an underachieving club and change things around, as Wenger did at Arsenal and Gérard Houllier is attempting to do at Liverpool, but the same approach could quickly lead to problems for a phenomenally successful side with nowhere to go but down.

Which brings us to the biggest difficulty of all. It is not safe to assume that any given manager would fancy taking over from Ferguson. There is precious little room for improvement and plenty of scope for spectacular failure. Furthermore, by the time Ferguson leaves, the United dressing room is likely to be full of players who have won everything there is to win in England and Europe, two, three and four times over. Practically every candidate so far mentioned as a possibility would find his own experience dwarfed by that of his players. It is a daunting proposition, professional sportsmen at the highest level being almost psychopathic in their intolerance of weakness or indecision in others, and some of the managers politely distancing themselves from the job at the moment may not be playing games. As Knighton said on Friday, 'The shrewdest invitee would probably turn it down.'

Former England managers Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle have the stature and breadth of experience for the task, which makes you wonder why they are quoted at the same price as Mark McGhee and Ray Wilkins, but the golden rule in these situations is to look for the candidate who comes closest to doing the job already. The trouble with United's old boys is that they might as well have played for a different club; nor do management duties at Coventry or Huddersfield have much in common with the Old Trafford beat. Who is playing for United now, synonymous with their success in the past decade and symbolic of their insatiable desire for more? Who already has the respect of everyone at Old Trafford, embodies every bit of Ferguson's combative spirit, and represents the best hope of a seamless transition?

Step forward Roy Keane, assisted by Steve McLaren and/or Brian Kidd. In two years time Keane will be 31, three years younger than Kenny Dalglish was when he took over at Liverpool, but with 10 seasons at United on his cv. Whether he will make a manager in the Ferguson mould is a matter for conjecture, but the point about managers in the Ferguson mould is that they are becoming extinct. It is unrealistic, for example, to expect the next United manager to last 16 years, and unnecessary to require him to have learnt his trade at St Mirren or some other impoverished outfit. Manchester United now make their own rules.

Keane could do a job, bridge a gap, take the club on, and is unlikely to shrink from the challenge.
fields.bodyText: Sir Alex Ferguson still has two years left at Manchester United, but the succession question is already the liveliest debate in football. Martin Edwards has admitted the matter is under discussion within the club; last week two Sunday newspapers exclusively predicted two different managers to take over from Ferguson (David O'Leary and Louis van Gaal); and eavesdrop any pub conversation on the subject and you cannot fail to be impressed by the depth of the field and the ingenuity of some of the theories. Perhaps because the situation is such an unusual one in English football - a long-serving and ultra-successful manager making way while his own reputation and that of his club are almost too bright for ordinary mortals to contemplate - the betting odds are all over the place. The field supplied by William Hill resembles the starting line at a particularly unruly Grand National, with selling-platers in with the Classic winners, some no-hopers at the front and several of the fancied runners still facing the wrong way. Granted, any betting show reflects the suppositions of the punters rather than any inside knowledge of the bookmaker, but even so, what has Arsène Wenger done to find himself a rank outsider, sandwiched comically between Paul Ince and George Best? Surely on his record in English football alone, the Arsenal manager ought to be a better bet than Ruud Gullit, Roy Hodgson and Lou Macari, all priced more flatteringly. Surely just by virtue of being a manager, leaving aside the not inconsiderable feat of winning the double a couple of years ago, Wenger should have a slight edge on qualification-free candidates like Eric Cantona, Denis Irwin and Gary Pallister (none of whom has yet demonstrated even an inclination towards management), but clearly the United connection is paramount. The names heading the list are the ones people imagine would jump at the chance to manage United, whatever they might say at the moment, whereas Wenger is evidently considered Arsenal through and through, unlikely to be asked and unlikely to accept. All of which may be true, but how likely is it that Steve Bruce, Gordon Strachan and Bryan Robson will be asked, regardless of whether they would accept? The assumption seems to be that Manchester United will be seeking to replicate Ferguson by following the processes they went through in 1986. Wanted: a promising young(ish) manager with a track record behind him but still something to prove, an Old Trafford old boy if possible but failing that someone with a solid reputation who would fit into the club's traditions and make a name for himself. On this basis, Strachan, O'Leary and Martin O'Neill must be leading candidates, with Alan Curbishley and Peter Reid as outside chances. Bruce is simply unproven, while Robson has made the odd mistake at Middlesbrough and probably lacks the media-savvy necessary to front the monster that Manchester United has become. Because, and this is the crucial point, Manchester United have changed massively since 1986. Nothing about the Old Trafford operation is remotely recognisable from the time Ferguson walked in 14 years ago, and just as the world's first billion-pound football plc would no longer consider selling out to Michael Knighton for £10 million, nor would they contemplate installing a manager, no matter how young and bright, who needed to learn on the job or time to find his feet in European football. In short, if the plc is looking to replicate Ferguson, they want a clone of the manager he is now, not the one who was not even the club's first choice in 1986. United will not necessarily demand a treble in the first season, but the days when Ferguson bought himself time with a solitary FA Cup success after four years are gone. This season United did not even enter the FA Cup, and it is a sobering thought for supporters of the home-based managers mentioned above that not one of them has managed even an FA Cup win with his own club. By the time Ferguson came to England he had ended Old Firm dominance in Cup and League in Scotland, and won the European Cup Winners Cup with Aberdeen. The obvious answer might appear to be to look abroad and hire one of the self-styled super coaches like Van Gaal or Marcello Lippi. Big names, big ideas, big salaries; possibly wouldn't fancy Sunderland on a wet Wednesday night or exchanging their Mediterranean lifestyles for an altogether more austere existence at Carrington Moss. It is debatable whether Manchester United are a bigger football club than Barcelona anyway, though if English clubs continue to flourish in European competitions leading managers will gravitate to the Premiership. Until that happens, however, the element of culture shock (think of Roy Hodgson at Blackburn) will always place a question mark against even the best qualified foreign candidates, which is why the assimilated and already successful Wenger might not be such a long shot after all. Foreign coaches also tend to bring in foreign players, which worked out well for Wenger at Arsenal, yet still causes resentment for Van Gaal at Barcelona. If stability and continuity are United's goals, anything potentially disruptive is to be avoided. It is one thing for a foreign 'guru' (Ferguson's word, not entirely approving) to walk into an underachieving club and change things around, as Wenger did at Arsenal and Gérard Houllier is attempting to do at Liverpool, but the same approach could quickly lead to problems for a phenomenally successful side with nowhere to go but down. Which brings us to the biggest difficulty of all. It is not safe to assume that any given manager would fancy taking over from Ferguson. There is precious little room for improvement and plenty of scope for spectacular failure. Furthermore, by the time Ferguson leaves, the United dressing room is likely to be full of players who have won everything there is to win in England and Europe, two, three and four times over. Practically every candidate so far mentioned as a possibility would find his own experience dwarfed by that of his players. It is a daunting proposition, professional sportsmen at the highest level being almost psychopathic in their intolerance of weakness or indecision in others, and some of the managers politely distancing themselves from the job at the moment may not be playing games. As Knighton said on Friday, 'The shrewdest invitee would probably turn it down.' Former England managers Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle have the stature and breadth of experience for the task, which makes you wonder why they are quoted at the same price as Mark McGhee and Ray Wilkins, but the golden rule in these situations is to look for the candidate who comes closest to doing the job already. The trouble with United's old boys is that they might as well have played for a different club; nor do management duties at Coventry or Huddersfield have much in common with the Old Trafford beat. Who is playing for United now, synonymous with their success in the past decade and symbolic of their insatiable desire for more? Who already has the respect of everyone at Old Trafford, embodies every bit of Ferguson's combative spirit, and represents the best hope of a seamless transition? Step forward Roy Keane, assisted by Steve McLaren and/or Brian Kidd. In two years time Keane will be 31, three years younger than Kenny Dalglish was when he took over at Liverpool, but with 10 seasons at United on his cv. Whether he will make a manager in the Ferguson mould is a matter for conjecture, but the point about managers in the Ferguson mould is that they are becoming extinct. It is unrealistic, for example, to expect the next United manager to last 16 years, and unnecessary to require him to have learnt his trade at St Mirren or some other impoverished outfit. Manchester United now make their own rules. Keane could do a job, bridge a gap, take the club on, and is unlikely to shrink from the challenge.

fields.headline: Me? I don't think so...
fields.trailText: doesn't fancy his chances of succeeding Sir Alex at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
It's quite a compliment - but being the realist that I am, I also look upon my position as the bookmaker's second favourite to succeed Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United as some kind of joke.

In view of his criticism of me in his autobiography, I would say that if he has anything to do with the choice of his successor, then even the steward who escorts him to the dressing rooms after a match would have a better chance of getting his job than me.

The obvious point to emerge from the conjecture about Ferguson's replacement is that, through his remarkable record of success, he himself has turned the job into the most difficult in the game. Assuming that United manage to maintain their present ascendancy right up to his retirement, it could be argued that the task that his successor faces will be more daunting than that taken on by any of the previous managerial giants in Britain.

It might be recalled that, when Bill Shankly called it a day at Liverpool after their 1974 FA Cup triumph, the club had to virtually twist the arm of his assistant Bob Paisley to take over from him. However, Paisley, then in his mid-fifties, did have a reasonable amount of scope to significantly improve upon Shankly's record, as he went on to emphasise by bringing Liverpool three European Cups, six Championships, three League Cups and the Uefa Cup in nine years.

In a number of ways, the scope to do what Fergie couldn't do is more limited; and, of course, the burden on the new manager would be rendered even heavier by United's stature as a multi-faceted global business empire.

United, in fact, are probably the most 'international' of all English clubs in their general outlook, so it strikes me that the job of leading them on the field in the post-Ferguson era is a role best-suited to a foreign manager, and particularly one with experience of being at a similarly big club.

That's why the most attractive Fergie-successor bets on the present bookmakers' list as far as I am concerned are the Italian pair of Inter Milan's Marcello Lippi and Roma's Fabio Capello, and Barcelona's Dutch coach, Louis van Gaal. I have an exceptionally high regard for the methods of Lippi, whom I met at Inter during a trip to Italy last summer, though one factor that might count against him - as far as Manchester United are concerned - is that he has not worked outside his own country.

But both Van Gaal and Capello have worked abroad, in Capello's case with Real Madrid; and another plus point in the case of Van Gaal concerns his experience of developing outstanding young 'home-grown' players during his career with Ajax.

As reflected by the impact of Arséne Wenger and Gérard Houllier at Arsenal and Liverpool, I think that leading foreign managers or coaches work better at the bigger English clubs than they do at the likes of Coventry, Leicester, Southampton and Wimbledon.

People like me work to a different agenda. Last week, for example, my attention was focussed not so much on teams and players in the European Champions League, but those in the Nationwide League.

Does that sound like the next manager of Manchester United to you?

fields.headline: Keegan grooms Rio's brio
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand - the New Bobby Moore - plays the waiting game. A trip with the U-21s is no put-down for West Ham's young defender.
fields.body:
For a young professional footballer born and bred in Peckham and brought up not far away, among the mugs of hot tea and cheerful greetings that symbolise the homespun ideals of West Ham, the world of Rio Ferdinand brims with continental promise. Last week he basked in the lavish praise of Franco Baresi, the peerless Italian whose poise and intelligence made him the best defender of his generation. Next week he's off to exhibit his blossoming talent in Barcelona, a city where footballing excellence is king.

Ferdinand has an endearing ability to let it all waft over him. His head is affectionately entrenched in the traditions of his boyhood club and, frankly, if he was any more comfortable at Chez Chadwell Heath he'd be welded to one of the plastic chairs.

Some say that by now he should be pushing himself out of the comfort zone, challenging himself to transform talk of a bright future into an iridescent present. But just because Ferdinand has been impressing since his accomplished debut at 17 and first international call-up a year later, we shouldn't forget that he is still a coltish 21.

Howard Wilkinson obviously hasn't, taking advantage of Ferdinand's continued eligibility for England's under-21 side to bolster the team for Wednesday's crucial play off against Yugoslavia with a place in this summer's European finals in Slovakia on the line. It's a strange one for Rio. Barcelona it may be but it's not the theatrical Nou Camp, it's the Mini Stadium next door which is usually used for reserve games. England it may be but it's not the real deal three lions, it's the feeder group he last turned out for some two-and-a-half years ago.

He refuses to perceive it as any kind of demotion. After all, there is a tournament at stake: 'For the progress of the young sters the more tournaments they are involved in and the more success they experience the better,' he says, exuding the sage maturity of a reflective veteran. The fact so many Premiership starlets are involved - he is joined by the likes of Emile Heskey, Kieron Dyer, Steven Gerrard, Gareth Barry, Joe Cole and Michael Bridges - bodes well.

Ferdinand is happy enough to lend his relative experience to the cause before resuming his priority mission: to establish himself firmly in Kevin Keegan's plans. Although technically there are no rules to say a player can't be selected for the summer's junior tournament in Slovakia before joining the seniors in Holland and Belgium, Ferdinand looks horrified at the prospect. Way too exhausting. And anyway, he knows where he'd rather be. He's homing in not only on the full squad, but a berth in the starting line-up.

By his own admission he hasn't quite made the international leap expected of him since he emerged as the latest New Bobby Moore, 'You set targets for yourself each year and I would love to have been a regular in England's first XI but that's not the case,' he explains. 'There are a lot of quality players who are very experienced to dislodge so it's difficult. But it's a challenge I relish. It's frustrating but I'm still young and I'm prepared to wait, because you've got the likes of Tony Adams in front of you. He's an unbelievable player whose been around for ages, come through the ups and downs of football and he's flying.

'I'm not stupid enough to think I've made anything of my career, I've still got loads to learn. I've still got to work hard on the training field and add to my game. It's about waiting, hoping I get my chance, and taking it with both hands.'

Beneath his laidback London cool inner ambition burns. The desire is equally strong at club level. With five years on his Upton Park contract he may be as fixed as an eel in jelly but he is desperate for tangible success. 'Winning the League is one of my ambitions and if we can do that I'll be here until the end of my career. When you look at the top clubs' results we're not in that kind of league but we should be challenging to win a cup. We should with the players we've got. If you look at the likes of Leicester who are a good, solid side, we should be in their position. We should have been at Wembley this year.

To be honest we thought we had a really good chance of winning something this season. We've got to make sure we start achieving. The idea of someone sitting here and picking up their money, that's for certain other players. We've a lot of young, hungry players here and I don't think many of them want to sit around and not win things. Europe is our main objective now for this season and if we don't achieve that it will be a disappointment.'

To that end, West Ham need to overcome Wimbledon this afternoon to hang on in there with the bunch chasing the last Uefa spot.

Eventually Ferdinand's ambition may draw him away - but not yet. With all those unfulfilled goals he might sound like a man ready to vault into the next phase of his embryonic career but he is still allowed to be a kid occasionally. Consider his reaction to that recognition from Italian icon Baresi: 'Flattering,' coos Rio quietly, before describing his feelings with wide-eyed, profanely expressed awe. 'It would be nice to follow in the footsteps of someone like that,' he adds. 'He was an absolute legend.'

webTitle: When United said 'mucho bollockoes' to Real

fields.headline: When United said 'mucho bollockoes' to Real
fields.trailText: Real Madrid v Manchester United next week is a good reason to reprint an Observer classic: Hugh McIlvanney's 1968 report of the 3-3 semi-final, second leg draw that took United to their first final.
fields.body:
With Manchester United and the European Cup it is always difficult to identify the boundary between the dream and the reality; to separate an objective expectation of failure from a dark, mystical suspicion that a mocking providence must always thwart Matt Busby's ultimate ambition.

What happened in Madrid on Wednesday did nothing to clarify these distinctions. The match that saw United through the semi-final at the fourth attempt was in many important respects the most bizarre, the most unnaturally (almost supernaturally) dramatic I have experienced. It was, for me at least, unique, with an essential pattern that denied comparison with any other game I have seen.

It could be suggested that the emotions of the past 11 years, the memories of those major and minor disasters this club has known in European football, rose like sediment from the bottom of a glass to cloud perspectives.

But that interpretation will convince no one who sat through the stifling hour and a half in the Bernabeu Stadium, whose sheer sides seemed to imprison the clamour and the stale air under a blue ceiling of cigarette and cigar smoke.

United, by their own standards, played moderately; Real Madrid played worse; inadequate defence had more significance than inspired attack. However, all this is only a limited version of the truth. The discrepancy between the events of the first half and those of the second was so staggering as to be unreal.

After coping skilfully, if rather uneasily, with Real Madrid's swift, controlled aggression for slightly more than 25 minutes, United's reinforced defence all but disintegrated. Pirri was pursued too late when he sprinted towards the near post to strike a, fine, powerful header beyond Stepney. Brennan, going to make an easy interception, was unfortunate to find the ball bubbling over his foot and Gento was left to race in unhampered. Stepney could not prevent the ball from spinning between his legs.

Zoco, incredibly transformed from the strong man of Old Trafford to a nervous incompetent, restored hope briefly by slicing Dunne's free-kick past Betancort, but the speed of the great Amancio's reflexes brought a third Spanish goal almost immediately.

At half time, anyone who wanted to bet on United might have been trampled in the rush, and by British feet at that.

What occurred subsequently was barely comprehensible. It was natural that United should commit themselves unreservedly to attack, with Sadler surging away from Foulkes's side, Charlton eagerly seeking openings for shots and Crerand moving through like an inside forward. But for all their adventurousness there was no impression of overwhelming menace and when the Real defence suddenly opened up to let them through it appeared to be a process as arbitrary as the parting of the Red Sea. It was as if some outside force had chosen to reward United for their greatness over the years and at one stroke had drained all their opponents' resistance.. There must be praise for the cool alertness that gave Sadler and Foulkes their decisive goals and even more for the brilliance with which Best prepared the way for the winner, but a sound defence would probably have prevented both.

'We played the double centre-half plan in their penalty area,' said Pat Crerand afterwards, condemning the opposition with a joke. So what did happen? There is a choice of practical explanations. 'We went out and played them,' Nobby Stiles shouted from behind a towel in the steaming, swigging, hugging, tearful hysteria of the dressing room. 'We went out and bloody played them and they cracked.'

Crerand elaborated. 'When we came in at half-time Georgie Best said "We're as well losing 10-1 as 3-1. Let's have a real go at them." The boss felt the same way. They made it easier by letting us have the ball in the second half. They must have thought they had done enough. Whenever we got moving they were knackered. You couldn't breathe out there because of the humidity. They kept running over to the trainer to get drinks and have water splashed down their neck. They just didn't stay with us.'

Bobby Charlton, having struggled to emerge from a state of shock ('I'm going mad me, going mad. This game will drive me bloody crackers') saw it similarly. 'There was no air at all. You couldn't sprint because it took you five minutes to recover. We didn't play nearly as well as we can but the lads deserved it because they kept going. They had the heart when most would have slung it.'

This takes us some way towards the basic truth about the match. United drove themselves well beyond the point that most teams would have seen as the limit of hope and endeavour. United's determination to win the European Cup has accumulated into something more potent then even they realise.

It is foolish to make extreme ethnic generalisations but it is possible to argue that Real Madrid had more formidable morale when the side was cosmopolitan rather than Spanish. The Real of Di Stefano and Puskas was clearly superior to this team in heart as well as in skills.

On Wednesday the most aggressive Spaniards were in the crowd, led by the hero who tried to smash Stiles's skull with a bottle, as I stood back to let the wing half step ahead of me into the team coach. Stiles had mixed a little mayhem with his magnificent defensive play but the villainous reprisal was as unwarranted as it was ineffective.

The victim's reputation for toughness is such that none of his team mates took the incident very seriously. 'You could hit him with a sledgehammer and he'd be back for more,' said Crerand, before leaning out of the window to respond to local insults in Gorbals Spanish. 'Mucho bollockoes.' United go forward to the Final with a buoyancy that is totally impressive and may well prove invincible. They outfought Real Madrid. It will be fitting if they dazzle Benfica.

Real Madrid: Betancort; Gonzales, Zunzunegui, Zoco, Sanchis, Pirri, Grosso, Perez, Amancio, Valasquez, Gento.
Goals: Pirri, Gento, Amancio.

Manchester United: Stepney; Brennan, Dunne, Crerand, Foulkes, Stiles, Best, Kidd, Charlton, Sadler, Aston.
Goals: Zoco (og), Sadler, Foulkes.

Manchester United won 4-3 on aggregate.

Bobby Charlton, having struggled to emerge from a state of shock ('I'm going mad me, going mad. This game will drive me bloody crackers') saw it similarly. 'There was no air at all. You couldn't sprint because it took you five minutes to recover. We didn't play nearly as well as we can but the lads deserved it because they kept going. They had the heart when most would have slung it.' This takes us some way towards the basic truth about the match. United drove themselves well beyond the point that most teams would have seen as the limit of hope and endeavour. United's determination to win the European Cup has accumulated into something more potent then even they realise. It is foolish to make extreme ethnic generalisations but it is possible to argue that Real Madrid had more formidable morale when the side was cosmopolitan rather than Spanish. The Real of Di Stefano and Puskas was clearly superior to this team in heart as well as in skills. On Wednesday the most aggressive Spaniards were in the crowd, led by the hero who tried to smash Stiles's skull with a bottle, as I stood back to let the wing half step ahead of me into the team coach. Stiles had mixed a little mayhem with his magnificent defensive play but the villainous reprisal was as unwarranted as it was ineffective. The victim's reputation for toughness is such that none of his team mates took the incident very seriously. 'You could hit him with a sledgehammer and he'd be back for more,' said Crerand, before leaning out of the window to respond to local insults in Gorbals Spanish. 'Mucho bollockoes.' United go forward to the Final with a buoyancy that is totally impressive and may well prove invincible. They outfought Real Madrid. It will be fitting if they dazzle Benfica. Real Madrid: Betancort; Gonzales, Zunzunegui, Zoco, Sanchis, Pirri, Grosso, Perez, Amancio, Valasquez, Gento. Goals: Pirri, Gento, Amancio. Manchester United: Stepney; Brennan, Dunne, Crerand, Foulkes, Stiles, Best, Kidd, Charlton, Sadler, Aston. Goals: Zoco (og), Sadler, Foulkes. Manchester United won 4-3 on aggregate.

webTitle: The Doc diagnoses Fergie's Pavarotti Syndrome

fields.headline: The Doc diagnoses Fergie's Pavarotti Syndrome
fields.trailText: Tommy Docherty, media pundit and after-dinner speaker, still regards being appointed United manager as his proudest footballing moment. He also tips Alan Curbishley to succeed Sir Alex...
fields.body:
What would have happened if Tommy Docherty had not fallen for the physiotherapist's wife? Quite possibly, Sir Alex Ferguson would never have got the job as Old Trafford manager.

Who knows how long Docherty's popular reign as manager would have continued - after all, he is still only 71 - if it had not been for his affair with Mary Brown, whom he later married. The liaison resulted in his sacking in 1977 for being in breach of contract. (Did it really stipulate his not falling in love?)

'I would have loved to have stayed for the rest of my life,' says Docherty, who describes his sacking - six weeks after United beat Liverpool in the FA Cup final - as ridiculous. 'Look at the present chairman. Who's worse than him? If people got punished today as I got punished there'd be no managers and no directors.'

Of all those who tried to recreate the Sir Matt Busby success story before Ferguson pulled it off so spectacularly, Docherty looked the only one who might have done it. Wilf McGuinness, Frank O'Farrell, Dave Sexton and Ron Atkinson were all fired as failures, but Docherty, before his venial sin, had restored the sort of fervent support the club enjoy now - 'We were great to watch, home and away' - and was building a team of substance.

'I felt when we came back up again [United were relegated in Docherty's second season] that we had really cracked it,' he says. 'I thought it was just a matter of getting one or two players from the youth policy and going into the market if we needed anyone else.'

Docherty rebuilt the side around young players such as Jimmy Nicholl, Arthur Albiston and Sammy McIlroy and experienced signings such as Jimmy Greenhoff. 'Jimmy was a great player for us. He took a 50 quid drop in wages to come to Old Trafford because we wouldn't pay him the wages he was getting at Stoke City; and we tried to sign Peter Shilton, but they wouldn't pay him 400 quid a week. Even then they were careful with their money.'

He acknowledges though, that the present regime at Old Trafford are prepared to invest in 'a sure thing', which is the essential difference between the conditions he worked under and those Ferguson faces. 'He doesn't have to speculate and back his judgment. He can go out and buy a Japp Stam, a Dwight Yorke or a Batistuta. There's no gamble. If you buy great players you don't have to be a great coach. If you were a singing coach and got hold of Pavarotti you wouldn't have to be that clever, would you?'

If you detect here a little grit in their relationship, you are right. Ferguson no longer speaks to him because of what Docherty describes as 'constructive criticisms' that he has made, while Docherty disapproves of the way Ferguson 'comes out and blasts other teams or managers' and also for what he wrote in his autobiography about the trustworthiness of Brian Kidd and Gordon Strachan, 'the sort of thing Sir Matt would never have done in a million years'. 'If you fell out with Sir Matt he would say, "Let's just forget about it"; but if you fall out with Alex, for whatever reason, it's for life. Make no mistake.'

Docherty, now a media pundit and after-dinner speaker, reckons a British manager will succeed Ferguson. 'There's no chance of Louis van Gaal getting the job because there'd be 16 Dutchmen at Old Trafford' - and names familiar candidates, O'Neill, O'Leary, Bruce and Curbishley, as the main contenders. He also says Joe Kinnear would do a great job.

He envies them all. He still regards being appointed United manager as his proudest footballing moment.

webTitle: Scotland bypassed by needs of the Old Firm

fields.headline: Scotland bypassed by needs of the Old Firm
fields.trailText: With only four of the 21 players Craig Brown named for the confrontation with the world champions likely to start the Old Firm match, fings certainly ain't wot they used to be.
fields.body:
A week that contains an Old Firm showdown at the beginning and a Scotland match in the middle is likely to end with affirmation of the notion that the leading clubs and the national side are well advanced along the road to polarisation.

Events at Ibrox this afternoon, when Celtic seek to reduce a 12-point deficit that will surely settle the issue of the 2000 Scottish Premier League championship, will carry only minor significance to the Scots' chances of coping with France in Wednesday's friendly at Hampden Park and their prospects of producing a team capable of picking their way, unharmed, through the looming World Cup qualifying series.

With only four of the 21 players Craig Brown named for the confrontation with the world champions likely to start the Old Firm match, fings certainly ain't wot they used to be.

Club managers have never been in love with the idea of sending entire battalions of players off to fight for the national cause (people can get hurt that way), but the modern trend towards the mass importation of foreigners has automatically reduced the risk. Barry Ferguson is the only first-pick Scot at Ibrox - when he had to miss a recent match Rangers, for the first time in history, fielded a team composed entirely of immigrants - while Celtic, who have four home players when Paul Lambert is fit, show unmistakable signs of treading the same path.

Dick Advocaat and Kenny Dalglish, of course, have responsibilities that take no cognisance of the future welfare of Scotland; the demands of their supporters for success at home and abroad make no allowance for such distractions. In this regard, Dalglish presently carries the heavier burden, having to bridge a gap between his own tormented team and Rangers that is actually widening.

It is an objective that cannot be achieved in one game and, even if Celtic were to beat Rangers convincingly in today's last derby meeting of the season, it would prove nothing that is not already known: that, on any given day, they are capable of victory. If Celtic were to take the three points, Dalglish would savour the moment along with thousands of others panting for relief, but he is too level-headed to be persuaded that it would signify the new golden era is at hand.

The phoniest of all false dawns was witnessed last season, when the Celtic side in the care of Jozef Venglos gave Rangers a 5-1 whipping at home and drew twice at Ibrox in the first three Old Firm encounters - and still managed to lose the championship by six points.

Dalglish's assignment covers a much longer term than one game, or even one season, and only he (and, possibly, Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald) knows if he will take the job of head coach for the foreseeable future. This should not be a significant hindrance to his ideas for making progress; as director of football operations, he has the remit to make assessments of the present personnel and to effect radical change - including buying and selling - with or without the sanction of a new head coach.

Pressed the other day on the question of restructuring, he insisted - as he has for some time - that the programme would begin in earnest at the end of this month when discussion of his own position would begin, reports on current assets were compiled and the overall framework for the future outlined.

'But just because I'm saying we we'll get down to it at the end of March,' he said, 'don't expect an announcement on the first of April. We've actually been restructuring since last summer, when we first came into the job. The facilities for the youths, the scouting and all other aspects have been affected. It's on-going.'

'There are areas where much improvement is needed, especially facilities for players, and we've accomplished some things and we're almost at the point where a few other things will have been done. I know the fans have heard a lot of this before. Tosh McKinlay [the former full-back who is now 35] used to say Celtic have been redeveloping Barrowfield since he was on the ground staff. But we are making progress.

'A long-term assessment of the playing personnel hasn't been made, but that, with many other things, will be part of the discussions when we sit down at the end of March to make plans. But some people seem to put too much emphasis on time scales, wondering when I'll decide about myself or when a new coach will be here, or who he'll be. I've said all along that it's not speed, but the quality of the man that's important.It's what is best for this club that matters.'

Victory over Rangers one week after securing the League Cup would, as Dalglish claims, restore some pride to Celtic supporters, and their chances seemed to have improved when Advocaat outlined the injury problems he has in defence. With Craig Moore, Tony Vidmar, Sergio Porrini and Dariusz Adamczuk all unavailable and Arthur Numan not certain to be totally recovered from injury, the Dutchman may have to change his usual formation to a three-man central defence that could include the inexperienced Scott Wilson and Tero Penttila in partnership with Lorenzo Amoruso.

Rangers have long since mastered the art of coming on strong when they appear weak and, comforted by the certainty that no result is likely to disrupt their plans to celebrate another championship, they appeal as improbable losers.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Baresi the gaffer, Pele the traitor and Guinan the unforgiven.
fields.body:
Franco: I'm coming over

The next boss at Sheffield Wednesday? Whoever David Blunkett chooses to succeed Danny Wilson - and there are plenty of candidates still waiting for their CVs to be noticed at the League Managers' Association website www.leaguemanagers.com (chin up, Terry Fenwick) - one surprisingly glamorous candidate has put himself forward: ageing former Milan skipper Franco Baresi.

Baresi announced this week his plans to follow Gianluca Vialli in starting a managerial career in England. In the country to promote Milan's youth links with British clubs, the 1982 World Cup winner said he was open to offers. 'Having worked with Milan since retiring, I am ready to move. If the opportunity comes up in England, I will consider it.

'In Italy we are very proud that Gianluca Vialli has done so well. He has brought a lot of his Italian experience and a lot of Italian feeling to the Chelsea team. Football is very different in England to Italy but English football is now at a high level, it has grown up a lot. If I get the opportunity, I would love to expand my horizons.'

Brazilian fury at 'traitor' Pele

The head of the Brazilian FA (CBF) has told Pele he will be to blame if Brazil lose the race to host the 2006 World Cup. 'Pele has not stopped criticising the candidature of his own country,' Ricardo Teixeira said last week. 'If we are rejected, it will be his fault.' He claimed that in recent meetings Pele had given misleading information about Brazilian stadia and security standards. 'It pains me that he is opposed to his own country in this way.' Legendary former striker Zico, acting sports ambassador, has joined the criticism. 'First he supported South Africa, later England, now Germany. Why does he not say what his true reason is for being against our bid and leave vanity aside?' Teixeira says the fact that Pele's sports marketing company wasn't commissioned to front Brazil's campaign has nothing to do with it.

Transfer deadline: China snap

Not the biggest deadline day transfer, but certainly the strangest. The deal involved Mark Blake, a former Fulham defender under Kevin Keegan, who signed for Aldershot last week - via China. The process began a month ago when Blake, 32, was playing for Cannes. At the suggestion of former Everton man Paul Rideout, he agreed to move to Chinese side Chongqing Vanguard, who offered him a massive wage. But after three good performances it all went wrong.

'I was in my room getting my training gear on at 9am,' he explains, 'when the kit manager burst in. He pointed at me, then started making aircraft noises and holding his arms out like wings. Next he grabs my case and starts pushing my things in.

'I couldn't believe what was going on. They bundled me into a car and drove me to the airport at Pusan, pushed me through the checkpoints and vanished.' Blake had to wait two days for a flight to France, and arrived back £2,000 out of pocket, and unemployed, until Aldershot took him on.

'Paul heard that my club lost a sponsor at the last minute,' says Blake, 'but it's still unbelievable to think what kind of behaviour they can get away with.' The PFA, and Fifa, are on the case.

Guinan: buns, banter and what else?

Cambridge United's decision to sack striker Steve Guinan last week has provoked much speculation. According to manager Roy McFarland, the striker was thrown out for 'totally unacceptable behaviour' at the club's sportsman's dinner - the toughest disciplinary action Cambridge have ever taken. 'Things go off all the time in football in training and on trips,' said McFarland, 'but this was completely unacceptable.' He refused, though, to go into detail, as did the player. So what happened?

'They were well out of order,' says an anonymous attendee, who denied reports that the incident developed into an ugly vomit and trouser-dropping routine. 'They were throwing food around and heckling the speaker. Some of them looked the worse for drink even before they arrived. It was very, very embarrassing.'

Win Cup semi-final tickets

AXA have given us two pairs of tickets for each of next month's FA Cup semi-finals: Villa v Bolton on 2 April, and Chelsea v Newcastle on 9 April. To win them, answer this simple question...

Which of the following officials has not refereed an FA Cup final: a) S.R. Bastard. b) W. Pierce Dix. c) Major Marindin. d) W. Anchor.

Send your entry on a postcard to AXA Competition, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Results next week.

Said & Done : david.hills@observer.co.uk

Tales from the tabs

PAULO OFF WITH BREAK FROM BOOS

Paulo Wanchope will be kicked out of West Ham this summer. The boo-boy victim is still a target for Leicester, who failed in a £4m deadline move.

OWEN FURY AT SHOCK KOP INJURY AXE

Michael Owen has reacted furiously to being dropped by Liverpool. 'I explained why,' says Gerard Houllier. 'And I don't like being argued with.'

AND THE REST...

Coventry's Moustapha Hadji has denied he's been lined up for a £5m summer move to Arsenal : 'It's flattering to know other teams are interested but I am with very nice people here and have made lots of new friends'; Noel Whelan has opened talks with Everton and West Ham over a possible close season escape from Coventry ; Derby are chasing £3m-rated Sparta Prague and Czech international striker Vratislav Lokvenc; Aston Villa could still keep Benito Carbone after making a massive new pay offer; Bradford have told Birmingham they want £1m for loan-star Isaiah Rankin - Trevor Francis wants to pay half that; David Burrows is likely to leave Coventry at the end of the season - Wolves nearly signed him on deadline day; Everton scouts are watching Preston captain Sean Gregan; Leeds are following Dundee's 6'3" teenage defender Lee Wilkie; Blackburn boss Graeme Souness has targeted Liverpool keeper Brad Friedel; Norwegian U21 captain Ragnvald Soma is close to a pre- contract deal with Middlesbrough ; Bobby Robson has tied up Greek star Nicos Dabizas on a new five-year Newcastle deal; Tony Cottee has signed a short-term extension to his Leicester contract; Wimbledon defender Dean Blackwell is a summer target for Southampton; and Tottenham are new favourites to land Sheffield United's £3m-rated Marcus Bent.

webTitle: Odds and sods - who will manage United next?

fields.headline: Odds and sods - who will manage United next?
fields.trailText: The outsiders have their say - plus all the latest betting in the running for football's hottest seat.
fields.body:
BRIAN McCLAIR (25-1, unattached)
'Twenty-five to one? You must be joking. How the likes of Capello, Lippi and van Gaal might view being ranked in the same bracket as me is another matter. You've made my day, mate - in fact, you've made my year.'
Best bets: 'The 25-1 shots!'

RAY WILKINS (40-1, Chelsea coach)

webTitle: Hearts left to regret post drama

fields.headline: Hearts left to regret post drama
fields.trailText: Hearts, with the chance of putting fourth-placed Motherwell firmly in their place, had to settle for a goalless draw.
fields.body:
Hearts, with the chance of putting fourth-placed Motherwell firmly in their place, had to settle for a goalless draw.

The men who will have been particularly disappointed by that result must have included Hearts' Colin Cameron and Mortherwell's Lee McCulloch. They were the players who came closest to scoring, with efforts that hit the woodwork. McCulloch, ironically a Hearts transfer target earlier this season, also had cause to bemoan his luck when a shot from eight yards was cleared off the line.

Hearts manager Jim Jefferies criticised the referee Mike McCurry for not giving his side a penalty. They had three spot-kick appeals rejected - two following challenges by Greg Strong on Colin Cameron and, in the last minute, an apparent shove by Pat Nevin on Gary Naysmith.

Jefferies said: 'Looking from the sidelines I don't know about the first one, but after Colin Cameron went through the second time it looked like he was brought down at the corner of the six-yard box.

'Maybe we would only have got a penalty if someone had dived full-length saving the ball going into the net with his hands.'

However, despite all this, Jefferies was honest enough to accept that his players should have done better. 'We took a bit of time to get going, but finished the first half the stronger before controlling the second. We certainly created enough chances to win the game.

'The problem was we kept hitting everything straight at their keeper (Stevie Woods). Stephane Adam did that twice with two terrific chances and Thomas Flogel did the same.'

Aberdeen, having won their three previous clashes with Dundee United, set themselves up for another victory by going ahead against them after only five minutes. Eoin Jess created the chance with a through ball to Arild Stavrum, who timed his run perfectly to beat the offside trap and slide the ball under United's keeper Alan Combe. Stavrum should have scored again three minutes later, when David Lilley put him in a similar position, but this time the Norwegian chose to square the ball and the opportunity was missed.

United, no doubt stimulated by the let-off, made it 1-1 after 27 minutes through an excellent build-up involving Craig Easton and Bernard Pascual, and a Joaquim Ferraz header from Pascual's cross.

Two of the most spectacular goals of the day could be seen at St Johnstone. The first came when the home team's defender, Gary Bollan broke the deadlock against Dundee in first-time injury time by driving forward with the ball from midfield and hitting it into the net from 30 yards.

Willie Falconer equalised within two minutes of the restart - his 14th goal of the season - but St Johnstone's new signing, Marc Miller, who had only been on the field for eight minutes, gave them a 2-1 win in the last minute with a shot from 25 yards.

fields.headline: Ferguson's predecessors
fields.trailText: Manchester United's managers since 1903. Remember Herbert Bamlett?
fields.body:
Ernest Mangnall (1903-12) Secretary-manager who presided over United's first golden era, reaching the First Division, and in 1908 winning the title. The following year they won the Cup and were champions again in 1911. But soon afterwards Mangnall made what would today be an unthinkable switch, leaving to join Manchester City.

John Bentley (1912-14) If player power was not quite the force of today, it was almost certainly one reason for Bentley's reign as manager being brief. United finished only fourteenth in his second season amid rumours that his style had upset senior players. He stood down in December 1914, resuming his old role as club secretary.

John Robson (1914-21) His largely undistinguished spell at least achieved one record, a crowd of 70,504 at Old Trafford against Aston Villa in 1920. After the war United disappointed, finishing twelfth and thirteenth.

John Chapman (1921-26) Chapman was lucky to survive a start of only one win in 15 matches that led to relega tion. But they returned and he took them to within one match of their first Wembley final, denied by Ernest Mangnall's Manchester City. The FA later accused him of 'improper conduct' - no details were disclosed - and suspended him.

Lal Hilditch (1926-27) Rushed into the job after John Chapman's suspension, Hilditch, a left-sided midfielder, became the first player-manager in the English First Division but was never more than a stopgap. Allegedly, he never had a foul given against him in his career.

Herbert Bamlett (1927-31) He was unsuccessful, spectacularly so in 1930-31 when United lost their first 12 matches, scoring 14 goals and conceding 49. They went down and Bamlett was sacked.

Walter Crickmer (1931-32; 37-45) Never officially appointed manager, filling in after Bamlett's disastrous season and again during World War Two. But he was responsible for the youth policy that would flourish under Matt Busby and Jimmy Murphy. The man who had joined United as a clerk in 1919 died in the 1958 Munich air crash.

Scott Duncan (1932-37) At first, United's decline continued under Duncan, a 2-0 win at Millwall in May 1934 saving them from sliding into Third Division North. A revival took them to the Second Division title in 1935-36, but they went straight back down again. Duncan resigned in November 1937 and went to Ipswich, where his wife, troubled by Manchester's pollution, found the air more to her liking.

Matt Busby (1945-69; 70-71) With his assistant Jimmy Murphy, Busby created United's first great post-war team around players like Johnny Carey and Charlie Mitten. Then came the legendary Busby Babes, eight of whom died at Munich. Busby himself nearly perished and twice received the last rites. His trailblazing in Europe, initially against Football League wishes, delivered the famous 1968 European Cup final win over Benfica. He returned briefly as manager in 1970-71.

Wilf McGuinness (1969-70) His 13 games for United in 1955-56 meant he qualified for a title medal, but injury forced him to retire young. His spell as manager, after Busby's enormous success, was ill-starred and he was demoted to reserve coach.

Frank O'Farrell (1971-72) Quietly successful at Torquay and Leicester, the universally liked O'Farrell made a triumphant start to the 1970-71 season at Old Trafford with only one defeat in 14 games. He also did United the immense favour of signing Martin Buchan, who would play 455 League and Cup games for the club. Otherwise, his first season turned steadily sour and after a poor start to the next one he was dismissed.

Tommy Docherty (1972-77) A fans' favourite, he survived United's return to the Second Division and repaid the club's loyalty by masterminding their immediate promotion. Huge crowds returned to Old Trafford and FA Cup final appearances followed in 1976 and 1977. It all ended, though, after he had an affair with the club physiotherapist's wife Mary Brown.

Dave Sexton (1977-81) He broke the club's transfer record four times - Joe Jordan (£388,888), Gordon McQueen (£450,000), Ray Wilkins (£700,000) and Garry Birtles (£1.25 million) - but his teams never quite produced an acceptable dividend on this massive expenditure. An FA Cup Final appearance in 1979 and second in the First Division in 1980 were deemed insufficient and the board fired him.

Ron Atkinson (1981-86) Atkinson, brash and confident, signalled a change of atmosphere at Old Trafford after Sexton's introspective reign. Bryan Robson arrived immediately in a £1.5m deal that also included Remi Moses and there were FA Cup triumphs in 1983 and 1985. In 1986, United won their first 10 League games and at one stage led the First Division by 10 points. But injuries and Liverpool caught up with them and in November 1986, after a five-year association, United and Atkinson parted company.

Alex Ferguson (1986-) On his third anniversary a fans' banner read: 'Three years of excuses: Ta-ra Fergie.' The turnaround began with Cup successes and reached completion with the start of the Premier League in 1992-93 when United became champions for the first time for 26 years. Since then a blend of British and overseas talent has triumphed, finishing the millennium with their famous treble.

fields.headline: Explain...
fields.trailText: Simon Burnton meets Mark Harrison, the former Port Vale goalkeeper and current manager of Bangladesh.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago Mark Harrison was given a dream job in international management. For those who don't know who he is, he was a goalkeeper at Southampton (1978-1980, no league appearances), Port Vale (1980-82, 70 league appearances) and Stoke City (1982, seven league appearances). Hardly a well-known name, but good enough to land him the managerial reigns of Bangladesh, the latest in an increasingly long line of British managers abroad.

Even more extraordinarily, Harrison had never even been to Asia before his appointment. 'It is definitely going to be a major challenge,' he says, 'a more exciting endeavour than anything I've experienced in my career.' Since Stoke, Harrison has coached in South Africa, and at Bristol City, Everton and Oxford. 'I have seen the Asians in action on television, but unfortunately never Bangladesh. But I've worked abroad before and enjoyed being in different places.' But why is it that British coaches are currently so popular around the globe? According to Terry Yorath (above), first-team coach at Bradford City and former manager of Lebanon, foreign folk admire the traditional British values. 'Basically it's our honesty,' he says. Recruitment can be an unusual process - Yorath got his job in Lebanon more by luck than judgement, through a friend who worked in the building trade there. But what could possibly convince a coach to give up his comfortable life and transport himself half way across the globe? 'It gives you an opportunity to get involved with a different way of life,' says Yorath. 'It's not always easy. We used to train at a stadium that was like baked sand in the summer, and in the winter it's flooded. Then there's the language - you pick up little bits and pieces but it's hard.'

Maybe it's just the David Beckham effect that's taking Britain's best from Bangladesh to Burma and the Bahamas, all of whom currently have English managers. On the other hand, maybe they're just hoping that a bit of our Premiership glamour will rub off on them. It hasn't worked yet, but in the meantime, ever more obscure Britons await the foreign call. Maybe, just maybe, one day it could be you.

fields.headline: Wednesday's contract fiasco
fields.trailText: A Wednesday old boy reveals how his old club left Danny Wilson undone.
fields.body:
When I joined Sheffield Wednesday in 1983 a local estate agent informed me that they behaved differently in Sheffield. Curious, I asked: 'In what way?' He replied: 'Down south they stab you in the back, up here we stab you in the chest.'

Consequently, while the rest of the country looks on with a mixture of anguish and amusement at Wednesday's plight, it comes as no surprise to see angry local MPs, unhappy shareholders and disgruntled supporters groups voicing their opinion, bluntly telling it how it is to whoever will listen.

Danny Wilson became the first Premiership manager to be sacked this season despite believing that his job was safe, until the end of the season, with the new board. Despite leaving with six months' compensation of £300,000 Wilson was still shocked and surprised to receive the fatal blow from new chairman Howard Culley last Tuesday.

Wilson made mistakes but his position was constantly compromised by both the previous board and the new one.

Last December Emerson Thome was sold to Chelsea for £2.5 million, which Wilson believed he could reinvest on new players. No money was released and no players came to Hillsborough.

Wilson was further undermined on the eve of the bottom-of-the-table clash at Watford. First team players Peter Atherton, Ian Nolan and Danny Sonner were suddenly informed on the Friday before the game that contract offers were being withdrawn.

With players reeling from the news it was hardly surprising that Wednesday produced a lack-lustre performance on the field, losing 1-0. How ironic then it was for Wilson to be sacked after the Watford game - the defeat that broke the camel's back for the board of directors.

There has been some suggestion that the board's decision was due to mounting criticism from shareholders, who have put in a motion for a vote of no confidence in the board due to be held on 6 April. The proxy votes indicate that the rebel shareholders will win comfortably with a 9-1 margin.

While off-the-field activities have not helped Wilson has also made errors. He created a perception that he found it very difficult to deal with certain players, namely Paolo di Canio and Benito Carbone.

Despite severe restrictions Wilson, in the end, failed to deliver results. In his first season, after flirting with relegation, the club finished in a respectable twelfth place, mainly through being hard to beat and counter-attacking effectively.

This season Wilson brought creative and flair-players into the squad in an attempt to move the club on. These players were meant to be the icing on the cake and to complement the side's dogged determination. Unfortunately the mix didn't work and the team crumbled as they got off to their worst ever Premiership start.

Now existing players have already been linked with other clubs and contracts have been withdrawn from others. With the financial situation of the club rumoured to be anywhere between £12m and £18m in debt, there is a fear in the city that they will 'do a Man City' and enter into free-fall until they reach a lower equilibrium where income, expenditure and ability meet.

Furthermore, if the health of the football club is measured by the relationship it has with its supporters then Wednesday are in a coma as fans stay away in their droves.

The new board will have to show leadership and direction if they are to win over shareholders and fans. Culley is a solicitor and in this post-Bosman age era his skills are vital on any board. However, there is a distinct lack of businessmen with any entrepreneurial flair who have a plan of action, with aims and objectives on how to rejuvenate a declining club both on and off the field.

Culley has offered no forward path as yet in order to bridge what seems an unbridgeable divide. Until he does there will still be some more blatant and latent blood-letting between all the warring factions.

Until stability reigns then Wednesday, despite being in the fourth largest city in England, will be unattractive to prospective managers and financial institutions. Yet despite their upheavals, Wednesday are ripe for some wealthy investors to gain ownership of the club cheaply and make it a viable proposition once again.

Journalist and broadcaster Lawrie Madden played for Sheffield Wednesday from 1983-91.
