Until stability reigns then Wednesday, despite being in the fourth largest city in England, will be unattractive to prospective managers and financial institutions. Yet despite their upheavals, Wednesday are ripe for some wealthy investors to gain ownership of the club cheaply and make it a viable proposition once again. Journalist and broadcaster Lawrie Madden played for Sheffield Wednesday from 1983-91.

fields.headline: Old man Walsh rolling on
fields.trailText: Walsh will be an unlikely record holder, writes Vic Marks. For a decade from 1984, when he made his Test debut, Walsh was the support bowler of the West Indian quartet; the uncomplaining workhorse who would bowl into the wind and shut an end up on long hot afternoons.
fields.body:
After their last two series against the West Indies tormented England cricketers have tossed their bats into their bags and consoled one another with the thought: 'Well, at least we won't have to deal with Courtney and Curtly again.' Another error of judgment by hapless English batsmen. The pair are still going; they may still be rolling in when the West Indies come to England in May.

Walsh leads the way. In Jamaica, on his home patch, he is on the verge becoming the highest Test wicket-taker of all time, surpassing Kapil Dev's tally of 434.

This will be no guarantee that the old boy (he's 37) decides to call it a day. He loves the game too much and he may take heed of the observation of Dennis Waight, the long-serving physio to the West Indies team: 'I've got a feeling that if Courtney stops playing, he'll never get started again.' Waight said this two years ago, adding with exasperation that Courtney was prone to turn out for his club side in Kingston in between Test matches 'because they were short'.

Walsh will be an unlikely record holder. For example, cast your eye down the list of 49 names nominated as possible Cricketers of the Century for this year's Wisden and CA Walsh is nowhere to be seen. For a decade from 1984, when he made his Test debut, Walsh was the support bowler of the West Indian quartet; the uncomplaining workhorse who would bowl into the wind and shut an end up on long hot afternoons. He only came on after Michael Holding or Malcolm Marshall had had a go. It wasn't until Ambrose was the last remaining pace giant that Walsh was entrusted with the new ball and he started galloping up those bowling records.

Walsh, the workaholic, became a strike bowler as well. His gangling, slightly uncoordinated action suggests - deceptively - that the ball is always coming into the right-handed batsman, leading to scores of victims in the slip cordon. That distinctive open-chested action makes the ball hard to pick up - at least Holding had the decency to possess the perfect, classical method of delivery, which enabled an early sight of the ball. Walsh changes his pace devilishly without any discernible change of action and has hit countless batsmen over the years - far more than Holding or Ambrose. (I'm one of them; the last ball I received in first-class cricket rearranged my knuckle and the scar remains).

But it is his stamina and loyalty to the cause that singles out Walsh. This was highlighted by his reaction to his sacking as West Indian captain two years ago when he was replaced by Brian Lara. With the exception of Gary Sobers, no West Indian captain, once removed from the job, had continued to play in the team. Walsh instinctively agreed to keep going and gave Lara his public backing (much-needed since Lara's first game in charge was to be in Jamaica). Moreover he supported him wholeheartedly throughout that 1998 series and beyond. His small ego and big heart dictated that he could do nothing else, a reaction that surprised no one in Kingston or his adopted home of Bristol. Now we wonder whether Lara is capable of doing the same for new West Indian captain, Jimmy Adams.

Yet before we get too misty-eyed about Courtney, also bear in mind that he has been the most ruthless and meanest of operators on the field, however ready the smile has been once play has ended. In his time Walsh has been prepared to explore the limits of fair play. In 1994 in Jamaica it was Walsh who launched a madcap assault on England's hopeless number 11, Devon Malcolm, which could not be justified. Umpire Ian Robinson from Zimbabwe, in a shocking abnegation of his responsibilities, looked on without saying a dicky bird (the real Dickie Bird would have intervened) as he peppered Malcolm from around the wicket with a succession of vicious, needless bouncers. Walsh showed no remorse for that intimidatory spell.

Just as memorable, though more acceptable, was his assault upon Michael Atherton in the same game. A keen adherent of the West Indian philosophy 'cut off the head and the rest will follow', Walsh targeted Atherton with more bouncers from around the wicket and refused to rest until England's captain was removed (he got him in the end). In this instance the cricket was awesome; with Malcolm on strike it was just plain awful.

We can assume from the safety of the press box that the 2000 version of Walsh would not be capable of such ferocity, but I doubt whether you will find any English batsman who is prepared to express that view in public. They have sighed with relief before. Until he has tossed his bowling boots into the Caribbean Sea and signed an affidavit that he has delivered his last ball in Test cricket, Atherton, Stewart, Hussain and co must assume that Courtney, his mischievous eyes on 500 Test wickets, will be gliding in to torment them yet again this summer.

fields.headline: Aussies in sight of record
fields.trailText: Michael Slater and Steve Waugh plundered centuries as Australia built a first innings lead over New Zealand in the second Test at the Basin Reserve.
fields.body:
Michael Slater and Steve Waugh plundered centuries as Australia built a first innings lead over New Zealand in the second Test at the Basin Reserve. Looking shaky at 51 for four, Australia showed typical middle-order resilience to finish the second day on 318 for five, 20 runs in front.

Slater claimed his fourteenth Test hundred before falling for 143 and Waugh, who was 109 not out at the close, his twenty-second as they added 199 for the fifth wicket to put pressure back on Stephen Fleming's side.

Waugh, like Slater looking for a big score after a recent run of failures, overtook David Gower to become Test cricket's sixth all-time leading run-getter. He also passed David Boon and Neil Harvey to move into fourth place in the list of Australian Test century-makers. Only Greg Chappell, Allan Border and Don Bradman are ahead of him.

New Zealand laboured away without Auckland Test spinning hero Daniel Vettori, who did not return for the final session after injuring his lower back while fielding. The attack was carried by Cairns, but he was punished with the second new ball and in one over he went for 13 runs.

Australia, who lead the three-match series after a 62-run victory in Auckland, are chasing a record ninth consecutive Test victory after equalling a 79-year-old Australian milestone in the opening Test against New Zealand.

New Zealand began strongly in the morning session when Cairns, who scored 109 on the first day, had Langer caught behind for 12 and Mark Waugh caught close to the wicket.

Andrew Flintoff returned to action with a sparkling 41 for Lancashire on their South African tour.

In his first appearance since breaking a foot playing for England in the Cape Town Test against South Africa, Flintoff played a major role as Lancashire crushed Western Province B by seven wickets in a one-day match.

But Flintoff played only as a batsman and England are hoping the all-rounder will prove his full fitness before the start of the summer's international programme.

Lancashire bowled out the South African side for 135, Mike Smethurst taking four for 29, and cruised to victory in the twenty-eighth over.

fields.headline: Reon lights the way
fields.trailText: They came in their thousands yesterday to witness history in the making, to glory in one of their own entering the annals, yet it was not to be and no one was disappointed. Every t'ing cool, den.
fields.body:
They came in their thousands yesterday to witness history in the making, to glory in one of their own entering the annals, yet it was not to be and no one was disappointed. The game is like that and instead the hordes thrilled at the sight of two pretenders, Reon King and Franklyn Rose - one a might callow, the other far from the flush of youth - riding in the slipstream of Courtney Walsh, still needing four wickets to eclipse Kapil Dev's world record 434, and Curtly Ambrose.

Parts of west and central Kingston are under curfew after a gun battle last week, but the players were cheered by the news that knives, bottles, rocks and other missiles would not be allowed in the ground. Licensed firearms holders, of whom Shivnarine Chanderpaul is one, have also been urged to leave their weapons at home too. Every t'ing cool, den.

Sabina Park, though, an oasis of sanity in a troubled downtown, looks a well-irrigated treat and is burnished now by a life-size bronze of George Headley, Jamaica's greatest batsman. And not before time. Test match Saturday is a national occasion and a crowd approaching capacity jammed into the grand sweep of the Headley Stand well before the start.

They are here to pay homage, of course, to two giants of the game, and today will be no different. Five Jamaicans in the side, including the newly installed captain, Jimmy Adams, are further cause for celebration.

The roof will come off when Walsh finally cracks the record, and Ambrose, trailing in his wake, also has his eyes set on the coveted 400-wicket mark. Rising 37, the Antiguan is in his ninetieth Test, with 376 wickets at 21 apiece and the body knows it. 'Only Curtly knows when to quit,' he says. 'It was refreshing to win last week and I've always said I do these things for the people because the game belongs to all of us.' You'd better believe him.

He missed the debacle in New Zealand with an elbow injury but is now back in good rhythm and still capable of wreaking havoc in short spells. 'I'm taking it game by game, because you never can tell,' he observes. 'Form can disappear, injuries occur or your fitness goes.' The true test of his likely longevity will come during the three-Test series against Pakistan in May, and the selectors must surely omit him from the intervening triangular tournament. Walsh ducked out of the one-day scene over a year ago.

To suggest, as several have, that nobody was ready to adopt Ambrose and Walsh's mantle is nonsense. King may have come of age in this match. Shy, diffident and mild-mannered, a man of few words, he kept his head in both forms of the game when the wheels fell off in New Zealand where Brian Lara underbowled him.

Adams has allowed him a full head, and he responded magnificently without luck in the first Test in Trinidad in tandem with Rose. Brought up on flat-bed wickets in Georgetown, Guyana, he has learnt to keep the ball up but hides a wicked bouncer off a fluent, lithe approach not dissimilar to Michael Holding. Mikey himself refuses to see it.

Rose is a contrasting figure, a lover of the limelight, even the catwalk in London, and the pair have agreed a pact to raise their game in harness. It seems to be working. On Friday evening, when Zimbabwe had staged a great recovery, Rose it was who cartwheeled Andy Flower's off stump when the captain shouldered arms.

It set the tone for yesterday morning's celebration of fast bowling when three wickets fell in the first hour and only token resistance seemed possible. Brian Murphy, the nightwatchman, saw his castle wrecked by a Rose yorker then Heath Streak suffered the same fate from a distinctly rapid King delivery.

Bryan Strang entered full of purpose and even had the temerity to charge Rose at one stage, carting him over the mid-wicket boundary. The response was predictable when Ridley Jacobs, the wicketkeeper, dragged down a superb catch to remove Strang off King, who earned his first five-wicket haul in Test. There are several more to come.

fields.headline: Killie's desire crucial
fields.trailText: Kilmarnock 1 - 0 Hibernian
fields.body:
In the kind of perilous position where points are more precious than polish, Kilmarnock gave a workmanlike performance to secure the victory which keeps them off the floor of the Premier League. The match may have been aesthetically challenged, but the home side at least offered more in the way of willingness and application than their curiously subdued visitors.

Having allowed a place in Europe, through a lofty league position, to slither further from their reach with the midweek defeat by Dundee, Hibs gave the impression for much of the time that their collective subconscious had been engaged by their looming Scottish Cup semi-final.

The cup seems likely to be the short route to the Continent this season as Rangers, with Ayr United in the semis, seem certain to reach the final and, with the league championship also apparently destined for Ibrox, Hibs need win only one game, against Aberdeen at Hampden Park on Sunday week, to be virtually guaranteed a place in the Uefa Cup.

Hibs were certainly uncharacteristically sluggish for much of the time, as though preoccupied with other matters. Without the injured John Hughes in central defence, they also appeared frequently to be a little vulnerable.

It was indicative of Kilmarnock's season-long malaise, however, that their abundant possession and attempts on goal failed for a long period to force Nick Colgan to make a save of note. Most of the home side's endeavours involved diligent application but without the required refinement in their finishing.

Rugby Park has a peculiar way of hinting at the pattern and even the outcome of a match within the first five minutes of play, and this one indicated 90 minutes in which the home side would be much the livelier and more ambitious. Other visitors with elevated ideas of their station, such as Celtic and Hearts, have discovered that a slow or flat start at this venue can be horrendously difficult to overcome.

By the interval, Hibs looked in need of a restorative if they were to summon the energy and the commitment to make an impact on Gordon Marshall, who spent the first half in idleness. His teammates were busy with the chore of putting the frighteners on their guests with a series of marauding assaults on the latter's goal area.

Nobody in the crowd knew whether it was a good thing or not that Ally McCoist, playing his first match in five months, should last only 15 minutes before sustaining a calf injury and being replaced by Samassi Abou. The veteran striker had caused one or two panics among his markers with some intelligent running and heading, but seemed unlikely to make a telling impact.

Abou should have made himself a hero within five minutes of his arrival when he was sent clear on the right of the penalty area by Christophe Cocard's perfectly-weighted pass. His scuffed attempt was the kind that would have taken the shine off patent leather shoes and, as his right foot shovelled up the dirt, the ball ran weakly into the arms of Colgan.

When Kilmarnock did take the lead, they had done enough to deserve it. It was no surprise, either, that the service should come from Tosh McKinlay; the veteran left-back still delivers a more intelligent and precise pass - whether down the line, through the middle or crossed from wide - than most players in the country.

This time, the ball was dropped nicely over the retreating defenders, allowing Jerome Vareille to push between them and then stop the ball with the sole of his foot. As Martin McIntosh and John Dennis scrambled to retain their balance and Colgan rushed out, Vareille chipped the ball on the turn with his right foot high to the left of the goalkeeper.

It was no surprise, either, that Franck Sauzee, another greybeard who still manages to look exceptional in the midst of a different generation, should come close to providing Hibs with an equaliser. Side-stepping the home defence as he worked the ball on to his left foot, he sent a fierce drive shoulder-high to the goalkeeper's left - giving Marshall his first save of the match.

The veteran striker had caused one or two panics among his markers with some intelligent running and heading, but seemed unlikely to make a telling impact. Abou should have made himself a hero within five minutes of his arrival when he was sent clear on the right of the penalty area by Christophe Cocard's perfectly-weighted pass. His scuffed attempt was the kind that would have taken the shine off patent leather shoes and, as his right foot shovelled up the dirt, the ball ran weakly into the arms of Colgan. When Kilmarnock did take the lead, they had done enough to deserve it. It was no surprise, either, that the service should come from Tosh McKinlay; the veteran left-back still delivers a more intelligent and precise pass - whether down the line, through the middle or crossed from wide - than most players in the country. This time, the ball was dropped nicely over the retreating defenders, allowing Jerome Vareille to push between them and then stop the ball with the sole of his foot. As Martin McIntosh and John Dennis scrambled to retain their balance and Colgan rushed out, Vareille chipped the ball on the turn with his right foot high to the left of the goalkeeper. It was no surprise, either, that Franck Sauzee, another greybeard who still manages to look exceptional in the midst of a different generation, should come close to providing Hibs with an equaliser. Side-stepping the home defence as he worked the ball on to his left foot, he sent a fierce drive shoulder-high to the goalkeeper's left - giving Marshall his first save of the match.

fields.headline: Putin faces electoral setback
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin may fall                                                                    short of outright victory in Sunday's                                                                    presidential election and be forced into a                                                                    runoff after a surprisingly strong                                                                    performance by the Communists,                                                                    according to early results.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin may fall short of outright victory in Sunday's presidential election and be forced into a runoff after a surprisingly strong performance by the Communists, according to early results.

While Putin would almost certainly win a second round, it would be a humbling setback for the former KGB officer who has become acting president and the nation's most popular politician with his calls to restore Russia as a great power.

The first election results showed the Putin with about 46 percent of the vote, Communist leader Gennady Zyuganov with 31 percent and Aman Tuleyev, a left-wing governor, in third place with about 9 percent, according to official figures.

Political commentators on Russian television networks suggested Putin could clear the 50-percent hurdle, but the outcome may be determined by a handful of votes either way.

The state-RTR television network, citing two exit polls, said Putin was getting about 50 percent of the vote with Zyuganov following with about 26 percent and liberal Grigory Yavlinsky in third place with 7 percent.

Overall turnout was at 65.8 percent, normal for a Russian election, according to the Interfax news agency. A new election would have been necessary had the turnout of eligible voters not reached 50 percent.

Putin's campaign may have suffered from the widespread assumption that he would win, convincing many of his supporters that there was no need to vote. But the fairly strong vote for Zyuganov was also seen as a protest vote by Russians unhappy about Putin's apparently inevitable victory.

Putin, looking relaxed, said he was confident of victory as he voted at a Moscow polling station. He told reporters he was going to relax at a sauna, saying he expected to face many new challenges starting Monday.

``Tomorrow is Monday, a hard day, and I will have to go to work,'' he said.

The tough, man-of-action image that Putin cultivates appeals to many Russians, tired of the uncertainty and mayhem of the final years of former President Boris Yeltsin. Putin has promised to end massive corruption, revive the economy after years of recession and restore the political and military influence that Moscow wielded before the Soviet collapse.

``I'm tired of all this disorder,'' said Vladimir Prishchev, a pensioner casting his ballot for Putin in Russia's Pacific port city of Vladivostok, where graft is rampant and life miserable for most people. ``When Putin takes charge of something, he takes it to the end.''

Some Russians, particularly liberals, fear Putin may trample Russia's fragile democracy and restore the iron control the secret police enforced during the Soviet era.

``He is dangerous. He seems too harsh,'' said Anna Polevaya, a 27-year-old architect from Moscow.

But some Russian reformers and Western officials and businessmen have praised Putin as a pragmatic reformer who will restore stability in Russia and improve people's lives by making reforms work.

With a trademark poker face, Putin comes across as stern and colorless, often cold. He is described often as resembling the archetypal ``chekist'' or secret policeman - which appeals to many Russians who believe tough government alone can clean up the country and restore stability.

Putin, who makes no secret of his plans to increase the power of the state and its security forces, insists he is a democrat. But he has been studiously vague about his plans beyond stressing the need for strong government and strengthening the security forces.

Some analysts say Putin has few specific plans because of his rapid rise to power and it may be months before his intentions are clear. Nor is Putin likely to turn things around quickly after decades of authoritarianism and economic disintegration, they add.

Yeltsin, who stunned Russians by resigning six months early and dubbing Putin as his political heir, said Sunday he was confident that the younger leader would continue the reforms set in place after the Soviet collapse.

``Everybody is waiting for change,'' said Yeltsin after casting his ballot. ``There will be some changes, but the main thing is the course of reform must stay, and it will stay. I am convinced of that.''

Putin, who rose through a series of mostly obscure government posts in the 1990s and has never held elected office, was appointed prime minister by Yeltsin in August. He gained immediate popularity for his vigorous image and his tough handling of the war in Chechnya. Putin was named acting president when Yeltsin resigned six months early.

Little is known about Putin and extensive checks by journalists and others in recent months have produced more questions and few insights. Unlike many prominent officials, Putin has not been linked to corruption, boosting his image in the eyes of Russians who have seen political insiders amass vast fortunes while living standards for most people plummeted.

The election campaign was lackluster with most Russians convinced a Putin victory was inevitable. The other candidates appeared resigned to not winning and there was little in the way of campaign rallies and trips. State television lavished Putin with daily coverage, boosting his chances.

The challenge awaiting Russia's next leader is enormous. The economy is in ruins and market reforms have been discredited by mismanagement and high-level corruption. Schools and hospitals are falling apart and millions of people go months without pay. Crime has flourished.

In another sign of the problems facing Russia's next president, rebels in Chechnya launched a new attack Sunday despite Moscow's claims that the insurgents have been defeated.

fields.headline: Governing bodies set for war
fields.trailText: It's the clash everyone wanted: UEFA v FIFA Good for latest
fields.body:
Football is preparing for global hostilities - Uefa v Fifa and European clubs v the rest of the world - following Fifa president Sepp Blatter's bombshell edict last Friday that a uniform synchronised world soccer calendar must be in place by 2004.

That would mean the Premiership shrinking to 18 teams and all domestic games being played in a 38-week block.

'There's now a lot of hard talking to be done. The Premier League isn't against a harmonised calendar in prin ciple but we, and the other major leagues in Europe, want it to be built around the season as currently constructed in Europe,' says League spokesman Mike Lee.

Uefa has already opened discussions with its counterparts in Africa and South America to try and build a united front. In the short term Fifa's plan will reopen the dormant debate domestically about reconstructing English football, for example a smaller Premiership and possibly 'Premiership Two'.

fields.headline: 'Junket Jack' set to referee rip-offs
fields.trailText: Jack Cunningham, Whitehall 'enforcer', will name and shame clubs that exploit their fans.
fields.body:
Football is finally to get a watchdog to penalise greedy clubs that rip off fans by overcharging for tickets and replica shirts.

Tony Blair's former Whitehall 'enforcer', Jack Cunningham, is set to chair the new body, which will 'name and shame' clubs that exploit their supporters. It will investigate complaints from fans and criticise clubs which disobey a new code of practice.

But Cunningham's likely appointment as head of soccer's Independent Scrutiny Panel has triggered a row over his suitability. There is concern that the former Cabinet Minister, dubbed 'Junket Jack' for his love of the high life, may not be ideal to investigate 'fat cat' clubs which allegedly abuse their fans' affections.

Cunningham sparked controversy during his two and a half years in the Cabinet by flying first-class on Concorde, staying in the best hotels and ordering a £2,000 mahogany table for his office. Questions were asked when he was Agriculture Minister about his decision to move his department from its unglamorous Whitehall base to swankier headquarters.

Some Ministers and fans' representatives also fear his close links with Newcastle United, which he has supported since boyhood, could prove a weakness. The club recently attracted widespread contempt for forcing several thousand of its own supporters to move from their regular seats near the pitch to accommodate corporate customers paying much higher prices.

However, Cunningham has the Prime Minister's backing for the post - a Government appointment - and is the choice of soccer's ruling bodies, the Football Association, the Premier League and the Football League. He is rated '98 per cent certain' to get it, despite the reservations.

The Government's decision to police the national sport through the panel means it has rejected, pleas from fans to set up a legally-backed regulator. Supporters' representatives, who want a powerful 'football audit commission' modelled on the telecommunications and water watchdogs Oftel and Ofwat, will see the panel as a toothless talking-shop.

But a Government insider said: 'We might still legislate for a full-blown regulator; we will keep that sword of Damocles hanging over football.

'But we will give the game two years to prove the ISP is all that's needed to improve the way the game is governed and remind clubs they mustn't take advantage of their fans.'

The body's powers will provoke a furious debate. It will investigate clubs but be able only to recommend, rather than ensure, remedial action. Much of its clout will rest on how clubs react if they are identified in new 'performance league tables' as having failed to consult fans, attract enough young supporters or treat visiting fans fairly.

Fans wanted a mainly advisory body which they would control. But football has finally agreed not to seek representation on the panel, and accepted that its membership has to be truly independent. The body will be in place for the start of the new season in August.

fields.headline: Smart salvages Watford pride
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 1 Tottenham Hotspur
fields.body:
Watfird secured a point and some pride against Tottenham yesterday, but it looks too late to save them from relegation. Allan Smart's late equaliser was a measure of revenge for Graham Taylor's men after the 4-0 mauling they suffered at White Hart Lane on Boxing Day, but with games running out, the Premiership's bottom club desperately need wins to stay up.

It was hard to believe Watford are fighting for their Premiership lives, so soporific was the first half at Vicarage Road. While they have only the slimmest of chances of survival, one would have thought they would approach this game with a bit more bite. Tottenham, after all, are playing only for the pride of a respectable finish in the table and there was something of an end-of-season atmosphere among their fans and players.

With precious little meaningful action on the pitch to keep them entertained, the supporters amused themselves dancing in the stand behind Ian Walker's goal. One or two were led out by police, but for the rest the biggest danger was being hit by the ball as Watford's shooting was of the wayward variety. Peter Kennedy and Richard Johnson were guilty of hitting the ball somewhere in the region of Row Z, while Heidar Helguson headed well over Walker's bar from a good position midway through the first half.

It was a miss mirrored by Chris Armstrong minutes later when the Spurs striker headed wide after a Steffen Iversen flick-on from a long throw from Steffen Freund.

In fact, the only serious efforts on goal during the first 45 minutes came from Darren Anderton, captain for the day in the absence of the injured Sol Campbell. Set up by David Ginola, the midfielder shot fiercely from the edge of the area, but his strike was matched by a good save from Alec Chamberlain. The Watford goalkeeper denied Anderton again when he fired in a low shot from even further out following a short free-kick in the 33rd minute.

Spurs finally made a breakthrough in the 51st minute. A long ball out of the Tottenham defence saw Chamberlain run out of his area and reach the ball ahead of Chris Armstrong, but his attempted clearance was charged down by the Spurs striker, who ran on to score his tenth goal of the season.

Spurs seemed well in control at this stage, with Stephen Clemence, Iversen and Armstrong all threatening. Watford's response was poor and Nordin Wooter mis-hit a shot well wide from a good position. The midfielder made amends, however, setting up the equaliser in the 78th minute when he poked the ball forward for Allan Smart to nip in behind the Spurs defence and flick a shot past Walker.

The goal gave Watford hope they could get something from the game and they stepped up a gear. Wooter had a snap shot blocked on the line from Mauricio Taricco and the young substitute Tommy Smith went close. But their increased desire also led to some rash challenges and Neil Cox and Paul Robinson were booked in quick succession.

Spurs also had late chances to snatch all three points. Substitute Les Ferdinand headed wide and Ginola saw a long-range shot fly just over Chamberlain's crossbar.

fields.headline: Sleepy Owls no wiser
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 1 - 0 Sheffield Wednesday
fields.byline: John Wilford at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Boro extended their unbeaten run to six games in a second-rate encounter that keeps Wednesday firmly embedded in relegationland.

Early action at both ends gave way to ennui and Andy Campbell's solitary goal was enough to sink the sleepy Owls. Juninho should have made the victory more emphatic but missed from the penalty spot.

The home side, in relative safety, could be forgiven for taking life easy but Wednesday were singularly lacking in the sense of urgency demanded of a team supposed to be battling their way out of the drop zone.

Defeat at Watford last week proved the final straw for Danny Wilson and the Wednesday board turned, once again, to Peter Shreeves. The last time he was caretaker - between the reigns of David Pleat and Ron Atkinson - Wednesday scored a 5-0 victory over Bolton Wanderers. But hopes of a similar result here soon vanished.

However, Mark Schwarzer almost gifted Wednesday a goal in the opening minutes when he hit a poor clearance straight to the feet of Gilles De Bilde. The Belgian's prompt shot from 20 yards hit the foot of the post. Alan Quinn then crossed expertly to Niclas Alexandersson and with Schwarzer struggling it took Christian Ziege's quick thinking to clear the header away for a corner.

But it was Boro who took the lead. When Juninho was fouled, Paul Ince took a quick free kick to Campbell, who had advanced into the box. The shooting position was poor but Kevin Pressman was in no-man's land and could only watch as Campbell's shot cleared his grasp.

Then Campbell, chasing Ziege's through ball, went to ground as Pressman came rushing from goal. A yellow card for the keeper and a penalty for Juninho to take which Pressman saved impressively, diving to his left.

There was one moment of comical confusion shortly before half time when Peter Atherton deflected a back pass away from Pressman and the keeper then had to scramble frantically back to palm the ball off the line.

After the break, Wednesday came more into the game and had three good chances to equalise. Alexandersson, put in the clear by Wim Jonk, lobbed tamely into the keeper's arms. Quinn, unmarked, volleyed over from Ian Nolan's promising centre. And Quinn, again, shot straight at Schwarzer when De Bilde rolled the ball temptingly into his path.

fields.headline: Reid's happy new year
fields.trailText: Sunderland 2- 1 Everton
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Sunderland's long wait is finally over. Kevin Phillips - who else? - was the man responsible for earning Peter Reid's fading team their first victory of the Millennium.

Eleven Premiership games without a win had tested the patience of their fans to the limit and the atmosphere within the Stadium of Light was turning sour at the moment Phillips claimed his 26th goal of the season.

It was one of the best, curled in from more than 20 yards in the 77th minute when Everton keeper Paul Gerrard appeared to have all the angles adequately covered.

Reid, under fire from those fans, had more cause than anybody to be grateful to Phillips, whose claim for a place in England's Euro 2000 squad is surely unanswerable after this latest demonstrating of his finishing technique.

Yet it couldn't have started better for Sunderland. With Everton still adapting to a formation that featured Joe Max Moore and Nick Barmby playing at the shoulder of Mark Hughes, Sunderland scored a goal that proved crucial to their morale.

Nicky Summerbee was the scorer after three minutes with a 25-yard free-kick that eluded an unconvincing dive from keeper Paul Gerrard.

The goal's value to Sunderland was immense. Reid had preached in the build-up about the importance of confidence and Summerbee's low shot was the ideal antidote to doubts raised by their decline in the past three months.

It was particularly satisfying for Summerbee, starting for the first time in six games after a dressing room dispute with Reid and marking his return with his first goal of the season. He should score more.

Indeed there should have been more first half goals for Sunderland, notably when Kevin Phillips went clear in the 23rd minute. Gerrard saved stylishly, while Alex Rae and Stefan Schwarz were off-target from long-range.

Then, with a superb strike, Nick Barmby adjusted the balance towards Everton, who had been restricted to a chance wastefully lifted over the bar by Moore.

Seven minutes from the interval, Barmby was given fractionally too much space outside the area and powered a first-time volley past Thomas Sorensen to add a little more credibility to his case for an England recall. Sunderland's earlier composure vanished in the wake of the equaliser and Rae marred an energetic midfield performance with an appalling miss in the 53rd minute after being sent clear by the vision and touch of Niall Quinn.

Gerrard's position in no-man's land should have made up Rae's mind to lob over the keeper; instead, the Scot lashed his shot yards wide.

A striker would surely have scored, but you couldn't be sure if the striker concerned was Mark Hughes. Goals from Everton's new signing have been a rarity in recent seasons and it was easy to see why in the 62nd minute.

An intelligent chip from John Collins left Hughes clear, but his fierce volley from 12 yards cleared the bar.

Reid, under fire from those fans, had more cause than anybody to be grateful to Phillips, whose claim for a place in England's Euro 2000 squad is surely unanswerable after this latest demonstrating of his finishing technique. Yet it couldn't have started better for Sunderland. With Everton still adapting to a formation that featured Joe Max Moore and Nick Barmby playing at the shoulder of Mark Hughes, Sunderland scored a goal that proved crucial to their morale. Nicky Summerbee was the scorer after three minutes with a 25-yard free-kick that eluded an unconvincing dive from keeper Paul Gerrard. The goal's value to Sunderland was immense. Reid had preached in the build-up about the importance of confidence and Summerbee's low shot was the ideal antidote to doubts raised by their decline in the past three months. It was particularly satisfying for Summerbee, starting for the first time in six games after a dressing room dispute with Reid and marking his return with his first goal of the season. He should score more. Indeed there should have been more first half goals for Sunderland, notably when Kevin Phillips went clear in the 23rd minute. Gerrard saved stylishly, while Alex Rae and Stefan Schwarz were off-target from long-range. Then, with a superb strike, Nick Barmby adjusted the balance towards Everton, who had been restricted to a chance wastefully lifted over the bar by Moore. Seven minutes from the interval, Barmby was given fractionally too much space outside the area and powered a first-time volley past Thomas Sorensen to add a little more credibility to his case for an England recall. Sunderland's earlier composure vanished in the wake of the equaliser and Rae marred an energetic midfield performance with an appalling miss in the 53rd minute after being sent clear by the vision and touch of Niall Quinn. Gerrard's position in no-man's land should have made up Rae's mind to lob over the keeper; instead, the Scot lashed his shot yards wide. A striker would surely have scored, but you couldn't be sure if the striker concerned was Mark Hughes. Goals from Everton's new signing have been a rarity in recent seasons and it was easy to see why in the 62nd minute. An intelligent chip from John Collins left Hughes clear, but his fierce volley from 12 yards cleared the bar.

fields.headline: Palace paralysis continues
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace 0 - 1 Charlton
fields.body:
Former Crystal Palace owner Ron Noades insisted yesterday that he will not allow the club to go out of business. Noades will have to put his money where his mouth is within the next four weeks because the Palace administrators fear that their fixture at Ipswich, on 25 April, could be the last in the club's history.

This latest performance was another testament to the character of Steve Coppell and his players as they matched the runaway First Division leaders kick for kick.

Charlton just deserved the win, secured through an 82nd-minute goal from substitute Paul Kitson, but they need not have been so greedy against their struggling neighbours. Charlton are going back to the Premiership next season with a £14 million transfer fund. Palace may not even exist then and Charlton's first win here in 65 years may also be their last.

As so often in the past, Palace's plight has brought out the best in their supporters, who continue to back the players and have raised around £1 million in an attempt to help keep the club afloat.

The Football Association will need to risk their 2006 World Cup bid by going to war with Fifa to solve the problem. Unless they can persuade the game's world governing body to solve the £5.5 million debt Palace owe to Juventus and Strasbourg, there will be no lifesaving takeover.

So Noades, the current owner-manager of Brentford who retained the ownership of Selhurst Park and the Palace training ground when he sold the club, holds the key.

'I have told the administrators that I will not let the club go into liquidation,' he said. 'That is why I cannot understand why they have not encouraged bids other than Jerry Lim's to come forward.

'Perhaps they are playing a tactical game to get the creditors to accept what is already on the table'.

Coppell said: 'The position is that Jerry Lim wants to buy the club, but we have this Juventus and Strasbourg problem. The Football League support us, but the FA will not because of the £5.5 million owing in transfer fees. Fifa say we have a moral obligation to pay and the FA are not prepared to go against them at the moment.

'The players and I are desperate to get to the end of the season. They are still owed £1 million in back wages and have been superb.

'But the extension of all this is that we will go out of business when the money runs out. The administrator told me this week that that day will come before the end of the season because he will have a legal obligation to go to the court and say it is not worth carrying on here any more.'

In the circumstances the result may have seemed relatively unimportant to the outside world, but the reason Selhurst Park was a rare sell-out yesterday had nothing to do with fans uniting and digging deep to help a club survive.

The pride of South London is at stake when Palace and Charlton meet, and both sets of supporters let their teams know this was a must-win occasion. It was something of a shame that the passion from the terraces seemed to float over the players at times.

A lame opening featured little more than a speculative long-range effort from Palace's on-loan Chelsea striker Mikael Forssell.

There was a low shot at the other end from John Robinson, and a strong run by Shaun Newton ended with a shot last seen heading towards the Sainsbury's car park.

Forssell did shoot the ball into the back of the net on the half-hour, but that effort was disallowed for an earlier push and the match was in danger of drifting towards half time on a wave of mediocrity.

Nine minutes before the break Robinson broke clear on the left and picked out Newton, unmarked and 10 yards from goal, but the midfielder stumbled and fluffed his shot, allowing Ashley Cole to make a goal-line clearance.

Then Palace sparked. Dean Austin went close with a header, Forssell narrowly missed with a bicycle kick and Hayden Mullins shot a couple of feet over the bar.

A half-time hailstorm was still driving down when the teams restarted on a now partially white and very slippery pitch, and Charlton began to exert some control. They should have taken the lead when Matthias Svensson headed down to present Andy Hunt with an open goal. But Hunt slipped and ended up with a muddy backside.

The home fans broke into another chorus of 'I'm Palace Till I Die'. An admirable sentiment, but there may not be a Palace before long. The more people sit back in the thought that it just can't end in tears, the more unlikely it will be that Palace will see out the season. They won't be the last club to fall in the current climate, but it will be a crying shame if Crystal Palace become Crystal Paralysis.

fields.headline: McGregor's Devon treble cream
fields.trailText: Torquay United 0 - 4 Plymouth Argyle
fields.body:
Emerging proud and unscathed from the hailstorms on the English Riviera, Plymouth Argyle were yesterday lunchtime unofficially crowned as the champions of Devon. More significantly, this biggest win over their rivals in 30 years leaves both teams with a chance of landing the bigger prize of a place in the Third Division play-offs.

A colossal 14,893 braved the rather more seasonably acceptable rain deluge on Boxing Day when these teams met at Home Park for an enthralling 2-2 draw. The Devonian neighbours again shared four goals yesterday, at the more restricted Plainmoor, but an opener from Plymouth-born Craig Taylor and a hat-trick from leading goal scorer Paul McGregor meant it was Plymouth loading the cream on their scones yesterday tea-time.

You'll remember Paul McGregor. Four seasons ago he scored against Lyon to take Forest through to the Uefa Cup quarter-final. After short stints with Carlisle and Preston, the 25-year-old wound up at Plymouth on a free last summer.

McGregor produced some classy and nonchalant finishing to bring Kevin Hodges' side the three points their great application warranted. Hodges will have allowed himself a glass of something celebratory last night. He held Plymouth's appearance record in his playing days, during which he appeared in their 1984 FA Cup semi-final - then he led Torquay to the Third Division play-off final two years ago before moving along the A38 to take charge at Argyle.

Plymouth, defeated only once in eight games, are a team of haircuts. It was one of their skin-headed brethren, Taylor, who nodded them into a 24th-minute lead from Jon Beswetherick's right-wing centre.

Beswetherick had a stormer. His 31st-minute service from the other flank was stabbed home by McGregor before the surreal hail torrent gave way to summer-like sunshine. The pitch was still pitted with puddles when, 19 minutes from time, after a great Plymouth move culminated in Beswetherick's dashing dribble from the left wing, McGregor slotted his second.

In the 78th minute, running free, he nutmegged the goalkeeper to complete his second hat-trick of the season. 'I didn't want to look too cocky but the keeper stood up and gave me no choice. I'm just so pleased that we produced such a good performance in such an important game.'

webTitle: Hoddle's day made by hapless Sutton

fields.headline: Hoddle's day made by hapless Sutton
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Southampton
fields.body:
Since returning to club football, Glenn Hoddle has not experienced the happiest of reunions with old friends. Mentor Arsène Wenger inflicted his first defeat before he was humbled at his old White Hart Lane temple with a seven-goal beating.

Returning to his old stamping ground at Stamford Bridge, he found Chelsea far more accommodating. They created enough chances to win this game several times over.

It was another name from Hoddle's past who threatened to make the first telling impact on the game. Chris Sutton, who had fallen out with the former England coach when he rejected the chance to prove himself in the international B team, was offered generous opportunities to release any lingering bitterness. He endured such a torrid time in front of goal you had to wonder whether he was suffering the consequences for past misdemeanours.

A moment of dazzling control and a deliciously enticing cross from Gianfranco Zola carved Sutton a magnificent chance. The attentions of a defender closing in was enough to ensure he missed the connection. Worse was to follow, this time from three yards out after Albert Ferrer had obliterated the Saints defence with the perfect cross. It begged for any kind of touch. Sutton tried a clever back flick but only ended up looking a little foolish.

He was not the only one to gasp in horror as the goal went a-gaping. Chelsea forced a series of chances, from Emerson Thome crashing a towering header on to the crossbar to Zola's cunning free kick charged impossibly away by Dean Richards on the line. The cool, upright defender, assisted by the composed presence of Morroccan international Tahar El Khalej, was proving a mighty barrier to breach.

Chelsea had changed over half the team which was conquered by Lazio last week. Vialli wanted fresh faces and fresh ideas to invigorate their fading league form. Energy wise, they played with more zest than recent Premiership stalemates but they could not really afford to be overly wasteful, as sprightly Southampton were always dangerous on the break. Lively interplay between Hassan Kachloul and the skipping feet of Marian Pahars gave Chelsea some uncomfortable moments.

This was not an opportune game for Ed de Goey to suffer from an attack of the butterfingers. Twice in the first half his fumbles were extraordinary. No visiting player, though, was close enough to profit.

Chelsea kept chipping away in the second half, and George Weah was the next to falter when 35,000 rose in expectation of a certain goal. From Dennis Wise's astute cross the Liberian, back after an eight-game absence, skewed narrowly wide from close range.

The more an increasingly dominant Chelsea spurned, the more dramatic the inevitable sucker punch. It all began when Sutton conceded possession, Kachloul's surging run down the left flank speared through the rearguard, Wayne Bridge helped the ball on to Jo Tessem, and the Norwegian let rip with a rifling shot from 20 yards.

Southampton were soon brought back crashing to earth, though. When Wise sent a hopeful chip into the box Richards, backpedalling to clear, could only loop the ball over his goalkeeper.

Chelsea came close to seizing the win through John Harley's outrageous lob 40 yards away and hugging the touchline. Jones scrambled back to tip over to safety, before foiling a glancing header from substitute Gus Poyet. This was not Chelsea's day. It was Hoddle's.

fields.headline: Division One round-up
fields.trailText: Goater's late boost for City
fields.body:
Manchester City's hopes of automatic promotion were revived in dramatic fashion when they came from behind to beat West Bromwich Albion 2-1. As if to emphasise their reputation for stretching the fans' nerves to breaking point, Shaun Goater scored the winner in the last minute.

City's determination to end their record of seven successive matches without a win was reflected in their first-half performance. They came particularly close to taking the lead in the 25th minute, when midfielder Jamie Pollock hit a 20-yard shot against the bar and Shaun Goater volleyed the rebound over. Mark Kennedy also hit the woodwork, and West Brom's keeper, Brian Jensen, brought off two outstanding saves from the Irish Republic international winger in the space of a minute.

City's agony was compounded early in the second half through a goal by Lee Hughes, but the mood turned to one of ecstasy when Kennedy equalised after 77 minutes - before Goater put maximum points in their pockets.

Ipswich also found it tough against Fulham, who spent much of the first period trapped in their own half. Fulham's goalkeeper, Maik Taylor, blamed by their manager, Paul Bracewell, for the goals which brought Blackburn their 2-2 draw at Craven Cottage the previous week, was the key figure in frustrating Ipswich. His best save was from a 25-yard shot by Jamie Clapham. But he was also lucky - notably when Ipswich defender Tony Mowbray had the goal at his mercy only to steer his header wide.

As with City, it was not until the last minute that Ipswich scored their winner, through their new Dutch loan signing Martijn Reuser.

The day's best scoring performance came from Portsmouth's Lee Bradbury. Recently overshadowed by his striking partner, Steve Claridge, Bradbury scored a hat-trick - his first goals since 3 January - to help Pompey demolish Swindon 4-1.

Similarly prominent was QPR's Chris Kiwomya, whose goals brought his side a 2-2 draw against Norwich after they had twice been behind.

While Stockport's creditable draw at Wolves brought them the distinction they least wanted - that of having gone a club record 16 successive matches without a win - their top scorer last season, Brett Angell, again showed why Preston have taken him on loan.

Angell has found it difficult to maintain the scoring form which brought him five goals in his first three matches for Preston. Nonetheless, his physical presence and experience did play a big part in their 1-0 win over Wrexham.

It seems strange that Angell has hardly been seen in Stockport's first team since Andy Kilner became manager last summer. But Angell says: 'I told him that if there was an opportunity for me to move to a bigger club, I did not want to be held back. From that moment, he made it plain that I did not feature in his plans.'

Angell, who had signed a contract tieing him to Stockport until next season, stresses he still wanted to play for the club.

'But I am still very ambitious,' he adds. 'The minute I stop wanting to better myself will be the minute I decide to retire.'

Angell admits he is still haunted by the memory of his lack of success at Everton and Sunderland: 'It bothers me that I am looked upon as a player who has only produced his best with smaller-type clubs.'

One of those clubs is Notts County, where he responded to his one-month loan signing earlier this season with five goals in six matches.

As for Preston, who have borrowed him for the rest of the season, he says: 'Though they are noted for knocking the ball around [according to Opta Index, they are the Second Division side who have made the most passes this season], they are very conscious of the need to get the ball in the box. The service I am getting is tremendous.

'Big things are happening here. In the First Division, I reckon Preston would be regularly getting crowds of 18,000-20,000, and that's partly what excites me.'

fields.headline: Classic duels long forgotten
fields.trailText: Liverpool 2 - 1 Newcastle United
fields.body:
Only a last-minute goal by substitute Jamie Redknapp saved Liverpool from another embarrassing home draw which would have raised doubts about their Champions League ambitions. Steven Gerrard, who made the first goal for Titi Camara, was rash enough to suggest beforehand that Liverpool were capable of overtaking Leeds for second position. Unless they get their act together in front of goal, they will be lucky to stay in third place.

This fixture has a reputation for goals, and the ball was in the back of the Newcastle net after 10 seconds, but Paul Durkin's whistle for a push on Steve Howey was heard well before David Thompson beat Shay Given. At the breathless rate Liverpool started, a real goal seemed imminent. Newcastle could barely get out of their half as Liverpool swarmed forward, and even without Michael Owen there were enough touches from Emile Heskey and Camara to keep the home crowd roaring encouragement.

Yet times have changed since these two sides used to trade goals in batches. Liverpool have stiffened their defence with the arrival of Sami Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz, and Newcastle under Bobby Robson are no longer the generous opponents of Kevin Keegan's time. But as the first half wore on, with hardly a shot for either goalkeeper to save, the realisation dawned that two once-formidable attacking sides are now sadly diminished.

Newcastle could be the more readily excused since they do not have anything to play for, and as the away side were content to let Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson go through their nuisance repertoire as isolated presences upfield. That is not the way Keegan would have advised his sides to play, though even he might have made an exception with an FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea in two weeks.

Liverpool's problems could probably be solved at a stroke by the return of Owen and Robbie Fowler, but the reality is they have to find a way of playing without those two, which is partly why they spent £11million on Heskey. The former Leicester player is still without a goal in four appearances, and does not possess the sort of confidence to cope easily with a prolonged wait. He was never exactly a goal machine at Filbert Street, but as the main prong of the Liverpool attack at present the number of chances falling his way is disappointing.

Heskey put in a couple of strong runs, but caused Newcastle most problems by taking the ball out wide and crossing well while under pressure. Three times he managed that in the first half and three times was left to wonder why he had bothered, since Liverpool do not possess a player remotely resembling a centre forward. The only time there was a red shirt in position to meet a Heskey centre it belonged to Thompson the smallest men on the pitch, who predictably failed to rise above Alain Goma.

Neither will it help Heskey if his junior partners keep upstaging him. Camara, only playing because of Owen's absence, swept in the first goal and created an opening four minutes later from which Gerrard should have made the game safe. Redknapp had only been on the pitch 12minutes when he scored with a header from a corner. Gerrard was the provider for the first goal, skipping past Goma on the right and sending over a cross which missed out Heskey but was met by Camara at the far post. When Newcastle sent too many bodies up in search of an equaliser shortly afterwards, Camara almost hit them on the break with a superb backheel pass to Gerrard, only for him to show too much of the ball to Given.

Hyypia also went close just past the hour, shooting narrowly over from a corner, but when Newcastle mounted a counter attack they claimed an equaliser with surprising ease. Aaron Hughes's cross was met by Shearer who rose between Henchoz and Dominic Matteo for a header which crept in by the left-hand post. Liverpool then made a mockery of their previous dominance by allowing Kieron Dyer to strike a post from Kevin Gallacher's cross, but just as the home fans were beginning to turn on their reluctant heroes, two substitutes effected a happy ending.

Duncan Ferguson has never lost to Liverpool before, but when Redknapp met Danny Murphy's corner there was no time left to argue.
fields.bodyText: Only a last-minute goal by substitute Jamie Redknapp saved Liverpool from another embarrassing home draw which would have raised doubts about their Champions League ambitions. Steven Gerrard, who made the first goal for Titi Camara, was rash enough to suggest beforehand that Liverpool were capable of overtaking Leeds for second position. Unless they get their act together in front of goal, they will be lucky to stay in third place. This fixture has a reputation for goals, and the ball was in the back of the Newcastle net after 10 seconds, but Paul Durkin's whistle for a push on Steve Howey was heard well before David Thompson beat Shay Given. At the breathless rate Liverpool started, a real goal seemed imminent. Newcastle could barely get out of their half as Liverpool swarmed forward, and even without Michael Owen there were enough touches from Emile Heskey and Camara to keep the home crowd roaring encouragement. Yet times have changed since these two sides used to trade goals in batches. Liverpool have stiffened their defence with the arrival of Sami Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz, and Newcastle under Bobby Robson are no longer the generous opponents of Kevin Keegan's time. But as the first half wore on, with hardly a shot for either goalkeeper to save, the realisation dawned that two once-formidable attacking sides are now sadly diminished. Newcastle could be the more readily excused since they do not have anything to play for, and as the away side were content to let Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson go through their nuisance repertoire as isolated presences upfield. That is not the way Keegan would have advised his sides to play, though even he might have made an exception with an FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea in two weeks. Liverpool's problems could probably be solved at a stroke by the return of Owen and Robbie Fowler, but the reality is they have to find a way of playing without those two, which is partly why they spent £11million on Heskey. The former Leicester player is still without a goal in four appearances, and does not possess the sort of confidence to cope easily with a prolonged wait. He was never exactly a goal machine at Filbert Street, but as the main prong of the Liverpool attack at present the number of chances falling his way is disappointing. Heskey put in a couple of strong runs, but caused Newcastle most problems by taking the ball out wide and crossing well while under pressure. Three times he managed that in the first half and three times was left to wonder why he had bothered, since Liverpool do not possess a player remotely resembling a centre forward. The only time there was a red shirt in position to meet a Heskey centre it belonged to Thompson the smallest men on the pitch, who predictably failed to rise above Alain Goma. fields.headline: Champions deliver
fields.trailText: Bradford 0 - 4 Manchester United
fields.body:
Three more effortless points for Manchester United, courtesy of a perfunctory performance that suggested chances of Sir Alex Ferguson's team relinquishing their Premiership title are as slim as Mrs David Beckham.

Having weathered an energetic opening from Bradford, and survived some poor handling and kicking from Mark Bosnich, two goals from Dwight Yorke before half-time removed any air of competition.

It appears that one of Leeds's best hopes of unseating the leaders currently lies with Trinidad and Tobago manager Ian Porterfield. The only minor inconvenience of the weekend for Ferguson lay in the fact that Yorke has rediscovered his ruthless form of last season just as he could be absented from Old Trafford for lengthy international duty.

Bradford, uninterested and completely outplayed in the 4-0 defeat at Coventry one week earlier, made an impressive start although their early momentum owed as much to uncertain handling from Bosnich as it did Paul Jewell's powers of inspiration.

Barely two minutes had gone when Peter Beagrie collected a short free-kick 30 yards from goal and produced an instant shot that United's inconsistent keeper appeared to have covered. But, in shades of the notorious Massimo Taibi error against Southampton that effectively cost the Italian his United career, the ball squirmed from Bosnich's grasp, fortunately rolling to safety instead of over his line.

The moment clearly unsettled Bosnich, a poor kick followed as Bradford enjoyed an unexpected glut of early pressure. Jamie Lawrence shot over from distance and more Bosnich uncertainty saw the keeper dawdle over a clearance and allowed Jorge Cadete, making his full City debut, to charge down his kick. Everything was most certainly not going according to United's plan.

But at this level of the game, spirit and enthusiasm - two qualities Bradford have generally possessed in abundance this season - can only get a team so far.

So it proved as United's width, the probing of David Beckham and Ryan Giggs down the respective flanks, began to stretch and test the home side to the full. They were not up to the task.

Roy Keane's pass sent Giggs down the left, his low cross being turned behind by Wayne Jacobs in a taste of things to come. Giggs only had the keeper to beat when played through by David Beckham but chipped wide and a Beckham corner, glanced on by Paul Scholes, was almost forced over the line by a Yorke header only for Matt Clarke to scramble it off his line.

The inevitable finally arrived in the 38th minute, the first of two - and what could have been three - United goals in two minutes courtesy of a wonderful demonstration of the art of finishing by Yorke.

Beckham's corner produced the opener, Yorke rising unopposed to head over the line from eight yards. Within seconds, the Trinidadian had struck the inside of the left-hand post after uncertainty in the home defence presented the ball at his feet just inside the Bradford area.

The second goal looked, at first glance, fortunate but there was an instinctiveness to Yorke's finish that almost defied belief. Beckham's dart into the area led to Giggs and Yorke playing a one-two, featuring a dummy by the striker that threw City's defence woefully off the scent. Finally, Yorke's off-balance chip looped agonisingly over Clarke and bounced over the line.

The only question was going to be by how many United would win. The answer, after Gary Neville's glancing header and Beckham's chip were well saved, was four.

Scholes' third was a fabulous strike from an even more fabulous piece of passing from Beckham, who saw his team-mate unmarked on the edge of the area at a left-wing corner - and delivered the perfect pass for Scholes to volley in first time.

Beckham, after playing a withdrawn role early on, arguably became the most significant contributor. The goal his efforts warranted came in the 79th minute when he wrong-footed Clarke from 15 yards after receiving Andy Cole's cross.

fields.headline: Carbone ups the ante
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 2 - 0 Derby County
fields.body:
John Gregory put the onus on his players by declaring that FA Cup semi-final places were at stake in this game and his Villa team responded with a comfortable victory.

There was a bonus for Gregory with the return of England striker Dion Dublin, who was given a run-out for the last 10 minutes. Relegation-threatened Derby had plenty of possession but none of Villa's cutting edge and their plight is looking more perilous.

Eight days before their FA Cup semi-final against Bolton at Wembley, Villa fans greeted the return of Dublin to the substitutes bench with warm applause. His return came just three months after he suffered a broken neck in a horrific incident against Sheffield Wednesday. The brave striker came into a squad much changed from the one that surrendered a 12-match unbeaten League record feebly at Southampton.

David James returned in goal after missing six games because of a thigh injury but J Lloyd Samuel, a 19-year-old central defender, made his first Premiership start in the continued absence of club skipper Gareth Southgate, sidelined with an Achilles tendon injury and rested for next Sunday's match..

Derby made one change from the team beaten by Liverpool, stiffening their midfield with Stefan Schnoor to the exclusion of Malcolm Christie up front. It meant that Georgiou Kinkladze operated just behind the lone striker Branko Strupar.

It was Strupar who had the first sight of goal, but he mis cued his volley from 20 yards.

Villa took time to piece together anything productive, Horacio Carbonari halting their first genuine raid as Joachim tried to profit from a link-up between Gareth Barry and Paul Merson.

A flying header from Julian Joachim that flew just over from Merson's corner signalled a brighter period for Villa which resulted in a goal by Benito Carbone five minutes before the interval.

Carbone has been the subject for unrest among supporters, annoyed that the club have yet to complete his £1million move from Sheffield Wednesday.

The player himself urged them not to make protests towards chairman Doug Ellis as the Italian believes contract talks can be finalised by the end of the season.

Here, there was no disguising Carbone's delight as he accepted a pass from Merson, manoeuvred space 22 yards out and then beat Derby goalkeeper Martin Poom with a shot into the bottom corner.

Two minutes later Merson almost added a second goal, but his shot hit the bar.

Stefano Eranio drove Derby's best second-half chance straight at James, and his miss was punished when Merson, out on the left touchline, delivered a peach of a cross with the outside of his right boot straight onto the head of George Boateng for the midfielder to net the second.

Two minutes later only a splendid one-handed save by Poom from Carbone prevented Villa going further ahead.

webTitle: France enchanted by the cup exploits of Calais

fields.headline: France enchanted by the cup exploits of Calais
fields.trailText: 'I dedicated our victory over Cannes to all the educators of the North. I dedicate this victory over Strasbourg to my parents. It's the most beautiful day of my life.'
fields.body:
Once again a football team have gripped France, although this time they are not the national side but Calais of the fourth division.

Eight days ago the Maritimes played Strasbourg of the first division in the quarter-finals of the French Cup. Calais were drawn at home, but because their ground was too small they had to play the game 65 miles away in Lens.

Two hundred and fifty buses took the Calais fans to the game. What happened is already a French legend. Strasbourg scored first but Calais won 2-1 after the sports social worker Christophe Hogard equalised on his twenty-fifth birthday, and Strasbourg's keeper joined in the spirit of things by letting a free-kick from shopworker Jocelyn Merlen drop through his hands.

'They have sauerkraut, but we have tripes!' a Calais supporter is said to have cheered. So a club that stands eighth in the fourth division, that only trains in the evenings, today finds itself in the draw for the semi-finals. No fourth-division side has ever progressed this far.

Of all the world's nations, the French are best equipped to ponder the meaning of such an event. Ladislas Lozano, the Calais coach, named after a Hungarian uncle killed in the Spanish civil war, fought back tears as he said: 'I dedicated our victory over Cannes to all the educators of the North. I dedicate this victory over Strasbourg to my parents. It's the most beautiful day of my life.'

He was only just warming up.

'We have written an immensely beautiful page in the history of amateur football. My players do not realise this and so much the better. The last thing I will do is tell them.'

The players did seem to have an inkling, however. Scorer Hogard said: 'I had 200 relatives and friends at the match. Words fail me.'

Fabrice Baron, a defender, added: 'The stands of this stadium resound like cathedrals. It was fabulous.'

And from Mickael Gerard, a striker who sells alcohol to English day-trippers in a local cash-and-carry: 'I carry a photo of my children in my tracksuit and look at it every half-time.'

Returning to Calais after the match the players were welcomed by a chorus of trumpets and thousands of people. To the local burghers, this cup run is something of a French version of The Full Monty . With heavy industry dying, about 20 per cent of them have no job, and in the neighbourhood around the Calais stadium the proportion rises to 40 per cent. Last season the club lost about £200,000.

The players, most of whom normally receive no pay at all, need this cup run. When they beat Cannes of the second division each man received a bonus of £2,000 pounds (which for some was equivalent to three months' salary) and now a couple of them are raking it in by selling club souvenirs.

Jean-Marie Pui-ssesseaux, the club president, says: 'If we are knocked out in the semi-final, we will earn at least £400,000. That allows us to see the future rosily.'

The nation is with them. The day after the Strasbourg game, Lozano was feted on national television, and then ate at Fouquet's, the legendary restaurant on the Champs d'Elysé, where the other diners paused from their labours to give him a standing ovation.

Gerard says: 'This is huge, but we do not plan to stop here. I have already said there will be 30,000 people from Calais in the Stade de France,and we are no longer very far away.'

Given that the other three semi-finalists are Bordeaux, Lyon and Monaco, it is probable that Calais are facing their last match (although, of course, everyone said that before they played Strasbourg). The one thing that is certain is that they will play the semi-final in Lens: in the French Cup, any team playing a side two divisions above them receive home advantage. Tens of thousands of their fellow citizens will be there, and perhaps even a few English alcohol-buying tourists.

Outside J.L. Carr's novel How Steeple Sinderby Wanderers Won The FA Cup , it is hard now to imagine such a cup run happening in England. The equivalent would be Dover Athletic reaching the FA Cup semi-finals. In fact, until a few years ago, Dover and Calais played an annual fixture that was pretty evenly matched.

But quite soon Dover might emulate Calais. To the big English clubs, the FA Cup has become a waste of time. Any team unlucky enough to win it must endure the embarrassment of playing in the Uefa Cup. So they will increasingly find excuses to drop out (tournament in Brazil, my aunt's sick, etc) or start fielding their under-14 teams.

The future could be Calais. Anyone wanting to watch them in action soon could go across for their tricky fourth-division away match at L'Hopital on Tuesday. Kick-off is at 5.30pm. Tickets are still available.

fields.headline: Profit and education don't mix
fields.standfirst: Britain should learn a lesson from the US, says  Gregory Palast
fields.trailText: Britain should learn a lesson from the US, says Gregory Palast
fields.body:
The daring escape of three very expensive headmasters from the schools to which they were confined, prompted a flummoxed Education Secretary David Blunkett to do what he does best at times of crisis: issue a press release announcing a new programme to expand the privatisation of state schools. This desperate wheeze was for so-called city academies, which will operate outside the control of local education authorities and free of the Government's own curriculum and employment controls.

Although Blunkett made no mention that for-profit operators would run the academies, the National Union of Teachers smelt a rat. But I smelt Benno Schmidt.

Dr Schmidt is president of New York-based Edison Schools, the biggest, hottest corporation hoping to cash in on calls from US Republicans for the privatisation of America's state-funded schools. It is bankrolled by Microsoft co-founder, Paul Allen.

Blunkett's description of the city academies sounded suspiciously close to a profile of Edison's controversial 'charter schools', so I called Edison's headquarters. The company confirmed that a few weeks ago, Edison hosted a delegation from Blunkett's Department for Education and Employment. And Schmidt himself told me that this was only one of several exploratory approaches he has made to the DfEE since New Labour came to power. (Once I mentioned the Edison connection to the DfEE, a spokesman would say only that it welcomed the firm's participation.)

A potential new market in Britain could be ideal for Edison, which is not going through the best of times. Despite the Microsoftian connection and the stock market fever over company flotations, an initial offering of Edison shares last November at $18 each saw the price crumple to $12, though it was up to around $20 last week.

Part of the reason for Edison's falling share price was an announcement by Nasdaq, the over-the-counter market, that Tesseract, once known as Educational Alternatives (EAI), would be de-listed for failing to meet Nasdaq's minimal tangible assets requirements. EAI was the pioneer of US schools privatisation, and Edison must have hoped that memories of it would be dead.

Before Blunkett turns his press releases into the bricks and mortar of new schools, he might want to check the reasons for the death of America's initial experience of schools privatisation.

EAI became a stock market sensation and neo-liberal icon in 1992 when its founder, copying machine salesman John Goole, schmoozed the city of Baltimore into turning over nine schools to his company. EAI promised that, using no more cash than the city would spend, it would improve the pupils' test results.

It did so. However, reporters at the Baltimore Sun exposed the test results as inflated. In truth, EAI students scored less well than a matched control group. The company was sacked before the end of its five-year contract.

But by then, EAI had already convinced the city of Hartford, Connecticut, to turn over the running of its entire school system to the company. (Hartford has roughly the size and demographics of the Islington school system, which the DfEE will this month place in the hands of a private consultancy.) In Connecticut, EAI promised building repairs, better test scores, cash savings and lots of school computers.

The scheme collapsed in little more than a year following allegations of financial impropriety and educational failure.

EAI's high-profile belly-flop appeared to kill off the privatisation of US schools. But the dream of educating for a profit lived on with Republican candidates and bankers hungry for a piece of the $350 billion US education market.

In 1995, in stepped Edison, announcing its takeover of two schools in Sherman, Texas. Today, Edison's sales pitch rests on a claim that it has raised pupils' test scores by '5 per cent'.

What do the experts say? Not much, because some are afraid to speak. The Observer has learnt that the one big independent study, by the respected American Institutes for Research, removed its analysis of the Edison schools in response to a perceived threat of legal action by the company.

The institutes' chief researcher on the project, Dr Rebecca Herman, confirmed the Edison material was excised from her report following a complaint by the company. Asked whether this decision was a response to threats of legal action, she said: 'I promised the lawyers I would not talk about that.'

The institutes' unpublished findings, you will not be surprised to learn, are less than glowing about Edison's performance. Company president Schmidt says he 'knows nothing' about the alleged strong-arming of the institutes. He told me that this body should not have dared to evaluate his company. 'Honest education researchers would say you need at least five years of data' to assess performance, and Edison has run only four schools for that long.

I wondered whether Schmidt was accusing his own company's researchers of dishonesty for selling school boards on its '5 per cent gain' reports. He downplayed the company's own claims of success but was 'very confident of the long-term outcomes'.

Dr Sam Stringfield of the Johns Hopkins University Center for the Social Organization of Schools is less sanguine about Edison's forcing the institutes to censor its report. 'It is ethically troubling when a group of educators won't allow scrutiny of its methods and falls back on courts' to stifle a review.

Schmidt says profit motivates his company to succeed. Profit also motivates Edison to find 'savings' that could, say some educationists, cost children dearly. In 1997, the US Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights heavily fined Edison for failing to provide legally required classroom help for a disabled child.

This month, facing its first contract's renewal, Edison withdrew from the schools at Sherman, Texas, rather than face banishment.

The city's school superintendent said that, while Edison promises to educate kids for the same cost per pupil as the public system, taxpayers ended up forking out an added $4 million to subsidise Edison's operation. Worse, the test scores of pupils in Edison's schools fell behind those of the others in the area.

'They were more about money than teaching,' said the official, Phillip Garrett.

Schmidt, however, says Garrett misread the data, and the company was happy to dump Sherman, having lost millions on the venture.
