The problem is that the privateer hangs itself with its own promise to provide better educational outcomes at no extra cost.

Underpinning the privatisation game is the nostrum that: 'You can't cure a school's problems by throwing money at it.' This diseased notion has floated over from America's rancid right, and an outbreak of educational 'free lunchism' has infected Islington, where Blunkett has forced the borough to turn over the direction of its schools to private consultants who have promised to radically improve schools without extra money.

And, in light of the crying need to obtain and retain better staff, it will pay higher salaries - to CEA consultants. 'I'm not ashamed to say money matters in hiring good staff,' said Foreman.

But this shameless truth, he added, does not apply to teachers. There will be no higher salaries to attract and retain good instructors. Blunkett would not permit that. Teachers will be motivated by the Torquemada system of educational reform.

When the failing George Orwell school in Islington was transformed into the failing Arts and Media school, all but six teachers were cast out by DfEE inquisitors. Under CEA's contract to operate Islington schools, the firm can receive a bonus of up to £600,000 a year if test scores improve.

Though he personally favours forming an Edison UK, and he is flattered by New Labour's ill-disguised infatuation with Edison's profit-motivated methods, his investors have reservations. Because Edison contracts to take no more money per pupil than governments spend, it refuses to operate in US states which notoriously underfund education, such as Louisiana (where, in Randy Newman's song, 'Our Boys go in Dumb, Come out Dumb too'). There's little room for profit in the UK, Schmidt notes, so long as Britain's annual spending of £2,000 per pupil remains 25 per cent below that of the poorest US swampland districts.

fields.headline: Natascha McElhone
fields.standfirst: Branagh's new leading lady
fields.trailText: Natascha McElhone has pulled off the impossible in her new film Love's Labour's Lost: she makes Kenneth Branagh look sexy. Okay, not that sexy. The Bard's best friend still wouldn't push Brad Pitt close in a swimsuit contest, but it's a start.
fields.body:
Natascha McElhone has pulled off the impossible in her new film Love's Labour's Lost: she makes Kenneth Branagh look sexy. Okay, not that sexy. The Bard's best friend still wouldn't push Brad Pitt close in a swimsuit contest, but it's a start.

In the exuberant Thirties-style musical, McElhone is one of the stand-out members of the ensemble cast. Tall and graceful, she deftly switches between the blank verse and singing standards such as 'They Can't Take That Away From Me'.

As Rosaline, she's a knowing flirt with flaming eyes, enjoying her verbal warfare with Branagh's Berowne - although most of the original dialogue was removed to make way for a host of familiar show tunes.

The film is a delightful throwback to an era when the Gershwin brothers, rather than the Gallaghers, shaped popular music, and a scene just wasn't complete without someone bursting into song and leaping into the air. McElhone is perfectly cast as the most glamorous figure in this elegant, colour co-ordinated world.

She is best known for playing Jim Carrey's lost love in the hugely successful The Truman Show. In contrast to the rigorous casting process young actresses usually face, director Peter Weir cast her after an informal audition in his hotel room. 'His assistant taped us both playing a scene and he called my agent the next day to say I'd got it.' It wasn't a career-making role. Apart from a few flashback scenes, McElhone spent most of her screen time watching and reacting to Truman's so-called life, but it worked wonders for her profile. She followed up her first major box-office success in Ronin, a monosyllabic action thriller co-starring Robert De Niro, Jean Reno, Sean Bean and Stellan Skarsgård. Her character, the mysterious contact for a band of hired guns, was one of the guys.

'The role was written for a woman, but it's funny because director John Frankenheimer said it could have been written for a man,' she said. 'She wasn't there to be a seductress, or ingratiating or just rescue some guy.'

The 28-year-old studied at the London Academy of Music and Drama and attentive Ab Fab fans may recall her screen debut guesting as Art Gallery Assistant in an episode called 'Death'. Her real break came after James Ivory spotted her performing open-air theatre in Regent's Park. A few months later, barely one year out of drama school, she was acting opposite Anthony Hopkins in Surviving Picasso, one of the forgotten links in the Merchant-Ivory heritage production line.

The IRA thriller The Devil's Own proved another mixed blessing. Despite starring with Harrison Ford and Brad Pitt, the film was an expensive flop. Ironically, her screen chemistry with Pitt, who plays her love interest, is negligible - Branagh is a better match. Pitt even attacked the film prior to release for its political naivety.

McElhone is a smart player, consistently winning roles alongside A-list leading men without yet making a Catherine Zeta Jones leap to OK! magazine stardom. She's expecting a baby in April, prompting a screen hiatus, but she'll return. For Ken's sake, let's hope so.

webTitle: Race hate in Britain is rife - just ask my wife

fields.headline: Race hate in Britain is rife - just ask my wife
fields.standfirst: British Olympic hopeful Ashia Hansen and her partner were in hiding last night after a vicious race attack. Richard Ellis, tells how his personal experience in a mixed-race marriage has convinced him that this country is 'foul, racist and deeply prejudiced'Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Am I shocked by what happened to Ashia Hansen and her boyfriend? Yes; it was an horrific, dreadful, despicable attack. Am I surprised? Not a bit.
fields.body:
Am I shocked by what happened to Ashia Hansen and her boyfriend? Yes; it was an horrific, dreadful, despicable attack. Am I surprised? Not a bit.

Liberal white Britons must face facts: despite smug boasts of 'aren't we a nice multicultural, all-get-on-together society', it just isn't so.

Stephen Lawrence's death was not a one off. Chris Cottter's stabbing and attempted scalping was not an isolated incident. Outside of small pockets, Britain is foul, racist and deeply prejudiced.

The evidence is overwhelming. For every high-profile racist attack, there are a hundred others - some reported, some not. For every physical attack, there are a thousand verbal assaults. And underpinning it all is an insidious, systematic racism that subtly and not so subtly discriminates against black people from cradle to grave.

As a white Briton married to a black Briton, I have seen at first hand what goes on everyday in homes, offices, schools and on the streets. We have been lucky, and avoided anything as horrendous as what happened to Ashia Hansen and Chris Cotter. We live in a nice, largely middle-class area of London.

Yet those incidents that have happened are enough to make me sometimes feel ashamed to be white. After I first introduced my wife to my family, one relative saw absolutely nothing wrong in telling a joke that involved a black man with 'big rubbery lips'. He still wonders why I haven't spoken to or seen him since.

Shortly after my son was born, our white au pair took him swimming to the local pool in south London. She fled home in tears after two white youths began shouting at her, calling her a 'nigger lover'. Out shopping at Marks & Spencer when my son was eighteen months old, he became fascinated, as kids of that age do, by the shiny rings of the middle-aged white woman standing in the queue behind us. As Joshua's little hands tried to grab the rings, she remarked: 'Starting young, isn't he?' I didn't know whether to cry or just simply tell her to get lost.

When my brother-in-law and his mixed race team went to play a football match in Kent, taking the then eight-year-old Josh for a day out, it descended into a running battle of racist abuse that left my son shaking and asking why white people disliked black people. It is an incident to which he still refers, and to which he still seeks answers.

Examples of ignorant, street behaviour? Perhaps. But in 20 years as a journalist, I came across newsrooms festooned with such ignorant, prejudiced minds. I remember one news conference at a supposedly liberal national paper, where the picture editor described the family of a white man in the news as being 'strange'. Why? Because they were black. When I complained, the editor laughed it away, saying: 'That's picture editors for you.'

A couple of months ago, a man rang our doorbell at 4am. My wife spoke to him through the door, where he tried (but failed) to gain entrance by spinning a story about having run out of cash for his electricity meter and needing our help. The next day, she rang to report the incident to the police. Having not seen the man, she was unable to provide a description.

'Did he sound black or white?' the policeman asked. 'That's an interesting question,' she replied. 'What do I sound like?' 'Well, you sound white,' the policeman replied. It was a week after the new commissioner of the Met had proclaimed the force as on the way to being 'a truly anti-racist police service'. What do they teach police officers on their much vaunted race awareness courses?

Outside the liberal middle-class minority in this country, racist jokes and remarks remain commonplace and accepted. In Asda the other month, a white shopper remonstrated with a black assistant, telling him to 'f---- off back to Africa.' No one bothered to intervene.

Yet at dinner parties in Hampstead, Notting Hill or Downing Street, among much of the British establishment and intelligentsia, all this could be happening in another country. For this white leader-class, black people are welcome dinner guests (so long of course as they fit into one of two expected groups: the erotic exotic black person or the complex radical black person; ordinary black people are, well, not quite black enough).

The conventional white wisdom is that racial issues have vastly improved from the Fifties, Sixties, Seventies; ergo things are fine. Then there are the types - including some of my relatives when they first met my wife - who pretend they 'don't see skin colour'. It would be laughable, were this myopia not almost as dangerous as the openly racist themselves.

What many of these liberals love to point to, of course, are other countries. Look at France and Jean-Marie Le Pen, they cry. Look at the US , with its divisions, discriminations and hatreds. Look at Germany, with its opposition to immigrants.

So how they loved to come across us after we had lived in South Africa, covering, as journalists, the end of apartheid. It must have been awful as a mixed-race couple, they would exclaim, waiting excitedly for us both to tell tales of horror at the hands of the Afrikaners. They would then retreat in disbelief when my wife told them life was actually more difficult for her and us in Britain. At least in South Africa you knew where you stood and people were more welcoming and less offensive than here in good ol' multicultural Britain. I was certainly made more welcome in Soweto than my wife would be in Eltham.

After 15 years in a mixed-marriage, this is the first time I have written about my personal experiences - despite being asked to many times. I do so now reluctantly, only to add my voice to others trying to shake up a complacent liberal intelligentsia and an establishment that parrots platitudes and accepts that things are generally fine. An establishment that mouths sorrow following the Lawrence case, then fails to implement half of the changes recommended in the Macpherson report. An establishment that cannot accept that it is as guilty as the foul-mouthed, Union Jack-clad yob on the street corner who stuffs BNP leaflets into letterboxes and beats up vulnerable black people for fun.

It's for these reasons and many others that my wife - and many other black people in this country - remain intensely angry and resentful. Why, even if they describe themselves as black Britons, they don't really feel part of this country.

Twenty-odd years ago, I went to Rock Against Racism concerts and marched in Anti-Nazi League demonstrations hoping for a better future. The future is now, and as my children grow older, I grow increasingly concerned about the prejudices and discrimination they still face solely on the basis of their skin colour. My son's experiences out on the streets of London are likely to be little different from his uncle's 20 years ago.

The statistics stink. The reality stinks.

My son - who is 12 in July - is more likely to be stopped, searched, arrested, sent to prison, than his 12-year-old white cousin. He's more likely to be attacked on the street because of his skin colour than his cousin. He's more likely to be regarded with suspicion when he walks into a shop. He's less likely to get a bank loan, more likely to be unemployed, less likely to get promotion should he get a job. The list is depressingly endless. How does that make me feel about my fellow white Britons?

So angry I can hardly articulate it; and so fed up with benign liberal platitudes every bit as ill-informed and ignorant as a BNP supporter that I feel physically sick. Whites have got to realise there are not a few bad apples out in society ruining their 'multicultural dream'. The bad apples are in a majority and the so-called multicultural dream is actually a nightmare.

 Richard Ellis is a former Africa correspondent of the Sunday Times.

webTitle: Long haul to be a qualified success

fields.headline: Long haul to be a qualified success
fields.trailText: Overseas, coaches are astonished by the fact that we have scores of unqualified coaches in this country, and that some of our best players are taught by people with no qualifications.
fields.body:
My first reaction to the news that the Football Association are planning to ensure that all coaches in this country must have proper qualifications was 'Why did it take us so long?'

I know that I have been going on about the subject in this column for a long time, but I still find it frightening that we have moved into a new Millennium before we took the step that will help us catch up with the rest of the world.

Whenever I go abroad and speak to foreign coaches and football people, they are astonished by the fact that we have scores of unqualified coaches in this country, and that some of our best players are taught by people with no qualifications.

You would not entrust your children's education to unqualified teachers or have an operation performed by an unqualified surgeon. Not that I think coaching is anything like so important, but it is still a skilled profession and to think that someone can become a good coach simply because they were decent players is laughable.

The other thing many foreign coaches ask is how we allowed the situation to get like this, and I would blame the clubs. There is an incredible culture of nepotism, jobs for the boys, where a manager or chairman will surround himself with the same people, however fit they are for the job. This really could not happen abroad, certainly not if the coaches were not fully qualified. We all saw the problems David Platt had in Italy last season when Sampdoria, whom he had played for, wanted him as coach. He was not allowed to become coach because he did not possess the Italian pro-licence, and was given another title and different role.

Of course there are some high profile foreign coaches working in England, not all of them qualified either, but there are relatively few English coaches working abroad. I am not sure if the new system will change that situation, because there are still other cultural differences on the continent. The pro-licences over there require the command of at least two languages, and let's face it, some of our players struggle to speak English properly!

Where I do think the introduction of a proper licensing system in England can make a big difference is in the number of black coaches moving into the higher levels of our game. I noticed that an initiative was launched last week to try to bring more black people into coaching in a wide range of sports.

Certainly in football the number of black coaches and managers is way out of proportion to the number of black players.

I am a member of the London Coaches Association, and our black coaches are constantly frustrated by their inability to move up the ladder into the top jobs.

Chris Ramsey, the former Brighton player, is a good coach but I know he found it difficult to get a job with a club and now he works as a regional director for the FA, who have given him his chance to progress.

There is no reason why there shouldn't be the same proportion of black coaches in a few years time as there are players now, and I'm sure that would make the game more exciting and perhaps more accessible for black people in general.

The new system should mean it will not be so easy to make the transition from player to coach. It will take four years to become a qualified coach, so most players will start when they are coming towards the end of their playing careers. Even then, I have to say that there are few really good coaches under 40 years of age since it is one of those jobs where experience is vital, and if you look at the best coaches and managers throughout England and Europe, they tend to be in their early fifties.

All the coaching ability in the world can be ineffective without good man-management, and although that aspect of the job is now included in the coaching syllabus, there is nothing like hands-on experience.

webTitle: Football acts to halt refs exodus

fields.headline: Football acts to halt refs exodus
fields.trailText: Restoring referees' authority and stemming the huge exodus of disillusioned officials are urgent priorities for the Football Foundation, a new body being launched next month to channel £50 million a year into the game's grassroots.
fields.body:
Referees who have quit the game in disgust at rising levels of abuse and intimidation will be promised extra cash and better behaviour by players in a new initiative to tempt them back. Football's rulers, shaken by the huge exodus of disillusioned officials, are planning a recruitment drive to find thousands of extra whistlers to stop matches being played without someone keeping order.

Restoring referees' authority has been identified as an urgent priority by the Football Foundation, a new body being launched next month to channel £50 million a year into the game's grassroots. It will provide money to 'top up' the meagre match fees - often as little as £15 and with no travel expenses - paid to referees. It will also fund training and education programmes to help match officials better discharge their responsibilities.

The Foundation's backers - the FA, Premier League, the Government and English sports council - believe tackling the growing shortage of referees is vital to their planned rejuvenation of football's lowest levels. An advertising campaign to 'sell' the idea of refereeing as important and honourable is planned to boost the profile of the men in the middle. 'We have to turn refereeing into what marketing people would call "a more attractive product",' explained a Foundation source.

Extending the FA's ongoing crackdown on misbehaviour in professional football down to pub, park and Sunday levels should make referees' lives easier too. 'The difficulty of finding a ref to take control of a match is the single biggest problem facing football's grassroots, apart from the poor quality of pitches.' The Football Foundation is a groundbreaking partnership between four organisations that often operate in a climate of mutual suspicion. Their alliance represents a belated recognition that, if the national sport is to prosper and England regain their long-lost standing worldwide, everyone with real influence must work together. Its launch, in mid-April, will kick-start an era of unprecedented investment in the unglamorous parts of the game rarely visited by Sky's cameras. The new body will plough millions into improving the chronic state of so many grass and artificial surfaces.

'If we're going to make kids want to get out of bed early on a Saturday morning to play football, and encourage participation generally, there must be changing rooms with locks on the doors, showers with hot and cold running water and pitches that aren't covered in dog mess. We'll pay for those to be built and looked after,' said one of the Foundation's creators.

The Premier League will donate five per cent of its deal with Sky to the Foundation. The Government will match pound-for-pound whatever sum the top flight puts in. The FA and Sport England will also contribute several million each. That should give a total pot of around £25m in the financial year starting on 6 April and perhaps £60m a year from 2001.

The Foundation will build on the work of the Football Trust which, since the 1989 Hillsborough disaster and Taylor Report, has channelled £300 million into an all-seat stadium revolution that has left British grounds the envy of the world. But as Trust chairman Tom Pendry MP writes in its latest annual report, it is time for new challenges. While the Foundation will still monitor ground safety, its other two decision-making panels - dealing with grassroots football and clubs' role in their local communities - reveal its real priorities. Mini-soccer, the hoped-for salvation of the English game; developing education centres at league clubs to encourage learning; women's football; and, crucially, giving youngsters the basic skills to ensure Joe Cole proves to be a trailblazer and not a one-off.

* Copies of the Trust's annual report are available free from 1 Waterhouse Square, 138-142 Holborn, London EC1N 2ST.

webTitle: News is still the big attraction

fields.headline: News is still the big attraction
fields.trailText: And so to nextminute.com - the Net sensation that hasn't quite happened yet. In a brief span of days, you've seen AOL buy out Bertelsmann, MSNBC try a little unbundling and the Chicago Tribune gobble Times Mirror at an $8 billion breakfast. Not to mention the market's culling of lastminute.com. Time to take five minutes to think.
fields.body:
And so to nextminute.com - the Net sensation that hasn't quite happened yet. In a brief span of days, you've seen AOL buy out Bertelsmann, MSNBC try a little unbundling and the Chicago Tribune gobble Times Mirror at an $8 billion breakfast. Not to mention the market's culling of lastminute.com. Time to take five minutes to think.

One word links most of the Net cavorting, and it is 'content'. Lastminute lacks it. AOL wants Bertelsmann's content clout, but not its junior partnership. Microsoft needs to let its successful, content-rich alliance with NBC breathe. And Chicago aspires to become the MSNBC (or CNN) of the future.

You can, in short, open all the portals you like; but you have to provide something on them to draw the punters and thus the advertisers. For news organisations this means great and commodious news coverage. The Chicago Tribune, with backing TV and radio stations, will be putting Los Angeles, the New York of Newsday, and Chicago itself on the web together.

These are the US's three great cities and represent potential critical mass for advertisers. It is also a step towards creating an America-wide network of locally focused sites, which is another key to advertising victory. But, most important of all, it is the first giant move by a newspaper company dripping in content to wrest the cyberspace initiative away from the broadcasters and service providers who have thus far made most of the running. This is a newspaper company's chance to dominate - and (attention Fleet Street) that involves mergers in the staid world of ink and paper.

Of course, the US and British markets are different in significant ways. The balance between national, regional and local papers is different; so is the regulated context of broadcasting. But the Net has a way of eroding differences. When there's talk, for instance, of Rupert Murdoch's TV news channels and papers (including his UK big four) signing a content provision deal with Yahoo, then the result could be as significant in Bristol, England as in Butte County, Idaho.

Suddenly the websites produced with greater or lesser fervour by British newspaper groups start to look isolated. The huge international groups now forming will want contractually to embrace their UK niche news competitors as content providers in the big shop windows.

A difficult offer to turn away. If you seek franchise revenue and enhanced advertising take, then you'll have to sell your news online to the highest bidders. They want your reporting staff and you need their cash. But, in so selling, you diminish the viability of your own core site. Can you resist and try something separate, Chicago-style? Only if there are news economies of scale which, inevitably again, points to mergers of companies, if not of titles.

The logic is plain enough. Whether skill in execution will follow it, though, is rather more problematic. If I were a fledgling investor in the great Chicago enterprise, for instance, I'd be a little uneasy. The Tribune website - despite massive investment and a dedicated staff of news gatherers - is neither particularly innovative nor interesting. 'Challenger ousts Kane County state's attorney.' 'Rivals knock down Illinois House incumbents.' There's no flair for electronic communication here in the clunky headlines and meat-and-potato news diet.

The challenge isn't simply piling regional news sites together and claiming triumph through weight of numbers. The art is in the editing and integration (which is what Yahoo, without Mr Murdoch's help, does so well).

That is precisely the point that one British news alliance can make to America because it, in positioning, is already where Chicago, and other scrabbling US groups like Knight-Ridder, want to be. Fish4 (touted on a poster site somewhere near you) is an oceanic platter of news and small ads supplied by 80 per cent of our regional press, acting and subscribing together. You can trawl through the labours of over 800 daily and weekly papers, seeking cars and homes and jobs.

It ought to be a winner, and perhaps it will be. But the vital main news index lacks focus before it spins off too randomly to feature tales from places such as Lincoln and Swindon, which have no intrinsic national interest - and the individual newspaper websites thus cross-referenced are still desperately patchy. You are invited to put in your postcode and see what's happening near you. I did that and can reveal that nothing has happened in my neighbourhood for six days.

There is something lugubrious about Fish4. It is much less than the sum of its parts. It makes you wonder whether our big regionals have quite got the point. The American newspaper rush to invest in the web has been by local papers desperate to get a lock on their cities and towns. In Britain, by contrast, putative national dalliances seem to have run ahead of local effort - and sometimes almost to have replaced it. Gonefishing.com?

fields.headline: Chancellor encourages greater staff ownership
fields.standfirst:
Isas and employee share schemes are singled out to help the nation save
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Two budget measures appear designed to stimulate savings by enhancing the attractions of existing schemes. The increase in the annual Isa investment limit to £7,000 for the next tax year postpones the expected drop to £5,000 per annum after 5 April.
fields.body:
Two budget measures appear designed to stimulate savings by enhancing the attractions of existing schemes. The increase in the annual Isa investment limit to £7,000 for the next tax year postpones the expected drop to £5,000 per annum after 5 April.

Meanwhile, changes to the capital gains tax rules turn many employee-shareholders' investments into 'business assets', making them eligible for more favourable tax treatment.

On the subject of Isas the fund management industry can do little else but applaud the Isa increase.

However, there has been no attempt to respond to urgent pleas for simplification of Isas. In particular, the confusing distinction between maxi and mini plans is thought to have caused problems for many investors.

Wolverhampton financial advisers Torquil Clark calculate that the extra £2,000 of savings - though raising the investment limit to £7,000 for a second year - could have earned investors an additional £4,391 if invested in the average UK All Companies sector fund over the last 10 years. 'The increased allowance is pleasing,' says managing director Don Clark.

But the industry is finding it hard to get very excited. Janine Starks, investment adviser with Bath intermediaries Chase de Vere, points out that with the joint Pep and Tessa allowances available before 6 April 1999 you could save a total of £54,000 tax-free over five years. This dropped by half to £27,000 over five years with Isas.

The extra £2000 for a further tax year brings this figure up to £29,000 - no more than a small gesture for those big investors who were saving up to the limit under the old regime, and neither here nor there to the rest of us who struggle to put away a couple of thousand pounds a year.

The solution, perhaps is for all of us to invest in our employer's shares. Employee share schemes allow staff to buy shares on advantageous terms.

The Budget changes operate in two ways:

1) They shorten the period over which capital gains tax taper relief is applied to business assets. Taper relief progressively reduces the percentage of assets chargeable for CGT, and currently operates over a ten-year period, so investors have to hold shares for at least ten years to get the maximum benefit.

2) The maximum holding period is now reduced. With the new rules, only 25 per cent of the asset will be taken into account after it has been held for four years.

The effect is to reduce the rate of CGT to 10 per cent after four years for the higher rate taxpayer.

They bring employee shareholdings within the category of business assets, which widens the advantage of the shorter taper period to many private investors. The new rules apply to any shareholding, however small, and to part-time as well as full-time employees.

The new rules appear to cover any type of scheme for share acquisition by employees, this includes Savings-related share option schemes (SAYE), Profit-sharing schemes (to be phased out in April 2002), the new All-employee share plans (announced in the November pre-Budget report), Company share option plans (aimed at executives, but used by some companies for all staff), and even the 'share shops' allowing easy purchase often with dealing costs covered.

fields.headline: Hard-working families credited
fields.standfirst:
Neasa Macerlean unravels WFTCs
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: If you claim Working Families Tax Credit for children under 16, you are one of the people Gordon Brown was thinking hardest about when he was finalising his Budget last week.
fields.body:
If you claim Working Families Tax Credit for children under 16, you are one of the people Gordon Brown was thinking hardest about when he was finalising his Budget last week.

Many of the changes were signalled to encourage 'hard-working families'. The biggest change in money terms was the rise in Child Tax Credits - one of the building blocks of WFTC - from £19.85 for children under-11 and £20.90 for those aged between 11 and 16, to £25.60 for children of all ages in October. The Child Poverty Action Group welcomes this - and some other boosts to the purses of parents.

Director Martin Barnes says: 'These are important increases - but we had been expecting a more radical Budget. Perhaps the Chancellor wanted to do more but the pressure to give more to health and education meant this was not quite the Budget many people were expecting.'

Another major problem with the new measures is that they are extremely confusing. Many potential claimants will not understand how much better off they will be if they go back into work.

Anyone unsure of their position should contact Gingerbread, a citizen's advice bureau or some other specialist adviser to work out a 'better off' calculation.

The Treasury will now be lobbied by the Daycare Trust and other charities to introduce more far-reaching reforms. The Daycare Trust this week calls for the principles of WFTC to be extended to students.

It is concerned about the lack of childcare provision for infants under three years of age, and is also calling for a relaxation of the tax rules that make it so hard for employers to subsidise nursery places.

The CPAG is calling for 'more financial support for pregnant women and very young children'.

It welcomes the increase in maternity grant for low-income mothers, from £200 to £300.

But Barnes says: 'It hasn't really tackled the inadequacy of money when a baby is born.'

Contact details:

Gingerbread: 0800 018 4318.

National Council for One-Parent Families: 0800 018 5026.

fields.headline: The finer China
fields.standfirst: Antony Barnett tours the pariah 'beautiful island', whose new pro-independence president has thrown it once more into the path of its all-powerful big brother
fields.trailText: Blind masseurs sit outside an ancient temple waiting patiently for customers. Screaming firecrackers explode as men in technicolour costumes dance over a fire on the way to thank Matsu, the Taoist Goddess of the Sea. A haze of incense fills the air.
fields.body:
Blind masseurs sit outside an ancient temple waiting patiently for customers. Screaming firecrackers explode as men in technicolour costumes dance over a fire on the way to thank Matsu, the Taoist Goddess of the Sea. A haze of incense fills the air.

Down Snake Alley, cobras' throats are slit and their blood offered as a drink to 'help you love long'. Outside a restaurant, a giant albino python is caressed by a young girl while a live chicken is offered as bait.

Further along, turtles have their heads wrenched off and then displayed, still wrig gling, on a plastic tray. The juices of the decapitated animal are supposed to prolong life - for humans, not turtles.

Across the road, a street vendor sells deep-fried bat on a skewer and nearby the latest hip-hop beats emerge from a trendy downtown bar where teenagers mix their red wine with Coca Cola. From everywhere mopeds buzz at you, mobile phones screech at you and wide Chinese smiles welcome you.

But this is not China. To be precise it's not the People's Republic of China. This is Taiwan, named Ilha Formosa, the beautiful island, by Portuguese explorers, but which now calls itself the Republic of China.

Alphabetically speaking, the difference between the two Chinas may be only seven letters and a possessive apostrophe but politically the gulf is enough potentially to spark World War Three.

Understanding the relationship between mainland China and Taiwan - which sits 100 miles off the south-east coast of the mainland - is key to grasping the attraction of Taiwan as a destination.

In 1949, the Communists under Mao Zedong wrested control of the Chinese mainland by overthrowing the nationalist Kuomintang (KMT) which was headed by the militarist nationalist Chiang Kai-shek. The KMT then fled to Taiwan, together with 1.5 million mainland Chinese, taking most of the merchant class with them as well as a flag and a constitution.

So began the bitter saga of 'two Chinas', with the KMT's Republic of China in Taiwan optimistically vowing to take mainland China back from the Communists as soon as possible. For their part the Communists have always insisted that Taiwan is merely a region of China and have promised to 'shed blood' if the island ever declares independence.

It is this tension which propelled last weekend's presidential elections in Taiwan on to the front pages, as the island's democratically elected new leader is pro-independence. What happens next is anyone's guess but most China experts see the bellicose rhetoric as just a bit of sabre-rattling that flies across the Taiwan Straits from time to time.

Most of the world's major countries are scared of offending China and losing access to it and so have no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan. The good news for travellers is that the Taiwanese crave any independent international recognition and so treat European visitors - who are few and far between - majestically.

The bad news is that Taiwan is no longer cheap. The mixture of the country's paranoia over China, its international isolation and its determination to be self-reliant has driven its people to create one of the world's most successful economies. They have turned the island from the home of the cheap plastic gadget into a silicon superpower. It is now a world leader in making computers and all the electronic bytes and bobs that go inside them.

It is this balance between a fast-growing hi-tech capitalist success story and traditional Chinese culture that makes the island a fascinating destination.

The mix is nowhere more apparent than in Taipei, Taiwan's dirty, sprawling capital which dominates life for the 21 million people that live on an island the size of the Netherlands. On the surface Taipei is ugly: it has not got the skyscrapers of Hong Kong or the slickness of Singapore. Yet it has a heartbeat of its own. And the greatest thing about Taiwan is you will rarely see another European tourist.

Snake Alley is just one of several night markets that bustle in the metropolis from around 8pm. Although it is the only one doing a line in cobra blood, the rest are equally captivating and sell everything from Chinese medicine to fake Gucci handbags and PC gizmos.

The latest craze lining the neon-laden streets is a kind of dance Karaoke machine where dance instructions, instead of song lyrics, are relayed on a screen. You get points for putting your foot on the correct coloured square at the right time. It means even the most uncoordinated have a good chance at mimicking a Spice Girl routine. These are real markets, where the Taiwanese shop and come out to play.

More highbrow culture comes in the form of the National Palace Museum, which has the largest collection of Chinese art and artefacts in the world. Most of the exhibits - including the Imperial Art treasures from Beijing's Forbidden City - were taken from China by the KMT when they fled. The Cultural Revolution on the mainland virtually destroyed China's cultural heritage, making Taiwan's impressive collection of paintings, porcelain and jade unique.

Best of all, though, are the titbits you learn about Chinese culture. For instance, bananas are a symbol of melancholy and used to be planted in a garden by a wife whose husband spent too much time in court. Binding a woman's feet was supposed to enhance the feminine sex drive as well as make them look prettier. And the Chinese started writing downwards because, before they invented paper for the world, they used to write on chopstick-like wooden strips.

I was lucky enough to visit Taiwan at the time of the Lantern Festival - the fifteenth and last day of the Chinese New Year. Tradition has it that spirits can be seen flitting through the skies and lanterns are used to spot them. Nowadays, the Lantern Festival brings the New Year season to a close and is the big day for children. Everywhere children are assembling plastic dragons lighted by battery-powered bulbs ready for a night of glowing festivity.

In Taipei, huge crowds congregate at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial - an enormous walled compound with a large garden at its centre and the National Concert Hall on one side and the National Theatre on the other. Both buildings are splendid examples of traditional Chinese architecture, and during the festival they put on a four-hour show of traditional drumming, dragon dancing and acrobatics.

At the far end of the square is the white-marble memorial hall which houses a colossal statue of Chiang Kai-shek, who died in 1975. This is guarded by soldiers wearing sparkling silver helmets who perform a slow-motion balletic march, swirling their rifles above their heads.

Also worth visiting in Taipei is the College of Performing Arts where students are chosen at the age of eight to learn roles in Chinese opera. Up every morning at five, they follow a rigorous 16-hour day of training. While the music might be painful for most Occidental ears, the acrobat school is truly amazing with young boys and girls performing tumbling, balancing and juggling acts that are hard to believe. One woman training for her role as a kung-fu fighter juggled spears on her feet and volleyed them back to colleagues in a way that made David Beckham look leaden-footed.

Travelling outside the capital is straightforward, with fast and reliable trains, buses and planes. In the south west of the island is the historic city of Tainan, the centre of traditional Taiwanese culture. It is famed for its 200 temples which are either Buddhist, Taoist or Confucian. The Cultural Revolution destroyed many temples in mainland China as well as persecuting worshippers, but there are 5,000 temples in Taiwan, most of which remain active places of worship.

Whole villages make yearly pilgrimages to some of the oldest monuments, such as the 1,000-year old Taoist temple in Lukang. Almost every hour a new procession reaches the gates and sets off a glorious explosion of firecrackers, music and dancing. Devotees burn incense and offer gifts, such as fake money or food, to the gods. In some they also take part in a kind of lucky dip, pulling out a wooden rod at random which tells their fortune. The one I chose told me a pleasant surprise would not be far away.

Sure enough, it wasn't long before the prophesy came true. The one thing I had not expected in Taiwan was the spectacular landscapes outside the cities. The island is on the western edge of the Pacific 'rim of fire' where tectonic shifts have created dramatic mountain ranges, rising directly out of the sea, down large parts of the east coast.

Tragically, the downside of the island's geology was seen last year when a violent earthquake hit the central region of the country, killing several hundred people.

Most of the mountain ranges are set in Taiwan's six national parks, the jewel being the breathtaking Taroko Gorge with its towering cliffs, glorious marble canyons, whitewater ravines, crashing waterfalls and hot springs. Pagodas and tea houses are perched on seemingly impossible peaks.

Hiking trails steer you through the spectacular monsoon rainforests peppered with the sound of tree frogs and monkeys. There are also aboriginal villages in the parks where small pockets of native tribespeople still live.

It is hard to envisage waves of British tourists flocking to these shores against the competition of Hong Kong, Singapore and the other China. But Taiwan's fiery cocktail of Chinese culture, technology, geopolitics and dramatic mountainous scenery means it is certainly worth popping in for a week if you're in the region. For me the trip brought a whole new meaning to the words 'made in Taiwan'.

Fact file

Antony Barnett flew with EVA Air (020 7380 8300) which operates three flights weekly from Heathrow. Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) has a return fare of £573 including taxes for travel by 13 June. He stayed at the Grand Hotel in Taipei (00 886 2 596 5565; fax 2 594 8243).

The next Lantern Festival is on 8 February 2001.

Taiwan's summer is May to September with temperatures between 27 C and 35 C.

The island is only 245 miles long, but has a population of around 21.5 million, making it one of the most densely populated areas in the world.

Visas are not required by UK passports holders.

For further information: Tourism Bureau hotline ( 00 886 2717 3737).

fields.headline: What a song and dance
fields.standfirst: Kenneth Branagh has made the Bard more accessible, with a helping hand from the masters of the Hollywood musical
fields.trailText: Kenneth Branagh has made the Bard more accessible, with a helping hand from the masters of the Hollywood musical
fields.body:
In 1929, United Artists released a film version of The Taming of the Shrew, starring Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford, which has long been regarded as boasting one of the worst credit lines in movie history. After mentioning the involvement of some obscure chap called William Shakespeare, it announced: 'With additional dialogue by Sam Taylor.'

In his latest film, Love's Labour's Lost, Kenneth Branagh does not go so far as to give a screenwriting credit to the movie's co-writers, but it's fair to say that they are rather more deserving of recognition than Mr Taylor. 'With additional dialogue by Irving Berlin, Cole Porter and Gershwin' does have a certain ring to it.

Resetting the romantic geometry of Love's Labour's Lost in the Oxbridge of the Thirties, and replacing sections of the ornate text with musical numbers like 'Cheek to Cheek' and 'I Get a Kick Out of You' is a classic Branagh gambit. Not only does it lay down an obvious challenge to those who regard Shakespeare's words as inviolable, but it also raises more complex questions about whether it is possible, in this more cynical age, to make a film musical that does not just give the nod to Hollywood's great all-singing all-dancing productions, but lovingly embraces them.

For his part, Branagh makes no excuses; the approach arose solely from the text. 'When I played Love's Labour's Lost in the theatre, it always reminded me of the silly, charming mood that you get with those old Hollywood musicals,' he says. 'And the text constantly refers to song and dance.' But, he says, the language of the play - one of the least performed Shakespeares - can be so dense that it excludes as many as it draws in. He concluded that lyricists like Porter and Ira Gershwin could give Will a helping hand. 'It was a strangely organic process of cutting the play first and then scanning the text for references,' Branagh says. 'I was always looking for songs that moved the plot on. You try to find the dramatic impulse.'

And so, when one amorous courtier describes how: 'When love speaks, the voice of all the gods make heaven drowsy with the harmony', his next words are the first lines from Irving Berlin's 'Cheek to Cheek': 'Heaven, I'm in heaven...' It could be desperately cheesy and many may still find it so, but those who hold an affection for Hollywood musicals will surely get the idea. You do not so much have to suspend your disbelief as chuck it away altogether.

If the film succeeds, it is because it makes not a single compromise. True, some of the actors, including Alicia Silverstone, Richard Briers and Branagh himself, are clearly rather less than accomplished musical performers, but their contributions are carefully tailored to their talents. In any case, there are more seasoned song and dance men like Nathan Lane and Adrian Lester on hand to deliver the goods.

There are top hats. There are tails. There are kick lines. There is even a rendition of 'No Business Like Showbusiness'. OK, it isn't exactly Metro Goldwyn Meyer and Arthur Freed, but it is more than just a casual stab at hommage.

The job of arranging the songs fell to Oscar-nominated composer Pat Doyle, who has worked with Branagh on all his other Shakespeare films.

'As a music student, I played piano in bars and I was required to play these songs,' he says. 'So I knew them very well. I also adore the work of Irving Berlin. What I was intrigued to see was how they would sit with Shakespeare. Eventually, I came to see them almost as arias, there to heighten the action.'

Initially, Branagh toyed with the idea of commissioning brand new songs in the style of Porter and Berlin. 'I'm glad that didn't happen,' Doyle says. 'That would have been a bit risky, a bit cheeky. It would have needed serious courage.'

Eventually, not only did they plump for a set of 10 cast-iron standards, but the lush arrangements were, if not exactly conventional, then at least true to the age in which they were first written and performed. 'Our first instinct was to be slightly restrained and use a smaller ensemble rather than a symphonic orchestra and that, by its nature, would have given a more contemporary feel to the music,' Doyle says. 'But then we realised it needed bigness to match the scale of the image. I think my job was to make the narrative accessible through the musical numbers and to put these songs on the plinth they deserve.'

Only one arrangement, 'Let's Face the Music and Dance', which is used in a mass courtship scene, veers away from the traditional into a more modern bump and grind of jungle drums and brass. 'It was always the drama that dictated what would go on in the music,' Doyle says. 'The moment we saw the choreography for "Let's Face the Music", we could see that was the way it had to go.'

As to the question over the continuing viability of the film musical, that, to all intents and purposes, remains unanswered. It is such an idiosyncratic work, such an original piece, that it tells us little or nothing about the genre. All that can be said is that, of all the Shakespeare movie adaptations set in Thirties Britain and using the songs of Gershwin and Porter, this is undoubtedly one of the best.

 Love's Labour's Lost opens on Friday

fields.headline: Snakes in the grass
fields.standfirst: Sinister though they seem in bud, fritillaries bring a subtle beauty to the spring garden
fields.trailText: Sinister though they seem in bud, fritillaries bring a subtle beauty to the spring garden
fields.body:
Fritillaries sound like nothing else on earth and now, damn her, I can never see one or hear it named without thinking of the bag lady of Finchley and Michael Palin. 'He's frit,' crowed 'Lady' Thatcher in one of her more lucid moments, aiming her remark at the much-maligned Neil Kinnock. I am still not sure if it was a result of her increasingly Gormenghastian dentistry that made her mispronounce 'He's fit!' (Whoar, you can see her thinking, I could fancy some of that. A bit far-fetched, I admit, but a delicious thought) or whether she was just thinking floral and the word fritillary burst unbidden to her lips only to be nipped in the bud. We shall probably never know, but that's the wonderful world of gardening for you, rich with imponderables.

And, if you are lucky, rich with fritillaries. Rich is the right word. The common snake's head fritillary, Fritillaria meleagris, is as opulent as a harem - chequered stained-glass petals hunkered over spangled light. No snake's head was ever so beautiful, although they do have a kind of sinister, reptilian quality, especially before they open out, the pointed flowerhead hooked over from the straight stem with its evenly and sparsely spaced leaves - hardly more than thin green grooves. Look at the chequered petals closely and you will see how they are a perfect combination of blocked precision and smudged expressionism - perfect because it is not predictable or measurable. Each flower head its own. I like their folk name of Sulky Ladies - it exactly catches their pouty appeal.

The bulb goes dormant after June until August when it grows new shoots that stop just below the surface and also go dormant in response to cooler night temperatures. As soon as the weather warms up in spring, they start to grow fast from this poised position so that they can flower and set seed before the grass gets growing. Man and flowers rubbing along fine.

Cowslips spread in the wild under an identical regime in dry, limestone meadows. But the lesson should be heeded for the garden. Snake's head are best planted in wet ground with gentle summer shade, although I saw a very happy little colony beneath a Kilmarnock willow in a garden whose soil seemed to be pure sand. Winter wet is the key and it is wonderful what a hosepipe can do to mimic rain. They should seed themselves and spread to establish a colony if, like the meadow grass, they do not have to compete as they establish. They can be planted as bulbs in August or in flower now. I bought and planted three dozen, including about 10 white-flowering ones, on 10 April last year, which was right at the end of their flowering period. They all seem to be coming up fine this year.

A new book by Rod Leeds, The Plantfinder's Guide to Early Bulbs (David & Charles, £19.99), is geared towards the keen bulb grower rather than the general gardener, and is generally heavy on botany and horticulture and light on inspirational anecdote, but has the following wonderful image: 'On a sunny day, the bulb frames [note the plural] containing fritillaries will draw queen wasps...which fertilise the plants...These insects seem to be the main pollinators of the early fritillaries...' What an amazing fact! What an added texture of opulence that adds to the plant!

Although they are the best known, snake's head fritillaries are by no means the only ones. There are more than a hundred different species of this member of the lily family. The only other one we grow is the crown imperial, F imperialis, which is quite another beast altogether, and is just coming into flower now. With a tuft of shiny green punk-leaf seemingly growing out of the middle of the circlet of hanging orange-yellow bell flowers, growing on a thick stem 1m high, it is as stridently in-your-face as the snake's head is shyly beautiful. It stinks of tomcat, too. In fact, the bulbs - great squashed things - smell almost poisonous in an acrid, chemical way. You plant the bulbs on their side, the pointed end horizontal to the ground. We have F imperialis 'Lutea' in pots, which has clear yellow flowers, and orange ones in the jewel garden. I like the look of 'Rubra' with its almost helleborean flowers. At the moment there are three in the spring garden where they are rather louche against all the rest of the seasonal subtlety. I think that this year I shall dig them up (always a good idea every three years or so anyway, to replant them with more organic material under them so that they flower with noticeably extra vigour) and put them into pots. They are really a specimen plant to be enjoyed as a freak show and then tucked away to bake over the summer and be repotted in the autumn. Thinking about it, all fritillaries look good in pots, just as increasingly I like all 'wild' or naturalised flowers in pots. Even if you only have a tiny space, this is a really good way to get touches of the water meadows, woods and hills into your back garden.

If you want to grow a muscular, bunched kind of fritillary rather than enjoying the delicacy of so many of the species, then I think that F camschatcensis is a much more handsome plant than the crown imperial. It comes from the other side of the world (the crown imperial is from Turkey, whereas F camschatcensis is from the Pacific Rim). It will grow best in damp shade (but not too shady) and in June has a deep purple, almost brown, cluster of flowers borne on a strong 18in stem. The bulbs are made up of dry scales, so are fragile to handle, but probably worth the trouble. I shall try it.

I like the look of F pyrenaica, which has yellow flowers washed over heavily with burgundy/purple. The edges of the petals are turned up, revealing a golden interior as the light streams through the thin flower walls, and that tiny detail is enough to replace all the languid menace of the snake's head with charm. It comes from the Pyrenees and therefore needs more sunlight than F meleagris, but is easy to grow and will form clumps. The only drawback seems to be that it does not come true from seed, the seedlings being rather paler than the parent. Does that matter? Perhaps.

F michailovskyi is another fritillary with the combination of purplish-brown outsides and bright yellow interiors bleeding out at the tips of the petals. Apparently, this was considered a rare and elusive bulb until recently, when new propagation techniques have made it as common as muck - and none the less attractive for that. It is best grown in troughs.

F orientalis is a good tone darker, without the bonnet-like flicked-up rims. I really like the look of them, although I am slightly perturbed by Bill Chudziak's caution in the excellent Bloom (Channel 4 books/Collins & Brown, £20): 'Fanatics might enjoy the challenge of... F orientalis, ' whereas Rod Leeds merely comments that 'this is a good garden plant that will thrive in semi-shaded positions in the open ground.' Perhaps he is a frit fanatic anyway.

Which brings me back to Michael Palin. How does he fit in the frits? Unfortunately for him, he is inextricably yoked to Lady T in my mind. I was at one of those terrible showbiz award lunches where Palin was given some kind of lifetime, awfully-good-chap award. Lady milk-snatcher was wheeled on to read the nominations and weirdly announced the winner to be 'Michael Par-lin', thereby spurring the mispronounced comic into a wonderfully funny acceptance speech entirely at Lady T's expense. Tears of joy ran down the audience's cheeks and, best of all, the old girl stood by his side throughout, oblivious to any part of the joke.

fields.headline: The Hurricane blows itself out
fields.standfirst: Norman Jewison's life of Rubin Carter should have been a knock-out. Sadly, it loses on points
fields.trailText: Philip French: Deeply sentimental and bursting with liberal platitudes... The principal means by which The Hurricane evades examining the idea of institutionalised racism and all its social implications is by turning Carter's story into a New Jersey version of Les Miserables
fields.body:
In 1967, Sydney Poitier was riding high. The first big black star in Hollywood, he appeared that year in three hit movies - In the Heat of the Night (which won Oscar for best film), Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? and To Sir With Love, in each playing a saintly black, morally and intellectually superior to the white folk around him.

It really seemed as if a radical transformation was taking place in the American public's attitude towards racial matters. However, that same year Mohammed Ali, the greatest boxer who ever lived, was publicly humiliated and stripped of his heavyweight title for refusing on grounds of conscience to be drafted for military service.

And even more appallingly, a less well-known prizefighter, the black middleweight Rubin 'Hurricane' Carter, was framed for the triple murder of three whites in a Paterson, New Jersey bar and given three consecutive life sentences.

Norman Jewison, whose reputation as a serious moviemaker still largely rests on In the Heat of the Night, has now tackled the story of Rubin Carter in The Hurricane. And, inevitably, he has cast in the central role Poitier's natural successor, Denzel Washington, an imposing actor whose career has been largely devoted to playing noble blacks, including a Christ-like Steve Biko in Cry Freedom, the eponymous hero of Malcolm X, and a benevolent angel in The Preacher's Wife.

Because Carter was eventually freed after 20 years in jail, the tale can be given a happy, upbeat ending and indeed the movie is presented as doubly inspirational through the parallel stories it tells.

It goes without saying that Carter's case is a compelling one that arouses a proper indignation in everyone who reads of it or hears of it through Bob Dylan's classic song 'Hurricane'. But the movie seems to me disappointing in almost every respect other than in its technical proficiency.

The Hurricane unfolds out of sequence in an elaborate series of flashbacks, covering events from Carter's first stretch in reform school for defending himself against a white, middle-class paedophile at the age of 10, up to his release from jail in 1985 at the age of 50.

But within the first 15 minutes, we hear of the bestselling memoir, The Sixteenth Round, that he wrote in 1974, which showed his spiritual transformation from hard man to philosopher. 'Writing is a weapon more powerful than any fist,' he says in the movie.

This has the effect of putting the transformed, mature, pacific Carter in the foreground almost from the start. But it's necessary to the screenwriter's strategy because it introduces the second strand of the narrative - the accidental discovery in 1981 of a secondhand copy of Carter's book by Lesra Martin (Vicellous Reon Shannon), a black teenager who has been rescued from the Brooklyn ghetto and is being reared in Toronto by a curious trio of white Canadian philanthropists (John Hannah, Deborah Kara Unger, Liev Schreiber).

Lesra's black consciousness and academic ambitions are raised by the book; he corresponds with Carter and becomes a surrogate son. Consequently, the lad's Canadian guardians devote themselves to re-investigating the case and freeing the boxer. How closely the film corresponds to the facts I don't know (though it omits the events of 1976 when Carter and the man convicted with him were released on bail for nine months before a second trial).

But The Hurricane is deeply sentimental and bursting with liberal platitudes. The three Canadians are a smug, superior, self-congratulatory bunch, forever swapping conspiratorial glances that acknowledge a shared sensitivity.

Can their fellow Canadian Norman Jewison really intend them as representatives of a superior culture coming from across the 49th Parallel to free the saintly Hurricane from the clutches of his American persecutors?

The movie, however, doesn't directly indict the American system. The horrors of prison life are alluded to but scarcely shown. After an initial protest, Carter is excused from work and from wearing prison clothes, and Clancy Brown, unforgettable as the sadistic chief warder in The Shawshank Redemption, has been deliberately cast as the sympathetic warder who befriends Hurricane.

Another piece of casting intended to evoke an earlier role is the cameo performance by Rod Steiger as the wise federal judge who frees Carter, ruling that his conviction was based on 'racism rather than reason, and concealment rather than disclosure'. We naturally recall that Steiger won an Oscar as the bigoted Southern sheriff converted to liberalism by Poitier in In the Heat of the Night and is given a line that all too easily could have fitted into this movie: 'Virgil, you're a credit to your race - I mean the human race.'

The principal means by which The Hurricane evades examining the idea of institutionalised racism and all its social implications is turning Carter's story into a New Jersey version of Les Misérables. From childhood onwards, Carter is the doomed Valjean to the vindictive Inspector Javert of Detective Vincent Della Pesca, an obviously fictitious New Jersey policeman who bears on his shoulders the whole weight of the criminal justice system's racism.

Played with a saturnine menace by Dan Hedaya, Della Pesca sees it as his mission to destroy the hapless Carter. He pursues him for 40 years, threatens the Canadian intruders when they revive the case, and is finally left scowling like a frustrated villain from Victorian melodrama as a courtroom packed with jubilant supporters cheer the vindicated Carter.

webTitle: Hugh joins Bridget's singletons on screen

fields.headline: Hugh joins Bridget's singletons on screen
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hugh Grant is to spend his summer filming in Notting Hill - again. And it is all due to the film project that is closest to the heart of many a single woman.
fields.body:
Hugh Grant is to spend his summer filming in Notting Hill - again. And it is all due to the film project that is closest to the heart of many a single woman.

Bridget Jones' Diary, based on the bestselling novel by Helen Fielding, is due to begin filming in London this summer and this weekend casting directors are finalising deals with its two leading male stars.

The film is being made by the team behind two of Britain's biggest cinematic hits, Notting Hill and Four Weddings and a Funeral.

It was confirmed last month that the Texan actress Renee Zellweger, star of Jerry Maguire, would play the role of Bridget, but until now question marks have hung over the romantic interest: who will play Daniel Cleaver, the cad, and Mark Darcy, the brooding and proud hero of the diaries?

This week the film's producers are expected to announce that Grant will take the part of the sexually persuasive, yet emotionally unsatisfactory, Daniel.

The actor worked with Jones co-screenwriter, Richard Curtis, on both Notting Hill and Four Weddings and a Funeral.

The part of Darcy has gone to the man who was in Fielding's mind when she first created her hero. Colin Firth, who played Darcy in the BBC adaptation of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, is to play the role in a pay-off to Fielding's in-joke.

The film will be shot around Notting Hill and is not to be Americanised in any way, according to producers Working Title. The loss of Jones's trademark phraseology, for instance, 'fuckwittage' and 'v.g', would have dulled her distinctive voice.

webTitle: It's RIP basic human rights in 'worst UK legislation ever' looms

fields.headline: It's RIP basic human rights in 'worst UK legislation ever' looms
fields.standfirst: Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: To LSE for a conference on the Interior Ministry's Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill, currently in Committee in the Mother of Parliaments. Readers of this column will know that, among other things, this odious piece of legislation reverses the ancient principle of natural justice that says that a person should be pre sumed innocent until proven guilty.
fields.body:
To LSE for a conference on the Interior Ministry's Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill, currently in Committee in the Mother of Parliaments. Readers of this column will know that, among other things, this odious piece of legislation reverses the ancient principle of natural justice that says that a person should be pre sumed innocent until proven guilty.

Specifically, the bill stipulates that if a message or device traced to you contains encrypted data, you can be required by a statutory order to hand over the key needed to decrypt that data. If you have lost or forgotten that key, you will be presumed to be guilty of an offence and required to prove to a court that you have indeed lost or forgotten it. If convicted, you will go down for two years.

This, of course, raises the question: how do you prove that you have forgotten something? When taxed with this, Charles Clarke, the junior minister charged with shepherding this attack on liberty through the Commons, repeated the official mantra. 'The Bill,' quoth he, 'creates a defence for an individual who has forgotten or mislaid a key or password. It is true that he or she must prove the defence, but they need to do that only on the balance of probabilities.'

Ah, that magic phrase, 'balance of probabilities'. And how, pray, is that to be assessed? By the use of lie-detectors in British courts? Clarke was repeatedly pressed on this at the conference, but declined to be drawn. Instead he intoned the 'balance of probabilities' mantra like a speak-your- weight machine on valium.

In the circumstances, there seemed little point in drawing his attention to a celebrated judgment in Canada's Supreme Court that held: 'If an accused is required to prove some fact on the balance of probabilities to avoid conviction, the provision violates the presumption of innocence because it permits a conviction in spite of a reasonable doubt in the mind of the trier of fact as to the guilt of the accused' (Reg v Whyte (1988) 51 DLR (4th) 481).

Clarke belongs to a government which claims that it wants to make the UK the best place in the world for e-commerce. It was interesting then to hear a question from a chap who works for AT&T and is responsible for the security and integrity of the networks of several large banks and financial institutions. He holds lots of decryption keys as a result of that responsibility, and has a contractual obligation to his clients to protect their secrets.

Under the terms of the RIP Bill, he can be required to disclose those keys to a duly authorised goon - but he is also legally forbidden to reveal to his clients that their secrecy has thereby been compromised. As he spoke, you could see Clarke opening and shutting his mouth like a stunned carp. The only sound to be heard was the noise of online banks stampeding to leave the country.

With the exception of the original Official Secrets Act, rushed through in a single afternoon in 1911, the RIP Bill is probably the worst piece of legislation ever laid before Parliament. It proposes to give the Interior Minister the kinds of powers Robert Mugabe can only fantasise about. (In fact it was claimed at the conference that the only other country in the world proposing legislation like this is Zimbabwe.)

The Bill proposes the violation of what any civilised society would regard as elementary human rights (presumption of innocence, the right to a fair trial, protection of privacy and freedom from random surveillance, to name just four). It does so under the breathtaking assertion that these abuses are necessary to bring the UK in line with the European Convention on Human Rights. And it will be law by October.

Readers of this column will know that, among other things, this odious piece of legislation reverses the ancient principle of natural justice that says that a person should be pre sumed innocent until proven guilty. fields.headline: Morris Karloff
fields.standfirst: Chris Morris is back in the medium that best suits him, plying his trade in a place far beyond satire.
fields.trailText: Chris Morris is back in the medium that best suits him, plying his trade in a place far beyond satire.
fields.body:
Seeing Red ITV
Puppy Love C4
Love and Money C4
Jam C4

According to a particularly Auntie-ish BBC2 voiceover, Budget Day is the only time alcohol is allowed inside the Commons (and since an Act of Parliament in 1670, on Budget Day a rare breed of wonk-faced sheep is, probably, also entitled to ruminate in the public gallery), but I'd barely had time to get my head around this bit of arcane nonsense when here was David Dimbleby pithily summing up a bit of perceived governmental Robin Hoodery:

'Have loads of kids and don't worry about getting married!' 'But,' chipped in A. Fiscal-Pundit Esq, 'only if you're on a low income!' Which showed just how far Coral Atkins was ahead of her time.

Last Sunday's Seeing Red told the truish story of Ms Atkins, the 1970s TV star-turned-hopelessly romantic, idealistic owner of a touchy-feely free-range children's home. Coral's truth was strange enough but after being filleted and filtered as drama, the result was inevitably a Sunday night smile-and-sob story, told with several spoonfuls of saccharine to help the unpalatable realism go down.

But whatever you thought of the screenplay - the baddies all cardboard cut-out villainry, the goodies all bleeding heartiness - this was Sarah Lancashire's big moment or, more accurately, the latest in this year's line of increasingly impressive Sarah Lancashire moments.

Right after a taut double-handed Coronation Street opposite estranged TV husband Curly Watts in early January, she was on to Clocking Off, during which one could never not watch her, even when she was just passing through another character's plotline. But now I think Lancashire has proved herself the best British actress of her generation, bar none.

In his film, Puppy Love, Waldemar Januszczak identified what he described as our 'cruel ambivalence about the dog'. Examples? Um, describing people as 'a dog' or 'a bitch', apparently. Silly Waldemar - these aren't examples of humankind's cruel ambivalence to canines, but ongoing proof of mankind's cruel ambivalence towards women. Well, I've never heard of a man being described as 'a dog', even on his very worst comb-over hair day. Admittedly, I write as a pathetically biased dog owner, but Januszczak's tirade was an intolerant hatefest, littered with numerous other clunking misobservations and boasting a subtext of ill-disguised misogyny, none of which, I hasten to add, stopped it from being immensely watchable.

Unfortunately, however, Januszczak couldn't quite contain himself from making a few reasonable and pertinent points along the way, particularly about the kind of in-breeding that has ensured bulldogs are now so freakily deformed they practically breathe out of their eyes: 'If the Nazis were doing this to people, we'd be calling it eugenics, but when the British do it to their dogs, it's just a bit of fun and out come the marquees.'

It may be that I'm over-sensitive, but it struck me that throughout Puppy Love a certain sort of female dog-owner cliché - perhaps childless, certainly frustrated in love, desperately sentimental but unconsciously manipulative - had at some point left her sweaty pawprints all over Januszczak's soft furnishings, because he seemed both downright terrified and riddled with loathing for women he identified as inured to the needs of dogs, while exercising the control that they might well have been forced to relinquish in other areas of their lives.

Still, what of it, Waldemar? Not exactly Nazis,are they? Personally, I have no qualms about admitting that I gave a recidivist Battersea dog a comfortable, permanent home, two square meals a day, lots of nice walks and, in return, expected (and received) unconditional doggy love, replete with unwaveringly devoted gazing into my eyes and round-the-clock snoozing while curled like a warm, soft comma at my feet. And if anyone thinks that this marks me out as a needy, barren old sad-sack, then so be it.

I don't know if he is or has ever been a dog owner, but I suspect that George, star of the first in a predictably prurient new documentary series called Love and Money, husband of Karen, father of Bertie and all-round cartoonishly hilarious sexist pigface of the very first order, might enjoy the company of, if not wolves, then perhaps a Staffordshire terrier ('Such big testicles!' the nice Aussie vet had observed admiringly of the breed during Puppy Love, just before he'd chopped them off).

But then I decided that George and Karen had been sent to try me in what was fast turning out to be National Misogyny Week. Love and Money looked at the problems that beset a Double-Income-No-Kids couple when they decide to breed and thus lose one salary, at least for a while.

In fact, it was a statistic from Relate that had inspired the programme: according to a 1998 survey, British couples argue more about money than any other subject. George must have known he was presenting himself as a sullen, spud-faced bastard for whom greed is good but women are no better than they ought to be. 'I make the decisions round here because I earn the money'; 'You got the vote; what more do you want?'; and of his decision not to allow Karen to be signatory on their joint bank account: 'I didn't want her to get her grubby little hands on it. Spend it on shoes and cigarettes and women's fripperies.' George was fortyish. This was satire, right?

The first in his new series, Jam, saw Chris Morris plying his compulsively dark and unlovely trade in a place somewhere just beyond satire, though it's too early to say precisely where that might be, because Jam was much closer to Morris's defunct Radio One show, Blue Jam, than to either The Day Today or Brass Eye and, indeed, only the sketch featuring the woman miming Minnie Riperton's 'Loving You' while being beaten with a Spacehopper was giggle-making; the rest was merely madly - and maddeningly - compelling.

For when he isn't making you laugh, Morris is capable of bringing out the latent Angry of Media Vale inside almost any reasonably well-balanced viewer.

For me, the most haunting and disturbing sketches (though it's not quite the right term for a writer and performer whose 'sketches' are more Francis Bacon than they are Morecambe and Wise) were those that recalled the dread quasi-dreamscape and loss of control that often comes with impending anaesthesia. Morris is usually described as surreal but Jam is, in its own way, very far from surreal - more like a persuasively warped commentary on a thoroughly bad-to-the-bone and threatening world we perceive to be slipping swiftly and scarily from our individual grasp.

Anyway, I'm glad Morris is back and producing true millennial terror TV, brilliantly abusing the medium he knows best, especially given that he proved himself a disappointingly unfunny spoof newspaper columnist. So much suppurating rage, Chris - perhaps you need a dog?
