fields.headline: Visions of Johanna
fields.standfirst:
Behind the dynasty that is BMW lies a matriarchal figure, her two children and an intense belief in the worth of the marque
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: At 72, Johanna Quandt still goes to her office every day in the little town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt and works there until late each evening before returning to the fortified villa where she lives alone. Although she is one of the richest women in the world, with a family fortune estimated at £14 billion, she always flies economy class and the only luxury she allows herself is the large BMW she drives.
fields.body:
At 72, Johanna Quandt still goes to her office every day in the little town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt and works there until late each evening before returning to the fortified villa where she lives alone. Although she is one of the richest women in the world, with a family fortune estimated at £14 billion, she always flies economy class and the only luxury she allows herself is the large BMW she drives.

Frau Quandt's daily routine is made more agreeable by the fact that her daughter Susanne, 37, and son Stefan, 33, work in the same building and the family gets together frequently for modest meals and quiet chats. Last week, these gatherings were almost certainly dominated by the fall-out over the sale of Rover by BMW, a company in which the Quandt family owns almost half the shares.

'The family was upset by the press reaction, particularly because so many of the claims made were untrue. We are taking legal action over some of these assertions,' the family's spokesman, Thomas Gauly, told me last week. The Quandts have never given an interview to the media ('Why should they?' asks Gauly) and they have seldom been photographed.

But British anger over BMW's handling of the Rover sale has dragged this publicity-shy family into the limelight and allowed them to be portrayed as heartless plutocrats who are unmoved by the fate of thousands of British car workers.

Some newspapers have even used Frau Quandt's relationship through marriage to the family of Hitler's propaganda minister, Joseph Goebbels, to imply that the family has a secret Nazi past, a slur that chimes neatly with popular British prejudice about the Germans.

'As prominent people, the Quandts have to put up with media attention, however unpleasant. But they remain well disposed towards Britain and the British,' Gauly insists. The row over Rover is likely to blow over soon enough and Trade Secretary Stephen Byers was eager to patch up relations with BMW when he visited their headquarters in Munich on Thursday. But the Bavarian carmakers' disastrous British venture, which has cost the company more than £5bn, has raised questions about the future of BMW itself as an independent company.

The Quandts insist that they have no intention of selling their stake in BMW and Gauly strenuously denies that the family has been engaged in secret negotiations with Ford about the sale of the company.

'If they were to sell it, what should they do with the money? The Quandts are not venture capitalists. They don't know anything about Internet businesses. What they know about is the motor industry,' he said.

The motor industry has certainly been good to the Quandts and the family's stake in BMW is now worth 10 times what it was in 1982 when Johanna's husband, Herbert, died. Herbert was born in 1910 into a long-established industrial family and his father, Gunther, was one of Hitler's chief economic advisors. Gunther's second wife, Magda Friedlaender, later married Goebbels and the young Herbert spent part of his youth at the propaganda minister's home. By the time war broke out, however, Herbert was already an adult and was no longer in close contact with Goebbels, who poisoned himself, his wife and their six children in Hitler's bunker in 1945.

Much of the Quandt family business was in ruins after the war and a great part of what survived had been commandeered by the invading Soviet forces. The task of rebuilding its fortunes fell mainly to Herbert, who proved to be a highly effective businessman, saving BMW from bankruptcy in 1959 by increasing his stake in the company and unflinchingly selling the family stake in Daimler-Benz when he judged the time to be right. This sale set off a tradition of rivalry between BMW and Daimler that has continued to this day and may have contributed to the Bavarian company's present crisis.

Johanna, who had been Herbert's secretary, became his third wife in 1960 and inherited most of his fortune, including his entire stake in BMW, on his death in 1982. Johanna was determined from the start that her two children should have as normal an upbringing as possible and when Susanne went to work at BMW, she took a job in the canteen.

Johanna and Susanne made the news briefly and unwillingly in 1978 when a last-minute police intervention foiled an attempt to kidnap them. A 14-strong gang led by convicts on day release from the local prison had intended to snatch the two Quandts from their home in broad daylight and demand an £8 million ransom.

This experience may explain the Quandts' extreme aversion to publicity, and both Susanne and Stefan are accompanied by bodyguards at all times. According to one guest at their parties, the younger Quandts are socially reserved to an unusual degree. 'The bodyguards are always very much in evidence but what struck me as unusual is that, even when they are the hosts, the Quandts seldom circulate among guests. They just sit at their table, talking quietly among themselves while others enjoy their hospitality,' he said.

BMW declines to give details of the extent of the family's involvement in business decisions but Susanne and Stefan sit on the advisory board and Johanna is known to have approved the decision to buy Rover in 1994. Gauly insisted last week that all negotiations surrounding the sale of Rover to the venture capital firm, Alchemy, were handled by BMW's chief executive, Professor Joachim Milberg.

But Alchemy's boss, Jon Moulton, appeared to cast doubt on that story earlier in the week. 'The idea to buy Rover came in the autumn from Tom Sommerlatte,' he said. Mr Sommerlatte is vice-president of the management consultants, Arthur D. Little, in Wiesbaden and a member of the Alchemy board. He is also reported to have close links with the Quandt family.

The Quandts have remained scrupulously loyal to Milberg during the past few days and Gauly told me that he expects the chief executive will still be in his post a year from now. But BMW's British adventure is being seen in German business circles as the worst case of mismanagement since Edzard Reuter's doomed attempt to turn Daimler-Benz into a technology conglomerate.

The company most analysts believe is best placed to buy BMW is Ford, which last week snapped up Land-Rover for its luxury division, which already owns Jaguar, Volvo, Aston Martin and Lincoln. In a bitter irony for the Bavarians, this Ford division is led by Wolfgang Reitzle, a former BMW manager who left the company last year when he was passed over for the top job in favour of Milberg.

Six years ago, Reitzle warned his colleagues that their British adventure would end in tears and predicted that Rover would cost BMW DM13 billion by 2000. His prediction, which was dismissed at the time as an absurd prophecy of doom, was inaccurate. Rover has cost BMW an estimated DM16bn.

Instead of buying Rover, Reitzle wanted to develop a middle-of-the-range BMW 2 series, along the lines of the A Class developed by the Bavarians' rivals in Daimler-Benz (now Daimler-Chrysler). But his fellow managers argued that introducing a more downmarket model would damage the BMW brand and that the best way to expand BMW's range would be to acquire other marques. The Quandts were believed to be uneasy about acquiring Rover but they went along with the strategy of Berndt Pitschetsrieder, Milberg's predecessor, for almost six years.

It was only when Rover's losses threatened to damage BMW's core business that the family decided that Pitschetsrieder had to go. Reitzle expected to take over as chairman last year but his appointment was blocked by trade union representatives on BMW's board, who made it clear that they would not co-operate with his plans. Milberg was chosen as a safe pair of hands but, at 61, he was widely viewed as a transitional figure whose primary task was to make Rover profitable or gracefully get rid of it.

Gauly insisted last week that Milberg had performed the task he was given by withdrawing from Rover when it became clear that the company could not be turned around. But the cost has been enormous. The Rover 75, universally acknowledged as one of the best new cars to be produced in recent years, has turned out to be a commercial flop. The manufacturers blame the strength of the pound against the euro for the Rover 75's failure but the truth is that it has performed badly in Britain as well.

Despite the exchange rate, Rover continued to buy 85 per cent of its components from British suppliers until last year - missing out on an estimated saving of DM2bn. By the beginning of this year, even Land-Rover was losing money and everyone at BMW realised that the condition of the English Patient - as Rover is known in Munich - had become critical.

This did not stop the company from issuing a sharp denial of a report last month that the BMW board was considering selling Rover. At the beginning of this month, BMW executives attending a motor show in Geneva were repeating the same, confident lines about Rover's future. One German magazine was reminded of the uplifting speeches delivered by East Germany's leaders on the fortieth anniversary of their state's foundation, a few weeks before the Berlin Wall fell in 1989.

Speculation about the Quandts' intentions towards BMW focuses on Susanne and Stefan, both of whom went to business school in the United States and are less steeped in the German corporate tradition than is their mother. Gauly denies that the younger family members, both of whom run businesses outside the motor sector, are driven, like most British and American investors, by shareholder value.

'Their ideas are closer to the stakeholder concept, whereby the value of a company is not only measured by the index but also by, for example, the question of how a company deals with its employees or how much social responsibility it undertakes,' he said. Gauly claims that the Quandts are not politically-minded but Johanna has long been friendly with the former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and the family contributed almost £1 million to Germany's conservative parties in the run up to the general election in 1998.

When Gerhard Schröder's Centre-Left government came to power and Oskar Lafontaine, the former finance minister, threatened to squeeze more tax from the rich, the Quandts transferred their stake in BMW to a succession of joint-stock companies. Hans Eichel, Lafontaine's successor as finance minister, has performed a dramatic U-turn on tax and delighted big business by changing the terms under which companies can sell their stake in other firms. Until now, a decision to sell their stake in BMW would result in a massive tax bill for the Quandts, but from 1 January 2001, such a deal will be entirely tax-free.

The Quandts have told Germany's conservatives that they can expect no more donations until they clear up the scandal surrounding Kohl's illegal funding network. And although he insists that the family will not be selling BMW 'this year or next year, either', Gauly has not ruled out future donations to Schröder's Social Democrats: 'It's too early to say. We'll have to see about that.'

Johanna Quandt

Born: Johanna Bruhn

Early employment: Secretary to motorcycle manufacturer and BMW boss Herbert Quandt; married 1960

Current job: £14bn motor matriarch

Children: Susanne Klatten, 37, and Stefan Quandt, 33, now BMW principal stockholders

Home: Fortress-like villa, near Frankfurt

Brush with death: Failed £8m kidnap bid by local convicts

Likes: Family meals

The task of rebuilding its fortunes fell mainly to Herbert, who proved to be a highly effective businessman, saving BMW from bankruptcy in 1959 by increasing his stake in the company and unflinchingly selling the family stake in Daimler-Benz when he judged the time to be right. This sale set off a tradition of rivalry between BMW and Daimler that has continued to this day and may have contributed to the Bavarian company's present crisis. Johanna, who had been Herbert's secretary, became his third wife in 1960 and inherited most of his fortune, including his entire stake in BMW, on his death in 1982. Johanna was determined from the start that her two children should have as normal an upbringing as possible and when Susanne went to work at BMW, she took a job in the canteen. Johanna and Susanne made the news briefly and unwillingly in 1978 when a last-minute police intervention foiled an attempt to kidnap them. A 14-strong gang led by convicts on day release from the local prison had intended to snatch the two Quandts from their home in broad daylight and demand an £8 million ransom. This experience may explain the Quandts' extreme aversion to publicity, and both Susanne and Stefan are accompanied by bodyguards at all times. According to one guest at their parties, the younger Quandts are socially reserved to an unusual degree. 'The bodyguards are always very much in evidence but what struck me as unusual is that, even when they are the hosts, the Quandts seldom circulate among guests. They just sit at their table, talking quietly among themselves while others enjoy their hospitality,' he said. BMW declines to give details of the extent of the family's involvement in business decisions but Susanne and Stefan sit on the advisory board and Johanna is known to have approved the decision to buy Rover in 1994. Gauly insisted last week that all negotiations surrounding the sale of Rover to the venture capital firm, Alchemy, were handled by BMW's chief executive, Professor Joachim Milberg. But Alchemy's boss, Jon Moulton, appeared to cast doubt on that story earlier in the week. 'The idea to buy Rover came in the autumn from Tom Sommerlatte,' he said. Mr Sommerlatte is vice-president of the management consultants, Arthur D. Little, in Wiesbaden and a member of the Alchemy board. He is also reported to have close links with the Quandt family. The Quandts have remained scrupulously loyal to Milberg during the past few days and Gauly told me that he expects the chief executive will still be in his post a year from now. But BMW's British adventure is being seen in German business circles as the worst case of mismanagement since Edzard Reuter's doomed attempt to turn Daimler-Benz into a technology conglomerate. The company most analysts believe is best placed to buy BMW is Ford, which last week snapped up Land-Rover for its luxury division, which already owns Jaguar, Volvo, Aston Martin and Lincoln. In a bitter irony for the Bavarians, this Ford division is led by Wolfgang Reitzle, a former BMW manager who left the company last year when he was passed over for the top job in favour of Milberg. Six years ago, Reitzle warned his colleagues that their British adventure would end in tears and predicted that Rover would cost BMW DM13 billion by 2000. His prediction, which was dismissed at the time as an absurd prophecy of doom, was inaccurate. Rover has cost BMW an estimated DM16bn. Instead of buying Rover, Reitzle wanted to develop a middle-of-the-range BMW 2 series, along the lines of the A Class developed by the Bavarians' rivals in Daimler-Benz (now Daimler-Chrysler). But his fellow managers argued that introducing a more downmarket model would damage the BMW brand and that the best way to expand BMW's range would be to acquire other marques. The Quandts were believed to be uneasy about acquiring Rover but they went along with the strategy of Berndt Pitschetsrieder, Milberg's predecessor, for almost six years. It was only when Rover's losses threatened to damage BMW's core business that the family decided that Pitschetsrieder had to go. Reitzle expected to take over as chairman last year but his appointment was blocked by trade union representatives on BMW's board, who made it clear that they would not co-operate with his plans. Milberg was chosen as a safe pair of hands but, at 61, he was widely viewed as a transitional figure whose primary task was to make Rover profitable or gracefully get rid of it. Gauly insisted last week that Milberg had performed the task he was given by withdrawing from Rover when it became clear that the company could not be turned around. But the cost has been enormous. The Rover 75, universally acknowledged as one of the best new cars to be produced in recent years, has turned out to be a commercial flop. The manufacturers blame the strength of the pound against the euro for the Rover 75's failure but the truth is that it has performed badly in Britain as well. Despite the exchange rate, Rover continued to buy 85 per cent of its components from British suppliers until last year - missing out on an estimated saving of DM2bn. By the beginning of this year, even Land-Rover was losing money and everyone at BMW realised that the condition of the English Patient - as Rover is known in Munich - had become critical. This did not stop the company from issuing a sharp denial of a report last month that the BMW board was considering selling Rover. At the beginning of this month, BMW executives attending a motor show in Geneva were repeating the same, confident lines about Rover's future. One German magazine was reminded of the uplifting speeches delivered by East Germany's leaders on the fortieth anniversary of their state's foundation, a few weeks before the Berlin Wall fell in 1989. Speculation about the Quandts' intentions towards BMW focuses on Susanne and Stefan, both of whom went to business school in the United States and are less steeped in the German corporate tradition than is their mother. Gauly denies that the younger family members, both of whom run businesses outside the motor sector, are driven, like most British and American investors, by shareholder value. 'Their ideas are closer to the stakeholder concept, whereby the value of a company is not only measured by the index but also by, for example, the question of how a company deals with its employees or how much social responsibility it undertakes,' he said. Gauly claims that the Quandts are not politically-minded but Johanna has long been friendly with the former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and the family contributed almost £1 million to Germany's conservative parties in the run up to the general election in 1998. When Gerhard Schröder's Centre-Left government came to power and Oskar Lafontaine, the former finance minister, threatened to squeeze more tax from the rich, the Quandts transferred their stake in BMW to a succession of joint-stock companies. Hans Eichel, Lafontaine's successor as finance minister, has performed a dramatic U-turn on tax and delighted big business by changing the terms under which companies can sell their stake in other firms. Until now, a decision to sell their stake in BMW would result in a massive tax bill for the Quandts, but from 1 January 2001, such a deal will be entirely tax-free. The Quandts have told Germany's conservatives that they can expect no more donations until they clear up the scandal surrounding Kohl's illegal funding network. And although he insists that the family will not be selling BMW 'this year or next year, either', Gauly has not ruled out future donations to Schröder's Social Democrats: 'It's too early to say. We'll have to see about that.' Johanna Quandt Born: Johanna Bruhn Early employment: Secretary to motorcycle manufacturer and BMW boss Herbert Quandt; married 1960 Current job: £14bn motor matriarch Children: Susanne Klatten, 37, and Stefan Quandt, 33, now BMW principal stockholders Home: Fortress-like villa, near Frankfurt Brush with death: Failed £8m kidnap bid by local convicts Likes: Family meals

webTitle: 'We have no reason yet to forgive or forget or embrace or completely trust'

fields.headline: 'We have no reason yet to forgive or forget or embrace or completely trust'
fields.standfirst:
The liberal dictum 'Don't Mention the War' is wrong, says Carol Sarler
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Our man in Berlin, Ambassador Sir Paul Lever, took it upon himself last week to attack the British press for peddling anti-German propaganda. He flailed in all directions, citing the Times, the Telegraph and the Sun, moving even the Sun to deny the accusation. 'Old-fashioned, war-related jibes at the Germans are counter-productive,' it declared.
fields.body:
Our man in Berlin, Ambassador Sir Paul Lever, took it upon himself last week to attack the British press for peddling anti-German propaganda. He flailed in all directions, citing the Times, the Telegraph and the Sun, moving even the Sun to deny the accusation. 'Old-fashioned, war-related jibes at the Germans are counter-productive,' it declared.

In doing so, the Sun placed itself firmly at the supper table of the chatterers. For everyone knows, now, that scathing references to Germans are the province of the yob; that away from Millwall, here in polite society, the Germans are our friends, our allies, our European partners, that what's done is done, that there's no point in harking back because (my great favourite) it's 'not useful', so whatever you do: Don't Mention The War.

This is a unique exemption that we afford the German people. The general rule - most especially for those of the liberal Left - is to show off the history that informs your conversation. You cannot hold views on, say, Ireland, unless you can drop with ease such dates as 1916, 1920 or, if you want to be dead flash, the rebellion of 1641. A debate on Palestinian land rights is incomplete without dragging in Balfour, and when it comes to the Balkans, wow! There are those who can play with 900 years on that one.

The role of the British in world history informs the liberal most of all: what 'we' did to the Aborigine, to the Indian, what part 'we' played in American slavery or the ransacking of the Far East. 'We', of course, did none of it; our great-great-forefathers did. But never mind - a little conscience goes a long way and is, thus, no bad thing.

Yet if we are to remember our great-greats, if we are to remember what William did and what Patrick did next, or how the proud Ibo was abducted from his native land and carried to the cotton fields all those years ago, then I cannot see why we are not supposed to remember what Hans's daddy did, just a blink away from yesterday.

In fact, Don't Mention The War is usually only a euphemism; what we are really saying is Don't Mention The Holocaust. We act as if it is somehow vulgar and indelicate to refer to one of the greatest obscenities in the history of the world, particularly because it might, heaven forfend, upset Hans if we do.

Well, tough.

Fact One: it happened. Fact Two: it happened because a great many Germans made it happen, and a great many more let them. Fact Three: the people in power in Germany today are the first generation after; the children of those who did and those who let. And it beggars belief to suggest that their family relationships had neither influence nor effect.

I need look no further than my own family to illustrate. When I was young, we would bicker with the best of them as my parents expressed their views while I formed mine. Few such views, in the end, passed directly down; my mother, for example, had faith where I have not, my father (occasionally) voted Conservative, which I do not. Now I bicker with my daughter in the same way - lordy, you should hear her on the Prince of Wales, for whom she shows inexplicable support, and for dozens of her own reasons she would prefer that I was not writing this piece today.

Nevertheless, although our views may be different, I am struck by how our values are not. What we hold in common is greater and, I venture, more important than that which divides us - like, just for instance, how you should try to treat with respect those who differ from you in opinion, in culture, in sexuality, in caste or in creed.

So why is it rude or foolish or prejudiced to consider that Hans and millions of his cousins might have been just as greatly influenced by the people they loved most, when they were knee-high to an impressionable age? Tell me, do, O Mein Papa. Perhaps part of the reason for blanking this thought is the fear that, should we scratch the surface of Hans's mind, we might find something nasty lurking there - a deep-rooted anti-Semitism, maybe - and that we should then feel bound to address it; to do something about it.

But no. Why? It is not our policy to annihilate those of separate thought, no matter how offensive that may be. Besides, it is to be hoped that gradual evolution and changing experience will take their healthy toll on future generations of Germans.

But not in one generation, they won't. We have no reason, yet, to forgive or forget or embrace or, completely, to trust. And I'll tell you what: if my daddy did what Hans's daddy did, and all I had to cope with were jokes about nicking sunbeds, I'd think I'd got off pretty damned lightly.

fields.headline: BMW flies into another dogfight
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The war of words between Britain and car manufacturers BMW escalated yesterday when the head of Rover blamed the Government's 'Rip-Off Britain' campaign for undermining the company.
fields.body:
The war of words between Britain and car manufacturers BMW escalated yesterday when the head of Rover blamed the Government's 'Rip-Off Britain' campaign for undermining the company.

His attack came after Tony Blair had pledged not to let the sale of the Rover Group by the German company, which threatens thousands of jobs in the West Midlands, affect Anglo-German relations.

Professor Werner Samann, Rover chairman and chief executive, has been angered by accusations that he lied to Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers. Samann said: 'The poor response to the Rover brand was caused by Mr Byers' Rip-Off Britain campaign - the Department of Trade and Industry initiative on car pricing. Everyone now expects prices to fall by another 10 per cent.'

Samann said Rover had been losing £2,000 for every car sold in the UK and that the rising strength of the pound had cost the company £800 million. He believed customers were staying away in the hope that an impending report by the Competition Commission would force price cuts.

Byers was quick to hit back. 'I think we have to get away from the blame game and look at what we can do for the future of these workers,' he said last night.

fields.headline: Don't mention the car
fields.standfirst:
The battle over Rover has reawakened old enmities. Denis Staunton in Berlin and Burhan Wazir find that Germans are increasingly baffled by our hostility
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: It all started with a dispute between the British Government and a German car manufacturer and ended with the pantomime sight of a writ being served at a conference designed to promote relations between Britain and Germany.
fields.byline: Denis Staunton  in Berlin and  Burhan Wazir
fields.body:
It all started with a dispute between the British Government and a German car manufacturer and ended with the pantomime sight of a writ being served at a conference designed to promote relations between Britain and Germany.

It's been quite a week for Anglo-German misunderstanding. Even the well-intentioned élite gathering at Oxford University for the annual Königswinter conference this weekend has been unable to escape the fall-out from the row over BMW's sale of Rover Cars. Britain's ambassador to Berlin, Sir Paul Lever, had to leave the conference to be served a writ for libel from chairman of the Telegraph Group Conrad Black, whom he had accused of having an anti-German bias.

Anti-German rhetoric reached a new pitch in the British press after BMW's announcement. But for the first time since the end of the Second World War, there were signs that Germans are no longer prepared to accept their bashing sitting down.

'Sometimes, as in moments of national euphoria over football, the sentiments are almost like old-fashioned propaganda,' says Dr Hans-Friedrich von Ploetz, the German ambassador to Britain. He says attitudes are changing, albeit slowly. 'And maybe there is an element of fun there as well; but humour is a line too easily crossed. In this case, with jobs dependent on BMW's position, the old prejudices are easy to resurrect.'

Earlier in the week he had suggested that anti-German campaigns in the British press were not only damaging relations between the two countries; they could also deter German investors from coming to Britain.

In private, German officials are scathing about Britain's anti-German complex, which they say has less to do with the reality of Germany than with Britain's - or more precisely, England's - identity crisis. And Germans living in Britain are increasingly fed up with the hostility they experience.

Jürgen Kass has lived in Britain for all his 29 years - his parents moved to Glasgow in the mid-Sixties. His father ran a successful office equipment firm, Dextronics, in Paisley in the Eighties. Anti-German sentiment, he says, had a distinctive cruelty in the classroom - especially among adolescent boys. 'We started learning about World War Two,' he says, 'and my classmates - who were all friends - suddenly decided they didn't like me anymore. There'd be goose-steps behind me, and people wearing false Hitler moustaches. At one point, I seriously considered changing my name.'

Dieter Werlin, 37, an engineering student at City University in London, says the British tabloid press is often the most vehement supporter of anti-German hysteria. 'It's an old stereotype,' he says. 'That we're efficient, cold and humourless. People have to get beyond that - and the BMW news must be seen as a financial decision. Are you telling me any other company would have done any different with a failing operation?'

Opinion polls show Germans are well-disposed towards the British, whom they regard as reserved but friendly, fashionable and amusing. British comedy shows such as Absolutely Fabulous, Monty Python and Mr Bean are hugely popular.

'I think the British have a certain flair, a kind of Sixties spirit that we've lost in Germany and I find that attractive. I can understand their reaction to BMW's sale of Rover. Rover was obviously in a worse state than anyone realised and BMW probably had to get rid of it. But it's reasonable of the British to have expected BMW to behave better,' said Frank Prill, a 41-year-old Berliner.

Older Berliners retain an especially strong affection for the British. The Berlin Airlift of 1948 transformed Allied forces overnight from an occupying power into a protecting force by keeping West Berlin supplied with food, clothes and medicine throughout the Soviet blockade. British soldiers are still popular in Germany but their numbers have shrunk so much that few Germans outside a small area in the north of the country have any contact with them.

British people who visit Germany are usually surprised by how much they like it and by the fact that Germans are not quite as humourless or authoritarian as they expect. Germans who move to Britain, on the other hand, often find the experience overwhelmingly negative.

'I think life in Britain is a huge disappointment for most Germans,' says a German doctor who has spent four years in London. 'The place is much poorer than I expected and the public services are like something from the Third World. I think the British have an inferiority complex. They keep going on about how everything is world-class and world-famous but most of it is very unremarkable.'

Jürgen Kroenig, the London correspondent for Die Zeit, summed up the experience of many Germans living in Britain in a recent article called 'Krauts'. He acknowledges that the British make fun of all foreigners and that Germans experience hostility in many European countries. But he argues that British antipathy is incomparably intense and that, despite friendly relations between the two governments, it is getting worse.

'The postwar generation have grown up with the same images: in films, TV series, cartoons, newspaper articles and TV commercials, they see stupid German soldiers, thin-lipped SS men with purring voices, humourless bureaucrats and the famous German holidaymakers who put their towels down on the best spots near the swimming pool at the crack of dawn,' he says.

Official relations between London and Berlin have probably never been better. But German officials dismiss British claims that London may soon rival Paris in Berlin's affections and they are contemptuous of Tony Blair's leadership ambitions in Europe.

'I have seen Blair during EU negotiations and he does not strike me as a politician ready to share a leadership role in Europe,' said one senior official. German popular attitudes to Britain remain positive but this may be changing. Papers such as the mass-circulation Bild have started to run anti-British headlines that would have been unthinkable a few years ago and there are signs Germany's patience with British bloody-mindedness is running out.

As one young German living in Britain put it: 'Why don't the British leave us alone and sort out their own problems? Why don't they get a life?'

Denis Staunton writes for The Irish Times

A decade of squabbling

Low points in Anglo-German relations over the past 10 years:

1990: Nicholas Ridley, interviewed in the Spectator , suggests the Germans are still out to dominate Europe. He subsequently resigns as Trade Minister.

1993: German newspapers denounce a British musical about the life of Marlene Dietrich, Where Have All the Flowers Gone?, suggesting many Germans revile her as a traitor.

1994: the FA arrange a friendly match between England and Germany on the anniversary of Hitler's birthday. Michael Schumacher drives Damon Hill off the road to win the Grand Prix World Championship in Adelaide.

1996: European Championships: a few choice headlines marking the England/Germany tie: 'Achtung Surrender - For You Fritz Ze Euro 96 Championship is Over' (Daily Mirror) 'Let's Blitz Fritz' (Sun) 'Herr We Go - Bring On the Krauts' (Daily Star)

1998. Siemens closes its factory in Wallsend, Tyneside, with loss of 1,100 jobs. A survey of British schoolchildren puts Hitler at top of the list of 10 most famous Germans (with 68 per cent of the vote).

1999: Departing German ambassador to London, Gebhardt von Moltke, accuses the British of 'profound ignorance' about modern Germany, and suggests history teaching in Britain appears to end with Hitler's defeat. Millennium Wheel's opening is delayed after a part in each of the 32 German-built computer-controlled devices is found to be the wrong size. Ten times more German students visit the UK than British students travelling the other way. One for the future: Both countries bid for the 2006 World Cup.

Dorota Nosowicz

As one young German living in Britain put it: 'Why don't the British leave us alone and sort out their own problems? Why don't they get a life?' Denis Staunton writes for The Irish Times A decade of squabbling Low points in Anglo-German relations over the past 10 years: 1990: Nicholas Ridley, interviewed in the Spectator , suggests the Germans are still out to dominate Europe. He subsequently resigns as Trade Minister. 1993: German newspapers denounce a British musical about the life of Marlene Dietrich, Where Have All the Flowers Gone?, suggesting many Germans revile her as a traitor. 1994: the FA arrange a friendly match between England and Germany on the anniversary of Hitler's birthday. Michael Schumacher drives Damon Hill off the road to win the Grand Prix World Championship in Adelaide. 1996: European Championships: a few choice headlines marking the England/Germany tie: 'Achtung Surrender - For You Fritz Ze Euro 96 Championship is Over' (Daily Mirror) 'Let's Blitz Fritz' (Sun) 'Herr We Go - Bring On the Krauts' (Daily Star) 1998. Siemens closes its factory in Wallsend, Tyneside, with loss of 1,100 jobs. A survey of British schoolchildren puts Hitler at top of the list of 10 most famous Germans (with 68 per cent of the vote). 1999: Departing German ambassador to London, Gebhardt von Moltke, accuses the British of 'profound ignorance' about modern Germany, and suggests history teaching in Britain appears to end with Hitler's defeat. Millennium Wheel's opening is delayed after a part in each of the 32 German-built computer-controlled devices is found to be the wrong size. Ten times more German students visit the UK than British students travelling the other way. One for the future: Both countries bid for the 2006 World Cup. Dorota Nosowicz

webTitle: How brash BMW ran Rover to catastrophe

fields.headline: How brash BMW ran Rover to catastrophe
fields.standfirst:
Germans ignored warnings of the size of the challenge, says Joanna Walters
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Germans ignored warnings of the size of the challenge, says Joanna Walters
fields.body:
They would not listen. When BMW bought Rover, British experts lined up to advise the German carmaker on how to transform the mutt into a pedigree, but their wisdom was reportedly ignored.

Last week they queued to deride BMW's cries that it was all the British Government's fault that Rover fell apart. The experts said the German company was 'amateurish' to put the entire blame on the strength of the pound against the euro and the 'consumer strike' in UK car retailing sparked by the Government's botched 'rip-off Britain' campaign.

All the car manufacturers are squealing about these issues. But BMW cannot escape the fact that it made huge errors in its stewardship of Rover since it snatched it from the British group's previous partner Honda in 1994. Many agreed that the currency issue merely hastened a disaster of BMW's own making.

One senior industry executive said last week: 'From the beginning, people who were intimately familiar with the business told them Rover was a far bigger bundle than they realised, and that they had to start all over again.

'Rover was cheap, a few of the BMW directors were very enthusiastic and underestimated what they were buying. It did not have profits or a strong balance sheet, and had been starved of cash for decades. But in terms of capitalisation and the capacity to build 700,000 cars - against BMW's 500,000 - it was huge.'

He said the German management team at BMW's headquarters in Munich had little international manufacturing experience, 'whereas companies like Ford and General Motors had been managing factories all over the world for 60 years'.

The over-enthusiastic BMW took a hands-off approach to Rover management initially, but much of the best talent had left the company or been plundered by former owner British Aerospace. A top team needed to be parachuted in to take control to improve quality, productivity, product strategy and brand value.

BMW has a successful US factory in South Carolina, producing the Z3 sports car. But it was built on a greenfield site with German management, training, engineering and design, and it makes a proven, BMW-badged product.

Rover was very different, but BMW failed to take a grip.

Professor Dan Jones, director of the Lean Enterprise Centre at the Cardiff University Business School, said: 'They took the company over in a hurry. They were trying to leapfrog Daimler-Benz [owner of Mercedes] before it merged with Chrysler, and they thought this was a clever way of doing it.'

Jones said BMW failed to consult industry experts and former executives, such as the much-admired Rover boss George Simpson, who concluded the sale to BMW before leaving for Lucas and ultimately GEC, which he restructured, earning a peerage.

'BMW did not do their homework, they did not understand the depth of the problems and they did not listen,' Jones said.

He added that when BMW bought the company, by trumping an offer from Honda, UK observers were flattered that such a prestigious firm was interested. 'But they took a very amateurish, sentimental approach to brand and product strategy, and ended up with the wrong car - the large, executive Rover 75. And a new Mini was not what they needed next. They should have turned their attention to Longbridge before Cowley, and invested in a new medium-sized car.'

The new Rover 75 has won critical acclaim - although some say it is staid and overweight - but it was blighted from the outset.

One observer said: 'When BMW declared a crisis at Rover and threatened to shut Longbridge at the Motor Show in Birmingham in 1998 just hours after the debut of the 75, dealers lost a lot of faith. This was exacerbated when deliveries of the new car were delayed because of quality problems.'

Motor traders who specialise in estimating second- hand car values said sales of the 75 fell short of what was needed from the outset because its resale prospects were blighted by the uncer tain future of Rover. Private motorists and businesses buying company cars by the thousand set a lot of store by what a new car will be worth six months or two years later. The fact that an equivalent Ford or Vauxhall is reckoned to keep at least 10 per cent more of its value than the Rover has depressed sales of the 75. Poor sales across the rest of the range exacerbated the problem.

Meanwhile, Joe Dickinson of industry consultant AT Kearney said: 'BMW are not justifed in blaming the pound. It is a factor, of course, but you have to look at the turn-around of production performance at both Peugeot and Jaguar factories in Coventry and the fact that Nissan's Sunderland plant is the most productive in Europe.

'If you get the branding and the product right you can be successful regardless. They messed up the Rover brand. Their intentions were good and they had fondness for the idea of reviving these dead and dying marques such as Rover, Mini, MG, Morris and Riley, and building up volumes to become a major manufacturer. But it was unrealistic.'

In the last 18 months, BMW is widely thought to have made a mess of its funding request to the British government, with the dubious threat of moving Rover to Hungary, which the European Commission did not believe. The EC decided to investigate, holding up the revival plan while Rover's losses deepened.

And it should have conducted a thorough review of its strategy after the boardroom shake-up this time last year that saw the sacking of the top two BMW executives, the pro-Rover Bernd Pischetsrieder, now destined to join Volkswagen, and Wolfgang Reitzle, who only ever wanted Land Rover and has belatedly got it now that he is at Ford, which secured a deal to buy the four-wheel drive outfit for £1.8 billion nine days ago.

In the final débcle, BMW miscalculated when it lied to the Government by denying it would abandon Rover, rocking Anglo-German relations and covering the proud Bavarian company and its aristocratic majority shareholder, the Quandt family, in dishonour and embarrassment.

Observers believe it will soon abandon Rolls-Royce too, and hand the rights to produce the world's most famous car over to Volkswagen, which owns the sister Bentley marque.

This would bring a humiliating and very expensive end to a British misadventure by the bumptious Bavarians.

webTitle: Austrians stay discreet over Haider's outing

fields.headline: Austrians stay discreet over Haider's outing
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The outing of far-right leader Jörg Haider has hardly caused a stir in Austria where, according to a lone commentator, there has been a 'sudden silence in the beer hall'.
fields.body:
The outing of far-right leader Jörg Haider has hardly caused a stir in Austria where, according to a lone commentator, there has been a 'sudden silence in the beer hall'.

It took a foreign newspaper (the Tageszeitung or taz of Berlin) to publish what has been common knowledge here for years, but has never been publicly declared.

'It's now the hot topic in editorial meetings, but it might take the media a few weeks to decide how they should react,' said one journalist who asked for his name to be withheld.

'Austria is a Catholic country, so the collective psyche works differently. Traditionally, you only really discuss these things with your priest in a confessional.'

So far the Freedom Party (FPO), of which Haider is de facto leader, has refused to speak. The leader of its parliamentary group, Peter Westenthaler, would only say: 'I refuse to comment on such absurdities and sleaze-mongering.'

Among the media only the liberal daily, Der Standard, and Austria's first private television station AT, which began broadcasting three weeks ago, have touched the subject.

Austrian outing 'specialist', Kurt Krickler, who in 1995 outed five Catholic bishops, says: 'It's characteristic that no one till now has gone public with the information. That's because by doing it you out yourself and put your neck on the line.'

Speak to people in gay bars in Vienna, and the reaction is much the same. 'We can't name names, it's dangerous even to talk about this because he has such good connections within the police force and the secret services,' said a 28-year-old gay man in Rosa Lila, a trendy gay and lesbian meeting point which a Freedom Party MP once denounced as a 'subsidised brothel'.

But they nod when asked to confirm the allegations printed in taz. While some say the outing of Haider - a man who enjoys defaming and denouncing other 'minorities', whether foreigners, artists or women - is justified, playing him at his own game, others fear it will be damaging to the gay cause and provoke a wave of anti-gay feeling.

fields.headline: Russia's men of power
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText:
Lenin, Vladimir Ilich
Marxist theoretician who led the October Revolution in 1917. First Prime Minister of the Soviet Union, formed in December 1922, but died in 1924. Deified by Communist state.
fields.body:
Lenin, Vladimir Ilich
Marxist theoretician who led the October Revolution in 1917. First Prime Minister of the Soviet Union, formed in December 1922, but died in 1924. Deified by Communist state.

Stalin, Josef
Ruthless General Secretary of the Communist Party from 1922 and Prime Minister from 1941. Used police terror intensively, beat Nazi Germany, absorbed much of Eastern Europe and led Soviet Union into the nuclear age.

Khrushchev, Nikita Sergeyevich
First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (1953-64) and Prime Minister of the Soviet Union (1958-64). Pursued a policy of 'peaceful coexistence' with the capitalist West but liked to rattle a sabre.

Brezhnev, Leonid Ilich
In effect was leader of the Soviet Union for 18 years and oversaw a massive expansion of the military-industrial complex.

Andropov, Yury Vladimirovich
General Secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee from November 1982 until his death 15 months later. After ill health set in, he was never seen in public again.

Chernenko, Konstantin Ustinovich
Brezhnev protégé, chief political leader of the Soviet Union from February 1984 until his death a year later. Like his predecessor, Chernenko's health deteriorated soon after taking office.

Gorbachev, Mikhail
Party and government leader of the Soviet Union, 1985-91, took presidency in 1990. His glasnost (openness) led to break-up of the Soviet Union.

Yeltsin, Boris
President from 1990; in 1991 Yeltsin became the first popularly elected leader in Russian history. Promoted economic reforms but their failure to bring growth - allied to his ill health and aberrant behaviour - dimmed his popularity.

fields.headline: Mrs Blair's Diary
fields.standfirst:
Sexier than Paxman. And Tony is left holding the baby (not)

Blairs' babe: special report
fields.trailText: Monday: I don't know if I see quite what all the fuss is about with this paternity leave stuff; seems perfectly simple to me. Tony, on the other hand, is being that odd mixture of selfishness, arrogance and indecision that can afflict some members of the human race at certain times in their lives - i.e., male members, between the times of birth and death.
fields.body:
Monday: I don't know if I see quite what all the fuss is about with this paternity leave stuff; seems perfectly simple to me. Tony, on the other hand, is being that odd mixture of selfishness, arrogance and indecision that can afflict some members of the human race at certain times in their lives - i.e., male members, between the times of birth and death.

His argument seems to be the country simply can't be run without him, and he appears to think this argument is watertight - a statement, I had to tell him, with which I would wholeheartedly agree if only he were to substitute the word 'watertight' with another, such as 'pompous' or 'tomfool'.

I walked off eventually, having lost patience, leaving him whining - oh, I'm sorry, but that voice can go on sometimes, and I really don't feel that great these days - about the lack of an alternative. 'Who could take over? I mean, y'know, dear, if you can think of anyone, anyone - with, look, that people would listen to, anyone else with gravitas. Honestly, I can't think of anyone...

Tuesday: 'And finally,' boomed Gordon, a smile playing around his lips, his triumph complete. All over the country, I suspect, thirtysomething women swooned, as when Paxman does his little moué at the end. I hadn't realised money could be so exciting. And I don't think the party realised spending money could be so exciting.

I do think, though, that he shouldn't have asked Tony to turn the pages for him; a little bit demeaning, that. As was the filling the water-glass bit, and the brushing-fluff-off-the-suit bit.

'There isn't anyone , dear,' comes the whine that night. Much less convincing. We're winning, girls.

Wednesday: Tony has decided, wisely and bravely, to blame Gordon if it all goes wrong. Lots of muttering about taxes going up, unelectability, heads rolling, Scots, bachelors, etc.

Papers ecstatic. Country ecstatic. People want to pay more taxes.

Tony has decided, wisely and bravely, to take credit for the Budget.

Thursday: Lisbon lovely. Schröder less so. Tony shouted at him for a while, until he was asked, politely, whether there were perhaps any personal problems in his life.

Friday: I point out to Tony that the country hasn't yet disintegrated in his absence, and smile sweetly. Oh yes, I think this is going to be fun.

fields.headline: Gay slur on Putin opponent
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Crude anti-Semitic and homophobic propaganda has been used by the Kremlin-controlled media in a last-minute attempt to target one of the key opponents of Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting President who it is widely believed will win today's presidential election.
fields.body:
Crude anti-Semitic and homophobic propaganda has been used by the Kremlin-controlled media in a last-minute attempt to target one of the key opponents of Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting President who it is widely believed will win today's presidential election.

In one broadcast, alleged members of a gay group, Blue Heart, were shown enthusiastically endorsing Grigory Yavlinsky, a liberal candidate who could take enough votes from Putin to prevent him gaining the 50 per cent needed to win the first round. In Russian 'blue' is slang for gay. A rival broadcasting organisation said the entire event appeared to have been staged.

Another report, broadcast last Thursday on the 51 per cent government-owned television channel ORT, claimed Yavlinsky had received financial backing from one of the country's most powerful Jewish businessmen, the media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, who also has Israeli citizenship. Gusinksy's deputy, Igor Malashenko, said the report, which used images of Jewish people wearing traditional skullcaps, was clearly appealing to anti-Semitic sentiments.

Commentators are accusing Putin's campaign team of exploiting entrenched homophobic, anti-Semitic and xenophobic attitudes in a last-ditch campaign to secure the support of wavering and apathetic voters.

If Putin wins less than 50 per cent of votes, the election will go to a second round in mid-April - damaging his prestige.

Russia's often unreliable opinion polls showed Putin's popularity had dipped slightly. By last Thursday - the last day polls could be published - his support had fallen from 60 per cent to less than 55 per cent. Although still well ahead of his closest rival, the communist leader Gennady Zyuganov - who has about 23 per cent - he was dangerously close to the runoff margin.

This was the point at which the attacks on the liberal candidate began. Yavlinsky, a distant third, has just 6 per cent of votes. But he has seen his support rise at the tail end of the campaign, crucially eating into Putin's popularity. Putin's campaign advisers identified Yavlinsky's 6 per cent as crucial to an outright victory for the former KGB man.

The other state-owned channel, RTR, provided more anti-Yavlinsky ammunition, quoting reports he had recently had plastic surgery.

December's parliamentary elections were tainted by a vicious campaign against Putin's key rivals in prime time ORT broadcasts. Boris Berezovsky, the tycoon who has a major stake in the channel, said last Friday he was proud of the role the station played in dispensing with former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov and Moscow mayor Yury Luzhkov.

fields.headline: From here to paternity
fields.standfirst: Blairs' babe: special report
fields.trailText: Edwina Currie spoke the most sense on whether Tony Blair should take paternity leave. 'I hope he takes a week off,' she said. 'Any longer and he'll be exhausted. Looking after your children is a lot harder than looking after your country.' For good measure, Currie could have added: 'And after three kids he knows as much', but we all got the picture.
fields.body:
Edwina Currie spoke the most sense on whether Tony Blair should take paternity leave. 'I hope he takes a week off,' she said. 'Any longer and he'll be exhausted. Looking after your children is a lot harder than looking after your country.' For good measure, Currie could have added: 'And after three kids he knows as much', but we all got the picture.

Blair can't be that concerned about leaving the running of the country to John Prescott, otherwise those halcyon weeks the Blairs spend holidaying in Tuscany each year would have turned into a snatched weekend at EuroDisney by now. What probably worries Blair is that, after the initial euphoria of dad-to-baby bonding has passed, he might get a little restless, warming bottles and supporting Cherie, while his government chums are grappling with exciting 'guy' stuff such as the aftermath of the London mayoral elections or decommissioning weapons in Northern Ireland.

Truth is, children are wonderful but looking after them has to be one of the most difficult, draining and undervalued jobs on the planet. However much you worship your offspring, however gladly you'd take a bullet for them, the fact remains that child rearing is drudgery dressed up as destiny. Any working mother who says different either has a full-time nanny and cleaner, a job she hates, or less brain cells than it takes to power a light bulb.

A woman with a huge salary and a full-time nanny doesn't seriously need several weeks' 'help' from her husband after she's had her fourth baby. What she might need, or indeed just want, is a bit of on-site validation. Four children on, Cherie might feel, like an exasperated lady owner of a frisky puppy, that it's time to rub her husband's nose straight into the mess and stink of babyhood. After all, how else are they supposed to learn? That's if they actually want to learn.

I'm sure Tony Blair is a very nice dad in his own way, when he can be, and under his own terms. Get the picture? Women put their children first. Men tend, without thought or malice, to put their children a poor third - after themselves, and the people they want to be.

Indeed, it's my firm belief that a lot of women are existing as quasi-single parents without even realising it. Everyone knows about absent parents, most of whom are men, but there also seem to be quite a lot of what I would term 'abstract parents' around, most of whom are also men.

Abstract dad is different from absent dad in that he is around as such, especially when it comes to the big, glory-hunting occasions (the birth, the birthdays, the romp through the park with the toddler on the shoulders, holidays, family occasions, school speech day and so on).

There is abstract dad in the photograph album, being 'fun' and 'great'. However, when it comes to the dull, repetitive, daily slog of parenting, abstract dad rather cleverly manages not to be there for you or your child. He vanishes - to his study, his work, his pub, (his government?) or any of the other long-established male hidey-holes.

The fact is if hands-on, full-strength parenting was so much fun, men would have made sure that they go to do it. As it is, while you sometimes hear about men being jealous of women's ability to have babies, you never hear about this jealousy extending to mothers of chocolate-fingered toddlers or miserable teenagers. Not enough glory in that, you see.

And you can't help but wonder how many women live with abstract dads. How many women are in a relationship with children, but feel completely alone? My guess is an awful lot and the real mystery is why they put up with it.

webTitle: Tsar Vladimir the Terrible dreams of today's crown

fields.headline: Tsar Vladimir the Terrible dreams of today's crown
fields.standfirst:
Neal Ascherson on the career of the monarchist who reached the top without trying

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The table-talk of Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin is not extensive. The crumbs of wisdom collected would hardly fill a Russian lunch- time. But some of those crumbs are startling. For example, Putin - today presumably being elected President of the Russian federal republic - has admitted a weakness for monarchy.
fields.body:
The table-talk of Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin is not extensive. The crumbs of wisdom collected would hardly fill a Russian lunch- time. But some of those crumbs are startling. For example, Putin - today presumably being elected President of the Russian federal republic - has admitted a weakness for monarchy.

Putin-watchers think this is to do with his dream of extending the Russian presidential term - perhaps to seven years. But there could be another reason. Putin has reached the top without trying to, something almost unknown in the modern democratic or undemocratic world.

He enjoys leading Russia, but never expected to. Instead he was in the crowd on the fast escalator when somebody tugged his sleeve and said: 'You! Yes, it's you we want. Come this way!'

There is a great deal of as-if about Putin. His parents survived the siege of Leningrad, but all he has seen of hot war is what the generals let him see in Chechnya. He had boyish daydreams of joining the KGB as a young 'Knight of the Revolution', but was turned down when he applied; it was only later, when he was at university, that they came to him.

He was an intelligence officer in East Germany in the Cold War, but his job was not exciting or dangerous. Boris Yeltsin made Putin head of the FSB, the KGB's successor, in 1998, but the agency found him colourless and indecisive. He was constantly promoted into posts above his qualifications, which he had not struggled to win. The one big exception is his time in St Petersburg in the Nineties as lieutenant to the charismatic mayor, Anatol Sobchak. Putin was the organising genius who kept the city fed by ignoring central government and trading with the outside world. He seemed to find himself, to gain a practical vision of how a post-Soviet Russia might work.

In the Tsarist past, according to historian Geoffrey Hosking, there were two models for a Russian ruler. One was the Christian 'basileus', a saint leading his people towards moral salvation. The other was the 'khan', the autocrat who hammered his people into a strong state able to conquer and absorb others.

Most tsars had elements of both. So does Vladimir Putin. He is a convinced Westerniser, sure that Russia's future lies with Europe and in an open, law-bound market economy. But much of his popularity comes from his threats to stamp out corruption and profiteering. He is admired for being morally and financially clean, for his self-effacing manner. But his programme for the resurrection of Russia has only three phases: establishing 'the dictatorship of law', rebuilding 'a strong state' and restoring 'Russia's dignity'. There is no democratic phase.

Once there was an ascetic young tsar, who came to the throne determined to deal with the rich, corrupt boyars who threatened the survival of Russia. Like Putin, he had pure moral ideals, but a state too weak to carry them out without using tyrannical violence. His name was Ivan IV, remembered as Ivan the Terrible.

webTitle: The Blairs just get more silly

fields.headline: The Blairs just get more silly
fields.standfirst:
All this talk of paternity leave makes Gordon Brown the obvious candidate for PM

Blairs' babe: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians tend to be pretty weird people with more eccentricities and obsessions than most of us. But some are better than others at conveying an image of solid common-sense and down-to-earth reliability.
fields.body:
Politicians tend to be pretty weird people with more eccentricities and obsessions than most of us. But some are better than others at conveying an image of solid common-sense and down-to-earth reliability.

Gordon Brown is, I'm sure, seething with all kinds of strange and powerful emotions, but he still manages to appear as a shrewd and sensible Scotsman - just the man to be trusted with the country's finances and even, hopefully, with the country as a whole.

In contrast Mr Blair, with his shining eyes and happy-clappy manner, has always looked pretty batty, albeit in a reasonably harmless way. The same is true of his wife, Cherie, who gives an impression, perhaps unfairly, of having only limited contact with the real world.

All the silliness of the Blairs came out last week when Cherie made some heavy hints in a public speech that she was expecting her husband to follow the example of the Finnish Prime Minister and take some weeks off when their new baby arrives in May.

To what possible purpose? The idea of paternity leave is a peculiar one in any case, given the fact that new-born babies spend most of their time sleeping. The Blairs we can be fairly sure will in any case employ a live-in nanny to do most of the baby care. And at the earliest opportu nity, after a month or so, Cherie Blair will return to her highly paid legal job leaving the nanny in control. From then on neither pair will see much of their child. So why should anyone be impressed if in the early days Mr Blair takes time off from his duties to be with Mrs Blair? The only result of all this is to make both the Blairs look even sillier than they do at present, thereby once again enhancing the image of Mr Brown as the solid Scotsman with little time for this kind of nonsense.

Batty barons
IF ANY CLASS of person is generally battier than politicians it must be the press barons with their long tradition going back to the founder of the modern press, the great Lord Northcliffe, who was literally insane during his final years.

The first Lord Rothermere was a great admirer of Adolf Hitler. Rupert Murdoch similarly reveres Mr Pat Robertson, the would-be American president and anti-Semite who claims to be able to speak in tongues. 'He's right on all the issues,' the Digger told his faithful lieutenant, Andrew Neil.

Several press lords have been Canadian like Lord Beaverbrook and the former owner of the Times and Sunday Times Lord Thompson of Fleet. Lord Thomson was asked once by a reporter if he regretted not having been to university. He replied: 'If I'd been to university I'd be working today for someone like me.'

Continuing the tradition is another Canadian, the present owner of the Daily Telegraph Conrad Black. Mr Black, who has described himself as an amateur psychiatrist and who has a worrying fascination with Napoleon, has recently developed a taste for litigation. Last year he issued proceedings against the Prime Minister of Canada, Jean Chretien, who has managed to obstruct the life peerage that Tony Blair is keen to bestow on Britain's most right-wing newspaper owner.

Now Mr Black has issued a writ for libel against Sir Paul Lever, the British ambassador in Berlin who, in an interview with the German paper, Die Welt , accused the Telegraph of being anti-German. Although Sir Paul wrote a conciliatory letter to the Telegraph , backtracking from his earlier comments, Mr Black is not satisfied. He is fed up, he says, with being described as a Euro-phobic foreigner and will not rest until every single word has been retracted by the ambassador in open court.

Who will be the next to get a writ from Mr Black? Possibly Sinn Fein/IRA for objecting to the Telegraph 's strongly pro-Unionist bias. Whatever happens, we shall all have to watch our step in future before voicing any criticism of Mr Black and his outstandingly brilliant and impartial newspaper.

Perks and peers
AS ALWAYS wearing a seraphic and slightly foolish smile, the newly ennobled Lord Birt of Wood Lane has been pictured at his installation in the House of Lords, standing proudly with his sponsor, the former BBC employee Baroness Jay of Paddington.

The peerage is good news for all those who make a complete balls-up of things in their chosen profession. Abject failure, even on the John Birt scale, is no longer any bar to perks and peerages.

Another happy beneficiary of this new enlightened approach towards general uselessness will be the woman behind the Millennium Dome, Jennie Page, who, according to reports, will be made a Dame in the next available Honours List.

Ms Page was sacked from the Dome project at the insistence of her colleague the British Airways boss Bob Ayling, but he in turn has now been sacked by BA to the apparent rejoicing of pretty well all his staff. Never mind. Mr Ayling is, we are told, also now in the running for an honour - probably a peerage just like John Birt's.

This could be the solution perhaps to the still unsolved problem of what to do about Piers Morgan, the much reviled wheeler-dealer editor of the Daily Mirror who has given Mr Blair and his government so much hurtful support in his paper. He, too, could be given a life peerage and as Lord Morgan of Viglen, enjoy an honourable retirement with plenty of time still to pursue his hobby of stockmarket speculation.

fields.headline: The hard men behind Putin
fields.standfirst:
Russia's fat cats pushed Putin to the top. But now his promise to curb their influence has them worried, reports Amelia Gentleman in Moscow

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: In his final appeal to the nation before today's presidential elections, Vladimir Putin appeared on state television to announce solemnly that Russia was on the threshold of a new epoch.
fields.body:
In his final appeal to the nation before today's presidential elections, Vladimir Putin appeared on state television to announce solemnly that Russia was on the threshold of a new epoch.

'The old time is over,' he declared, grave-faced. 'The day of the elections will usher in the beginning of a new era.'

For many Russians, the most alarming aspect of the presidential vote is that no one knows what this new dawn will entail. Right up to the end of the campaign, Putin has flatly refused to issue a manifesto or clear economic programme or explain how he proposes to rule. With his victory, Russia embarks on a journey into the unknown.

Even before the polling stations opened this morning, there was no doubt who would win the election. The question was whether the poll would go to a second round.

Although the election result is a foregone conclusion, the uncertainty about what awaits Russia once Putin's presidency is formalised has created a wave of tension among the Kremlin's powerful backstage elite - nervous that Putin may be on the brink of orchestrating a Stalinist purge of the old order.

The fate of the oligarchs - politically influential multi-millionaire bankers, oil magnates and media moguls who became rich fast with the collapse of communism by buy ing up state assets on the cheap - is now cloudy.

If, as polls predict, Putin does secure himself more than 50 per cent of the vote today, then his behaviour over the next few days will be a crucial indication of whether he truly has the power and inclination to cut ties with the murkier elements of Russia's old regime or whether his pledges to combat state corruption were simply hollow rhetoric.

One of Putin's most populist campaign promises was his vow to distance himself from the reviled oligarchs. Adopting tough Leninist language, he declared last week: 'The oligarchs will cease to exist as a class.'

For the majority of Russia's population - impoverished by what they believe was a corrupt privatisation programme - a ruthless approach to the men who creamed off the profits is essential. And foreign investors see Putin's readiness to take on these influential figures as a test of his willingness and ability to achieve wider economic reforms.

On Friday morning, Boris Berezovsky - Russia's most powerful oligarch, who holds crucial stakes in the state television channel ORT, and the oil and aluminium industries - took the unusual step of giving breakfast to journalists where he announced that Putin would not survive without the oligarchs' support. He arrived in a chauffeur-driven Mercedes (a flashing blue light on top giving him the right to flout road regulations) escorted by two black jeeps full of security guards.

He stressed his friendly relations with the acting President: they spoke regularly by telephone; Putin had even attended his wife's birthday party last year, he said. Berezovsky - a member of former President Boris Yeltsin's inner circle who secured himself immunity from future prosecution by becoming a deputy in December's parliamentary election - added confidently: 'For me personally, little is going to change. The role of the oligarchs will grow. The term oligarch means simply big capitalists in Russia. And big business is going to play a bigger and bigger role in Russia.' But Berezovsky admitted that Putin could win valuable popularity by putting him in prison, and added enigmatically: 'Putin is a politician and I'm a politician. The concept of gratitude has no place in politics. Putin doesn't owe me anything.'

The billionaire head of Alfa financial group and another of Russia's notorious plutocrats, Mikhael Fridman, told The Observer that Putin was right to try to separate powerful business figures from political influence.

'There should be new rules about the relationship between business and government. I think Putin has the power and political will to do that - but it won't be easy,' he said. But Fridman refused to describe himself as an oligarch, hinting instead that he had business rivals in mind.

Some analysts argue that Putin has already shown that, despite his slogans, he is in no hurry to crush these groups. His first act on taking over from Yeltsin on New Year's Eve was to grant his predecessor immunity from prosecution. This hardly indicated that he planned to eradicate the old regime's evils.

A simmering scandal in the aluminium world is seen as another sign of his ambiguous attitude to the oligarchs. Putin's anti-monopoly Minister, Ilya Yuzhanov, was recently asked to investigate the reported takeover of several big aluminium plants by firms controlled by Berezovsky and another leading oligarch, Roman Abramovich (who also secured himself immunity by becoming a deputy in December). The deal was reported to have given the two men control over 60 per cent of Russia's vast aluminium empire, but Yuzhanov later reported that the purchases had not violated anti-monopoly laws.

In the next few days, Putin's appointment of Prime Minister will show how serious he is about combating the problem. If, as predicted, Mikhail Kasyanov, currently first Deputy Prime Minister, gets the job, this would send out negative signals. Of the old guard, Kasyanov is seen as a friend to the oligarchs.

Despite his popularity, Putin may feel he does not yet have the power to beat these groups. Keen to distance himself from Berezovsky, he also knows that he is in his debt.

This was clear in the December parliamentary elections, when a slur campaign by Berezovsky's ORT channel savaged his two rivals. In a popular evening news series, Moscow Mayor Yury Luzhkov was demonised as a crook and a murderer, while gruesome footage of a hip operation was broadcast to show that for mer Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov (who had recently undergone surgery) was too frail to run the country. Both men - once thought to be serious presidential contenders - later dropped out of the race.

Berezovsky had no qualms about admitting his firm's role in Putin's success. 'I was extremely pleased [with ORT's work],' he said. 'I believe that they helped Russia with a historic task.'

Igor Malashenko, deputy chairman of MediaMost - run by rival oligarch Vladimir Gusinsky - said Putin would wait before cracking down on Berezovsky. 'Putin cannot enjoy being in Berezovsky's hands. But ORT is a powerful force in Russian politics. At the moment it is being used to support Putin, but Berezovsky can turn his weapon on anyone he likes,' he said. 'ORT demonstrates every day how easily politicians can be destroyed.'

ORT's licence comes up for renewal at the end of May, and this could be a chance for Putin to restrain publicly Berezovsky's influence.

Political analyst Lilya Shevtsova said Putin would slowly push out Yeltsin's favourites. 'He doesn't want to be hostage to the old family, he's going to create his own oligarchs from his own circle,' she said.
