But Berezovsky admitted that Putin could win valuable popularity by putting him in prison, and added enigmatically: 'Putin is a politician and I'm a politician. The concept of gratitude has no place in politics. Putin doesn't owe me anything.' The billionaire head of Alfa financial group and another of Russia's notorious plutocrats, Mikhael Fridman, told The Observer that Putin was right to try to separate powerful business figures from political influence. 'There should be new rules about the relationship between business and government. I think Putin has the power and political will to do that - but it won't be easy,' he said. But Fridman refused to describe himself as an oligarch, hinting instead that he had business rivals in mind. Some analysts argue that Putin has already shown that, despite his slogans, he is in no hurry to crush these groups. His first act on taking over from Yeltsin on New Year's Eve was to grant his predecessor immunity from prosecution. This hardly indicated that he planned to eradicate the old regime's evils. A simmering scandal in the aluminium world is seen as another sign of his ambiguous attitude to the oligarchs. Putin's anti-monopoly Minister, Ilya Yuzhanov, was recently asked to investigate the reported takeover of several big aluminium plants by firms controlled by Berezovsky and another leading oligarch, Roman Abramovich (who also secured himself immunity by becoming a deputy in December). The deal was reported to have given the two men control over 60 per cent of Russia's vast aluminium empire, but Yuzhanov later reported that the purchases had not violated anti-monopoly laws. In the next few days, Putin's appointment of Prime Minister will show how serious he is about combating the problem. If, as predicted, Mikhail Kasyanov, currently first Deputy Prime Minister, gets the job, this would send out negative signals. Of the old guard, Kasyanov is seen as a friend to the oligarchs. Despite his popularity, Putin may feel he does not yet have the power to beat these groups. Keen to distance himself from Berezovsky, he also knows that he is in his debt. This was clear in the December parliamentary elections, when a slur campaign by Berezovsky's ORT channel savaged his two rivals. In a popular evening news series, Moscow Mayor Yury Luzhkov was demonised as a crook and a murderer, while gruesome footage of a hip operation was broadcast to show that for mer Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov (who had recently undergone surgery) was too frail to run the country. Both men - once thought to be serious presidential contenders - later dropped out of the race. Berezovsky had no qualms about admitting his firm's role in Putin's success. 'I was extremely pleased [with ORT's work],' he said. 'I believe that they helped Russia with a historic task.' Igor Malashenko, deputy chairman of MediaMost - run by rival oligarch Vladimir Gusinsky - said Putin would wait before cracking down on Berezovsky. 'Putin cannot enjoy being in Berezovsky's hands. But ORT is a powerful force in Russian politics. At the moment it is being used to support Putin, but Berezovsky can turn his weapon on anyone he likes,' he said. 'ORT demonstrates every day how easily politicians can be destroyed.' ORT's licence comes up for renewal at the end of May, and this could be a chance for Putin to restrain publicly Berezovsky's influence. Political analyst Lilya Shevtsova said Putin would slowly push out Yeltsin's favourites. 'He doesn't want to be hostage to the old family, he's going to create his own oligarchs from his own circle,' she said.

webTitle: Medicinal boost for a sick system

fields.headline: Medicinal boost for a sick system
fields.standfirst:
Despite Gordon Brown's rhetoric, the Budget marked a loosening of fiscal policy, argues Andrew Dilnot

Budget 2000: special report
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Despite Gordon Brown's rhetoric, the Budget marked a loosening of fiscal policy, argues Andrew Dilnot
fields.body:
Budgets are all about tax. Well... not this one. This was about public spending, and especially health spending. Perhaps you thought spending decisions were now made once every three years in the Spending Review in July. Tony Blair did too apparently. On the Breakfast with Frost interview which launched the health spending debate on 16 January he said of health spending: 'If this July when we work out the next three year period... ' That job has now been done early, and we were told in the Budget what health spending would be for four years from this April.

The big picture here is that when the Government came to power it faced high, albeit falling, public borrowing. This led it to increase taxation and hold public spending down so as to be sure of meeting its own public borrowing rules. In the last three years the economy has done well and it now seems that the tax increases were greater than needed to bring the public finances into shape. On Budget day, Gordon Brown announced increases in public spending for the future, funded by the past tax increases. Spending on health and education is going up.

So for 2000-01, health spending rises by an extra £2 billion, which when added to the previous plans gives a real increase of 7.4 per cent. Education gets an extra £1bn, which will give it an overall annual real increase of 9 per cent. There is also extra money for transport and the Home Office, of £280 million and £285m respectively. Beyond 2000-01, we are told about the health spending for the following three years. Over the period from 1999-2000 to 2003-04 real spending on health will grow at an average of 6.1 per cent.

This is a long period of growth above what the NHS has ever seen so far: 3.7 per cent. These increases may almost bring health spending in the UK to one version of the EU average. The injection of funds is very large. One natural question is whether this means that health will absorb all the resources that are available for increased spending in the next few years. Such an outcome would be very odd, and inconsistent with the Government's statement that education is a top priority.

We don't yet know the detailed allocation for any spending department other than health, but the Budget did announce the overall public spending limits until 2003-04. Total spending is to grow at 3.4 per cent p.a. in real terms from April 2001. So even if education spending grows over the whole period at the same rate as health, all other items of spending could grow at 2.5 per cent. Health and education spending would go on growing as a share of total spending, but other departments need not be squeezed to pay for it.

How can this be possible? Will tax have to rise in future to pay for Brown's largesse? Over the next four years, the answer is no. The tax increases needed to pay for this spending growth, which exceeds the rate of growth of the economy, happened in the July 1997 and March 1998 Budgets, and they're being spent not on reducing tax rates and bringing the tax burden back down, but on public services. Ironically, this means the Conservative 'tax guarantee' could probably be delivered in the next Parliament. The Government budget forecast shows the tax burden falling from 39.9 per cent of GDP in 2001-02 to 39.3 per cent in 2004-05. This is still higher than the 37.6, but would be falling in a Parliament running from 2001.

But this shouldn't delude us into thinking that in the long run a policy of increased public spending doesn't mean increased taxation (or for that matter that reduced taxes don't imply reduced spending). It does, and in this case the taxation has already been done. There has been some debate over whether fiscal policy is being tightened or loosened as a result of the Budget. The Treasury's Budget Red Book states that the effect of the policy measures in the Budget is a reduction in the Budget surplus of £4bn in 2000-01, rising to £16bn in 2003-04. That is the equivalent by 2003-04 of the cost of cutting the basic rate of income tax by 5p to 17p. This is a loos ening. It is also true that the Budget surplus is now forecast to be higher in 2000-01 than it was forecast to be for that year in the March 1999 Budget, which suggests policy is tighter now than it was expected to be then. But the important point is that the Budget announces dramatically increased public spending - a loosening of policy.

Where does this leave the Comprehensive Spending Review process, meant to deliver firm three-year spending plans which would 'provide departments with a solid basis for planning'? Eleven months into the first year of the first three-year cycle, the spending plans for year two for health, education, transport and the Home Office have been rewritten, and year three is to become year one of the second spending review. Only half of overall public spending plans were ever covered by the three-year plans, but that now seems to have fallen to just a fifth of government spending - basically defence, agriculture and trade and industry. The annual big spend is back.

This was the health service Budget, and the sums pledged are large. Since overall government spending will rise as a share of national income, education can also expect big increases. The combination of earlier tax increases and a strong economy means this can be paid for by allowing borrowing to rise, not taxes.

 Andrew Dilnot is Director, and Carl Emmerson a senior research economist, at the Institute for Fiscal Studies

fields.headline: Students still feel the pinch
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Alastair McKenzie is in his third year studying English at Southampton university. He does not yet have a career mapped out although he is interested in e-business and was enthusiastic about the promotion of internet technology. He said: 'The tax breaks are definitely a good idea because a lot of people I know have got ideas for e-commerce and have tried to start things.' He set up a short-term business six months ago, promoting health clubs around the area and explained: 'I wasn't using the internet at the time but for any future ideas it is becoming more important.'
fields.body:
Alastair McKenzie is in his third year studying English at Southampton university. He does not yet have a career mapped out although he is interested in e-business and was enthusiastic about the promotion of internet technology. He said: 'The tax breaks are definitely a good idea because a lot of people I know have got ideas for e-commerce and have tried to start things.' He set up a short-term business six months ago, promoting health clubs around the area and explained: 'I wasn't using the internet at the time but for any future ideas it is becoming more important.'

He approved of the amount of money going to education, especially as it is going straight to the head teachers, but he could see no help for students in the Budget: 'There is a still a major gripe at universities about fees but the £1 billion going into education is all being spent on primary and secondary schools.'

He felt that the Budget was consistent in trying to stop people smoking but believes the increase in petrol is disproportionate to the amount they are spending on public transport and roads. 'At the moment, it is big financial figures and it is difficult to see exactly how it is going to affect everyone.'

He cynically concluded: 'It was a vote-winning budget in terms of the NHS but what people will remember is petrol and fags.'

webTitle: Means-testing by another name for poorer pensioners

fields.headline: Means-testing by another name for poorer pensioners
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Consider the case of two elderly neighbours. Before retiring, one worked for a company long enough to qualify for a modest pension, well under £10 a week. When added to his basic state pension, a few pounds from the state top-up scheme Serps, his income is a little over £75. He saved as best he could during his working life and has just over £8,000 in the building society.
fields.body:
Consider the case of two elderly neighbours. Before retiring, one worked for a company long enough to qualify for a modest pension, well under £10 a week. When added to his basic state pension, a few pounds from the state top-up scheme Serps, his income is a little over £75. He saved as best he could during his working life and has just over £8,000 in the building society.

His neighbour had similar jobs before he retired and a similar income, but there was no company pension scheme available. And he had a larger family and found it more difficult to save. He has savings of just under £3,000 and his only income is from the basic state pension, which pays him just over £67. He qualifies, therefore, for income support which tops up his state pension to £75 and enables him to receive a range of free services from the state.

Neighbour number one feels understandably sore that his savings of just over £8,000 and his company pension, which he helped to pay for himself, mean that he is no better off than the man next door.

One of the most significant announcements in the Budget was aimed at tackling this sort of unfairness.

It is a decade since the Government changed the rules on the amounts that people on low incomes can have in savings before they lose entitlement to income support. The rules assume that people are earning a lot more interest on their savings than they are; a ludicrous 20 per cent in fact.

So the Chancellor has listened to Cash's call for reform and announced an increase in the £8,000 figure to £12,000 and a doubling in the lower threshold - below which savings are ignored entirely - from £3,000 to £6,000. In a penny-pinching move, the change will not come into effect for another 12 months. Nevertheless it is welcome and the Government is to publish a report on other ways that pensioners who just miss out on income support can be helped.

This issue is becoming urgent because there has been a fundamental shift in the way the state deals with the income of pensioners. The Conservative government started to run down the basic state pension by cutting its link to earnings. Labour recognised the increasing poverty of pensioners reliant entirely on the state by introducing what it calls the Minimum Income Guarantee. This is means-tested pension provision by another name; pensioners who have no more to live on than the basic state pension now have their income topped up to a minimum level. But pensioners must claim for this entitlement. Since more than 750,000 are already failing to claim for income support, a publicity campaign is called for.

None of this may seem relevant to younger generations. But it is. You are likely to need a private pension fund, from one of the new stakeholder pensions or another type of private scheme, of tens of thousands of pounds to produce an income that will do more than the state would have done had you not saved. If it does not address this problem, the message the Government is sending to today's savers is 'Why bother?'

Don Cruikshank, the man the Government put in charge of unearthing the truth behind the profitability of our banks, did not disappoint when he delivered his report last Monday. And he was back later in the week expressing his fear that the Government may be planning a weak response.

The Treasury was so disturbed that it rushed out affirmations of its resolve.

Cruickshank has shown himself to be more than a match for the wily banks.

Now it is up to the Government to deliver.

webTitle: Nurse welcomes extra NHS cash but may still lose out

fields.headline: Nurse welcomes extra NHS cash but may still lose out
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Tamsin Grant of Liphook in Hampshire is a nurse and pleased about the extra money going to the NHS: 'I work in Accident and Emergency. We have been asking for assistance for quite a while; sometimes patients have to stay in the department inappropriately overnight because there are no beds available in the wards. We are not equipped for that and don't have the staff to cope.'
fields.body:
Tamsin Grant of Liphook in Hampshire is a nurse and pleased about the extra money going to the NHS: 'I work in Accident and Emergency. We have been asking for assistance for quite a while; sometimes patients have to stay in the department inappropriately overnight because there are no beds available in the wards. We are not equipped for that and don't have the staff to cope.'

But she is cautious in her support: 'Like everything, you have to be a little sceptical and wait for the changes to filter down. We want the money where it is needed, right in the wards. We will have to wait for that. If they use the money wisely and create more beds, I will be pleased.'

Apart from that, she feels she has done badly from the Budget. She is married to Martin and has two children, Megan two-and-a-half and Joshua, five.

She said: 'The abolition of the married couple's allowance and mortgage interest tax relief makes a big difference to us and we will lose out heavily on those two things.

'The changes they have put in place, such as income tax coming down by 1p and higher child benefit, will not balance them out.'

She needs a 1600cc car because of her mileage and the best she can find from the Budget is that petrol increases are not as bad as they could have been.

She is not in a position to take advantage of the higher Isa limits: 'I have £3,000 in a small cash Isa but, with a family, we are going to have to use the money. It is unlikely that I will be able to put any money into an Isa next year.'

fields.headline: Can the NHS be cured?
fields.standfirst:
Brown signalled an unprecedented boost for the health service. But, Anthony Browne reports, doubts remain as to whether the patient is out of danger
The future of the NHS: special report
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Brown signalled an unprecedented boost for the health service. But, Anthony Browne reports, doubts remain as to whether the patient is out of danger
fields.body:
Dr Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, knew what his reaction was going to be. He had seen it all before. He wrote a draft press release declaring his disappointment and then sat down in his ornate offices with an air of resignation to watch the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, deliver his fourth Budget.

But the press release never went out. As soon as Brown sat down, Bogle ripped it up and started again. 'We saw more money than we ever envisaged. It was really exciting,' he said. The final press release began with the words: 'We are delighted. 'Bogle jumped in a taxi to meet the other heads of the medical profession who had watched the Budget on television in the office of the Health Secretary, Alan Milburn. Milburn had phoned them that morning to ask them along to Richmond House.

The assembled heads of the royal colleges had no idea what to expect when they sat down with Department of Health tea and biscuits to watch the Budget. But as Brown announced the biggest ever increase in spending on the NHS - with straightforward figures and no double counting - they were stunned into silence. Professor Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, banged the table with excitement.

Brown had announced not just an extra £2bn for the NHS this year, but a sustained increase of 6 per cent above the rate of inflation for the next four years. The amount spent on health would rise from £1,850 per household last year, to £2,800 per household in 2004, bringing it within striking distance of the much-vaunted European average.

But the medical leaders were quickly left in no doubt that the money would come with strings attached. As soon as Brown had delivered the Budget, Milburn rushed back from Parliament to brief them about how he and the Prime Minister wanted their help in drawing up plans to modernise the NHS, to make sure that the money was not just poured down a bottomless pit.

They then left for Downing Street, where Tony Blair reiterated the message: 'We've given you the resources, now deliver the modernisation.' Blair was enlisting the help of the doctors, nurses and managers in what he sees as a battle for the survival of the NHS. If they do not succeed, those that want to privatise it almost certainly will.

The winter crisis had made clear beyond any doubt that the under-resourced and often chaotic NHS was costing lives. The horror stories came to light daily, but it was poor Mavis Skeet whose plight symbolised all that was wrong with the NHS. Because of the shortage of beds, her cancer operation was cancelled four times before her doctors declared her condition was inoperable.

The crisis in the NHS wasn't just eroding Labour's poll ratings, but also public support for the state-funded, free-at-the-point-of-access health system that had once been Britain's pride. The Conservatives, and increasing numbers of doctors, declared the present system beyond repair, and urged the promotion of private medicine. Patients voted with their wallets, and went private in rapidly growing numbers.

Blair realised that without radical measures, he would go down in history as the Prime Minister who pledged to save the NHS, but ended up destroying it.

The winter crisis had given a sense of urgency to the plans, but Ministers and their officials had been working on them since last autumn. Milburn, then Chief Secretary to the Treasury, was drawing up government-wide spending plans until 2004. But he had previously been a junior Health Minister - and his partner is an NHS consultant - and he knew that it would be impossible to modernise the NHS without dramatically increasing resources.

Eventually, Downing Street and Brown came round to Milburn's argument. When Blair promised to David Frost on TV in January that Labour would increase health spending up to European levels, it was no slip of the tongue. The only reason his spokesman then officially downgraded it to an 'aspiration' was that they did not want to be forced into giving the whole game away.

In what amounts to a dramatic mid-term relaunch of health policy, Blair outlined his plans to Parliament the day after the Budget. It was the first time that he had personally made an announcement to Parliament on a domestic spending issue. Blair was to chair a new Cabinet committee on modernising the NHS, with six new task forces in the Department of Health tackling issues ranging from professional development to patient empowerment. The task forces, staffed by representatives of NHS managers, doctors, nurses and patients, have been given four months to come up with plans to drag the worst performing parts of the health service up to the standards of the best performing.

The medical profession was as stunned by the fact they were being asked - rather than told - what to do, as they were by the extra cash. 'It's a method of working we thought no government would try,' said Bogle. 'But the other way, of "let's bang the profession on the head", just hasn't worked. It took them three years to see the light, but at least they did.'

Behind it lies a shrewd political calculation. By giving so much extra cash, Blair has made it impossible for health workers to claim they cannot modernise because of lack of resources. 'It makes things possible,' admitted Alberti. 'Without the money it would have been extremely difficult.' By bringing the health professionals on board, he is making them jointly responsible for the success of NHS rescue plans.

The doctors and managers are under no illusions about the scale of the task. The variation in performance between health authorities and hospitals can be startling - and almost inexplicable. While some hospitals have no one waiting more than six months, others have more than half their patients waiting that long. In some hospitals, consultants are doing half the number of operations as in others.

It's already clear that any improvements will take time - and there will be few instant results.  Last year, in-patient waiting lists were cut by 50 per cent in some hospitals, but rose by 3 per cent in others.

fields.headline: Sterling effort threatens more jobs
fields.standfirst:
Depite Gordon Brown's rhetoric, the Budget marked a loosening of fiscal policy, and that's just the problem, says William Keegan. It means the pound is destined to remain too high

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Depite Gordon Brown's rhetoric, the Budget marked a loosening of fiscal policy, and that's just the problem, says William Keegan. It means the pound is destined to remain too high
fields.body:
The absent guest from Gordon Brown's Budget party last Tuesday was of course the pound. It rated barely a mention. Nor was there a word about the problems of British industry in general, or Rover, Ford and Harland & Wolff in particular.

Before the Budget the Chancellor had received hints from the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) that a loosening of fiscal policy would imply the need to tighten monetary policy - that is, raise interest rates. And the International Monetary Fund had emphasised the need for a fiscally neutral Budget. Indeed, some IMF directors had argued that fiscal policy needed to be tightened to prevent interest rates and the exchange rate from rising further.

Responding to the Chancellor's Budget speech is one of the most difficult tasks of the year for any Opposition leader. William Hague not only spotted that the pound was the dog that did not bark during the Budget speech, he drew attention to the revelation in the Budget Report that the balance of payments deficit on current account was forecast to rise from nothing in 1998 via £15.5 billion in 1999 to £28bn by 2002.

This trend, rather like the troubles at Rover et al , rather gives the lie to fashionable rationalisations that British industry is happily adjusting to living with a strong pound.

The report itself shows that the volume of UK exports rose by a mere 2.5 per cent last year, compared with a 7.25 per cent surge in imports. During the fourth quarter of 1999, which officials hope was exceptional, exports fell at an annual rate of 10 per cent, and imports rose at an annual rate of 11 per cent.

The deteriorating trend spotted by Hague is forecast to take place despite official estimates that exports will recover rapidly this year. Thus, according to the report, while imports are expected to continue apace (rising by 8 per cent in volume this year) exports are expected to rebound from 2.5 per cent growth in 1999 to around 6 per cent growth this year, even though the average value of the pound rose by 7 per cent during 1999, and has edged higher since.

Immediately below its export forecasts, the Treasury conceded: 'There are clear downside risks to the outlook. Despite improvements in Europe and elsewhere, global demand remains heavily reliant on the US economy [one of the UK's main export markets] which would falter if equity values fell sharply.'

This is a diplomatic way of saying: 'If, as many fear, Wall Street crashes.'

The Treasury goes on: 'Persistent strength in sterling might also lead to a sharper fall in UK exporters' market share and stronger imports.'

In other words, even the the present forecasts, which predict cumulative balance of payments deficits totalling an alarming £75bn in the three years 2000, 2001 and 2002, are postulated on the assumption of some devaluation of sterling over the period.

The Treasury is more worried about the high pound than it has publicly let on, whereas the Bank of England has been increasingly frank about its concerns. But the pound has strengthened since the MPC went public on the subject last summer.

Influencing the level of the exchange rate is not in the MPC's brief, which is simply to achieve an inflation target of 2.5 per cent. Governor Eddie George has told the Parliamentary Treasury Committee that, if the Chancellor wanted him to address the exchange rate directly, it would have to 'change my marching orders'.

In the minutes of its meeting for March, the MPC states: 'More might now need to be done to slow the pace of domestic demand growth.' But in deciding to do nothing this month, some MPC members cited the view that 'a rise in interest rates risked pushing up the market's interest rate expectations and hence sterling - which would exacerbate the imbalances in the economy and push inflation further below target in the short run.'

With Parliamentary committees showing increasing interest in the possibility of policy changes which would target the exchange rate, the Budget Report states categorically: 'However, attempting to target both the inflation rate and exchange rate in the short term would lead back to the policies that caused past economic instability.'

Without stating the mechanism by which the goal is achieved, the report adds: 'Maintaining low inflation and sound public finances is essential to secure a stable and competitive exchange rate in the medium term.'

The Chancellor declared he believed in 'a stable and competitive exchange rate' on the day (6 May 1997) that he anounced he was handing over operational responsibility for monetary policy to the Bank. Since then, the exchange rate has gone up and up. The crucial sterling/mark rate averaged DM2.84 in 1997, and has been between DM3.15 and 3.25 so far this year. There is great sensitivity about all this among the Chancellor's advisers. To suggestions that all would have been better if they had run a tighter fiscal policy, they reply that this has been tightened to the tune of £40bn (or between 4 and 5 per cent of gross domestic product) since 1997.

'If we had said in mid-1997 that such a tightening of fiscal policy would be followed by an appreciation of the pound, no one would have believed us,' says one senior official.

This does not necessarily deal with the point, however. The tightening has come partly from the prolonged public spending freeze, and partly from so-called 'stealth taxes'.

Although the Government complained that the inflationary outlook was deteriorating when it took office, its disavowal of an active fiscal policy meant it was not prepared to raise direct or consumer taxes to cool the consumer boom. The Treasury effectively relies on the MPC to manage demand for it. And the instrument, the rate of interest, that is used to cool the economy also makes London a more attractive place to hold funds, contributing to the strong exchange rate.

The Treasury notes that the pound has actually fallen againsty the dollar - from around $1.62 last year to $1.58 in mid-March - and that the problem has been the relationship with the euro.

For all the fashionable derision of the euro as a weak currency, that weakness has done the euroland economies a power of good. There is a strong suspicion in Whitehall that the continentals are perfectly happy with this.

Meanwhile, behind the Chancellor's success with fiscal policy and inflation is an awful lot of potential instability in UK industry. Ask the workers of the West Midlands.

fields.headline: Hawks fly high
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: While lobbyists and pressure groups spent last week puzzling over the effects of the Budget, one group were feeling unambiguously pleased with themselves: the monetary hawks.
fields.body:
While lobbyists and pressure groups spent last week puzzling over the effects of the Budget, one group were feeling unambiguously pleased with themselves: the monetary hawks.

Gordon Brown's plans to spend £4 billion on the NHS, schools, transport and crime prevention may have warmed Labour's heartlands, but it has also allowed those who predicted interest rates peaking some way higher than the City's 6.5 per cent consensus this year to say 'told you so'.

The mood among British manufacturers, however, was not so frothy. From Brown's speech last Tuesday, they could be forgiven for thinking industry had been forgotten amid the flood of public spending and reams of small business-friendly measures. Brown didn't even mention the strong pound, Longbridge or the euro.

Kate Barker, chief economist at the Confederation of British Industry, says: 'It confirms the view that many people have, which is that they don't care about manufacturing.'

Dougie Peedle, economist at the Engineering Employers Federation, says public spending, combined with a Budget deficit the Government forecasts as slumping from a £12bn surplus this year to a £13bn deficit in 2005, will 'end up fuelling inflation, higher interest rates and, we fear, lead to a higher pound'.

Fears about increases in interest rates are confirmed by City economists. David Walton, UK economist at Goldman Sachs, says: 'It is very unusual for us to make any changes on the back of a Budget, but this is a much greater fiscal easing than we would have expected.'

He points to increases in total Government spending of 5 per cent next year, followed by 3.1 per cent and 2.5 per cent. 'This will boost domestic demand. Given that the MPC seems quite keen to see a slow-down in demand, they are likely to react.' His forecast for the interest rate peak increases from 6.25 per cent to 6.5 per cent.

More hawkish commentators say the Budget confirms their views. Barclays Capital's David Hillier says his 6.5 per cent forecast now looks more likely than before Tuesday.

Richard Jeffrey of CCF Charterhouse, whose prediction is 7 per cent, says: 'It is now more likely that interest rates will have to go even higher.'

Extreme hawk Danny Gabay of JP Morgan - his forecast is 7.25 per cent - says: 'Our figure looks more likely now.'

But Garry Young, of the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, disagrees. He says the Chancellor has actually confirmed his credentials for prudence by keeping spending within the totals allowed by his 'golden rule' - not to borrow to fund current expenditure.

'The markets will see that government borrowing has stayed within the golden rule. If Brown had been tighter, I am not sure he would have been believed.'

NIESR's 6.5 per cent interest rate target is likely to stay unchanged - or even be revised down.

Despite the generally hawkish consensus, there is, as both Hillier and Gabay point out, a crucial conundrum at the heart of the Budget. It centres on whether Treasury calculations of future tax revenues are correct, or whether they are overoptimistic. On this depend the levels of both interest rates and, manufacturers fear, the pound.

On one hand the Chancellor's largesse - which totals £3.3bn after social security and other savings are taken into account - is likely to stoke demand. On the other, the Treasury claims this will be tempered by consumers having to pay more tax. It forecasts revenues rising by £12bn next year, £10bn in 2001-02, then £7bn, then down to £3bn. This is what underlies Brown's claim that the Budget is tighter.

But economists are asking whether this improvement in revenues is structural - caused by fundamental changes in the economy which make them permanent - as the Treasury claims. If it is, the interest rate view could be perhaps too hawkish.

But if it is not, if it is cyclical - revenue rising because growth is generating more wealth to be taxed - then demand is less likely to be tempered, and revenues will slump when the economy turns down. If the latter is the case, rates need to rise.

But the fact is, the proof will not emerge until we hit a slowdown and revenues fall off. For now, economists are clearly sceptical of the Treasury's claims. By the time we find out, it may be too late for many manufacturers.

fields.headline: Prudent - or just predictable?
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: When the details of this year's Budget have slipped from the memory - and, let's face it, some have already - one will never forget the way the Chancellor of the Exchequer announced that the Prime Minister would be giving chapter and verse on the new health plans. It was for all the world as if Tony Blair were a junior colleague.
fields.body:
When the details of this year's Budget have slipped from the memory - and, let's face it, some have already - one will never forget the way the Chancellor of the Exchequer announced that the Prime Minister would be giving chapter and verse on the new health plans. It was for all the world as if Tony Blair were a junior colleague.

The following morning Blair told the BBC's Today programme that it was not an ignoble ambition for the Chancellor to want to be Prime Minister. This called to mind a rumour going the rounds before the Budget that Gordon Brown was deliberately keeping all the economic goodies back for another term, so that he would get the credit as the eventual Prime Minister.

I've heard many a conspiracy theory about New Labour, but this one took the biscuit. For all the putative difficulties in their relationship, Blair and Brown are in this together. Minor pieces of infighting are neither here nor there. If New Labour were for some reason to lose its hard-won reputation for economic competence, Brown and Blair would both go down with the ship.

They took a potentially big risk in the price they - and we - paid for their bid to be deemed financially prudent. Many of the problems they are now trying to deal with in the health service arose because of the two-year freeze on public spending. To please the financial markets, and to stop the skeletons of Labour's history from rattling in the cupboard, they ignored the message the British electorate gave the Conservatives in May 1997: that we wanted better public services. We felt entitled to them; and we knew from our travels that they were achievable.

Those of us who have been campaigning for more funds for the health service can only welcome this central aspect of the Budget. But the consequence of the earlier freeze is that problems have piled up. If it were not for the state of the Conservative Party, I should say that New Labour had left it perilously late to reap the fruits of its 'Prudence for a Purpose' - described by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy as 'spending for a second term'.

One of the ironies of the period since mid-1997 is that, as if the freeze and the strictly limited growth plans were not bad enough, Whitehall departments proceeded to underspend. They surprised even the Treasury.

In the old days governments certainly knew how to spend. Whitehall practice was to find out how much departments intended to spend, examine the likely trend of the trade balance over the following 12 months, and then see what was left for the consumer. The Treasury published a table showing the desired path of consumer spending. If the forecasts indicated that, without budgetary action, consumer spending would be 'excessive', the object of the Budget was to rein it back.

These days the consumer is king. When the combination of the public-spending freeze and a deteriorating export trend was depressing economic growth in 1998-99 - with the result that it looked as though the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) would undershoot its 2.5 per cent inflation target - the Bank deliberately took action to stimulate consumer demand. And how. A common theme of the Budget Report and the latest MPC minutes (for March) is that the pace of growth of consumer demand, and house prices, remains too strong for comfort. But controlling that is now the job of the MPC.

This consumer boom coincides with the increases in public spending which were budgeted for the latter half of this Parliament. Last week's boost to health and education spending comes on top. For all the trumpeting, all we have reached is a position in which public spending as a whole is from now on scheduled to grow in line with the underlying growth rate in the economy of 2.5 per cent.

Brown is emerging as a very eclectic Chancellor. He arrived in office wanting to raise productivity, redistribute income, and return us to full-employment. In some ways he resembles Sir Geoffrey Howe (Chancellor 1979-83) in his obsession with encouraging enterprise and small business.

He is so coy about sounding Old Labour, though, that, when asked about redistribution, he tells the BBC: 'We're redistributing to entrepreneurs by the capital gains tax... we're putting money into entrepreneurs.' Only then can he relax and add: 'We're putting money into tackling child poverty.'

The Institute for Fiscal Studies agrees that Brown's Budgets have largely helped the poorer sections of the population.

But the 'redistribution' has been decidedly limited, with most of the Thatcher/ Howe/Lawson tax reforms for the rich still firmly in place. And the view of accountants last week was that much of the Budget largesse aimed at encouraging new entrepreneurs was in fact going to benefit existing 'fat cats'.

Perhaps this is what the Chancellor means by a 'wealth-owning democracy'. Industry did not get much joy out of this Budget, and the pound remains disturbingly high. For all its merits the Budget did not address this central threat to the government's entire economic and European strategy.

fields.headline: War-chest of pirate treasure
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown's ship has come in, and it's loaded with bullion. Is he spending it lavishly enough?

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's budget was a  Labour budget, one of its behind-the-scenes architects informed me. And it was good. It directed substantial new cash at Britain's poorest working families; it raised real spending next year on health and education by 8 and 9 per cent respectively. It promised big increases in health for the years afterwards that will surely be matched in education.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's budget was a Labour budget, one of its behind-the-scenes architects informed me. And it was good. It directed substantial new cash at Britain's poorest working families; it raised real spending next year on health and education by 8 and 9 per cent respectively. It promised big increases in health for the years afterwards that will surely be matched in education.

And in choosing the Budget speech, the hallowed text devoted only to taxation, to announce a gigantic £2 billion of extra funding for the NHS, the Chancellor could not have made a more dramatic statement of Labour's political preferences. Labour prefers to spend cash on improving the quality of public services to tax cuts. The Tories do not. It is a politically defining moment.

More than that, Brown is doing two things that have needlessly eluded the British Left for too long. He combines a political position at once sympathetic to entrepreneurship and business-building with a concern for social justice.

The social-democratic Left's position has always been that the dynamism of capitalism should be harnessed for the common good; that not only can you be simultaneously in favour both of making money and redistributing it, but that successful public services and help for the disadvantaged are predicated upon such capitalist vitality. Brown is living political proof that the syllogism works.

And he has built up such a strong financial position that he is able to turn on the spending tap in Year Four of a parliament, unlike every other post-war Labour chancellor who has to had to launch painful spending cuts at this stage in the parliament. Moreover he has not had to soak the rich and middle classes to fund his ambitions. It is good, even very good; and it is hard to believe that the country can seriously contemplate electing the Tories, with their infantile approach to taxation and public spending, in Labour's place.

But if the central strategy is on the button, there are qualifications and reservations around the edges that explain why so many have had such serious doubts about New Labour. For a start Brown, for the third year running, has been dramatically caught out disguising the lusty health of the public finances in the name of prudence. This time last year he said he would borrow £3bn in the financial year just ending, a forecast that looked implausibly pessimistic at the time; in the event he has repaid £12bn of the national debt.

He is congratulated for his probity - yet if the Treasury's forecasting had been remotely accurate the big build-up in public spending could have started a year ago. Financial 'prudence' has taken precedence over real lives. For some children in sink schools and NHS patients, that's a lost year which can never be brought back, and which so easily could have been avoided.

This time round we're asked to believe it's different, and that the combination of a big build-up in capital investment, growing by 33 per cent a year, and the projected increases in health spending will see the Government ceasing to pay off the national debt in 2002.

As for prudence, even if the economy grows 1 per cent a year less rapidly than the cautious central forecast of 2.25 per cent a year assumed by the Treasury, we needn't worry our heads. The surpluses will still be high enough for the Government to meet its own criteria for financial caution - already the toughest of any leading industrialised country.

Extraordinarily this understates Brown's strength, to which he will still not admit. Only on Friday the auction of the next generation of mobile phone licences had raised £4.5bn; when completed next month the auction will raise £10bn - at least £7.5bn more than Brown has included in the budget projections. Not since Drake's Golden Hind moored in the pool of London laden with Spanish gold has any British government been as unexpectedly rich as this.

What this means, amazingly, is that Brown could do much, much more. He could index the growth of social security benefits to wages rather than the much lower growth in prices. He could scrap the disabling Private Finance Initiative, which has so shrunk the size of new hospitals for example, and relegitimise public-private partnerships by putting the public sector in the financial driving seat in deals with the private sector. Cuts in incapacity benefit could be restored. The scope for jury trial could be extended rather than narrowed, and the capacity of Britain's creaking courts doubled. The science budget could be made the most generous in Europe. The road and rail system could be made world-class. And with never a further rise in any tax rate.

So far only the NHS has been formally allowed to share in the bounty. Health expenditure is set to rise for the three years after next by 5.6 per cent in real terms, to give a four-year increase of 6.1 per cent - three times the real growth in NHS spending between 1992 and 1998.

Although education spending is slated to fall back again next year, according to the old forecasts, the inside steer is to expect the growth in edu cation spending to match health. But if we are to believe Brown's numbers, the implication is that the rest of the public sector will continue to be squeezed - with current spending on housing, law and order, transport and the rest only growing by 1.6 per cent in real terms to allow for the growth in health and education.

If Brown does allow such a squeeze, his only let-out will be that the economy will have got so close to full capacity that any more spending would be inflationary. But even that argument would be dubious. There is scope to increase taxes, notably reforming council tax so that it becomes a proper progressive tax on property, that would allow increased spending while withdrawing demand from the economy. Brown holds every fiscal ace.

The question-mark is over the scope of his progressive ambition. In this budget, for example, he offered nothing to advance the cause of Lord Roger's urban task force; no taxation of greenfield development - no incentive for brownfield development. He backed off the Cruickshank report's call for regulating the ludicrously high monopoly profits the banks make from operating the cheque-clearing system.

He caved in to Eurosceptics and the City's desire to become the world centre of tax avoidance by the abolition of withholding tax on international bonds. And he has, over the past few months, been less than progressive about both BBC funding and the minimum wage. Not so good.

But the central point stands. Last week we saw why Blair tolerates his brooding Heathcliff of a Chancellor. He delivers. And it takes an obsessive to have the self-discipline and rigour to have put the British Left where it now is. We all have ideas about how we would spend Brown's largesse. But it took Gordon to get us here.

fields.headline: Imagine a health service where...
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: • You can get an appointment with your GP on the day you call
fields.body:
 You can get an appointment with your GP on the day you call

 You can visit a GP either near your home or near work

 You can go to a walk-in clinic anywhere and the doctor can access your medical records on computer

 You have more than six minutes with your GP, so they have time to give you a full explanation and answer your questions

 You can have yearly health check-ups

 You can book an appointment direct with a consultant if you know the general nature of your problem

 You can choose the time of your appointment

 You can choose your consultant and your surgeon

 Operations are never cancelled

 The food in hospital is edible, the toilets are clean, the paint isn't peeling, and the staff aren't harrassed

 You don't have to wait more than half an hour to see a doctor at accident and emergency

 You don't have to spend days waiting on a trolley in a corridor if you are admitted to hospital through accident and emergency

 If you have suspected cancer, you can have a scan and a biopsy the next day

 If you are diagnosed as having cancer, you can start treatment immediately and you are treated by a cancer specialist

 If you have stroke you are treated by a stroke specialist

 If you are you need a heart operation, you are operated on immediately

 If you have a non life-threatening but painful condition such as severe arthritis, you don't have to wait more than three months for an operation

 You aren't denied life-saving treatment, which you would be given if you lived in another health authority.

webTitle: TB risk as flow of vaccine dries up

fields.headline: TB risk as flow of vaccine dries up
fields.standfirst:
Production shortfall leaves high-risk babies vulnerable to resurgent disease

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Medical experts are warning of a tuberculosis epidemic after the collapse of the Government's vaccination programme in parts of the country. An Observer investigation shows some health authorities have even had to cancel immunisation programmes for new babies - regarded as the highest risk group for the deadly infection.
fields.body:
Medical experts are warning of a tuberculosis epidemic after the collapse of the Government's vaccination programme in parts of the country. An Observer investigation shows some health authorities have even had to cancel immunisation programmes for new babies - regarded as the highest risk group for the deadly infection.

TB can be spread by coughs or contaminated food and can lead to coughing up of blood, weight loss, fatigue and night fevers and death. It was once one of Britain's biggest killers.

The number of TB cases has been growing for 10 years and has risen by 24 per cent in parts of London. Doctors are alarmed at the rapid rise of a new drug-resistant strain thought to have come from developing countries. The World Health Organisation recently declared the growth of TB a global emergency, killing two million people a year.

Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham Health Authority in London last week suspended its vaccination programme for babies until the autumn, blaming a shortage of the vaccine and of staff. Dr Donal O'Sullivan, consultant in communicable disease control for Lambeth, Lewisham and Southwark, played down the threat to public health: 'Postponing the vaccine in this way should not have any significant effect on a child's lifetime risk of developing tuberculosis.' However, Dr John Watson, consultant epidemiologist at the Government's Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre, said: 'It is a patch of London where there is a large number of children born in high-risk groups. There is concern. Children will not get the protection we believe they should have, and could get infected.'

The shortage of the vaccine is the result of production problems at the Government's sole supplier, Celltech Medeva. Eighteen months ago the drug company decided to upgrade its factory at Speke in Liverpool but had trouble getting it restarted. Last October the Department of Health suspended routine schools vaccinations to conserve supplies for high-risk groups.

Francis Upchurch, medical director of Celltech Medeva, said they were now solving the problems. 'There should not be a problem with supplies for high-risk groups. It is the first I have heard of it.'

A Department of Health spokesman said: 'We are keeping up pressure on Medeva to sort out supply problems and are actively approaching other suppliers to see if they can help.'

Most TB cases occur among recent immigrants, their families, or among Aids patients, cancer patients, drug addicts and others with suppressed immune systems. It is usually treatable, but 392 people died of it in 1998.

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Longbridge lunacy mustn't kill ideals
fields.trailText: The sound and fury in the West Midlands over the past week has had to be heard to be believed: Stephen Byers, despite our suspicions that he will not be long for the job, is essentially trying to bolt the door even though Dobbin is halfway back to Munich.
fields.body:
The sound and fury in the West Midlands over the past week has had to be heard to be believed: Stephen Byers, despite our suspicions that he will not be long for the job, is essentially trying to bolt the door even though Dobbin is halfway back to Munich.

So far he has had little luck in trying to derail the deal between BMW and Alchemy. The only 'White Knight' is John Hemmings, a West Midlands software millionaire - and Byers has even managed to pair him with John Towers, a former Rover Group chief executive. So whatever happens, it seems Rover or MG Cars will end up in the hands of someone called John - a fine English name.

With BMW reporting its own results this week, we can expect the theme of 'treacherous German dogs' to continue for a few days more. However, it seems that given the lack of other potential buyers, BMW's abrupt exit was all but inevitable, albeit badly handled. That might be a controversial thing to say in the light of the job losses in the West Midlands, but BMW had seen £2 billion go down the swanee before pulling the plug.

What crosses one's mind almost inevitably is whether the kind of abuse and recriminations heaped on BMW, which would appear to be sacrificing even its own independence as a cost of its foolish adventure in the UK mar ket, will be applied to Chris Gent and Vodafone as it takes on the mighty Mannesmann. The view of the German intervention at the time of that disputed deal was that it was completely and utterly arcane and unwelcome. Let the market decide, we cried. I'm afraid that one of the lessons of participating in the global marketplace is that we have to do unto others as we would be done unto ourselves.

This begs the question of how we view nationality when it comes to the ownership of industry. Our view has been that if the playing field is level, we are as unconcerned as the Welsh rugby team about where the players come from. But the downside of international capitalism epitomised by the lessons of Rover: it is always possible for a government to twist the arms of its own citizens when it comes to extracting commercial favours. On the other hand, BMW's Joachim Milberg would be unmoved by the thought of a peerage, even if he were eligible for one.

We have gone too far down the path of preaching the Anglo-Saxonisation of markets to change our minds and switch to a protectionist stance merely because an unprofitable car plant is heinously mismanaged.

But do we need a redefinition of what our industrial policy should be? Given the mixed messages emanating from the DTI over the past year, and given the deafening silence on the subject from the Chancellor in his Budget, I think we could all do with a pre-election reminder of what we are aiming to achieve.

In the short term, of course, Byers would appear to be fully occupied with applying a sticking plaster to a haemorrhage over at Rover.

British Midland should be awarded the right immediately to launch services from Heathrow to the US. Midland may not be the glitziest show in town, but it is a rock solid performer that has done more to increase competition in the UK domestic and European markets than anyone else for 15 years.

It is time the Government and Whitehall stopped acting as British Airways' lackeys and forced BA to face the competition.

fields.headline: The tide turns progressive
fields.standfirst:
The terms of exchange between Right and Left have been reversed. That is the greatest triumph of New Labour

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Some moments in politics are so sensational that everyone misses them. It is a cliché everywhere acknowledged that New Labour will win the next election. Any fool knows, as every wise man also forecasts, that Tony Blair will not only secure that unprecedented second term for a government of the Left, he'll probably do so handsomely. The assumption, widespread before the Budget, has since become even more universal. In the space of three years, what history told us was wildly unlikely has become the confident prediction of every futurologist. The world stands on its head.
fields.body:
Some moments in politics are so sensational that everyone misses them. It is a cliché everywhere acknowledged that New Labour will win the next election. Any fool knows, as every wise man also forecasts, that Tony Blair will not only secure that unprecedented second term for a government of the Left, he'll probably do so handsomely. The assumption, widespread before the Budget, has since become even more universal. In the space of three years, what history told us was wildly unlikely has become the confident prediction of every futurologist. The world stands on its head.

The Right has triumphed at every British general election since before the beginning of my adult life. In 1979, again in 1983, again in 1987, and yet again in 1992, the Left fought with out-dated weapons against an enemy that dictated the battlefield. Like the Polish cavalry charging German Panzers, at every encounter the progressive forces were crushed by the forces of Conservatism. Eventually, a Tory party exhausted, corrupted and divided by all those years in power, and confronted with the brilliant remake called New Labour, finally lost in 1997. Even then, the Left still did not really win.

Oh sure, in terms of giant swings and swags of parliamentary seats, Tony Blair had a smashing, record-booking victory. But New Labour advanced into office by surrendering territory to the Right. The most important promises Tony Blair and Gordon Brown made to gain power were the things they felt compelled to pledge themselves not to do. They would not put up income tax. They would not spend more than the Conservatives in the first two years. Neurotically armouring themselves against Tory tax bombshells, Blair and Brown virtually expunged the word spending from the Left's vocabulary. Any member of the Shadow Cabinet who talked about commitments that would cost any money was told to wash his mouth out with nitric acid.

What a difference 35 months in office makes. New Labour now proudly presents a four-year plan which lavishes upon the National Health Service the largest investment ever received by that cherished creation of Heritage Labour. Blair and Brown, for whom spending was the love that dare not speak its name, become the men who project themselves as the big spenders. And they will be the last of them if all that money does not transform the NHS.

What this should surely squash forever is the puerile assertion that New Labour is indistinguishable from Old Tories. In that fantasy universe in which a Conservative government was re-elected in 1997, the health service would never have received such an intensive injection. What made the Budget a doubly defining moment in the reshaping of the political landscape is the response from the Tories. It is now they who feel compelled to mimic New Labour. William Hague is obliged to declare that he 'unambiguously' welcomes the increased sums for health - and for education as well. The roles are reversed. Tony Blair felt he could only win the last election by binding himself to Tory spending plans. As the shadow of the next election casts itself over him, William Hague concludes he has to sign up to Labour's spending plans.

This is a massive change in the terms of political trade in favour of the Left. And it isn't the only shift in the centre of gravity. Since he became Shadow Chancellor, Michael Portillo, the great Right hope, has spent his time conceding ground to the Left. His singular contribution to the development of a Tory programme has been to adopt New Labour policies. The minimum wage and the social chapter, which not so long ago the quiffed one predicted would throw millions out of work, are now accepted by the Conservatives. The independent Bank of England - they have swallowed that, too. I forecast that they will also be forced to follow where Labour leads on child tax credits and pensioner income guarantees.

That the Tories are being impelled on to New Labour's territory is the greatest compliment that could be paid to the strategy pursued by the Prime Minister and Chancellor. The prudence of the early life of this Government always had the political purpose of laying the ground for the next election. Their first priority for the first Labour government in 18 years was to prove that it could manage the national finances competently. That was the essential foundation for building public support for progressive values.

The Tory's killer contention - that only the Right can be trusted with the economy - had to be exploded. Prove that people's money can be effectively and efficiently spent. Then rehabilitate the case for properly funded public services. You can quarrel with some of the tactics. The early spending corset turns out to have been drawn tighter than was strictly necessary. But a much worse outcome would have been to repeat the mistake of every previous Labour government. They splurged to begin with, lost the confidence of the markets and the public, and were then forced to slash and burn their natural supporters in the run up to the next election. This is the first Labour government that has arranged the fat years to coincide with the campaign for re-election.

The fogs of spin and rhetoric clear and the battle lines of that contest become defined. I wouldn't be surprised if there were a few tax sweeteners in the pre-election Budget. But Blair and Brown have made the broad and significant decision not to get into a Dutch auction of tax-cutting with the Tories. So the next election will be fought between a Labour Party which believes in active government and public services, and a Conservative Party arguing for shrinking the state and slashing taxes.

It is a familiar tableau, but only superficially so. There is a crucial difference with past elections. This time, the battlefield has been prepared to the advantage of the Left. Thanks to Gordon Brown's careful stewardship of the economy, there is much less juice in the Tory argument that the Left can't be trusted with the people's money. This doesn't mean that there can be any relaxation in the drive to prove that when the Government spends, it does so shrewdly and well. That is why Tony Blair has been at such great pains to tell the NHS that the price for greatly increased resources must be sweeping reform.

New Labour - the modernisers - versus the Tories - the privatisers. That will be the pitch.

Here's another of the election slogans that New Labour is already road-testing with the focus groups: 'Public services for the many, not tax cuts for the few'. The large question at elections is: 'Where is the money coming from?' Interviewers used to paralyse Labour spokespeople by demanding how they would pay for their reckless spending plans. Today, it is Tory Shadowpersons who thrash and gulp whenever pressed to explain what they will cut to fund their crazy tax plans.

It is the Right which is fiscally confused, intellectually demoralised and in ragged retreat. Fantastically unpopular as well. For the first time in a generation, it is the Left which is making the advances in the minds as well as the hearts of the electorate. Just for a moment, raise your gaze from the diverting daily froth and bubble about whether Tony will take time off to change the Blair babe's nappies. Look out to the ocean. There you will see that we are living through a sea change in British politics.

fields.headline: The wrong briefs
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It is a cliché to say that lawyers make dangerous politicians, but hard times have a depressing tendency to prove the truth of platitudes. The assaults on trial by jury, the interning of asylum seekers (which treats the genuine victims of the world's greatest crimes as criminals) and the attack on legal aid for the working and lower-middle classes are being organised by the lawyerly élite which dominates New Labour.
fields.body:
It is a cliché to say that lawyers make dangerous politicians, but hard times have a depressing tendency to prove the truth of platitudes. The assaults on trial by jury, the interning of asylum seekers (which treats the genuine victims of the world's greatest crimes as criminals) and the attack on legal aid for the working and lower-middle classes are being organised by the lawyerly élite which dominates New Labour.

The barrister directors of UK plc include Tony Blair and the First Lady, Jack Straw, Lord Falconer of the Dismal Dome and a friend of the Prime Minister since childhood, and - as if we could forget - His Eminence, Cardinal Irvine, the Lord High Chancellor of all England (and Wales, too), who was the head of Tony's and Cherie's chambers when they were bright-eyed young briefs.

'Lawyer' is not a particularly illuminating word in this context. We need to be specific. As in other professions, the explosion of income inequality since the 1970s has produced staggering divisions in the law. A solicitor in Rochdale on a salary of £40,000 who helps battered wives and defends petty suspects has nothing common with a £1-million-a-year partner in Herbert Smith or Clifford Chance. The commercial lawyers of the City of London and Inns of Court have not learned the hard way that a citizen must be presumed innocent until found guilty beyond reasonable doubt by a jury of his peers. They have never cross-examined a lying policeman or seen jurors bristle when a biased judge rants. Their training is in tax liabilities, not civil liberties.

Needless to say, the Government's lawyers are commercial lawyers, as are the Law Lords the unelected Irvine appoints to guard our human rights. It was at the Commercial Court that Irvine acquired the deep gravitas and awesome bottom which allowed him to boast he was the reincarnation of 'Cardinal Wolsey' running a 'hugely important' 'Star Chamber' that determined the legislative programme.

He made a small fortune representing Mohamed al- Fayed and Hong Kong businesses. Occasionally, he drew admiring purrs from legal London by hitting that revered £1-million-a year target. But as Dominic Egan writes in his spirited biography ( Irvine , Mainstream Publishing), one of the 'huge myths about Irvine's legal career _ is that [he] was one of the best barristers in the business'. He was good - you do not accumulate a hoard of Sickerts, Spencers and Nashes if you're a dunderhead. Yet there was too much pomp about him, too great an anxiety to stick to a plan he had sweated over in advance, for Irvine to be a great advocate. Unexpected evidence could throw him, as his nimbler courtroom rivals knew.

His Eminence never matched the skills or fees of the super-rich silks. A successful barrister working for a corporate client will make a paltry £350-£500 an hour. Anthony Grabiner and the other stars of the Bar receive £800 (excluding extras), the Lawyer magazine reported. 'Your case must be worth at least £100m if you want to instruct this lot,' one of their clerks said. Grabiner was ennobled by New Labour. He makes £200 more in an hour than the minimum wage delivers in a month. The House of Lords, his chambers and the Hendon Golf and Garrick clubs where he passes his days are as far as one can imagine from the miseries of life in the slums.

Last year, the Tories demanded it should be made more miserable still in their unhinged Common Sense Revolution. The black economy must be restricted by forcing the unemployed to sign on every day. The workless who lived miles from a benefit office would see a slice of their tiny incomes frittered away on bus fares. All would waste time when they might be looking for a job.

New Labour responded with a rare Left critique. Jeff Rooker, Labour's Social Security Minister, said daily reporting to the DSS was 'right-wing madness'. On 26 October, David Blunkett was asked in the Commons if he could cost the petty piece of viciousness. He could: 25,000 staff would have to be hired at a cost of £400m a year. Two days later, Blunkett revealed that the price of howling Conservatism was rising by the minute. 'It would cost £540m a year,' he replied to a second planted question. The money could be far better spent giving the unemployed the 'skills necessary to hold down jobs'.

On 9 November, Gordon Brown transformed insanity into prudence with a wave of his jowls. He announced an investigation of welfare fraud to discover if claimants suspected of - but not convicted of - working illegally should be forced to report daily. Lord Grabiner, New Labour's new peer, was ready to oblige him.

Many lawyers say that Grabiner is a brilliant barrister and a pleasant fellow. I found him an open and engaging man when he returned a call. When all the polite caveats have been made, however, he has produced a weak piece of work. He says that those suspected of fraud should report regularly to benefit offices, but he doesn't say how often or answer Blunkett's worries.

What motivates him is a determination to hit fraud hard. Now fraud discredits the welfare state. It allowed the Sun to scream 'Fleeced: The Scandal of Britain's Scroungers and Dole Cheats' when Grabiner's report was released earlier this month. (The paper didn't mention that its owner, Rupert Murdoch, who also controls the Times , Sunday Times , News of the World and BSkyB, has employed the best tax lawyers around and left his simple readers to find the £1.4 billion of British corporation tax he has dodged since 1988.)

Grabiner says that a survey by the Benefit Office estimated that 120,000 were working while claiming benefit - although most, presumably, were not netting £800 an hour. Estimates of fraud are notoriously vague. In 1997, the DSS asserted regularly that one in eight disabled people was on the fiddle. A Benefit Integrity Project scared tens of thousands by ordering them to submit to new medical examinations. At the end of a year of prying, not one scrounger had been uncovered.

Even if his estimates are rightish, doesn't the case still have to be proved? Apparently not. Offenders on probation will lose all benefits when they are accused of breaking court orders. Grabiner will order claimants to benefit offices when they are suspected of being frauds. Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised by the lazy authoritarianism. The principles of the presumption of innocence and trial by jury are not in the bones of the Blairite briefs. Why should we expect them to know how to behave?

New Labour abolishes the pound
They're coming. The grasping foreigners. The economic migrants. The sly ones who suck money out of old England, send it abroad and laugh behind their hands at us all the way to their bank.

Not asylum-seekers, but Sodexho, the French company which will begin on All Fools' Day printing and distributing the 50p, £1 and £5 vouchers that compose the Asylo, Europe's newest and most debased coinage .

Sodexho will not reveal how much profit it will make. Jack Straw showed the hauteur of a Eurocrat when he told the Commons that the payments to Sodexho from public funds were a secret. ('The contractual details are commercially confidential.') All we are allowed to know is that the cost of abolishing the pound and imposing an alien currency is far greater than paying cash benefits.

The point is to push below the poverty line those who have been waiting years for successive Home Secretaries to manage their department and make decisions on their cases, and to deter others from flying to Heathrow. A single man will have to live on £35 a week. A family of four will get £110. As the supermarkets are not allowed to give them change in coins of the realm - they might spend them on phone calls and other fripperies - begging will be a tempting option. Then, if I understand Ann Widdecombe and Barbara Roche correctly, they'll be incarcerated because asking for charity is so hideous an offence in the new Britain that supplicants must suffer for their cheek.

Like the Euro, the Asylo is a studied insult to Our Sovereign Lady, the Queen. No Windsor bonce will appear on the vouchers. It will be a corporate currency featuring a hologram in which the initials SP (Sodexho Pass) will float on an intricate arrangement of colours to prevent forgery.

A black market, however, is unstoppable as Asylos are traded below their face value for the pennies the supermarket cartel can't pinch.

Sodexho was once only a caterer. Then it learned that the Anglo-American political class is good for all kinds of strange new business ventures. Sodexho has moved out of supplying buns and bought a stake in the Corrections Corporation of America. Straw, who I remember deploring private prisons, has given the corporation two British jails.

In 1998, Sodhexo took over an American services company called Marriott. Employees were not allowed to form a union.They were banned from talking to outsiders or even their colleagues about working conditions. Sodexho had to relent when the US Labour Relations Board condemned the suppression of free speech as unconstitutional. But the firm managed to run strike-breaking operations in New England hospitals last year.

Straw isn't launching the Asylo with a business partner, but an ideological soulmate.

Now fraud discredits the welfare state. It allowed the Sun to scream 'Fleeced: The Scandal of Britain's Scroungers and Dole Cheats' when Grabiner's report was released earlier this month. (The paper didn't mention that its owner, Rupert Murdoch, who also controls the Times , Sunday Times , News of the World and BSkyB, has employed the best tax lawyers around and left his simple readers to find the £1.4 billion of British corporation tax he has dodged since 1988.) Grabiner says that a survey by the Benefit Office estimated that 120,000 were working while claiming benefit - although most, presumably, were not netting £800 an hour. Estimates of fraud are notoriously vague. In 1997, the DSS asserted regularly that one in eight disabled people was on the fiddle. A Benefit Integrity Project scared tens of thousands by ordering them to submit to new medical examinations. At the end of a year of prying, not one scrounger had been uncovered. Even if his estimates are rightish, doesn't the case still have to be proved? Apparently not. Offenders on probation will lose all benefits when they are accused of breaking court orders. Grabiner will order claimants to benefit offices when they are suspected of being frauds. Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised by the lazy authoritarianism. The principles of the presumption of innocence and trial by jury are not in the bones of the Blairite briefs. Why should we expect them to know how to behave? New Labour abolishes the pound They're coming. The grasping foreigners. The economic migrants. The sly ones who suck money out of old England, send it abroad and laugh behind their hands at us all the way to their bank. Not asylum-seekers, but Sodexho, the French company which will begin on All Fools' Day printing and distributing the 50p, £1 and £5 vouchers that compose the Asylo, Europe's newest and most debased coinage .
