('The contractual details are commercially confidential.') All we are allowed to know is that the cost of abolishing the pound and imposing an alien currency is far greater than paying cash benefits. The point is to push below the poverty line those who have been waiting years for successive Home Secretaries to manage their department and make decisions on their cases, and to deter others from flying to Heathrow. A single man will have to live on £35 a week. A family of four will get £110. As the supermarkets are not allowed to give them change in coins of the realm - they might spend them on phone calls and other fripperies - begging will be a tempting option. Then, if I understand Ann Widdecombe and Barbara Roche correctly, they'll be incarcerated because asking for charity is so hideous an offence in the new Britain that supplicants must suffer for their cheek. Like the Euro, the Asylo is a studied insult to Our Sovereign Lady, the Queen. No Windsor bonce will appear on the vouchers. It will be a corporate currency featuring a hologram in which the initials SP (Sodexho Pass) will float on an intricate arrangement of colours to prevent forgery. A black market, however, is unstoppable as Asylos are traded below their face value for the pennies the supermarket cartel can't pinch. Sodexho was once only a caterer. Then it learned that the Anglo-American political class is good for all kinds of strange new business ventures. Sodexho has moved out of supplying buns and bought a stake in the Corrections Corporation of America. Straw, who I remember deploring private prisons, has given the corporation two British jails. In 1998, Sodhexo took over an American services company called Marriott. Employees were not allowed to form a union.They were banned from talking to outsiders or even their colleagues about working conditions. Sodexho had to relent when the US Labour Relations Board condemned the suppression of free speech as unconstitutional. But the firm managed to run strike-breaking operations in New England hospitals last year. Straw isn't launching the Asylo with a business partner, but an ideological soulmate.

webTitle: Serbs beat up Albanian rights lawyer

fields.headline: Serbs beat up Albanian rights lawyer
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A prominent Albanian human rights lawyer from Belgrade has been severely injured in an attack at his home which he believes was politically motivated.
fields.body:
A prominent Albanian human rights lawyer from Belgrade has been severely injured in an attack at his home which he believes was politically motivated.

Hysni Bytici has worked as a human rights lawyer in the Serbian capital for more than 40 years. He suffered head injuries and had several ribs broken when three masked gunmen burst into his Belgrade flat 10 days ago.

One of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's most outspoken and long-standing critics, Bytici had been receiving an escalating number of threats on his life in the last few months. Anonymous callers warned him to 'keep his mouth shut or else', and when his daughter Ema's car was damaged a few days before his attack he received a call saying: 'This is only the beginning.' Just before the masked men burst into his flat, he received a silent phone call at home. He believes his assailants were checking that he was in.

Bytici and his wife Sanie, 52, who was slightly injured in the attack, are convinced that it was politically motivated, particularly as nothing was stolen. Bytici had spoken out against the 'ransoms' of several thousand pounds demanded from relatives by some Serb lawyers for the release of at least 1,400 Albanians estimated to be in Serbian prisons. Natasha Kandic, of the Humanitarian Law Centre in Belgrade, says that some of these disgruntled lawyers may have arranged the attack.

Bytici was also due to represent a group of Kosovan Albanians accused of plotting terrorist acts in Belgrade during the Nato bombing last year, and supporters believe the attack may have been a bid to prevent him from defending them.

Doctors at Belgrade's Emergency Centre hospital did not believe that Bytici would survive the attack, but he has slowly recovered since surgery. However, conditions at the hospital are so bad that doctors told him his chances of survival would be better out of hospital than in it. He needs another operation for his head injuries.

Bytici's high-profile human rights cases include that of ethnic Albanian Flora Brovina, the eminent poet and paediatrician, who was jailed for 12 years on terrorist charges last December. The evidence against Brovina included possession of wool donated by Oxfam which she planned to distribute to displaced Albanian women to knit sweaters.

Bytici and his family have always lived in Belgrade, but the 10,000 or so Albanians living in the capital of the former Yugoslavia in 1989 has now dwindled to just a handful of families. Although he has, like the people he defends, been accused of Kosovo Liberation Army links, he is not a member of any political party, nor is he a nationalist. He has worked closely with Amnesty International to highlight human rights abuses in the city.

His attack has been greeted with outrage by the largely Serbian Belgrade Barristers Association and he has received sympathetic coverage on Belgrade's Studio BTV. While tensions mount in Kosovo between Serbs and Albanians, the situation in Belgrade is becoming more and more difficult for Albanians.

They too are considering leaving because they fear for their lives. 'The situation is very stressful here,' said Bytici's son Enver, 24. 'Many people here oppose Milosevic but he still has a lot of support. We all feel very worried.'

webTitle: Pitfalls line the road to Galilee

fields.headline: Pitfalls line the road to Galilee
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Small girls in fluffy confirmation dresses bobbed above the crowds, proudly held aloft by parents straining to catch the gaze of Pope John Paul II whose journey in the footsteps of Jesus brought him to the hometown of the Holy family yesterday.
fields.body:
Small girls in fluffy confirmation dresses bobbed above the crowds, proudly held aloft by parents straining to catch the gaze of Pope John Paul II whose journey in the footsteps of Jesus brought him to the hometown of the Holy family yesterday.

Two millennia after Christ, most of the 60,000 people of Nazareth are Muslim, but the city in northern Israel remains the heart of the Christian community in Galilee.

Yesterday thousands turned out in their finery, lining the streets around the Basilica of Annunciation, where the Angel Gabriel appeared to Mary, and where the Pope celebrated Mass, in the most spontaneous welcome yet for the pontiff during this historic visit.

'He is giving us hope. We know there are no easy solutions for us now, but maybe his coming will bring a miracle,' said Rose Salem, who turned out with her entire family to watch the papal motorcade enter the Basilica. 'Maybe his message of peace can finally shame us into sitting together and making a solution for all of us - Christians, Muslims and Jews.'

Such hopes trail the Pope as he makes his pilgrim's progress, which culminates today in a visit to the great shrines of all three faiths in old Jerusalem.

The twisted streets of the holy city could vex the patience of any man trying to preach reconciliation - especially the Pope, whose every step last week was a victory over ill health and old age.

A false move here, in the city whose power to divide is as eternal as its symbolic importance for the three monotheistic faiths, could ignite the religious and political passions of the Middle East - primed by his visit, and barely contained by Israeli and Palestinian authorities.

The peril of the road ahead was clear at Friday prayers on the Haram al-Sharif, the Muslim sanctuary that houses the golden Dome of the Rock. Sheikh Abu Sneya, a senior preacher, accused the Pope of using his pilgrimage to strengthen Christians in Jerusalem at the expense of local Muslims and to help Israel make the city Jewish.

The first signs of trouble came as the Pope boarded his plane in Rome last Monday. The Palestinians launched a 10ft hot air balloon draped with Palestinian and Vatican flags over their offices at Orient House in east Jerusalem, with a banner: 'Jerusalem, the eternal Palestinian capital, welcomes the Pope.' It was aloft for less than two hours before the Israeli authorities grounded it, but from then, the eternal battle for the eternal city threatened to eclipse this visit, and to turn a peace mission into yet another cause for enmity.

Regardless of the Pope's stated desire for private spiritual reflection on this visit, his celebrity has provided an opportunity for Israelis and Palestinians to air their woes.

Both Israeli and Palestinian officials are acutely conscious of the prestige of a papal visit and neither side wants to be blamed if the often childish brinkmanship goes too far, and erupts in widespread violence.

To date, the Vatican claims that sniping over Jerusalem has barely ruffled the Pope's serenity. 'He is determined to continue with his mission of peace,' the Vatican spokesman, Joaquín Navarro-Valls told reporters in Bethlehem. 'What is very clear in his mind is what he intends to say and do here.'

That has not included taking sides over Jerusalem. The Vatican, like Britain and most of the world barring Costa Rica and El Salvador, does not recognise Jerusalem as the capital and maintains an embassy in Tel Aviv. The Pope has yet to even pronounce the name of the city. But others are willing to rake up the controversy for him.

Israel's President, Ezer Weizmann, scored early, raising the topic of Jerusalem minutes after the Pope had kissed a bowl of holy earth during the airport arrival ceremony. 'Jerusalem has been the heart of the Jewish people throughout all the generations. It is what gives us our spiritual inspiration,' he said.

As if on cue, the brass band swung into 'Jerusalem the Gold', the Israeli hymn praising the city's capture in 1967.

Jerusalem's mayor, Ehud Olmert, was also there - although the Vatican had asked that he stay away because of the unresolved status of the city. Instead, he welcomed the Pope twice - first at the national airport and then racing 30 miles back home in time to greet the helicopter that flew the Pope to Jerusalem. 'Welcome to the eternal capital of Jerusalem,' Olmert told the Pope as he stepped off the helicopter.

The Palestinians had to wait a day for their turn when the Pope visited Bethlehem, part of the bundle of land grudgingly carved out of the occupied West Bank now ruled by Yasser Arafat's administration. The Palestinian leader, who, like the Pope, is rumoured to have Parkinson's disease, jumped up nimbly to greet him: 'Welcome to Palestine, and to holy Jerusalem, the eternal capital of Palestine.'

Even at Yad Vashem memorial, where the Pope's presence is seen as a turning point in 2,000 years of relations between Catholics and Jews, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, could not resist a reference to the eternal city.

The bickering has grown more strident during the visit. On Thursday night, the most important Muslim cleric of Jerusalem, Mufti Akram Sabri, boycotted an inter-faith meeting rather than sit with Israeli rabbis, arguing that would imply recognition of Israeli sovereignty over the city. One of Israel's chief rabbis was heckled, and the mufti's stand-in, abandoned the theme of reconciliation, using his speech to berate Israel for attacking Muslims and their holy places.

Today, as the Pope visits those same places, marks the most rigorous test yet of his ability to present a model of brotherly discourse that could ease the tensions here - if only for a single day.

fields.headline: Winter ain't icummen in
fields.standfirst: With the loss of our old seasonal certainties, the reference book tying us to our past is being torn up The weather: special report
fields.trailText: There is nothing like the city on a warm summer night. Despite the petrol stink, somehow the tangy, exciting smell of greenery and flowers hangs in the street; people seem friendlier - informal micro-carnivals outside the pubs and couples chewing one another under the streetlamps. In central London this week for the opening of Tate Britain, I found myself adopting the slow, contented, living-is-easy lope of summertime. And then I thought - hold on, but it's March.
fields.body:
There is nothing like the city on a warm summer night. Despite the petrol stink, somehow the tangy, exciting smell of greenery and flowers hangs in the street; people seem friendlier - informal micro-carnivals outside the pubs and couples chewing one another under the streetlamps. In central London this week for the opening of Tate Britain, I found myself adopting the slow, contented, living-is-easy lope of summertime. And then I thought - hold on, but it's March.

Yet again, we have missed the winter. Across much of the country there has been only a pseudo-winter of warm sunlight, muggy skies, erupting bulbs, confused insects and early blossom. Those whose job it is to take notes say England and Wales have had the sunniest winter since records began, though it's been punctuated by some dramatic downpours too. Overall, the 1990s was the warmest decade on record; and last year was the hottest year. And this, of course, is only the beginning; if you click on to the simulated globes at the Hadley Centre for Climate Prediction and Research, you see a frightening-looking sequence of blue and green (for cool) spheres giving way to hot red ones in the years ahead.

The official prediction is for the global average temperature to rise by three degrees by the 2080s, with massive effects across the planet. Stabilising carbon emissions would slow that by perhaps half a century but, despite the 1997 Kyoto accord, there is precious little sign of the movements needed around the world to make that likely.

Hardly anyone denies global warming is happening, though there is still a loud debate about the extent to which it is caused by human industrialisation, the growth of mega-cities and the 'great car economy'. No one seems to know for sure about rising sea-levels. There is an interesting controversy centred on the Isle of the Dead, a convict cemetery-island off Tasmania, where in 1841 a British captain and an amateur meteorologist carved a standard Ordnance Survey mark of the tide, still clearly visible - leading John Daly, a global warming dissenter, to declare that 'there has been no sea-level rise this century, none at all'. Others say he's simply misread the meaning of the OS benchmark.

But the precautionary principle alone suggests that action to stop the growth of carbon emissions is one of the prime challenges mankind faces. Never before have we experimented so blithely and on so vast a scale with the planet's system. Never before has political leadership on such a great question - in the US particularly - been so pitifully weak. If it happens that, by the time today's children are elderly, Africa has turned into a vast desert, and three billion people don't have enough water, and island-states have disappeared, then perhaps those living through it will reflect on the deadly weakness of Western democracy, a system that could not say 'no' to consumers. How natural are most of today's so-called natural disasters?

This is an area where we can raise two cheers at least for our own Government, one of the most active in Europe and therefore the world in setting tough targets and taking action to reduce our outputs of carbon dioxide, methane and the other greenhouse gases. John Prescott has been far more effective than most of his opposite numbers and is a bit of an unsung hero on the issue - the third cheer is missing because it seemed very much a Brown Budget last week, not a Green one.

But as Prescott launches an awareness campaign on global warming, the really striking thing is how little discussion there has been about how it's going to alter us, the British. For it will. There are the obvious changes, fairly well understood. A recent report from a group of Oxford scientists to Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, suggested that the new climate would bring an England of sweetcorn and sunflower fields, peaches and nectarines, berries and runner beans. Harvest festivals, apparently, may have to be moved from the autumn to the summer or even the late spring; traditional vegetables like turnips would become rare; but we will grow more cereals. It can sound pretty good - an England of Anglo-Tuscans, sitting around comparing vintages of fine Hampshire and Shropshire wines. Then there are the threats to buildings and lifestyles if, as expected, we get more extreme weather. They range from the flooding of low-lying land to the drying up of clay and massive subsidence problems for housing built there. Not much to be done about that. And the health threats. And the political threats - mass migrations, water wars abroad - which in turn affect the way we see the wider world.

Next, if the scientists are right, there will be greater climatic (therefore social and cultural) variations between the different parts of the UK. The North will be far wetter, the South hotter. Perhaps the English seaside holiday will become trendy and expensive as France and Spain are simply too hot and dry for comfort. Meanwhile, in Scotland, the North-West Highlands have been so wet in the past few months that, according to my parents' neighbours 'even the sheep are getting depressed'.

And then there will be the other cultural effects of a warmer South - not simply the café culture but changes in clothing and architectural fashions, food and leisure. More cycling, perhaps, and less brown beer and roasts and puddings, and a winter cricket season. Already, the traditional winter is something foreign to many British children. For the first two months of this year, barely any snow fell in lowland Britain and that is part of a pattern that, according to researchers at East Anglia University, is now well-established.

Less snow and ice means the jettisoning also of a lot of artistic and psychological freight. Somewhere inside, most of us are still trained to think of a seasonal cycle, part of which involves snowy landscapes, frost-crusted woods, icicles, frozen ponds. There is a primitive morality tale in it - after the penance of winter, the reward of spring. But this is all becoming folk-memory; the old photos in the family album of the thick post-war snowfalls, negotiated by people in thick woollen coats, seem as far-removed as pictures of peasants with scythes. I don't want to seem wet-eyed about this. Since most people I know are happier when the sun is shining, then it's perfectly possible that climate change may make the British happier generally - we may become more open and optimistic than we used to be, the glad recipients of atmospheric Prozac. But it's not necessarily the case. The displacement of old seasonal certainties takes us further away from our own history and culture. It unsettles, too.

Without the old winters, a lot of our seasonal poems, rhymes and novels don't make sense. Would 'Lear' or the opening scenes of Hamlet have been written without the biting cold of the 'little ice age' of Shakespearean England? Pickwick in an open-necked shirt? Like the harvest festivals, much else is uprooted, or seems wrongly placed; spring pushed closer back to Christmas, trees looking dark and dusty by June. We ceased to be a rural people, of course, before anyone else in the world. But with these climate changes, a thick reference-book connecting past Britons to present ones is being torn up, page by page.

For instance, in the new Tate Britain where my amble ended, walking among paintings which are themselves familiar, it's possible to feel a colder, rougher, emptier island which is unfamiliar. Romantic water-colours, Stubbses, wintry Constables, Pre-Raphaelite fantasias, heavily-dressed Victorians, Ford Madox Brown's soft 'Hayfield' at Hendon, Laura Knight's stunning evocation of spring in Cornwall... they are glimpses, reminders, of another country.

Climate change is now fact, not idea. It also means people change and social change and political change, though there is remarkably little writing on all that yet. Perhaps because we experience it through the distracting medley of daily life, inconsistently and contingently, and because it happens on a scale and timescale far removed from electoral cycles, and we feel helpless, it has barely touched politics or the national conversation. But there is a connection between how we in the West live and work and what's happening to the world's climate. Elsewhere, billions are potentially threatened; and only political action can help. We all know this. It is the omnipresent, obvious truth that barely dares speak. We should shiver in this warmth.

A recent report from a group of Oxford scientists to Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, suggested that the new climate would bring an England of sweetcorn and sunflower fields, peaches and nectarines, berries and runner beans. Harvest festivals, apparently, may have to be moved from the autumn to the summer or even the late spring; traditional vegetables like turnips would become rare; but we will grow more cereals. It can sound pretty good - an England of Anglo-Tuscans, sitting around comparing vintages of fine Hampshire and Shropshire wines. Then there are the threats to buildings and lifestyles if, as expected, we get more extreme weather. They range from the flooding of low-lying land to the drying up of clay and massive subsidence problems for housing built there. Not much to be done about that. And the health threats. And the political threats - mass migrations, water wars abroad - which in turn affect the way we see the wider world. Next, if the scientists are right, there will be greater climatic (therefore social and cultural) variations between the different parts of the UK. The North will be far wetter, the South hotter. Perhaps the English seaside holiday will become trendy and expensive as France and Spain are simply too hot and dry for comfort. Meanwhile, in Scotland, the North-West Highlands have been so wet in the past few months that, according to my parents' neighbours 'even the sheep are getting depressed'. And then there will be the other cultural effects of a warmer South - not simply the café culture but changes in clothing and architectural fashions, food and leisure. More cycling, perhaps, and less brown beer and roasts and puddings, and a winter cricket season. Already, the traditional winter is something foreign to many British children. For the first two months of this year, barely any snow fell in lowland Britain and that is part of a pattern that, according to researchers at East Anglia University, is now well-established. Less snow and ice means the jettisoning also of a lot of artistic and psychological freight. Somewhere inside, most of us are still trained to think of a seasonal cycle, part of which involves snowy landscapes, frost-crusted woods, icicles, frozen ponds. There is a primitive morality tale in it - after the penance of winter, the reward of spring. But this is all becoming folk-memory; the old photos in the family album of the thick post-war snowfalls, negotiated by people in thick woollen coats, seem as far-removed as pictures of peasants with scythes. I don't want to seem wet-eyed about this. Since most people I know are happier when the sun is shining, then it's perfectly possible that climate change may make the British happier generally - we may become more open and optimistic than we used to be, the glad recipients of atmospheric Prozac. But it's not necessarily the case. The displacement of old seasonal certainties takes us further away from our own history and culture. It unsettles, too. Without the old winters, a lot of our seasonal poems, rhymes and novels don't make sense. Would 'Lear' or the opening scenes of Hamlet have been written without the biting cold of the 'little ice age' of Shakespearean England? Pickwick in an open-necked shirt? Like the harvest festivals, much else is uprooted, or seems wrongly placed; spring pushed closer back to Christmas, trees looking dark and dusty by June. We ceased to be a rural people, of course, before anyone else in the world. But with these climate changes, a thick reference-book connecting past Britons to present ones is being torn up, page by page. For instance, in the new Tate Britain where my amble ended, walking among paintings which are themselves familiar, it's possible to feel a colder, rougher, emptier island which is unfamiliar. Romantic water-colours, Stubbses, wintry Constables, Pre-Raphaelite fantasias, heavily-dressed Victorians, Ford Madox Brown's soft 'Hayfield' at Hendon, Laura Knight's stunning evocation of spring in Cornwall... they are glimpses, reminders, of another country. Climate change is now fact, not idea. It also means people change and social change and political change, though there is remarkably little writing on all that yet. Perhaps because we experience it through the distracting medley of daily life, inconsistently and contingently, and because it happens on a scale and timescale far removed from electoral cycles, and we feel helpless, it has barely touched politics or the national conversation. But there is a connection between how we in the West live and work and what's happening to the world's climate. Elsewhere, billions are potentially threatened; and only political action can help. We all know this. It is the omnipresent, obvious truth that barely dares speak. We should shiver in this warmth.

fields.headline: Heatwave sets fire to Portugal
fields.standfirst:
Brussels is asked for emergency aid after global warming brings worst drought in 150 years

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Forest fires raging across northern and central Portugal have brought disastrous crop failures and raised fears that global warming presents a rapidly growing threat to the country's ability to sustain itself. Hundreds of firemen, supported by helicopters, have been fighting the fires that have been fanned by strong winds in a heatwave that began at the start of February.
fields.body:
Forest fires raging across northern and central Portugal have brought disastrous crop failures and raised fears that global warming presents a rapidly growing threat to the country's ability to sustain itself. Hundreds of firemen, supported by helicopters, have been fighting the fires that have been fanned by strong winds in a heatwave that began at the start of February.

The government admitted last week that more than half the country's production of cereal crops had been lost. The Minister of Agriculture, Capoulas Santos, has asked Brussels for emergency aid.

Global warming has been linked to the growing trend of climatic extremes in the Mediterranean. Last year's drought was the worst for 150 years, and this year's temperatures in Portugal are already on average 2C to 5C above normal.

The forest fires have affected virtually every region between the midland town of Portalegre and the northern border with Spain in what is normally the rainy season. 'I have been a fireman for 20 years, and I don't remember so many fires at this time of year,' said Castelo Branco's fire-fighting commander, Rui Esteves.

'Portugal is burning right now because it is so dry,' says Professor Eugenio Sequeira, a climate expert at Lisbon's New University. Sequeira believes Portugal's climate has been changing over the last 30 years, and that the failure of governments to tackle the growing threat of global warming may be to blame.

'The level of precipitation at this time of year has been falling steadily and significantly since the Sixties. It is very probable that climate change is behind the current drought and forest fires, as it was probably the cause of flooding in Mozambique.'

Over the last decade, fires have claimed nearly one million hectares of forest land in Portugal. The situation has been aggravated by the rapid spread of the paper industry's huge eucalyptus plantations, which have turned already marginal land bone-dry and left boreholes and streams once used for irrigation empty. The climatic change now threatens to make much of the country unproductive and uninhabitable.

'If drastic measures are not taken now, even worse climatic extremes could follow and much of Portugal may become a desert,' says Sequeira.

While once productive fields in the south have been rendered arid, fishermen report that catches of sardines and cod - which make up a large part of the Portuguese diet - are falling due to temperature changes in the North Atlantic.

Dr Fatima Espirito Santos, divisional director at Portugal's Institute of Meteorology, says: 'Are the drought and early forest fires the result of global warming? I don't know, it is too early to tell. But if this pattern is repeated in coming years there will be little doubt that Portugal's climate is changing.'

Water supplies to the main cities are running low, and the government is calling on Spain to release more water into the rivers that flow through both countries, to stave off summer shortages.

The two countries signed a water-sharing agreement in 1998, but Madrid is accused of not honouring the deal and holding back supplies. In the border town of Mertola, officials are planning to bring in tankers of drinking water.

When Capoulas met European Union Commissioner Franz Fischler to ask for emergency aid to farmers, he warned that rice production in parts of the south had been destroyed, while farmers' associations added that fruit trees and vines had matured earlier than normal and were now prone to frost damage.

webTitle: Gene glitch made man speak first

fields.headline: Gene glitch made man speak first
fields.standfirst: A freak mutation in one Stone Age man gave us language but could also be the source of depression, writes  Robin McKie
fields.trailText: A single mutation in the brain of one Stone Age man provided humanity with the intellectual boost it needed to conquer the world.
fields.body:
A single mutation in the brain of one Stone Age man provided humanity with the intellectual boost it needed to conquer the world.

That change gave Homo sapiens the power of speech and language, but also came with a curse, because it left mankind vulnerable to psychoses, such as schizophrenia and manic depression.

This startling idea is to be outlined on Tuesday by the Oxford University psychiatrist Professor Tim Crow at a London conference at which fossil experts, geneticists and anthropologists will debate one of evolution's most enduring mysteries: why did Homo sapiens triumph at the expense of all other types of human being?

Crow believes an abrupt alteration in our brains' hard-wiring was responsible for giving us control of Earth. 'Language appeared very quickly and provided us with a unique ability to exchange complex ideas, thus giving us a powerful advantage over other types of human being,' he said. 'Mental illness is the price we pay for possessing that prowess.'

One key implication of Crow's ideas for linking psychoses with language is that schizophrenia and manic depression must involve the breakdown of the brain's internal linguistic controls. People with these conditions can still speak but often believe they hear voices, or that others are controlling their thoughts. 'These psychoses clearly involve some kind of deviation in language function. That is a very important implication of this work,' Crow added.

In the past decade, scientists have established that by about 100,000 years ago, different species of humans had established themselves in different corners of the globe: Neanderthals in Europe and Homo erectus in the Far East, for example. Then a new breed of upstart Earthlings appeared on the scene: Homo sapiens, who emerged out of Africa and began to spread, with remarkable speed, across the planet.

Each encounter between native species and African invader appears to have been brief and one-sided, resulting in the extinction of the former - until, about 30,000 years ago, Homo sapiens was left in sole custody of Earth. Whether we indulged in 'species cleansing' or were more efficient at acquiring food and shelter is still unclear. Either way, Homo sapiens possessed a key advantage over all other forms of humanity.

But what was it, and how did we acquire it? Most scientists agree this change must have involved some dramatic improvement in our linguistic skills, though they have been unable to suggest what special circumstances might have prevailed in our African homeland for natural selection to cause our ancestors to acquire complex speech.

It is to this problem that Crow has proposed a dramatic solution. A freak mutation in a single, male member of early Homo sapiens was responsible. This biological change - which Crow believes can be traced to the Y chromosome, the DNA packet possessed only by men - was sufficient to trigger a cascade of biological changes that swept through our species, bringing major improvements in our linguistic ability in their wake.

The specific mutation outlined by Crow is one that widened the gulf between the two hemispheres of the human brain, a gap that freed one half to take over and develop the power of speech. Research by Crow - linking variations in people's cerebral hemisphere controls of their bodies to their linguistic prowess - supports this idea.

The first man to manifest this gift would probably have had the gift of the gab. 'He would have been favoured strongly for sexual selection,' said Crow. His genes would have spread quickly.

This capacity for complex speech also brought major disadvantages, in particular it triggered the appearance of schizophrenia in our species. Our sophisticated language controls occasionally go wrong. 'Schizophrenia is a linguistic breakdown in which the sufferer distinguishes his thoughts from his speech output and the speech input that he receives and decodes from others,' said Crow.

It is a startling way of understanding psychoses, and sparked considerable scientific interest among other researchers, especially as Crow has a reputation for individualistic brilliance. 'This is an intriguing idea, though I always hesitate about accepting single, neatly packaged explanations about our evolution,' said palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, of London's Natural History Museum. 'I think it is just as likely we accumulated characteristics like language in a piecemeal fashion and that there was no single, defining moment that heralded the arrival of complex speech in Homo sapiens, ' added Stringer, who will also be speaking at the conference, 'The Speciation of Modern Homo Sapiens' .

'However, this will be the first opportunity Tim Crow has had to convince anthropologists and palaeontologists about the evolutionary aspects of his ideas and he will certainly get a good hearing, albeit a lively one, I suspect.'

fields.headline: Art parties are hot tickets
fields.trailText: The telephone calls are already coming in, with their polite, but insistent inquiries: 'What date is the launch party, again? I just want to make sure I'm free.'
fields.body:
The telephone calls are already coming in, with their polite, but insistent inquiries: 'What date is the launch party, again? I just want to make sure I'm free.'

The 2,500 invitations to the celebratory opening night at the Tate Modern, on 11 May, have not been sent out yet. But it is clear that the event will eclipse other 'big bash' openings across the capital, such as the Royal Opera House rebirth.

Thursday night's glamorous relaunch party at the Tate Britain on Millbank was just a warm-up for the main event.

'There has been an amazing pressure on us to get tickets for people,' said one of the Tate's team. 'The new building at Bankside and last week's launch mean that everyone knows the big one is coming up.'

Ever since the Sensation exhibition of young British artists came to the Royal Academy of Arts in London in 1997, visual arts in this country have been hot. Neither the opera nor the ballet have a chance of competing for attention. As Thursday's party showed, modern art draws the really big stars.

Almost 2,000 guests piled into the Tate Gallery's original home at Millbank to mark its transformation into Tate Britain, a newly organised collection that will house works by British artists.

The country's most prominent artists, Gary Hume, Antony Gormley, Julian Opie and Tracey Emin, were joined by leading politicians, film directors, musicians, actors, and, of course, Madonna, the crowning jewel in the publicist's crown.

'The associations between rock and modern art have always been there, but they are stronger than ever now,' said Opie, who has designed the band St Etienne's latest album cover and is about to work with the singer Björk.

'There is a real interest in design and shape generally, and it is great to feel modern art is no longer an embarrassing joke that gets an easy laugh. That was such a stale, boring idea. There are often paparazzi at openings now and that can be unhealthy when it means the same artists are written about to the point when the public becomes bored with them.'

The £134m Tate Bankside, an entirely new museum built inside the vast shell of a disused power station, houses the Tate's international twentieth and twenty-first century collection.

'It is very unusual for an art museum of this size to open anywhere in the world,' said Jill Sil verman, chief executive of the influential Lissom Gallery.

'I actually think this is one thing that deserves all the hype it gets. It is going to be the centre of artistic research and education for years to come.'

The opening evening will be televised live by the BBC. The broadcast, presented by Kirsty Wark and Matthew Collings, will climax in a rock concert and a specially commissioned dance performance.

Once open, the Tate Modern will gain a large chunk of its income from hiring out the gallery in the evening to its 17 corporate funding partners. The gallery is already booked until nearly the end of the year.

To involve neighbours and the wider London community, the opening fortnight will involve a series of companion events, including an invitation to black cab drivers to an exclusive preview.

webTitle: Mind virus could give us shopping bug

fields.headline: Mind virus could give us shopping bug
fields.trailText: It may prove to be the most successful new selling technique the capitalist world has ever known. The 'mind virus' is the latest form of consumer brainwashing.
fields.body:
It may prove to be the most successful new selling technique the capitalist world has ever known. The 'mind virus' is the latest form of consumer brainwashing.

A mix of psychology and Internet technology, the aim is to create social epidemics by feeding the right information, or virus, into someone's mind. Once implanted, it can make the most useless of gadgets seem essential, the most unnecessary accessory irresistible. It is a money-spinning dream.

That is the claim of psychologist Paul Marsden, who believes he can help businesses to trigger shopping crazes for their products.

It works like this. First you find out how the mind of your target consumer works by getting at his or her ideas and subconscious thoughts. Marsden's company, Brand Genetics, is pioneering this, not through market research but word association games on the Internet that can tell the psychologist everything he needs to know.

Once someone has been lured to play the games their 'mindsets' or reactions to certain words and ideas are laid bare. The next step is to sell on the information to an interested business that can use it to create a product that is branded and packaged in a way that will be irresistible to the target consumer.

Demand for the service has been so strong that Brand Genetics already has a multi-million pound turnover with clients including American Express, Land Rover, Lloyds TSB, Mars and Metz.

Successful brands can be used as starting points and simply cloned. 'That part is like genetic modification. Really the basics are that our minds are tuned to wake up at certain terms related to certain concepts. Sex, survival and status are the big three for all humans,' says Marsden.

The consumers' enthusiasm for something that fits into their own mindset so well can go on to create a social epidemic.

'People are drawn to mimic the behaviour of others. It is contagious,' said Marsden. 'I would get my psychology student to stand in the middle of Oxford Street and stare at the sky. Within minutes it can bring the whole of Oxford Street to a practical standstill as people cannot resist copying and will stop to stare at the sky too. Add to that how we will follow anyone with status or celebrity and the cues to creating a social epidemic are all there.' Marsden calls it 'positive mind virus'. Bizarrely, he used his expertise in the psychology of suicide to develop the technique.

'Suicide is contagious,' he explained. 'When the report of a suicide appears in a newspaper, especially the tabloids, the suicide rate leaps by an immediate 10 per cent, sometimes as much as 20 per cent.' This led him to the conclusion that planting the right seed in a person's mind could achieve any end.

Marsden offers a recent example. He invited business people to visit a website in exchange for being entered into a prize draw for a holiday. They were asked to guess the next mobile phone innovation. The entries were collected and the best 100 ideas passed to a mobile phone company. The company had tapped into expertise that would normally cost a fortune to gather. 'This is about using the Internet as a virtual consumer to find people's mindset,' he said.

The Consumers Association confirms that, as long as people are not deceived into playing the Internet word association games, then it is all above board.

You have been warned.

webTitle: Clan feud flares over hills of Skye

fields.headline: Clan feud flares over hills of Skye
fields.standfirst: Attempts by the MacLeod chieftain to sell the Black Cuillins have opened up bitter, ancient divisions with the MacDonalds, reports  Stuart Millar from the Isle of Skye
fields.trailText: Attempts by the MacLeod chieftain to sell the Black Cuillins have opened up bitter, ancient divisions with the MacDonalds, reports  Stuart Millar from the Isle of Skye
fields.body:
Looming through the torrential downpour that whipped against the walls of Dunvegan Castle, the Black Cuillins were unmistakable, the spine of ragged peaks rising dark against the sodden Hebridean scenery of the Isle of Skye.

The hills have been MacLeod territory and a brooding, domineering symbol of their power since ancient times, but as an emotional John MacLeod of MacLeod, the 29th clan chief, looked across at them from his 800-year-old stronghold, the tears pricking his eyes were not of pride. 'I feel a failure,' he said, his voice faltering. 'This has been our land for centuries and I have a tremendous feeling of inadequacy that I will be unable to keep them in the clan.'

MacLeod - motto: Hold Fast - provoked outrage last week with the announcement that he is selling off the Cuillins, one of Scotland's most spectacular and important landscapes, for £10m to finance urgent repairs to his castle's roof. This weekend, amid renewed accusations that he is attempting to profit from land he has no moral right to sell, MacLeod revealed to The Observer that the saga may take an even more dramatic twist: he wants Sean Connery and other major celebrities to consider acting as white knights to save the Black Cuillins' 20 peaks for the nation.

The Edinburgh estate agents handling the sale, FPD Savills, said it was targeting 'high net-worth individuals with a passion for Scotland' but refused to divulge any names. But MacLeod said: 'I would love Sean Connery, Paul McCartney and other people like that to think about buying the Cuillins. They could get one of the big land bodies to manage it for them. It is going to take somebody like that because nobody is going to buy it as an investment.' With his office being bombarded by calls of support and sympathy from clan members around the world, the beleaguered 64-year-old chief also disclosed that he would consider donating the 35 acres of land to the public in return for state funding for repairs to Dunvegan, the MacLeod seat since the 12th century.

Anchored on a rocky outcrop on the shore of a loch, the castle is the epitome of a Highland chieftain's stronghold. But a flat copper roof installed in the 1950s has been no match for the elements sweeping relentlessly off the slab-grey water. Away from the sumptuously maintained areas open to the paying public, the dank stone corridors are lined at regular intervals with buckets, basins, flour containers and barrels to catch the rain.

According to MacLeod, Dunvegan can hold out no longer. The most urgent repairs will cost £2.8m; those that are merely necessary will eat up another £3.5m. Throw in £1m for contingencies and a couple more for capital gains tax and that, says the chief, who has been unable to secure public help with his roof, leaves him no option but to sell the Cuillins. 'I have worked hard to make the castle an effective business,' MacLeod, wearing his trademark kilt, said as he sipped coffee from a Dunvegan souvenir mug in a room bedecked with trophies awarded to the estate's prize Highland cattle herd.

His insistence that he is acting completely out of necessity, however, has not been helped by plans to invest some of the proceeds in other tourist ventures, such as a 60-80 bedroom hotel and leisure complex near the village of Dunvegan. The scheme has been in the pipeline for some time and is well advanced: detailed plans have been submitted to the local authority and planning permission was recently renewed. All that is needed is the cash, prompting accusations that the Cuillins sale is about more than a leaky roof.

But MacLeod said that if public money was made available just to pay for the new roof, he would consider handing over the Cuillins to the nation. By taking tax and seed money for the other ventures out of the equation, that raises the possibility of the public obtaining the land for a reduced cost of about £7m. 'If the repairs could be covered then an arrangement about the land would be possible,' he said. 'I would not sell the Cuillins just to build a hotel.' Neither this nor the celebrity solution, however, has appeased critics of the sell-off, led by Calum Macdonald, Labour MP for the Western Isles. 'The castle roof is totally irrelevant,' he said. 'The question is: does he have any moral right whatever to sell a unique area like the Cuillins to the highest bidder, and I don't believe he does. It is not his land. When were the title deeds to the Cuillins ever signed? The idea that these mountains are his to make £10m off is obscene.'

He is not the only vociferous opponent: in a scathing front-page editorial this weekend, the West Highland Free Press accused MacLeod of 'naked avarice'. But the MP's outspoken intervention has prompted the chief to raise the spectre of long-buried enmities between the MacLeods and the McDonalds being rekindled by their increasingly heated exchanges over the sell-off. Tensions between the clans, uncomfortably close neighbours on Skye, date back more than 1,000 years. It was the Cuillins that formed the dividing line in their territory, with the MacDonalds holding the Red range and the MacLeods the Black peaks.

Back in his sitting room at Dunvegan, MacLeod watched the wind and rain churn up the loch: 'The last few days have been hell but I took the decision and I'm trying to make it a success. I will always love the Cuillins, they are a part of me. But they have ceased to be MacLeod so that love has changed. I have to protect what is ours.'

 stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Yes, there is such a thing as a male menopause. And yes, there's a cure

fields.headline: Yes, there is such a thing as a male menopause. And yes, there's a cure
fields.standfirst: Age was once blamed for men's drop in drive but now, reports  Tracy McVeigh, testosterone is available at the click of a mouse
fields.trailText: Sybil Fawlty memorably blamed Basil's eccentric behaviour on his 'time of life' - but the joke is a miserable medical reality for millions of men suffering lack of drive at work, loss of libido or impotence, depression, irritability, night sweats and hot flushes. And the good news is that there is a cure.
fields.body:
Sybil Fawlty memorably blamed Basil's eccentric behaviour on his 'time of life' - but the joke is a miserable medical reality for millions of men suffering lack of drive at work, loss of libido or impotence, depression, irritability, night sweats and hot flushes. And the good news is that there is a cure.

Testosterone replacement therapy is now becoming recognised as a suitable treatment for what has been until now dismissed as a mid-life crisis rather than a serious medical condition.

Men, like women, suffer a drop in hormone levels as they age. In men the hormone is testosterone. Many men, and many GPs, will dismiss their symptoms as natural ageing, but last week the British Medical Journal revealed that there was a strong argument that the male menopause - called the andropause - does exist. Now The Observer can reveal the little-known fact that a treatment is available. The UK is the only country in the world where safe, oral tablets of TRT are available.

Fifty-something men can recover their lost youth, tired businessmen can find their killer instinct once more, beer bellies can be reduced and sex lives can be rejuvenated.

One group of Harley Street doctors is so convinced of the value of testosterone replacement therapy, and so frustrated by GPs' unwillingness to prescribe it, that they are launching a cyber-clinic, an online consultancy for men suffering from an age-related drop in testosterone levels.

Stress, alcohol intake and even environmental hormone disrupters are all causing an increase in the number of sufferers. Andropause hits high flyers, those with naturally high testosterone levels, hardest of all.

Bernard Collen, 54, credits the drug with having saved his marriage and his career. Ten years ago he was an irritable, exhausted salesman who put his lack of sex drive and bad temper down to the stress of his job. 'I really felt I was starting to lose my grip,' he said. It was his wife, Michelle, who heard of the UK Andropause Clinic and the pioneering work being done by Dr Malcolm Carruthers at the Gold Cross Medical Group in London's Harley Street.

'She rang him up and just forced the phone into my hand,' said Bernard. A blood test confirmed he had low testosterone and he was prescribed TRT. 'My life turned around. It restored my ability to do my job, it boosted my sexual desire, it seemed to give me better mental agility and the depression went overnight,' he said.

Dr Carruthers and his colleagues have been voices in the medical wilderness for 10 years, in which time more than 1,000 men have been treated with TRT at his clinic, and the group is now launching an interactive AndroScreen website. This means that men unhappy with their GP's advice can turn to the Internet for a medical appraisal.

Dr Carruthers believes he has convinced many other doctors that TRT is the way forward. 'All the evidence that has come forward, particularly over the past year, shows that the andropause is a real and serious condition,' he said. 'The data I have collected shows TRT is safe and highly effective. Around 50 per cent of men aged 50, 60 per cent of men aged 60 and 70 per cent of men aged 70 will be suffering from the male menopause now.

'There is no need to suffer. There is loads of evidence that TRT works very well. It even decreases obesity and increases lean body mass. It reduces the beer belly because it improves abdominal muscle.

'It is high time the condition is recognised and treated. That's why we have set up this Website - to make it available to people, not only in the UK but also in the States. TRT is one area we are actually ahead of the States in.

'The sad thing is that people keep going to their GPs and they are not being diagnosed. The doctors prescribing TRT are few and far between. And that is why we want to use the Web to create a new form of global consultancy and it will enable us to spread the scarce specialist advice in this field as far as possible.'

Testosterone was thought for a time to be linked to prostate cancer but within the past year that risk has been dismissed. In fact the regular screening of patients being prescribed TRT may even aid detection of the so-called 'silent killer'. The main remaining complaint against TRT is from those who do not believe it actually works and do not believe the andropause exists except as a natural ageing process.

 tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk
For further details of screening and TRT the website address is: www.AndroScreen.com

fields.headline: MI6 'plotters' face Yard probe
fields.standfirst: Shayler's girlfriend flies in with 'fresh evidence' of bid to assassinate Gadaffi
fields.trailText: The British intelligence officers alleged to have been involved in an illegal plot to assassinate the Libyan dictator, Colonel Muammar Gadaffi, could face a Scotland Yard investigation.
fields.body:
The British intelligence officers alleged to have been involved in an illegal plot to assassinate the Libyan dictator, Colonel Muammar Gadaffi, could face a Scotland Yard investigation.

Several innocent by-standers are believed to have been killed in a shootout in 1996 following a botched attempt on Gadaffi's life.

A police investigation could force Foreign Secretary Robin Cook to make a legally binding statement on any British involvement. He described the claims as 'pure fantasy' when former MI5 officer David Shayler first made them in 1998. Cook is now known to be unhappy with assurances he was given by MI6 at the time.

A top-secret intelligence document posted on the Internet last month backed claims by Shayler that the British secret service had prior knowledge of the plot. Shayler has always said that MI6 was behind it, but there has been no official inquiry into his allegations.

Shayler's girlfriend Annie Machon, who lives in exile with Shayler in Paris, will arrive in London tomorrow with statements and documents to back up his claims. She will call on the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, Sir John Stevens, to open an inquiry into whether MI6 officers were involved in an illegal operation overseas without Ministers' knowledge.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, who is also Shayler's solicitor, will be making arrangements with Special Branch in the morning to meet senior Scotland Yard officers.

Last night Machon, herself a former MI5 officer, told The Observer : 'For three years David has been persecuted by the authorities for merely trying to tell the truth. It is time the police used its resources to mount an inquiry into the serious crimes committed by others. There is clearly enough evidence.'

Wadham added: 'If David is right then serious crimes have been committed. There is no sign that Robin Cook or the Security and Intelligence Committee are investigating this matter. We are now forced to contact Special Branch who have a responsibility for investigating crime.'

If Stevens initiates an inquiry, Special Branch would find itself in the peculiar position of investigating the MI6 officers and the man who made the allegations against them.

Ever since Shayler left the intelligence service in 1997 he has been under investigation for serious breaches of the Official Secrets Act. Earlier this month at the Old Bailey, Special Branch was granted an order to force The Observer and the Guardian to hand over material relating to Shayler. Both papers have said they will fight the order and take the case to Europe if necessary.

Although there is likely to be fierce resistance from MI5 - the domestic secret service - and MI6, which works abroad, to any police inquiry into Shayler's claims, the recently appointed Met Commissioner is already investigating rogue elements of the services.

Stevens, who became the country's most senior police officer in February, is currently conducting an investigation into allegations that the one secret service unit burgled and burnt down his offices in 1990 when he was heading and inquiry into collusion between the British army and loyalist terrorists in Northern Ireland.

The two officers alleged to be involved in the Libyan plot have so far been named in the British press only as PT16 amd PT16/B, although their names have been published in a Portuguese magazine. Shayler passed their names to the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, last November along with those of other MI5 and MI6 officers whom he said could corroborate his story.

The so-called 'CX document', which appeared on the Internet last month, was circulated to several government departments in 1996. It reported that a Libyan military officer, codenamed 'Tunworth', had offered to act as a go-between with Islamic fundamentalists planning to overthrow Gadaffi.

Shayler alleges that he attended several high-level meetings where the plot was discussed in 1995, when he was working on the Libyan desk of MI5. The officer known as PT16/B was Shayler's opposite number at MI6 and was directly responsible for running 'Tunworth'. PT16 was the head of the MI6 section responsible.

Shayler was arrested in Paris on 1 August 1998, only hours after the Government refused the Mail on Sunday permission to publish his allegations. In the extradition proceedings that followed, Shayler's lawyers argued that the arrest was a direct attempt to stop the revelations being made public.

He spent three months in prison before the French courts released him on the grounds that he was being pursued for a political crime.

fields.headline: Oldies queue up for PlayStation
fields.standfirst: Pensioners are becoming hooked on PlayStations and computer games
fields.trailText: A major retailer says elderly customers are the biggest growth market for the games, despite the fact sales are targeted at youth. And Age Concern reports a growing demand from the elderly for computer and Internet training.
fields.body:
A major retailer says elderly customers are the biggest growth market for the games, despite the fact sales are targeted at youth. And Age Concern reports a growing demand from the elderly for computer and Internet training.

Tesco research on the rate at which older people are snapping up games software highlights a trend already identified by Age Concern and other organisations such as the Royal Chelsea Hospital, home to the Chelsea Pensioners.

Michael Gainsborough, governor of the Royal Hospital at Chelsea, said: 'We have provided a computer room for the residents it is very popular.'

PlayStations are popular because a computer is not needed. But unlike their grandchildren, elderly players do not like violence. Grand Turismo, which puts players behind the wheel of a race car, is the most popular. This is followed by the similar Le Mans 24-hour, then more traditional Chess Master, Monopoly and True Pinball. Ski game Downhill Racer sells more after each televised competition.

Age Concern said it could not meet demand from those wanting to learn to use computers and the Internet. 'Computer games and the Internet create an inter-generational bond,' said a spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Police cover blown by cyber-spies
fields.trailText: Hi-tech villains are using the Internet to sabotage police and customs operations - distributing details of unmarked surveillance vehicles, observation posts, confidential intelligence reports and even pictures of undercover officers.
fields.body:
Hi-tech villains are using the Internet to sabotage police and customs operations - distributing details of unmarked surveillance vehicles, observation posts, confidential intelligence reports and even pictures of undercover officers.

The World Wide Web is increasingly replacing pubs or nightclubs as the favourite criminal forum for exchanging useful information. The simplest of searches will produce dozens of sites dedicated to providing details, descriptions - often including the registration numbers - of unmarked police cars operating across the country.

Many of the lists are compiled by youngsters employed by criminal gangs to stand outside their local police station and note every vehicle entering and leaving. Most experienced undercover officers now prefer to park their vehicles some distance away and walk to the station when attending briefings.

More sophisticated searches reveal the existence of sites where specific information about suspected police informants and the identity of officers working on covert operations is disclosed. The information is often found within anarchist sites alongside tips for manufacturing explosives, picking locks and creating false identities.

Earlier this year, two undercover police officers were allowed to give evidence from behind screens after Tayside Police submitted documents to the Perth Sheriff's Court highlighting their concerns that underworld figures were creating and spreading details of drug squad officers.

Police chiefs, already concerned about the growing use of the Internet for criminal purposes, told the court that major underworld figures are creating and spreading databases with personal details of drug squad officers. They feared that increasing numbers of Internet sites could jeopardise large-scale operations and even threaten the lives of police officers and their families.

A common tactic is for police to bring in undercover officers from outside the area in which the targets live so there is little chance of them being identified. The spread of information leaking the identity of such officers could render the technique obsolete.

One officer attached to SO10, Scotland Yard's specialist division responsible for covert operations, told The Observer: 'It is one thing when a small gang of villains in a certain area share information among themselves. What concerns us about the Internet is the potential for criminals across the country and across the world to access the same information.'

In the past year, police in Britain have uncovered instances of Yardie gangsters using the Internet to arrange the sale of heroin and cannabis. Such sites are moved to new addresses on a regular basis to frustrate attempts to track them down. Further afield, drug cartels operating in Colombia and Mexico have made extensive use of the Internet to communicate with buyers around the world and assist in keeping track of cocaine shipments.

The ability to communicate securely and globally is becoming increasingly important because of the changing nature of organised crime. Where once traditional British family gangs would operate in virtual isolation and rarely stray from their home turf, the influx of drugs and the need to launder large sums of money mean that gangs in different areas are having to work hand in hand.

The worrying trend is set to expand further with the arrival of Freenet, a new Internet system that can give publishers of Web pages absolute anonymity. Unlike existing files, those on Freenet do not have a unique Internet address specifying the computer on which they are held. Instead, the files are distributed around the Net on computers belonging to Freenet members. Several copies of each file exist in different places to make it hard to delete them.

However, if Freenet users have copies of a file on their machine it doesn't mean they published it. In fact, they might not even know it is there. The system means that no one computer user can be held responsible for Freenet files because there is no way of knowing their origin.

The World Wide Web is increasingly replacing pubs or nightclubs as the favourite criminal forum for exchanging useful information. The simplest of searches will produce dozens of sites dedicated to providing details, descriptions - often including the registration numbers - of unmarked police cars operating across the country. Many of the lists are compiled by youngsters employed by criminal gangs to stand outside their local police station and note every vehicle entering and leaving. Most experienced undercover officers now prefer to park their vehicles some distance away and walk to the station when attending briefings. The information is often found within anarchist sites alongside tips for manufacturing explosives, picking locks and creating false identities. fields.headline: 'Spy' for animal rights  under fire
fields.standfirst: Home Office accuses anti-vivisectionist of fabrication, malpractice and cruelty
fields.trailText: An undercover animal welfare worker has been accused of cruelty, malpractice and 'fabrication' after she alleged a catalogue of failures at a company that breeds rodents, dogs and primates for experiments.
fields.body:
An undercover animal welfare worker has been accused of cruelty, malpractice and 'fabrication' after she alleged a catalogue of failures at a company that breeds rodents, dogs and primates for experiments.

The accusations - made by the Home Office, which exonerated the company on all but one allegation, and by a Labour MP - can be revealed because the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection has agreed to lift confidentiality on the issue.

Jane Eastwood worked undercover at the Leicestershire base of Harlan UK for 10 months and submitted video, audiotape, photographic and diary evidence to the BUAV last May. Her evidence suggested that dog cages were severely crowded, fights between dogs occurred, animals considered surplus to requirements, including 250 dogs, were culled, staffing levels were low, out-of-date drugs were used and, on one occasion, an animal was killed because the wrong drug was administered.

Her report also alleged that puppies were killed in sight of other dogs, that animals were left without food or water, that a puppy's rectal prolapse was 'repaired' with a ballpoint pen and that maggots and mould were found in the animals' food.

However, a £36,000 Home Office investigation into practices by Harlan UK cleared the company. A Harlan UK spokesman said: 'The Home Office investigators went through us with a fine-tooth comb. They were quite aggressive.

'We went through agony waiting for the report. Our staff were abused and are still abused. To be cleared except for one minor incident and then to have faced all this is very frustrating.'

He also claimed the BUAV investigator lied to colleagues and twisted the evidence.

Home Office Minister Mike O'Brien said he was satisfied the company had addressed any problems. BUAV said it was horrified at the slur on its investigator and at what in effect were accusations that the BUAV was concealing crucial information.

It has said it will be complaining to the European Commission. 'Whenever there is a choice between accepting Jane's contemporaneous written and video evidence or accepting the company's account to the investigators, the Home Office inspectors chose the latter,' said the BUAV's chief executive, Michelle Thew.

'Eastwood was interviewed once by the investigators in September and, although she made it clear that she would be available to answer any further questions, the Home Office went ahead with this report without giving her a chance to answer the accusations it contains.'

The allegations in the Home Office report against Eastwood range from malpractice to sloppiness. She is accused of allowing a baby guinea pig to die in agony; of failing to follow procedures with the result that caged puppies were forced to watch other puppies being killed, and of failing to shower before entering the pig unit.

It is also alleged that she failed to raise any of the problems with her managers. Eastwood rejects all these accusations.

The Labour MP Dr Stephen Ladyman has accused her of fabricating evidence. 'She was the only person there when the incidents she reports took place,' he said.

The Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker believes further investigation is called for. 'On the one hand, the BUAV is making serious accusations and their record is good and shows they do not go in for groundless scaremongering,' he said.

'On the other hand, they have been given a detailed response... Further investigation is needed by somebody who both sides accept is neutral.'

There is no disagreement that there were only 10 staff caring for 1,000-1,300 dogs, and the Home Office recognised several times in the report that some of Eastwood's evidence was correct, but has said that problems have been resolved subsequently.

Eastwood's video, photographic and diary records show bare concrete floors, fence partitions and (not in every cage) a metal flap leading to an outside concrete pen.

'Is this really what the public would regard as acceptable?' said Thew.

'We appreciate that not everybody is against all animal experimentation, but we believe that most people would assume that conditions were among the best in the world. Would people really be happy to know that so many animals are bred and then killed as waste? Some of the animals had no bedding, which is a clear breach of the code of practice.'

The BUAV claims that it has been discredited because its investigation was an explicit criticism of Home Office inspectors. They are responsible for monitoring 300-plus companies involved in animal breeding or experimentation.

'This system is totally closed. Nobody else can get a look-in,' said Thew. 'We would like an independent investigation into the allegations.'

 sarah.ryle@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Blondes have more fun - and brains

fields.headline: Blondes have more fun - and brains
fields.standfirst: Euan Ferguson meets Mariella Frostrup
fields.trailText: Euan Ferguson meets Mariella Frostrup
fields.body:
It is a clicheacute; of quite unforgiveable proportions to use the adjective 'husky' when describing Mariella Frostrup. As soon as the word looms the senses simply have to rebel against the tedious inevitability of its appearance; it's like coming across the word 'quintessential' in an article about David Niven, or (presumably) looking in the mirror if you are Andrew Lloyd-Webber and thinking of the word 'ugly.' And we are living whap bam in the middle of a cliché - we are sitting in the bar of the Groucho Club. The air is being kissed with such fierce frequency that were it a person it would amount to rape. Pashminas exist. We have stepped over a beggar to get in. We are sipping wine. It is white - I vow, there and then, to plough through ever-deeper adjectival seams for an elegant solution.

So. Mariella Frostrup, whose voice reminds me of an Arctic sled-beast of the genus canus, is getting angry. Not just for herself, but on general behalf of blond women with brains. Women such as Jerry Hall, who had a few months ago to suffer the schoolboy jokes that get made when England's male intellectuals leave the classroom for the playground. Jerry's crime, apart from being blond and a woman, was to have been picked as a judge for the Whitbread Book Award, as Mariella's is now to have been chosen as a panellist for this year's Booker. Comparisons have been made, of course; and the expected cries of 'dumbing down' have followed. Mariella is A Woman. Her hair is fair-coloured. Her face is not that of a smuggler's dog, and her body is not noticeably covered in stringwarts. Therefore, ergo, she is Thick As Shit and not fit to judge Britain's premier literary award.

'I hated all that meanness against Jerry, all that sniping, stuff about time at the hairdressers. I know that I was just as keen to find out what books Jerry had enjoyed as had, for instance, Melvyn Bragg, or whoever. And I'm sure Melvyn and Jerry spend an equal amount of time at the hairdresser's 

'But even then the comparisons between her and me are crap. Jerry's a 44-year-old mother of four who's fought her way up quite brilliantly from Hicksville. I'm a single 37-year-old journalist. What on earth do we have in common, apart from being women and not being famous academics? 'Also, also - ' she is warming to her theme now, which means she smokes more quickly, moves seats to face me directly and get away from the mirror ('I hate looking at myself in mirrors') and her voice drops in timbre until it resembles a whole pack of rasping harnessed polar tent-pullers - 'it's part of the problem with so much of our culture; someone out there seems to want to foster that you should do it - read that book, watch that film - because it's "good for you". Which is precisely the wrong attitude, and must put people off; why can't we just be told that something's brilliant, and therefore we should get on with enjoying it?'

Which is, she says, how she was brought up, in Norway and then, after the age of six, Ireland 'Reading was never a chore, it was a joy. We weren't allowed telly except on a Saturday night; we read, and loved it. I can still remember the excitement. I can still remember, very early on, my dad coming home with a copy of The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe, and the sense of happiness. I've always loved reading; it's one thing I do well.'

She talks of some of her favourites - Tim Winton, Graham Greene, Don DeLillo. Some Rushdie, particularly The Moor's Last Sigh. Disgrace. Her South American period. During her disquisition on recent literary fads, talk turns to Bridget Jones, and she halts. 'Now that, too, was a good book. In fact, that was a great book. But not a Booker book.'

But why not? If it was popular, and made people laugh, and made people think, and was a good book, why shouldn't it be considered as such by our literary minders - especially given Mariella's earlier lit-snob arguments?

'Oh, I know, it's difficult.' She sighs. 'But it's not a Booker book, books like that aren't. I really think they have to be about big themes; themes that reflect the human condition, not just one part of it.

'You know, also, one other reason I get angry at people who snipe, is this: I'm proud to be asked to be on the panel. I'm really looking forward to it, and in many ways I don't care what people say. I think five years ago I would have been embarrassed and upset. But less so now. Maybe, finally, I'm growing up.'

If she is, she says, it will be the second time. 'I grew up pretty fast when I was young. I was precocious. But then well, I moved to London at 16, and sometimes it's been a bit of a blur. It feels like I've been racing headlong with blinkers on for a bit too long. Now, finally, I think I'd like to slow down a bit, and I'm ready to do the things I love; reading, and travelling.'

A music-business PR hot and hip off the ferry from Dublin, she saw the world, found a rock star husband (Richard Jobson, now ex - in both categories), waltzed into telly, and walked into a million Soho sound-studios to voice a generation of adverts with her famous dog-voice. In the annals of sex and drugs and rock 'n' roll, she freely admits, she leaves Ann Widdecombe standing.

'It was fun, but  was it worth it? Yes, but ' I ask about the best things the dizzy years had brought her, the time as a PR, networking and schmoozing through the Thatcher years; the years as mini-celeb. The years when Mariella and a few dozen others, charming though they all may have been in person (and she is funny and kind and all the rest) seemed to be single-handedly keeping the Brown Economy alive, i.e. bullshit in its many and not particularly varied forms. She thinks for a while. 'Um  getting tables in restaurants. Yes. Definitely that. And  being recognised in the street. And  Christ. Yes. Fuck. You're right.

'But look, I wasn't wholly driven by a need for fame. Also, I haven't that many regrets. Some of the TV stuff  okay some of that was a touch tacky. But there are limits. I said no to Hello! when they offered me £30,000 to come inside my beautiful home. Okay, I do a film column for the News of the Screws - but I'd rather it was me doing it, pushing good films, than someone else pushing the latest Arnie blockbuster.' I am intrigued about her drive; if not fame, then what? She grows rather quiet.

'Money. Security. I've always needed that, always needed to know I could provide for myself. I've never really felt financially secure, always been worried about it. You see  we never had much.' But what happened to the money coming in from her father, a respected foreign editor of the Irish Times ?

'He drank it. Pretty well drank it all.' Living the stereotype to the end - fearless, clever Irish hack - he drank himself to death at the age of 44. 'I don't ever remember him without a bottle of Soave. And I don't ever remember ever being sadder, in my life, than when he died.'

And now, finally, she says she's growing up, again; and she has the Booker job to prove it. 'I'm also more at peace intellectually. The older I get, the more people I meet, the more I realise it's people's talent and capacity for thought that counts more than anything.'

Fulfilled, and confident - but she would, she says, like to be in love. She smiles fondly as I ask when she was happiest, and answers 'When I was 10. I fell in love with the postmistress's son in Connemarra. What a lovely summer' But real love, grown-up love, she shrugs, still eludes her. 'And it's not me doing the dumping. They always dump me. But who knows. Yes I'd love to meet someone.'

As we leave, with her fretting about the number of books she has to read for the Booker - six a week, and she's going to be monstrously thorough, she says - she wonders what it will be like meeting the other Booker judges. 'Simon Jenkins,' she asks; 'What's he like? Will I hate him?' No, of course not, I answer, thinking that this isn't the question I might have expected. Five years ago, I suspect, with a different, insecure Mariella, ditzy darling of the PR set, I suspect I wouldn't have liked her so much. And the question would have been 'Will he hate me?'
