webTitle: Crisis hits secret atom bomb plant

fields.headline: Crisis hits secret atom bomb plant
fields.standfirst: Safety fears and outrage as 1,400 workers face axe at Aldermaston weapons factory
fields.trailText: More than a third of the workers at Britain's top-secret nuclear weapons factory are to be axed, sparking fears of a safety crisis when troubled British Nuclear Fuels takes over the highly sensitive plant this week.
fields.body:
More than a third of the workers at Britain's top-secret nuclear weapons factory are to be axed, sparking fears of a safety crisis when troubled British Nuclear Fuels takes over the highly sensitive plant this week.

The Observer can reveal that BNFL wants to get rid of 1,400 out of the 4,300 staff at the highly sensitive site near Aldermaston, with a tenth of the workforce being sacked in the first few months.

Local MPs, residents, trade unions and anti-nuclear groups have reacted with outrage. They believe the job losses will severely compromise the safety at the factory, which makes Britain's Trident nuclear weapons.

BNFL's safety record is already facing heavy criticism after revelations that it deliberately faked safety data at its nuclear reprocessing operations at Sellafield in Cumbria. The future of that site is now in jeopardy.

The Observer has obtained internal documents from the Environment Agency, one of the bodies which will monitor BNFL at Aldermaston, that shows its senior staff are worried about BNFL's ability to run the plant.

In December, a BNFL-led consortium won a 10-year £2.2bn contract to take over Aldermaston from 1 April. This followed a catalogue of serious safety and environmental breaches at the plant.

For the last seven years, Aldermaston has been run by Anglo-American consortium Hunting Brae, which cut 2,000 jobs since 1993. Some experts believe only luck prevented a major nuclear accident at the site and the Environment Agency recently prosecuted the management for illegal radioactive discharges into the Thames.

Trade unions at Aldermaston were informed of BNFL's plans last week and believe that slashing the workforce will escalate these breaches. William Peden, nuclear campaigner at Greenpeace, said: 'This latest round of job cuts means Aldermaston has slashed the workforce in half in less than 15 years. How can anyone believe this has had no impact on health and safety?'

BNFL's contract to run Aldermaston should start next Saturday, but concerns over its safety record and poor management have forced the Government to review the position. The Ministry of Defence is expected to make a final decision on Friday and is considering returning the running of the plant to the public sector. If BNFL loses the contract, it could be the final nail in the coffin for government plans to partly privatise it and rake in £1.5bn.

webTitle: The gambler  trumped by an Orange card

fields.headline: The gambler  trumped by an Orange card
fields.standfirst:
David Trimble always plays his hand with supreme confidence. But his luck may now be running out, reports Henry McDonald

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: There is a side to David Trimble's nature that surprises most commentators: he is ruthless, single-minded and supremely confident of victory in a political scrap. He is also a gambler. But yesterday the numbers ran against him and his losing colour was a distinct shade of Orange.
fields.body:
There is a side to David Trimble's nature that surprises most commentators: he is ruthless, single-minded and supremely confident of victory in a political scrap. He is also a gambler. But yesterday the numbers ran against him and his losing colour was a distinct shade of Orange.

Now the Ulster Unionist leader finds himself in a tight corner. His room for manoeuvre in fresh negotiations with Republicans and the British and Irish governments is severely restricted. As a result, the peace process has entered a new crisis.

The irony is that this was a leadership contest that Trimble, with his legendary self-confidence, actively provoked. But his failure to win a convincing majority against the Rev Martin Smyth represents not only a miscalculation of his own strength but a failure to marginalise the Orange Order.

Most of the Orange delegates yesterday voted for Smyth, a 68-year- old Presbyterian minister and party chief whip at Westminster. Smyth has impeccable loyalist credentials, being the former Grand Master of the Orange Order and a party grandee since the late Seventies.

Five years ago Trimble was the toast of Portadown Orangemen for his role in opposing rerouting of their annual parade away from the nationalist Garvaghy Road. But the order renounced him when he led the UUP into the Good Friday Agreement.

Trimble contemplated cutting his party's links with the order, which sent as of right 120 delegates out of 860 to yesterday's council meeting. Most voted for Smyth.

Under the arcane rules of the UUP's ruling body, the Ulster Unionist Council, no speeches by any candidates are allowed during a leadership crisis. All 860 delegates cast their votes in silence, which was a disadvantage to Trimble, given that his oratorical skills vastly surpass those of the evangelical Protestant minister threatening to usurp him as leader.

When the votes were counted - Smyth pulled 348 or 43.2 per cent votes to Trimble's 457, or 56.7 per cent - Trimble's allies convicted him not just of miscalculation but also of poor party management.

Back in November, Trimble won 58 per cent of the UUC vote to enable him to set up a government with Sinn Fein. His allies wanted him to get more than that this time, ideally somewhere close to the 70 per cent mark. Smyth on the other hand had been modest throughout the week, predicting that he had a 50:50 chance of winning the battle.

The real aim, however, of the 'No' camp was that Smyth should get over 40 per cent of the vote, enough they believed to undermine Trimble's authority and restrict his room for manoeuvre in negotiations with Sinn Fein.

The struggle between Smyth and Trimble is at its heart a battle for the future of Unionism in the twenty-first century.

Smyth represents an older version with an emphasis on Orangeism, evangelical Protestanism and loyalty to a Britain of faith and Crown, a Britain that is fading into memory in the rest of the UK.

Trimble personifies the new Unionism, with its appeal to Ulster's prosperous but generally apolitical secular middle class and its ability to reach out to make new allies in London, Dublin and Washington.

Trimble had good historical reasons to trust his own judgment. In 1995 his decision to stand for the leadership was widely regarded as audacious. But he defeated, among others, his present challenger, Martin Smyth.

The UUP leader displayed the same boldness three years later, when he confidently predicted that the Northern Ireland electorate would back the Good Friday Agreement by just over 70 per cent.

His prediction turned out to be surprisingly accurate, given that 73 per cent actually voted for the peace deal in May 1998. Such confidence allowed him to gamble with his own position as party leader, particularly in November last year, when he managed to persuade his party, just, to enter into an unprecedented if short-lived assembly with Sinn Fein.

As he returned from the United States earlier this month, following a punishing round of political meetings and parties in Washington in the build up to St Patrick's Day, Trimble reached deep into the well of his own self-confidence again to steel himself for the most serious challenge of his career since the Good Friday Agreement - a leadership election against one of his fellow Westminster MPs.

The move, which precipitated Smyth, MP for South Belfast since 1982, into challenging Trimble, was a speech the UUP leader delivered in Washington on St Patrick's Day. In an address to the US media, Trimble hinted that he might take a second leap of faith into government with Sinn Fein - that he would set up the power-sharing Executive again prior to IRA decommissioning.

Sceptical Unionists across the Atlantic were outraged, seeing it as another attempt to water down the party's insistence on IRA decommissioning as a prerequisite for power-sharing. According to anti-Agreement Unionists, this was the final straw: a leadership challenge was now a real possibility.

Although Trimble later protested that his words had been twisted and that he would only jump into government again with republicans if - and only if - the IRA said the war was over for good, it is clear the UUP leader had been planning a change of tactics for some time. Last month in an interview not picked up anywhere in the British and Irish media, Trimble hinted heavily to the Boston Herald that he was going to switch strategy.

'If they [the IRA and Sinn Fein] expect us to do the same thing [forming a government] again, we'll need something a bit more concrete. That, I think, is simple human nature The sooner it's resolved the better. The sooner we bounce back the better,' he told the US paper.

The interview clearly sent out a signal to republicans that he was still prepared to re-form the Northern Ireland Executive. His later comments in Washington were designed to exert pressure on the Sinn Fein leadership, which had been hoping to use the St Patrick's Day stage to portray Trimble in America as the wrecker of devolution and the peace process.

While Trimble stalked the corridors of power on Capitol Hill, back home his opponents were dithering over which was the best tactic to prevent him from another shift. The first option was a stalking-horse challenge with Portadown UUP councillor and militant right-wing anti-Agreement activist Jonathan Bell as the likely candidate. Until last week, Bell had made it clear he was prepared to stand against Trimble and win enough votes to wound the UUP leader mortally. Mysteriously, Bell announced last weekend that he was resigning from the party and withdrew his challenge.

But Trimble's allies at home were not complacent; they knew that another more serious contender was about to come into the field. One Trimble aide said: 'David has been expecting a leadership challenge from Christmas, in fact he was surprised there wasn't one last year. He was quite prepared for it and was relishing taking them on.'

Into the breach last Thursday stepped Smyth, Although regarded as a fair MP who delivers for both Protestant and Catholic constituents in South Belfast, Smyth has been a bitter opponent of the Good Friday Agreement, despite his warm personal relations with Trimble.

His challenge, however, was not met with joyous enthusiasm among other anti-Agreement UUP members, such as the Lagan Valley MP and former Trimble aide Jeffrey Donaldson.

Donaldson personally opposed the leadership contest because he regarded it as premature. He did not even turn up at Friday's official press launch for Smyth's campaign in a cramped and badly lit room in Belfast's Europa hotel.

There is also the question of Smyth's age and his ability to hold his own in negotiations with other more capable opponents, such as Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams. Those attending the Smyth press launch represented an alliance. On the one hand was the pensionable generation of old Unionists who remember a time when their party lorded over Northern Ireland before the Troubles. In collusion with them were the Young Unionists, the Ulster equivalent of the now defunct Federation of Conservative Students, whose far-right brand of Unionism unnerves a party leadership determined to build a new liberal image of the UUP across the world.

The press conference was chaired by Peter King, the head of the Young Unionists, who admitted that Smyth was only 'right at this time' to lead the UUP - a tacit admission that the Right would have preferred a more robust challenger, such as Jeffrey Donaldson.

In sharp contrast, Trimble's official campaign launch half an hour later in the UUP's Glengall Street HQ, just around the corner from the hotel, was a slick, carefully choreographed affair. It began with 18 of the party's 28 Northern Ireland Assembly members filing into the conference room, the walls of which are adorned with framed photographs of murdered UUP members, including the Rev Robert Bradford, Smyth's predecessor as MP for South Belfast. When Trimble walked into the room accompanied by his deputy, John Taylor, the Assembly members burst into polite applause.

The support of Taylor, who has been sceptical about re-entering government with Sinn Fein, was regarded as critical for Trimble.

Asked the evening before if he thought Smyth's challenge was serious, that he was simply a stalking-horse, Taylor characteristically replied: 'Stalking-horse? Oh no. Martin's a cart-horse.' With Taylor at his side, Trimble appeared to brim with confidence, predicting that he would not only win but also decisively end the virulent strain of scepticism that has blighted his leadership over the last two years. Or to quote another close ally, the Assemblyman and former Minister of Culture, Michael McGimpsey: 'It's time to put up or shut up.'

Comparisons with other political leaders in the situation, though, are not favourable. In June 1995, John Major issued a similar 'put up or shut up' challenge to his Euro-sceptics or 'bastards', as he memorably labelled them. The challenge was taken up by John Redwood and, although Major triumphed by 218 votes to 89, the Euro-sceptic lobby refused to shut up. Major limped on until the oblivion of 1 May 1997, mortally wounded during the last two years of his premiership by his right-wing opponents.

The Agreement-sceptics in the UUP have vowed that, whatever the result of the Trimble-Smyth contest, they will continue to snipe at the leadership's handling of the peace process. Like Major, Trimble has probably spent too much time indulging his internal critics rather than routing them.

webTitle: Trimble suffers blow in key poll

fields.headline: Trimble suffers blow in key poll
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Grassroots Ulster Unionists delivered a stunning blow to David Trimble yesterday when they only narrowly re-elected him leader, threatening his future stewardship of the party and further jeopardising the fragile Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
Grassroots Ulster Unionists delivered a stunning blow to David Trimble yesterday when they only narrowly re-elected him leader, threatening his future stewardship of the party and further jeopardising the fragile Northern Ireland peace process.

Trimble is now a prisoner of his right wing after defeating the Rev Martin Smyth in the leadership election. The UUP membership gave Smyth more than 40 per cent of the vote. Trimble suffered a second setback hours later when a motion was carried linking the party's re-entry into peace talks with the retention of the name of Northern Ireland's police force, the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Both results mean Trimble's room for manoeuvre in fresh negotiations with Sinn Fein will be severely curtailed.

At the annual meeting of the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council, the suspended First Minister received only 457 votes (56.8 per cent). His challenger, the MP for South Belfast, who opposes the Good Friday Agreement, polled 348 votes (43.2 per cent).

Smyth's strong showing shocked Trimble's allies outside the conference centre at Balmoral in south Belfast yesterday. They had predicted the challenger would poll well under 40 per cent.Trimble's target had been 70 per cent.

The vote was used by the UUP rank and file as a de facto referendum on the merits of the two-year-old peace agreement, but Michael McGimpsey, the UUP Assemblyman for south Belfast and a Trimble aide, said there was still 'rock-solid support' for his leader. McGimpsey blamed Smyth's robust performance on grassroots anger over the Patten report on the RUC and the IRA's continued refusal to decommission.

Willie Ross, the UUP MP for East Derry and another critic of the Good Friday Agreement, said the blame for Smyth's vote lay at Trimble's own feet, particularly his speech in Washington on St Patrick's Day when he hinted he would be flexible about re-entering government with Sinn Fein before IRA decommissioning.

The Prime Minister's office welcomed Trimble's re-election adding that Tony Blair held the UUP leader in the highest regard. Downing Street refused to comment on the narrowness of the win.

Sinn Fein's national chairman, Mitchel McLaughlin. said the result was worrying for nationalists, who wanted Trimble to implement the agreement.

Yesterday's events will be read in Dublin and London as a hardening of mood among unionists, who believe they have given too many concessions to republicans with little in return. They also call into question Peter Mandelson's prediction that the power-sharing Executive could be back in place by Easter.

webTitle: Click here to buy a bargain warship

fields.headline: Click here to buy a bargain warship
fields.trailText: It will give anyone with enough money a licence to kill. A new Internet site is advertising enough weaponry to start a war.
fields.body:
It will give anyone with enough money a licence to kill. A new Internet site is advertising enough weaponry to start a war.

The website, powertochooseit.com, was set up by two Blackburn-based property developers who used to concentrate on leasing unusual properties, fast cars and helicopters to the film and music industries.

Now, under the heading 'defend your own country', you can find a 4,800-ton Royal Navy warship described as 'little used' and in 'excellent condition'. The ship has an Exocet missile launcher and two helicopter pads and sleeps 270. Extras include 30mm cannon. When commissioned in 1984, it cost the British taxpayers £80m, but 16 years later the depreciation in secondhand frigates is such that it can now be offered at the bargain price of £300,000. The ship can be viewed at Plymouth.

Other military wares for sale include a Soviet MiG 17f bomber with a maximum speed of 710 mph. It is based in Poland and can be purchased for around £70,000.

It is not just weaponry that is available, however. A mature bull elephant was recently on sale for £2,500. Rhama was described as only understanding 'verbal commands in Thai'. Viewing was in Chomburi, Thailand, and the reason for sale was that Rhama, once employed in the logging industry, had been made redundant and a 'new tractor forces disposal'.

Other interesting objects for sale include a 'deceptively spacious' oil recovery platform. Currently moored in the North Sea and weighing 111,000 tons, it sleeps 215. Fully water-proofed, it can be towed to a site of your choice. Open to offers.

According to managing director Gerald Dunbar: 'We have been e-mailed from around the world from people who have unusual objects for sale. They are all legitimate. The frigate comes from the Ministry of Defence, who agreed to allow us to put it on our website.'

Dunbar added: 'We've got a Chieftain tank coming on the market this week. It's a bargain at £15,000.'

The company is adamant that the objects won't fall into the wrong hands. A spokesman said: 'These MiGs came from the 1960s, and are basically for people who collect historic aircraft, not for anyone who wants to wage war.

'Anything we sell will be perfectly legal and vetted by all the appropriate authorities.'

 antony.barnett@observer.co.uk

Other interesting objects for sale include a 'deceptively spacious' oil recovery platform. Currently moored in the North Sea and weighing 111,000 tons, it sleeps 215. Fully water-proofed, it can be towed to a site of your choice. Open to offers. According to managing director Gerald Dunbar: 'We have been e-mailed from around the world from people who have unusual objects for sale. They are all legitimate. The frigate comes from the Ministry of Defence, who agreed to allow us to put it on our website.' Dunbar added: 'We've got a Chieftain tank coming on the market this week. It's a bargain at £15,000.' The company is adamant that the objects won't fall into the wrong hands. A spokesman said: 'These MiGs came from the 1960s, and are basically for people who collect historic aircraft, not for anyone who wants to wage war. 'Anything we sell will be perfectly legal and vetted by all the appropriate authorities.'  antony.barnett@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Do I forgive a friend who ignored my wedding?

fields.headline: Do I forgive a friend who ignored my wedding?
fields.trailText: I've been friends with P since university. He accepted the invitation to the wedding, but on the day he didn't turn up.
fields.body:
I've been friends with P since university, when he briefly went out with a friend of mine. We've always been close, to the extent that when I got engaged he came on my hen night. He accepted the invitation to the wedding, but on the day he didn't turn up. I hear through the grapevine that he was sent abroad by his work at short notice, but he has never contacted me to explain this himself.

It's a year since I got married. Now I see P in the distance at the supermarket or gym, and since I feel distressed and angry, I hide from him. If our friendship meant so little to him, I don't want to resurrect it, but I don't want these incidents to get in the way of my life. What should I do?

TF of London

A powerful sense of resentment comes through in your letter, probably a coded expression of a deeper attachment between you and P than mere friendship. You would do well to think about your feelings and what you expect from him.

A platonic friendship between people of different genders can be very special, with the sexual tension kept under control but somehow enhancing the strength of the tie. It's as if you were saying: 'I find you very attractive and it's only that you and I are spoken-for, and unavailable, that keeps a restraint on my feelings.'

A woman conscious of her own power to attract, even though she has a stable partner, likes to have a few satellite males willing to dance attendance and flirt a little. She likes to boast of her admirers and feel she could play the field. Sometimes, there is only one devotee whom she may treat with alternate indulgence and neglect. A courtier of this sort may get fed up eventually and take himself off.

On the other hand, you may have attached greater meaning to this man's commitment to you than was intended. Some men treat all single women as potential mates until removed from the pool by marriage. It is possible he was only interested in you as long as you were available.

His discourtesy in not sending you his apologies is reprehensible, as is his failure to make any kind of friendly contact since your wedding. But such civilities do not come easily to some people. Men are generally much worse at regarding social niceties than women, and attach less importance to them.

Your response in hiding from the friend whom you feel is at fault is illogical, but typically female! You clearly want to continue the friendship, in spite of his faults. Lift up your courage and go out of your way to meet him. Be light-hearted, swallow your sense of offence.

When you've re-established rapport, you could chide him gently for his neglect. You'll soon find out his attitude towards you; whether he wants to continue your special friendship, or whether he has simply crossed you off his list.

Reader's responses

If your friend didn't turn up at the wedding, then maybe he missed it for a very good reason. Some people find them minefields of emotional upheaval and prefer to stay away. Approach your friend when you next see him at the supermarket or the gym. Don't instantly reproach him, but ask what he has been doing since you last saw him. He will probably be as relieved as you to break the stalemate.

D.A. New Zealand

I have known friendships that change. What was once physical becomes spiritual as contact diminishes and lives take different courses. People I will probably never see again remain loved and the recipients of my goodwill.

I think you need to identify why you continue to feel so distressed and angry. Avoidance can be a pale shadow of authentic living. Be true to yourself and don't let P's choices interfere with your own. In the fullness of time, you may meet, and explanations will follow.

N.E. of Wiltshire

Next week's problem is from NG of Hampshire

My husband and I have one child. We do not plan to have any more. However, when I talk to people who are only children, they tell me how much they would have loved to have had siblings.

My life is quite well balanced and a second child would be a strain, both financially and emotionally. Am I being selfish or am I being influenced by the consensus that people should have more than one child?

Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday.

fields.headline: The Max factor
fields.standfirst: Louise Clifford has followed her father into the family PR business. It's not the most obvious platform from which to champion good causes, says  Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: Louise Clifford has followed her father into the family PR business. It's not the most obvious platform from which to champion good causes, says  Sarah Ryle
fields.body:
Louise Clifford looks just like her mother. She is petite and pretty, with a little nose and nice if wary eyes. But it is her father, PR guru Max, whom she aspires to be and whose unexpectedly quiet, ultra-polite manner she displays. She oozes adoration for him. He is her role model and has been her rock through her growing years as she handled the debilitating disease rheumatoid arthritis. Now he is also her boss.

At last week's British Press Awards ('the Oscars of the newspaper industry'), Louise joined the team from the News of the World while her parents supped with the pack from Harrods. 'They asked my dad but he was already going, so they got me instead,' Louise beams. She doesn't seem to mind being second choice. Unlike some children of famous people, she is happy to stand firmly in her father's shadow. She is, as she says, still learning her trade.

'I'd rather be known as Louise the daughter of Max Clifford, who is making a career in PR, than Louise the champion for disabled rights,' she admits. Which is bad news, in a sense, for Scope, the 'national disability organisation whose focus is people with cerebral palsy'. Scope has just published Stop Press! - a survey of words and pictures used to describe disability. They asked Louise to be interviewed in order to raise the report's profile. It should be right up her street because it highlights the 'appalling' way disability is handled. In 1,000 references to disability one month last year in national daily newspapers, 800 were deemed 'offensive' or 'discriminatory'.

As someone who had to use a wheelchair until she was 15, who also is more media savvy than most, Louise ought to be the ideal spokeswoman. Far from sticking to the points raised by Stop Press!, though, she seems more comfortable talking about her job and her life as Max's daughter. Louise is 28, and 18 months into her working life. She has been propelled to the giddy heights (or, some would say, depths) of Max Clifford's Planet Tabloid with just a year of hard experience and a three-year degree at Bournemouth in communications.

The Charlottes and Alexanders who currently churn out fodder for City PR firms may sneer at Max Clifford Associates, but they'd be fools. Clifford has cornered the market in lucrative dosh-for-dirt stories. He is a household name. He is, probably, the best at what he does.

'I can pick up the phone and give my name and editors will talk to me. That doesn't happen to most people,' she states. Louise states most things. There isn't enough expression in her quiet, measured voice to say she boasts.

It is Max's domination of the juicy tales that has his daughter on first name terms with Piers (as in the Mirror's Morgan) and Phil (as in the News of the World's Hall). Is she excited? Not a bit of it. 'I've grown up answering the phone at weekends to these people,' she explains. She considers the notion that she is just another rich kid with a famous parent to ease her path into a stab-em-in-the-back competitive world, but not for long.

'I don't mind,' she says. 'Why should I? I know I'm good at what I do although I'm still learning. My dad thinks that there is a real shortage of good people in PR. What's important is being creative, imaginative and working hard. I know what the competition is like and I'm not that impressed.'

She is unusually unconcerned about what she should or should not say. She is happy to talk about her dad's most famous clients. Antonia de Sanchez, she who had the mattress-in-the-basement, Chelsea shirt-wearing affair with former Cabinet Minister David Mellor, 'hated every minute' of the publicity and had never sought it, apparently. 'The friend of David Mellor's who let him use his flat bugged the phone and there is no law against that,' explains Louise. 'He sold the story. It was never Antonia's doing.'

Bu Max was there to guide her through it, as he was with Bienvenida Buck ('She loved all the publicity and she still rings Dad. She's hosting a TV show in Spain.') This brings us to the Clifford reputation: the common perception is that if there is scandal, there is Clifford. Jeffrey Archer's recent problems, Gary Glitter's ex-lover, the model who shoved a cream cake in Agriculture Minister Nick Brown's face. These are the most recent stories. But Louise insists that whatever the commentators say, the public loves her dad. 'People are really vociferous in their praise. They come up to him in the street and shake his hand.'

Her dad, she says, warns people who bring their stories to him that they can expect massive exposure. He tells them to go away and think about it again.

The measure of Clifford's fame is his recent appearance on the front page of the Mirror, wearing two black eyes after tackling some 'louts' after a debate at Cambridge University. This is exposure reserved for only the most household of names. Louise says she has always been very close to her father. Like her mother, he was always there. But it is her dad she talks about most. 'He never let me feel that I was just a disability, even though there was so much medical stuff and deformity around me. He always talked about my qualities.'

She insists she didn't set out to follow in his footsteps, though: 'I questioned whether I should be doing something a bit more caring like teaching or counselling, but then again that would be a bit of a cliché as well because you come up through the medical route and get to know hospitals and doctors and counsellors inside out.'

Discrimination is something that she is so matter of fact about that the inference has to be she is alarmingly accustomed to it. She says she was bullied at her state school in Wimbledon and begged to be sent to a school where there were other disabled children.

'I know some people say this is not helpful because it separates people out, but it made me feel more normal. At the mainstream school I felt physical disability was a problem they just couldn't deal with. If I'd had behavioural problems, they had people for that.' But the boarding school wasn't academic and hospital visits conspired to persuade Louise she wasn't either. 'I didn't do GCSEs, but I did go on to college to get A-levels and then did my degree. I wrote my dissertation on the way TV represents disability.' Ah yes. Disability in the media. Surely this was the moment to talk about the Scope report? When pushed, Louise has a view.

'My first thought was that it seemed a shame that the report doesn't seem to find much improvement since the last one 10 years ago. It surprised me because I've grown up in a period when the disability movement has got more and more organised. So you think other people are becoming more aware but you realise they are not.'

Nevertheless, one of Louise's closest friends is Jane Campbell, a leading light in the disability movement. 'She is trying to get me more involved. One of the things I feel strongly about is direct payments to personal assistants. People should have the money and be able to employ the right people. They are being clobbered over what are essential services, not luxuries. My condition restricts me in terms of personal care. I can't reach my feet to put my shoes on. It is not like having an au pair. I have friends in wheelchairs who are more independent than I am.'

And she doesn't like the way that new discoveries are hyped up. 'My nan was always ringing me up and saying "Louise have you seen this new cure, people are running up and down stairs with it." But you know it will be three years before clinical trials even begin.' People should, she says, think very carefully about the words they use and think whether they would talk about race in the same way as disability.

Louise admits she's special. Not because she's disabled. Not because she is heroic in the face of a debilitating disease. But because she is Max's daughter.

webTitle: Too many seats, not enough bums...

fields.headline: Too many seats, not enough bums...
fields.standfirst: Despite notable box office hits, business is not booming in the West End. Are we too spoilt for choice?
fields.trailText: Despite notable box office hits, business is not booming in the West End. Are we too spoilt for choice?
fields.body:
Does London have too many theatres? That's the radical view doing the rounds at the moment, with some people arguing that the capital has more theatres than any longer makes practical sense. It may look healthy on the surface: new Pinter opening this week, Maggie Smith in Alan Bennett's The Lady in the Van playing to packed houses, Patrick Marber getting raves in Speed the Plow.

Yet beneath the perception of a flourishing theatre, endlessly ripe for export to Broadway, is a climate - in commercial terms, certainly - of struggling shows chasing an insufficient public and of 40-odd West End theatres flailing about in a search for a just above-average product.

This scenario may not have been in evidence over, for instance, The Real Thing, which repeatedly broke box-office records during its recent run at the Albery Theatre, doing business on a level that most would envy.

But that kind of hit - The Lady In the Van paid back its £400,000 costs in just two months - is increasingly uncommon in a city where the commercial also-rans are less trumpeted than the occasional runaway success. Small wonder that theatre-owners are thrilled to find themselves giving homes to long runs like the Reduced Shakespeare Company (now five years old at the Criterion), The Woman In Black (11 years), An Inspector Calls (nearly eight), and, of course, The Mousetrap, now in its forty-eighth year and still selling out some weekends.

If a show can establish its own West End toehold, then that's one less venue whose owners need worry about new product. The only glitch: nothing is 'now and forever', to paraphrase the advertising slogan for Cats on Broadway, where the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical closes this summer after nearly 18 years.

The London theatre can give the illusion of prosperity because many theatres need only half-full houses to accrue a weekly profit, though it is disconcerting to discover that Helen Mirren in Collected Stories had quite a few nights when the 884-seat Theatre Royal, Haymarket, was barely selling 200 tickets. (That play's successor Miss Julie, starring Christopher Eccleston, hasn't been doing much better.)

Nor do accolades necessarily pull in the punters. Critics' darling Spend Spend Spend, has had its fair share of performances with the Piccadilly's upper reaches roped off so as to concentrate what audience there is down below, while Ayckbourn's Comic Potential, whose star Janie Dee has won a number of big awards, has failed to fill the Lyric. One of the reasons why the London theatres collectively will never agree to reporting the weekly West End grosses in my publication, Variety, is because many producers don't want anyone to know how badly their shows are doing. Let's just say that the Lyceum theatre's £20 million advance for The Lion King is not the norm.

So is there too much theatre? 'I don't think there are ever again going to be 40-odd attractions that would guarantee that all those theatres were full,' says Duncan C. Weldon, the West End veteran who began producing in 1969, with When We Are Married at the Strand. 'Ultimately, the situation here will be like New York. We will have to rearrange how the theatre industry works, and particular theatres will have to go dark.'

'No theatre now can count on a theatre-going constituency,' said the ex-head of the National Theatre Richard Eyre last week, at a lecture in aid of Lamda, adding elsewhere in his speech that 'a theatre without an audience is as pointless as an unguided missile.'

As it exists now, a theatre owner's fixed costs - those overheads known as the 'contra' that hover in the £12,000- £14,000 a week range for an average-sized venue - are ongoing whether or not the theatre has a show booked. It pays a venue to find something, no matter what, in order to collect rent. That explains the proliferation of openings from, among others, producer Bill Kenwright, whose brisk output has been a theatre owner's dream. 'I see a theatre free for eight weeks,' notes Kenwright dryly, 'and I open 22 minutes later.'

Interestingly, the Lautrec musical written by Charles Aznavour, which opens next month at the Shaftesbury theatre, will have to move out in the autumn as the theatre is already booked to house another musical, Napoleon.

Still, call it an interim booking or filler or whatever you like, the fact is that very few people even remember (let alone went to) Kenwright's own Four Steps To Heaven at the Piccadilly or - from other producers - Peter Barnes's Dreaming last summer at the Queen's or the husband-and-wife Hestons, Charlton and Lydia, in Love Letters at the Haymarket.

Of course, top-of-the-line fringe venues like the Bush, the Donmar, and the Almeida regularly sell out. ('If I can't sell 100 tickets a night in this town, I should be shot,' says Mike Bradwell, artistic director of the 105-seat Bush).

The rub comes when shows - sometimes from those same quarters - risk West End theatres five or 10 times the size. Last summer, everyone wanted to see The Real Thing in the intimacy of the 251-seat Donmar; come the autumn, and you couldn't give tickets away when the same producers put on Antigone, with Tara Fitzgerald, in the inhospitably big and ill-suited Old Vic.

'In any given year, there probably aren't enough good plays, particularly new ones, as there are theatres to put them on,' says Mark Ravenhill, who is one of the few contemporary dramatists to have benefited from the filler scenario with his play Shopping and Fucking. Perhaps the real argument isn't for less theatre but for a shift in assumptions about that theatre, given, as Weldon argues, that 'the commercial theatre will never be as strong and as big as it was'.

And why should it? The fact is, the public is hardly going to want to go to an increasingly pricey and overcrowded West End when they can see (and pack out) Pinter or Kevin Spacey at the Almeida or Theatre de Complicite at the Riverside, where Mnemonic was one of the few tough tickets of a soft-selling millennium theatre season.

'The theatre as a form keeps shifting, so the venues in which it's happening have to adapt,' says Jude Kelly, artistic director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds. 'Sometimes the theatre may become moribund as a result.'

Maybe a solution is to play up to audience tastes rather than pandering to them, with the result that you get the surprise success of the Almeida's Racine season 18 months ago in the West End or, more recently, of John Hurt in Beckett's solo play, Krapp's Last Tape. The average attendance for Hurt's Beckett was 87 per cent.

'Nature abhors a vacuum,' says Howard Panter, managing director of Ambassador Theatre Group, which owns the New Ambassadors where Krapp's Last Tape was on. 'New things come along that are creative, though I'm not going to pretend that everything is either high quality or making money.' Says the Bush's Mike Bradwell: 'There are an awful lot of empty libraries. At the same time, we wouldn't want to restrict the numbers of libraries.'

There is an altogether separate point to be made that one needs a sort of ongoing morass of work from which truly meritorious offerings can emerge. After all, what sort of Oscar race would there be tonight if only 10 films got released every year?

'You need to have a pile of shit to stand on,' says Peter Hall, who in his seventieth year has surveyed the London theatre from every perspective possible. 'That's one of the reasons we have so much good theatre. Unfortunately, in this Darwinian world you have to have some not very good things in order to make good things - whether it's animals or human beings or art.'

It may look healthy on the surface: new Pinter opening this week, Maggie Smith in Alan Bennett's The Lady in the Van playing to packed houses, Patrick Marber getting raves in Speed the Plow. This scenario may not have been in evidence over, for instance, The Real Thing, which repeatedly broke box-office records during its recent run at the Albery Theatre, doing business on a level that most would envy. But that kind of hit - The Lady In the Van paid back its £400,000 costs in just two months - is increasingly uncommon in a city where the commercial also-rans are less trumpeted than the occasional runaway success. Small wonder that theatre-owners are thrilled to find themselves giving homes to long runs like the Reduced Shakespeare Company (now five years old at the Criterion), The Woman In Black (11 years), An Inspector Calls (nearly eight), and, of course, The Mousetrap, now in its forty-eighth year and still selling out some weekends. If a show can establish its own West End toehold, then that's one less venue whose owners need worry about new product. The only glitch: nothing is 'now and forever', to paraphrase the advertising slogan for Cats on Broadway, where the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical closes this summer after nearly 18 years. The London theatre can give the illusion of prosperity because many theatres need only half-full houses to accrue a weekly profit, though it is disconcerting to discover that Helen Mirren in Collected Stories had quite a few nights when the 884-seat Theatre Royal, Haymarket, was barely selling 200 tickets. (That play's successor Miss Julie, starring Christopher Eccleston, hasn't been doing much better.) Nor do accolades necessarily pull in the punters. Critics' darling Spend Spend Spend, has had its fair share of performances with the Piccadilly's upper reaches roped off so as to concentrate what audience there is down below, while Ayckbourn's Comic Potential, whose star Janie Dee has won a number of big awards, has failed to fill the Lyric. One of the reasons why the London theatres collectively will never agree to reporting the weekly West End grosses in my publication, Variety, is because many producers don't want anyone to know how badly their shows are doing. Let's just say that the Lyceum theatre's £20 million advance for The Lion King is not the norm. So is there too much theatre? 'I don't think there are ever again going to be 40-odd attractions that would guarantee that all those theatres were full,' says Duncan C. Weldon, the West End veteran who began producing in 1969, with When We Are Married at the Strand. 'Ultimately, the situation here will be like New York. We will have to rearrange how the theatre industry works, and particular theatres will have to go dark.' 'No theatre now can count on a theatre-going constituency,' said the ex-head of the National Theatre Richard Eyre last week, at a lecture in aid of Lamda, adding elsewhere in his speech that 'a theatre without an audience is as pointless as an unguided missile.' As it exists now, a theatre owner's fixed costs - those overheads known as the 'contra' that hover in the £12,000- £14,000 a week range for an average-sized venue - are ongoing whether or not the theatre has a show booked. It pays a venue to find something, no matter what, in order to collect rent. That explains the proliferation of openings from, among others, producer Bill Kenwright, whose brisk output has been a theatre owner's dream. 'I see a theatre free for eight weeks,' notes Kenwright dryly, 'and I open 22 minutes later.' Interestingly, the Lautrec musical written by Charles Aznavour, which opens next month at the Shaftesbury theatre, will have to move out in the autumn as the theatre is already booked to house another musical, Napoleon. Still, call it an interim booking or filler or whatever you like, the fact is that very few people even remember (let alone went to) Kenwright's own Four Steps To Heaven at the Piccadilly or - from other producers - Peter Barnes's Dreaming last summer at the Queen's or the husband-and-wife Hestons, Charlton and Lydia, in Love Letters at the Haymarket. Of course, top-of-the-line fringe venues like the Bush, the Donmar, and the Almeida regularly sell out. ('If I can't sell 100 tickets a night in this town, I should be shot,' says Mike Bradwell, artistic director of the 105-seat Bush). The rub comes when shows - sometimes from those same quarters - risk West End theatres five or 10 times the size. Last summer, everyone wanted to see The Real Thing in the intimacy of the 251-seat Donmar; come the autumn, and you couldn't give tickets away when the same producers put on Antigone, with Tara Fitzgerald, in the inhospitably big and ill-suited Old Vic. 'In any given year, there probably aren't enough good plays, particularly new ones, as there are theatres to put them on,' says Mark Ravenhill, who is one of the few contemporary dramatists to have benefited from the filler scenario with his play Shopping and Fucking. Perhaps the real argument isn't for less theatre but for a shift in assumptions about that theatre, given, as Weldon argues, that 'the commercial theatre will never be as strong and as big as it was'. And why should it? The fact is, the public is hardly going to want to go to an increasingly pricey and overcrowded West End when they can see (and pack out) Pinter or Kevin Spacey at the Almeida or Theatre de Complicite at the Riverside, where Mnemonic was one of the few tough tickets of a soft-selling millennium theatre season. 'The theatre as a form keeps shifting, so the venues in which it's happening have to adapt,' says Jude Kelly, artistic director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds. 'Sometimes the theatre may become moribund as a result.' Maybe a solution is to play up to audience tastes rather than pandering to them, with the result that you get the surprise success of the Almeida's Racine season 18 months ago in the West End or, more recently, of John Hurt in Beckett's solo play, Krapp's Last Tape. The average attendance for Hurt's Beckett was 87 per cent. 'Nature abhors a vacuum,' says Howard Panter, managing director of Ambassador Theatre Group, which owns the New Ambassadors where Krapp's Last Tape was on. 'New things come along that are creative, though I'm not going to pretend that everything is either high quality or making money.' Says the Bush's Mike Bradwell: 'There are an awful lot of empty libraries. At the same time, we wouldn't want to restrict the numbers of libraries.' There is an altogether separate point to be made that one needs a sort of ongoing morass of work from which truly meritorious offerings can emerge. After all, what sort of Oscar race would there be tonight if only 10 films got released every year? 'You need to have a pile of shit to stand on,' says Peter Hall, who in his seventieth year has surveyed the London theatre from every perspective possible. 'That's one of the reasons we have so much good theatre. Unfortunately, in this Darwinian world you have to have some not very good things in order to make good things - whether it's animals or human beings or art.'

webTitle: Carmen or the Chuckle Brothers - now that's a tough one

fields.headline: Carmen or the Chuckle Brothers - now that's a tough one
fields.trailText: The Rake's Progress, Carmen | Pelléas and Mélisande
fields.body:
The Rake's Progress, Carmen Hexagon, Reading

Pelléas and Mélisande Coliseum, London WC2

Only the manifold talents of a company such as English Touring Opera could persuade you to spend two evenings, almost voluntarily, in the Hexagon, Reading. Such is the minimal charm of this 1977 edifice that the maligned Barbican appears a Taj Mahal in comparison. The brown hessian hanging off the walls dates its last (or first?) decoration all too accurately.

Judging from the small audiences, the people of Reading don't flock to fill its cavernous reaches either, though The Supremes and the Chuckle Brothers (appearing soon) are said to do well. Last week, Chris Smith opened the restored Town Hall, with its refurbished 1864 Father Willis organ, as well as a museum and art gallery. A strong season of concerts is planned for the 780-seat hall, silent as a music venue for a decade. Now it should be the turn of this six-sided concrete barn to get some of that same Heritage lottery money and have a revamp, before opera dies in the city completely.

ETO, an unrivalled asset to operatic life, managed gamely none the less. No stranger to tricky venues, it knows the nation's arts centres all too well, from Hexagon to Octagon (Yeovil), Crawley to Crewe. The spring tour follows the company's usual practice of staging a new production and a revival. The Rake's Progress, Stravinsky's 1951 opera after Hogarth's engravings, to a libretto by W.H. Auden and Chester Kallman, was the season's novelty. Robert Chevara brought customary clarity to this brittle piece of neo-classicism, designed in tangy, fresh colours by Emma Cattell, avoiding any whiff of predictable over-the-top campness.

Baba the Turk (the bearded lady), whom Stravinsky's lawyer called a 'distasteful homosexual joke', was indeed a bearded lady rather than a louche cross-dresser, a curiosity rather than a stereotype. She thereby challenged preconceptions all the more rigorously. All the principals gave intelligent performances. The orchestra, conducted by Andrew Greenwood, relished Stravinsky's tart wit, with fine woodwind solos. To perform to this standard with almost no response from the audience, mostly too far from the stage to engage with this teasing work, was a real feat.

Attendance at Carmen was healthier, as might be expected. The modern-dress production, again by Chevara with sets by Yannis Thavoris, emphasised the drabness of tobacco-factory life, rather than Spanish heat and light. Emma Selway, sharing the Carmen with Katija Dragojevic, has a sensational voice, but her pale beauty and statuesque physique seemed miscast. A natural for the queens and countesses of the operatic repertoire, she seemed uneasy as a hot, hip-waggling Mediterranean gypsy. Yet musical standards were high and the score sizzled, with Jeffrey Lloyd-Roberts catching the slow-witted anger of Don José to perfection, and Pamela Wilcock an affecting Micaëla. This is opera played straight and without fuss.

No one could accuse English National Opera's Pelléas and Mélisande of unnecessary clutter. First seen at Opera North in 1995, its set (by Antony McDonald) consists largely of what might be a large blackboard on which someone has chalked the outline of a wonky three-roomed house. In the orchestral interludes, played in their extended versions, a front cloth descended, depicting this house alone by the sea. Maeterlinck's play (which Debussy reworked) makes much of the oppressive forest. Yet this landscape was peculiarly denuded, as if specially chosen as an example of global deforestation, or set in a place famous for its treelessness - Shetland, or Long Island maybe.

But the extent to which the work's obsession with trees, pools, stagnant water should be taken literally has always been a matter for debate. Producers are free to do what they want. Symbolism is about symbols after all.

By taking this naked approach, Richard Jones forces the dark triangle of Mélisande, her husband Golaud and her lover Pelléas into grim focus. Only her long russet-red hair breaks the monochrome. Arkel (Clive Bayley), usually bearded and sage-like, has become a ghostly, hairless creature, twitching like a stoat. Thirteen-year-old David Wigram was enchanting as the pitiful Yniold, overgrown but emotionally stunted. At the end, the three cell-like rooms have become a morgue, Mélisande in one, Pelléas laid out in the next. In the last, a brilliant stroke, the gangly Yniold has pulled a sheet over his head, dead in life.

In Robert Hayward (Golaud), Joan Rodgers (Mélisande) and Garry Magee (Pelléas), ENO has a superb line-up of singing-actors. The orchestra, conducted by Paul Daniel, got into its stride as the work progressed, especially in the climactic third act. Hugh Macdonald's translation was easy to hear but has some bafflingly unmusical aberrations. Early on (and I was troubled hearing the same translation in Birmingham last week), Mélisande's first words are the percussive 'Ne me touchez pas'. Debussy set each of the five syllables to a separate note. Macdonald makes it 'Don't touch me', which loses two beats like dropped stitches. Comprehensibility is one thing. Leaving a gaping hole in the music is a more damaging matter.

fields.headline: Among giants
fields.standfirst: The new-look Oasis are leaner, more experimental and still have the best frontman in British rock. The backing guys aren't too bad either, says  Barbara Ellen
fields.trailText: Oasis
fields.body:
Oasis Bataclan, Paris

If Paul 'Guigsy' McGuigan or Paul 'Bonehead' Arthur had happened to be present at the first date of Oasis's European tour, at the Paris Bataclan, they might have felt slightly miffed at how obviously well new guitarist Andy Bell and new bassist Gem Archer were fitting in. For all their blunt charm, Guigsy and Bonehead always looked like they had wandered out to buy a bag of chips, bumped into Noel Gallagher at a bus stop, and somehow managed to inveigle their way into the biggest British rock'n'roll band of recent times.

By contrast, standing up there on the Parisian stage, Archer, formerly of Heavy Stereo, and Bell, formerly of Ride and Hurricane, look engaged, confident, even slightly predatory. Indeed, they look like what they are - not merry-hearted, interchangeable foot soldiers who know when they are well off, and are just happy to come along for the ride, but established songwriters who are more than able, and totally determined, to contribute properly to Oasis. With Archer and Bell on board, it isn't just a case of a new-look Oasis. Subtly, stealthily, it's a whole new sound too.

Live, there's still the feral energy of old (mainly thanks to Liam), but there's also far greater clarity and fluidity. The last time I saw Oasis was on the ill-fated Be Here Now tour, during which a 'tired and emotional' Noel Gallagher decided that giant clocks, cars and phone boxes were the way forward for rock'n'roll stage design. Noel has since been the first to admit that he was on such a giant bender, his Mastermind specialist subject at the time could have been 'The Colombian Export Industry, And My Part In It'.

Unfortunately, in a live context, the drug-fuelled madness affected Oasis in more ways than just visual. All too often, the songs were buried alive in bombast and melodrama, with Oasis behaving like bad chefs - pouring more and more rich sauce on top in an effort to disguise the fact that the meat was bad. This time around, the sound is more sanguine, stripped down and intimate. Be Here Now tracks are noticeable by their absence, while old classics such as 'Live Forever', 'Supersonic' and 'Cigarettes & Alcohol' are delivered with the laid-back swagger we have come to expect. Strangely, only 'Wonderwall' sounds lacklustre - as if blowing the dust off it required too much effort.

Interestingly, new songs from Standing on the Shoulder of Giants make a lot more sense live. I happen to think Giants is a pretty good album anyway (and I say that, stoically resigned to the fact that Noel Gallagher has an irritating, self-destructive habit of slagging off his own material and making his more sympathetic critics look bloody stupid).

In a live setting, 'Sunday Morning Call', a clock-watcher of an album track if ever I heard one, develops a dark, deep undercurrent of regret and reflection. Likewise, the steaming rendition of 'Who Feels Love' (a great song marred by an obvious and unnecessary 'Dear Prudence' steal). Elsewhere, the brilliant but moronically titled 'Fuckin' in the Bushes' could have done with being less raucous, and, if I never hear the execrable punk thrash of 'I Can See A Liar' again, I will die a happy music critic.

Of course, it doesn't hurt that the Bataclan is about as big as London's Astoria (it's a rare treat to see them up so close), or that, as ever, Liam is on ruthlessly good form. Because we see him in the papers every day, looking sullen and simian in an expensive cagoule, it's too easy to forget that, where it matters, on stage and in the studio, he is the biggest stick of dynamite to explode in British rock for 20-odd years.

A transcendent vocalist, Liam Gallagher can make weak songs sound great, and great songs sound greater. Such is his charisma that, in Paris, he even makes the tambourine (the three- wheeled van of the musical instrument world) look cool. He can't even be written off as a hybrid of John Lydon and John Lennon any more - Liam Gallagher is beyond all that. Liam Gallagher is Liam Gallagher - doing effortlessly and brilliantly what lesser frontmen struggle to do adequately.

While they might not be as massive as they once were, Oasis remain a righteously organic band who deserve a little respect. After all, unwittingly perhaps, Oasis were in their own way a hugely political force. Away from the headlines, they singlehandedly embarrassed the lazy, cynical music industry into taking rock musicianship and rock musicians seriously again.

When they escaped from their backgrounds, they took Britain's bored, disaf fected youth along for the ride. Maybe that is why, away from the media sniping, there is still such huge goodwill towards Oasis. It is certainly good to see the new-style Oasis working so productively in Paris. Noel Gallagher, British music's greatest living control freak, looks more relaxed, less the fusspot scout leader, than he ever has. The band itself seems all the better - friskier, more experimental - for the recent influx of new blood. Indeed, in Paris, Oasis looked like they're ready to thrive again. Got any better ideas?

Oasis play Dublin Lansdowne Road (8 July); Bolton Reebok Stadium (15, 16 July); Wembley Stadium (21, 22 July); Edinburgh Murrayfield (29 July); Reading Festival (25 August); Leeds Festival (28 August)

webTitle: Middle aged hit by tough benefits regime

fields.headline: Middle aged hit by tough benefits regime
fields.trailText: Hundreds  of thousands of people aged between 25 and 50 are to be drawn into Labour's tough 'three strikes and you're out' scheme for cutting the jobless figures.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of people aged between 25 and 50 are to be drawn into Labour's tough 'three strikes and you're out' scheme for cutting the jobless figures.

Details will be announced tomorrow about extending Labour's flagship New Deal policy to everyone under 50 who has been out of work for 18 months or longer.

Entry to the programme will mean months of weekly interviews with an individual case worker, followed by an offer of a job or retraining.

Participants will have limited choice about whether to take the jobs offered. Those suspected of not wanting to work will have benefits removed for between a fortnight and six months.

The scheme, that was introduced in 1998 for under-25s out of work for six months or more, costs £2,000 per head. About a third of those who take part are found jobs and about one in 20 is penalised.

Tory Social Services spokesman David Willetts said: 'What the Government has done is claim every young person who has got a job after entering the New Deal as having been found work by the New Deal.

'That is very arrogant. Youth unemployment was falling anyway, and there is no evidence the New Deal has made any difference.'

Defenders of the system say it has taught the long-term jobless basic disciplines, such as punctuality, and that the sanctions are there only to weed out those who deliberately cheat the system.

Employment Minister Tessa Jowell will announce details of the £350m-a-year extension to the New Deal tomorrow. She will claim it pays for itself through the money saved from those who stop drawing benefit and begin paying tax.

fields.headline: Building Bridget
fields.standfirst: She's the third generation of cinema's greatest acting clan, but Bridget Fonda has never quite made the A-list. Now, with five films due out in the next year, Henry's granddaughter is at last creating a name for herself
fields.trailText: She's the third generation of cinema's greatest acting clan, but Bridget Fonda has never quite made the A-list. Now, with five films due out in the next year, Henry's granddaughter is at last creating a name for herself
fields.body:
Who is Bridget Fonda? It's an easy question to answer on a dynastic level: granddaughter of Henry, daughter of Peter, niece of Jane. Personally and professionally, however, she's a little harder to pin down. Despite making more than 30 films in the course of a 13-year career, the 'breakthrough' role continues to elude her; for every commercial and critical success, like the stalker-plagued flatmate in Single White Female or the hotpanted, doped-up schemer in Quentin Tarantino's Jackie Brown, there has been a raft of what could most benevolently be described as 'quirky' indie projects, like Rough Magic (where she played a magician's assistant who laid an egg that hatched into a tarantula, before turning into a Mayan goddess - Fonda, that is, not the tarantula) and Drop Dead Fred (basically a doomed Hollywood vehicle for Rik Mayall in which she languished on the sidelines as a 'cold, huge-boobed bimbo'). She's more often mistaken for Helen Hunt or Jodie Foster than recognised for herself. 'I have no regular shtick,' she confesses. 'After all, this time, I still have no real idea of where I'm going.'

Her latest role won't help clarify matters. Lake Placid is a curious would-be comic monster movie, featuring a disparate bunch of Hollywood archetypes - Bill Pullman's rugged, no-nonsense ranger, Oliver Platt's eccentric amateur naturalist, Fonda's unworldly but sexy palaeontologist - who come together in an effort to catch a giant crocodile munching its way through Maine. Ally McBeal creator David E Kelley's script aims at postmodern irony, but the movie bombed in the States; still, Fonda gets to utter a series of classic creature-feature lines ('It's coming straight for us!') and try out her best maiden-in-peril scream. However, when I suggest that such enterprises must be like a busman's holiday for actors - nice location, not too taxing, FX-men taking the heat - she's quick to disabuse me.

'I thought the effects would do all the work, but it's actually a tough challenge to make something like this hang together. You have to bring energy to it; there's no laziness allowed. It was fun, great fun,' she concludes, sounding a little like she's trying to convince herself of the fact.

When you encounter Bridget Fonda in the flesh, you wonder how the Johnny-come-lately likes of Angelina Jolie and Ashley Judd have had the temerity to leapfrog over her and on to the Hollywood A-list. At 36, she looks a good 10 years younger, with her lustrous blonde hair (currently long and curled), animated grey-blue eyes, flawless, almost translucent skin, button nose, and doughty Fonda jaw (and yes, there's a passing resemblance to both Hunt and Foster). She fits right into the elegantly chic surroundings of LA's Mondrian hotel in a sheer beige blouse and knee-length navy skirt. She's also a captivating screen presence, elevating the humdrum likes of grunge comedy Singles and last year's A Simple Plan with her quicksilver intelligence. However, it quickly becomes apparent that she doesn't possess the ruthlessness or single-mindedness of, say, Demi Moore; when offered the choice of leads in Single White Female, she plumped for the much quieter, subtler role of the menaced Allie rather than the more grandstanding turn of the menacee Hedy, which established Jennifer Jason Leigh's career.

'I'm just not meant to be that kind of person,' she says of Hollywood's name-above-the-title multiplex fillers, 'and that's fine by me. My tastes are too diverse. I don't want to be known as someone who can only do a certain thing, or be a certain way; I want to have the freedom to experiment. Who wants to be narrowed down or put in a box? I'm freer this way; I'll never be cast as the girl who's so pretty she can just stand there, or the one who's so quirky and comical that the whole thing stands or falls on her performance. All I'm looking for,' she says passionately, 'is something that just gets me here.' And she points in the general direction of her gut.

As the conversation develops, however, you realise that Fonda's overdue promotion to the Premier League could be as much a question of confidence as destiny. She's referred repeatedly to herself in the past as 'a shy person' and declared that she had 'a lack of belief in myself'. 'You tend to focus on the negative when you're trying to figure out who you are,' she says now. 'You shouldn't define yourself that way, but I'm really self-critical; I have a hard time patting myself on the back. I'm trying to enjoy it more as I go along, because this is actually a great job and I love doing it. I also think it's helping me to be braver, because my first instinct is fear of failure, of the leap in the dark, which I have to override all the time. Part of the glory of acting is that you continually take chances, and sure, I've had bad experiences where I've ended up working with people I don't like, times when I've felt like Sisyphus, rolling the rock to the top of the hill only for it to end up at the bottom again. But when it all comes together,' she beams serenely, 'there's nothing better. I'm sorry,' she says suddenly, 'I'm a little like my father in that I take it all very seriously.'

Ah yes, her father. As if making it in the cut throat world of Hollywood wasn't Sisyphean enough, Fonda had to labour under the extra yoke of her illustrious provenance. The second child of Peter and his second wife, Susan Brewer - her elder brother, Justin, is a cinematographer - Bridget was born with a hole in the heart, which, she says, is a lot less dramatic than it sounds (though she has to take antibiotics before cleaning her teeth to prevent the risk of opportunistic infection). While her father was about to become the poster boy for the burgeoning counterculture via 1969's Easy Rider and the ingestion of prodigious amounts of hallucinogenics, Fonda's mother was a traditional homemaker, and her LA childhood reflected both parental strands.

'People imagine that I was dumped in the corner of a series of drug-fuelled orgies, and that we were like savages in the bush,' she says, 'but it wasn't like that at all. I grew up around adults who were imaginative and spontaneous, sure, and it was fantastic to go on that ride. I remember going to see my godparents [Larry 'JR' Hagman and his wife Maj], who lived on Malibu beach, and we'd have flag parades and put on hats and march up and down the beach while my godfather played the flute. And my dad would chase me round the tennis court on rollerskates.

'But I had discipline. I called everyone Mr and Mrs, like friends' parents and teachers, even though it was a time when everyone was insisting on being called by their first names. I always washed my hands before I ate, and used a napkin. I mean, my dad may have been a hippy biker in the public mind, but he was always a classy, well-turned-out hippy.'

Peter and Susan divorced in 1972, and the kids were taken to live with their mother (Peter launched an ultimately unsuccessful custody battle for her brother, ignoring Bridget, though this didn't seem to affect their relationship unduly; she went to stay on his yacht in Hawaii during the school holidays, snorkelling and collecting seashells). She toyed with the idea of becoming a fashion designer or artist until, appearing in a school play, she mistimed a cue and crashed through a partition on to the stage, cutting her knee as she did so. This inauspicious debut fuelled a desire to join the family firm, and she went off to study acting at New York University. She remembers her first day in class, when the lecturer invited each student to stand up and articulate their reasons for being there; when he got to Fonda, he said, dismissively: 'Of course, we know why you're here.'

Was she hurt by such slights, I ask. 'Not really,' she says tentatively, 'because I grew up with people knowing who I was and where I came from. I was noticed because of my antecedents, which was strange.'

And how had that affected her sense of identity? 'I can't answer that, because I have no idea what it would have been like otherwise. It's like saying, "What would it have been like if you weren't a woman?" Gee, I could guess, but that's all it would be.' (Though it's obviously a question that preys on her mind, because she later says: 'I often wonder what it would be like to come into this completely fresh - when I see people from a non-entertainment-industry family who've made it, I'm like, "Wow, you're here because of your own efforts - the way you're perceived isn't based on someone else's achievements." I can't allow myself that, because I always factor in nepotism. Still,' she shrugs, 'if no one wanted to watch me, I guess they'd have stopped hiring me a long time ago.')

When she told Peter she was going to be an actress, he said she'd have to climb Everest four times: for her grandfather, her father, her aunt, and for herself. It's a quote he's often repeated since. When I bring it up, Fonda groans theatrically. 'Oh, he loves that old Everest quote. True, everyone expected me to be good, automatically, and I had to learn to fall on my face. But actually,' she confides, 'the Everest thing was probably more of a problem for him than for me. You know, he was the son of the quintessential American icon. Grandpa Henry played Tom Joad, Abe Lincoln, Wyatt Earp, for heaven's sake. It would be hard for anyone to follow in those footsteps.' (She's previously said that 'Grandpa Henry' was the one in the family she most related to: 'He was very quiet and shy. He painted. He kept bees')

So she didn't take professional advice from her father or aunt? She looks incredulous at the suggestion. 'Everyone forgets - this is my family we're talking about. How would you feel if your mum or dad were giving you their opinion all the time? Say you're leaving the house, and one of them doesn't like what you're wearing - well, your natural inclination would be to wear something even worse, wouldn't it? You know, the nice thing,' she says, attempting to rein herself back in, 'is that I respect them. I never felt that I had to deny their existence or be embarrassed by association.'

It hasn't always been plain sailing with Auntie Jane, though - didn't Bridget once say that she 'couldn't give a damn' about her exercise videos, and that she couldn't think of anything more boring than 'jumping around with a lot of smelly, sweaty people'; that, furthermore, most of her movies were 'pretty lightweight', and she wasn't fired by politics in the same way because 'all politics are boring'?

Fonda rolls her eyes heavenward. 'At one time, there was nothing the press would have liked better than to set up a me vs Jane thing,' she says wearily. 'They were desperate for us to be bitter rivals. They'd also try to set me against my dad, to use me as a dart to throw at someone else. And no, I don't like aerobics - I hate any kind of regimented workout - but that's just me, it's got nothing to do with anybody else.

'People forget that Jane's not my mom - she's my dad's sister - and although we're close, I don't see her that often. She lives in Montana; I live in Los Angeles. I think people expect us to be constantly having these On Golden Pond hug-ins, and we don't. We're just not that kind of family - though I sometimes think it would be great if we were,' she says poignantly. (Consequently, she's unable to elaborate on the ramifications of Jane's divorce or her rumoured conversion to born-again Christianity.)

Such bruising encounters have led Fonda to be a lot more circumspect about her private life; she still shudders at the memory of early interviews, when she informed passing hacks of her impending marriage to English writer/director Lee Drysdale, flashed her engagement ring, and revealed that she wanted 'at least two children'. The relationship disintegrated after a few years. 'I was incredibly naive,' she says now. 'I thought it was impolite not to give people what they so obviously wanted. It took me a long time to realise it's my right not to answer questions.'

But her withdrawal was also a reaction to so much of her life being in the public domain, thanks to innumerable family interviews and her father's autobiography, Don't Tell Dad - a book she claims she's never read. 'My father's incredibly open, but I want to keep my memories my own,' she says earnestly. 'I don't want to read someone else's version of them in case they conflict with mine.' Her subsequent six-year relationship with Eric Stoltz was thus spared the harsh light of over-exposure (unless you count the explicit sex scene the pair essayed in the Stoltz-directed movie Bodies, Rest and Motion ). She's now seeing country singer Dwight Yoakam ('Yes, you can say that, it's a matter of public record'), and recently completed filming the lead role in this directorial debut South of Heaven, West of Hell.

'It's hard to define, which is what I'm attracted to,' she says of the part. 'I wrote pages of thoughts on where this person's coming from, none of which you'll see in the film. But she's a woman who returns to a horrible place she got away from, after attempting suicide and sinking really low, to save her cousin from what she fears will be the same fate. It's kind of abstract, but it really affected me.'

Her other upcoming movie, Monkeybone, is a delirious-sounding live-action/animation fable from the people who brought you The Nightmare Before Christmas, starring Brendan Fraser as a man possessed by the soul of an evil primate.

But while she may run and run, Fonda can't hide. Families are still uppermost in her mind, both venerable and putative. She's now 'closer than I've maybe ever been' to her father, who's been welcomed back into the Hollywood fold, after years in the wilderness, with his Oscar nomination for Ulee's Gold and the deadpan cool of The Limey. (I interviewed him on the release of the latter, and the pride that radiated out of him on mention of his daughter's name was so palpable, you could have warmed your hands on it; he also revealed, somewhat alarmingly, that he and Fonda 'bark like dogs' when greeting each other on the telephone.)

'I'm so happy for him,' she says. 'He's been working with great people, and he's having the time of his life. He's a real trouper, and he's so appreciative of the fact that he's still given the chance to do it. He's a cynicism-free zone, and I hope I'll be like that when I'm his age.'

She's also ready to start her own family, though, once bitten, she's careful not to lay down child quotas with designated partners. 'Yes, I'd love that,' Fonda says, 'but not at any cost. I mean, I want a family, I don't just want to be a mother.' You get the feeling that, once she's produced her brood, acting would be a secondary concern, though she says, 'I just don't know how I'd react once it was a reality; I'd have to see how the hormones settled. It would be great to experience life through their eyes, teach them all kinds of stuff, be with them all the time, but I also have so much fun doing what I do, I couldn't imagine living without it.'

This, then, may be the answer to the question of Bridget Fonda's identity: someone who's carved out an autonomous niche for herself against daunting precedent, in the light of which her quiet-but-stoic anonymity, and her determination to experiment rather than aim all out for the top like a heat-seeking missile, look less like underachievement and more like a survival technique.

'I can't help who I am,' she says. 'But I can be who I am on my own terms.'

 Lake Placid opens on 31 March
