fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: This week: dressing for the Oscars
fields.trailText: This week: dressing for the Oscars
fields.body:
Why have the Oscars become such a fashion fest? With four hours' air time and 1 billion viewers, the focus is as much on the frocks as the awards. At one time, the code was understated - now, designers are racing to dress the stars, and we have Armani to thank for it. He hired a publicist to make the connections in 1988.

Who are the hottest designers? Aside from surefire winners like Armani, Versace, Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren, designers such as Badgley Mischka, Valentino, Dolce & Gabbana, Richard Tyler and Vera Wang instinctively know what is needed for that red-carpet moment. Their dresses make front-page headlines. Even the guys get a look in - this year Brit tailor Timothy Everest is dressing Tom Cruise.

Who wields the power? The many stylists, costume designers and personal dressers who've become minor celebrities in their own right. The bigger the star, the more money they have, the better taste they are able to buy (read demand - stars now expect to keep the loaned dress). Costume designer Barbara Tfank has the most clout. She spun Uma Thurman into Prada couture in 1995, while in 1998 stylist Arianne Philips scored badly with Madonna's Jean-Paul Gaultier/Olivier Theyskins goth combo.

What do designers get out of it? Millions of dollars of free publicity, especially if the star is a winner. The day before the event, designers release their dress list to the press and celebs are expected to name names when they hit the red carpet.

This year's tips? At the couture shows in January and the ready-to-wear collections in February, fashion editors take careful note of the evening dresses and the front-row celebrities. This year, presenter Salma Hayek may wear Armani and Ashley Judd, Valentino and it's a good bet that nominee Hilary Swank will also be in Valentino. All eyes will be on Gwyneth Paltrow, Catherine Zeta Jones, Cameron Diaz and Julianne Moore. Tomorrow morning, log on to latimes.com or oscars.com and you will get the full dress list. If you are early, you might get your order in before anyone else.

What's a designer's worst nightmare? The actress who changes her mind at the 11th hour. It famously happened to Vera Wang in 1996 when, at the last minute, Sharon Stone dumped the dress that had been designed especially for her and slipped on a black Gap T-shirt, Valentino silk skirt and Armani coat which she put together herself - a star's prerogative.

fields.headline: Sweet and low
fields.standfirst: Hypoglycaemia - or low blood sugar - is more often than not diagnosed as stress related, say the experts. Even so, there are some nutritional steps you can take to stop that weak and shaky feeling
fields.trailText: Hypoglycaemia - or low blood sugar - is more often than not diagnosed as stress related, say the experts. Even so, there are some nutritional steps you can take to stop that weak and shaky feeling
fields.body:
Recently, I have been discussing the latest thoughts regarding hypoglycaemia (low blood sugar) with endocrinologists (hormone specialists), patients and friends. Ask the specialists about the incidence of hypoglycaemia and many of them will dismiss it as a fallacy - it only exists when people are taking medication such as insulin or tablets to control their diabetes or, in rarer circumstances, when someone has undergone gastric surgery or has a serious, detectable abnormality such as a tumour within the pancreas - the organ that helps the body control blood sugars.

But when I talk to patients, friends - even my sister - all of whom have problems controlling their symptoms, the majority will utter dismay at the thought that hypoglycaemia is a modern stress-related phenomenon and that, according to Professor Williams of University Hospital, Liverpool, it 'has nothing to do with low blood-sugar levels'. He believes that identical symptoms can be induced by stress, and particularly by overbreathing or hyperventilation. He also said at a recent media event, that 'it is simply a myth that certain sugar-rich foods cause blood sugar levels to rise dramatically and then crash shortly afterwards. This does not happen in non-diabetic subjects, because various hormones keep blood sugar levels within a very narrow range.'

But, that said, as a practitioner I am reluctant to turn around to patients who present classic hypoglycaemia symptoms and tell them that diet has nothing to do with it and they should just start breathing properly. Typically, hypoglycaemic patients can feel weak, shaky, extremely moody, nauseous, acutely tired, have problems sleeping and suffer headaches - they can even break out in a cold sweat. Children can be hard to appease, and adults can feel violent when they haven't eaten for a while. Even if some doctors and the Sugar Bureau profess that these symptoms have nothing to do with blood-sugar levels (in the majority of cases), I think it is extremely worthwhile to look at the way you're eating to see whether symptoms can disappear. For the majority of sufferers, nutritional changes can have profoundly positive effects - as soon as you eat in a way that enables your blood-sugar levels to remain as constant as possible (in your own terms), symptoms can disappear.

One of the reasons why many specialists believe hypoglycaemia to be a disorder diagnosed (frequently by oneself) incorrectly, is that the diagnosis is in itself difficult - blood tests frequently fail to reflect what and how you're feeling. Even then, everyone is different. In some people, symptoms can even appear when they haven't eaten for a while but their blood-sugar level is above the point at which it is technically considered to be low. Others experience symptoms which make them feel unwell after they have eaten a very sweet food - they just appear to be overly sensitive, for whatever reason. In a way we don't need to know the reason (as long as you have seen your doctor to exclude the issue of tumours or diabetes, etc). What matters is how to help yourself - which is where food comes in.

Usually, when you eat carbohydrate (sugar-containing food), in either a simple form, such as chocolate, or complex form, as in a piece of bread, the body secretes the hormone insulin, enabling it to use the sugar as fuel or store it as fat for later use. If too little insulin is secreted, the blood-sugar level remains too high, and you become diabetic. Hypoglycaemia is the opposite condition and is thought, in many cases, to be due to too much insulin being produced, which causes blood-sugar levels to plummet beyond a point you are comfortable with. The first and foremost guideline is to eat a well-balanced diet: plenty of fresh vegetables, fruits, wholegrain cereals, lean proteins, dairy foods, small amounts of fat and plenty of water. Eating regularly helps you 'stabilise' your sugar levels, so try not to leave more than three or four hours between meals or snacks. I cite the example of a friend who finds that unless she eats a substantial breakfast as soon as she wakes up, she feels dizzy, sick and can (according to many level-headed observers), appear to be in a daze. As soon as she eats, she becomes a functioning human being.

Eating regularly throughout the day should prevent your blood sugar from dropping below the point at which you're comfortable and helps you refrain from overeating at meal times, which could cause you to become overloaded with sugar-containing foods (which can trigger similar symptoms to those caused by low blood-sugar levels in some people). The majority of people I see feel a lot better if they have five or six snacks a day rather than two or three large meals. If you're worried about excess calories, split meals up - save your dessert for later.

It is best to avoid eating sugary foods on an empty stomach, as the rise in blood-sugar level may stimulate your body to secrete a larger amount of insulin than desirable: your sugar level falls quickly, followed by dizziness or other symptoms. Patients frequently find that all types of sugar food - sucrose, glucose, fructose, brown sugar, molasses, honey - have similar effects. I recommend fruit as a healthy snack, as the fruit's fibre cushions the effect of the natural sugar (fructose) and thereby the changes in blood-sugar level. Products labelled 'no added sugar' are by no means sugar-free; usually they are high in natural sugar of one kind or another. Although artificial sweeteners do not directly aggravate sugar levels, I don't recommend them as they don't taste good and can aggravate digestive complaints. It's far better to wean yourself off the desire for excessively sweet things if you find that they cause symptoms. Eating sweet foods after a meal containing a lot of fibre (vegetables and wholegrains such as brown rice, wholewheat pasta or pulses), or choosing a sweet dessert based around fibre - apple crumble with a wholemeal topping - are both measures which appear to be acceptable in a lot of 'sugar-sensitive' people.

Boosting chromium can sometimes help you feel less sensitive to sugar levels, so lean towards chromium-rich foods - cheese, shellfish (molluscs, such as scallops, clams, oysters), baked beans and wholemeal products. Better to do this rather than reach for the chromium supplement, as it is still uncertain exactly how much chromium we need and therefore there is the potential to overdose. (The majority of people absorb sufficient quantities if they include in their diet a good-sized portion of chromium-rich food daily, or every other day.)

Since caffeine causes your pancreas to secrete more insulin, overloading with tea, coffee or cola can aggravate symptoms - so the cup of coffee to perk you up can be disastrous. Instead, drink plenty of water, herb teas and the occasional freshly squeezed fruit juice. Avoid drinking alcohol on an empty stomach, as this causes blood-sugar levels to drop. Wait until your stomach contains some fibre (a banana or a slice of wholemeal toast), before you go out drinking. If you find yourself feeling horribly 'low' here's the survival plan: have a sweet, high-fibre snack to help bring your sugar level up to normal.

Sweets and chocolates may cause your body to produce more insulin than you're happy with, which causes even more problems - so watch these quick fixes. Fruit combines sugar and fibre, so a fruit-based snack is ideal. Try to eat a well-balanced meal as soon as possible afterwards. Avoid caffeine. Above all, rest - vigorous exercise will make symptoms worse. Relax, concentrate on breathing calmly, keep warm and have a hot drink, such as a mug of hot milk or camomile tea - all of which should soon bring the 'swing' to a stop.

fields.headline: Hard times
fields.standfirst: A new series of American books tries to tackle big issues for little readers. By Sanjiv Bhattacharya
fields.trailText: Poor Paul: he's only six, and he's got no one to play with. His sister Tina, 13, is a redhead crackhead who once tried to give him a naughty pill (a Dexedrine, an upper). He didn't take it, of course, he snitched on her, but then the cops found her smoking crack in the local park and all hell broke loose. His best friend José won't come round any more and his chances of going to soccer camp went up in smoke, literally, because Mom and Dad can't afford it, what with the cost of Tina's detox. So he's effectively lost his best friend and his sister. Damn that crack stuff.
fields.body:
Poor Paul: he's only six, and he's got no one to play with. His sister Tina, 13, is a redhead crackhead who once tried to give him a naughty pill (a Dexedrine, an upper). He didn't take it, of course, he snitched on her, but then the cops found her smoking crack in the local park and all hell broke loose. His best friend José won't come round any more and his chances of going to soccer camp went up in smoke, literally, because Mom and Dad can't afford it, what with the cost of Tina's detox. So he's effectively lost his best friend and his sister. Damn that crack stuff.

That, in a nutshell, is My Big Sister Takes Drugs, by Judith Vigna from Pennsylvania - a book written for six- to nine-year-olds whose difficulties, learning or otherwise, arise from drug use in the family. It's one of a handful of fairly alarming new children's titles dedicated to an audience of kids who grow up around hard drugs and alcoholism. Other titles include I Wish Daddy Didn't Drink So Much (Vigna, again) and The House That Crack Built, a non-fictional account of the rock cocaine trade.

At first glance, titles such as The House That Crack Built have the ring of satire, a black comic comment on the times in which we live. It's the pun that does it, the striking irony of turning a children's classic to such grim adult themes - Winnie the Pusher, Fantastic Mr Fix, Ginderella, Goldilocks and the Three Drunks, the list of possible variations goes on. After all, children do grow up ever so fast these days. However, neither The House... nor My Big Sister Takes Drugs is designed for laughs. In the US, teachers and care agencies use them, college students write theses on them and, even though they're only supposed to be read with an adult present, they can be found on the shelves of certain school libraries.

Inevitably, these books were born in the USA, so often the trailblazer for modern social dysfunction, but the UK is no stranger to the genre. For at least 15 years, both English and American children's authors have attempted the rare feat of walking like a child through the harshest traumas of life, in order to give traumatised innocents someone with whom to identify. One library in Berkshire, run by Reach, has more than 12,500 books covering cancer, death, violence, divorce, disability, the whole gamut - there are 300 for bereavement alone. Beverly Mathias, the director, claims that as many as 35 per cent of children have special needs. For some reason, however, there are as yet no titles about drug abuse aimed at six-year-olds in this country.

An exhaustive ring-around of bodies including Barnados, ChildLine, Adfam, the National Institute of Social Workers, the Children's Bureau, the Standing Conference on Drug Abuse and several more, typically yields a response like 'No, but there's some factual stuff for early teens if you'd like.' It appears that, having adopted both a drug problem an attempted solution to the drug problem from the US in the shape of the Drug Tsar, we have yet to employ early-reading fiction to assist the youngest and most susceptible victims.

'There is a need for good literature in this area,' admits Asha Philips of the Child Psychotherapy Trust, 'but it's not easy to come by. You have to be very careful when you're writing for kids. You mustn't patronise them or frighten them, or be too harsh on the parents, even if their behaviour is the cause of the problem - children feel very loyal towards their parents. The illustrations are crucial, the language must be familiar, as must the reference points. It's very difficult.'

By these criteria, My Big Sister Takes Drugs falls well wide of the mark. Aside from the alarmist dialogue - 'Without help she [Tina] may die,' says Mom to a terrified Paul - it's questionable whether affected kids will identify with this cutesy crack tale at all. Crack typically thrives in inner-city areas, ravaging poor minority communities above all, yet Paul lives in a cosy white suburb with neat lawns and a solid support network both at home and at school. There's not a black face in sight, and no hint of social deprivation.

In its current form, the story of Paul and Tina will find no takers in this country, but equally the potential audience for the right book is considerable. Drug and alcohol abuse have slipped inexorably down the reading ages, and there's undoubtedly a gap in the British market. Enterprising authors are warned, however, to heed the lessons of My Big Sister Takes Drugs before scribbling away - set the thing in Hackney rather than Winchester.

webTitle: Last outpost of the Khmer Rouge

fields.headline: Last outpost of the Khmer Rouge
fields.standfirst: It is 25 years since Year Zero and Pol Pot's murderous regime came to power. Brother Number One is dead, but his henchmen live on in the lawless mining town of Pailin. John Sweeney visits the town and discovers corruption, crooning and how to cook cobra
fields.trailText: It is 25 years since Year Zero and Pol Pot's murderous regime came to power. Brother Number One is dead, but his henchmen live on in the lawless mining town of Pailin. John Sweeney visits the town and discovers corruption, crooning and how to cook cobra
fields.body:
The cook of Pailin flashed a toothy smile, banged her ladle against the bubbling pot and said: 'I cooked cobra for Pol Pot.' She carried on stirring and dictated the recipe as if from page one of the Khmer Rouge Cookbook : 'First, kill the cobra. Then cut off its head and hang it on a tree for the poison to dry in the sun, away from the children. Collect the snake blood in a cup and serve it with white wine. Chop the cobra into little pieces and mash it into a pulp with a handful of peanuts. Add boiling water, bitter leaf of the vine, the herb of the lemon grass and yellow ground ginger. Simmer for one hour. Serves one.'

Brother Number One didn't like to share his food. Pol Pot, the genocidal Stalinist who oversaw Year Zero in Cambodia in 1975, and the consequent death of millions under his brutal Khmer Rouge regime, has been dead for three years. But the dark shadow of his rule lives on across Cambodia, and nowhere more so than in Pailin.

The town enjoys the following write-up in the 1996 Lonely Planet Travel Guide to Cambodia: 'Pailin (elevation 257 metres), 83km south-west of Battambang near the Thai border, is another place that foreigners won't be visiting for the foreseeable future. It is the Khmer Rouge gem-mining area, and, unless you look like a rich Thai gem trader, you have a very good chance of being shot if you turn up unannounced.'

These travel guides, they always get it wrong. I wasn't shot in Pailin, but the town is not exactly Sa Coma, Majorca. Its tourist potential is undeveloped. To say the town is beyond the writ of the Cambodian government is an understatement. You fly to Battambang, then you take a dirt road. The potholes are not big, they're lunar. You drive through potholes where naked children play in the dust and water buffalo wallow in potholes in the potholes. In the roadside villages, women cast seeds over fields with a timeless grace, while men yawn, comatose, in hammocks. The villages thin out. The road twists through a moonscape of naked grey hillsides, the ashes of the burnt-down rainforest. You drive past miles and miles of charred earth and stumps, the legacy of a lost forest canopy. In 1960, 90 per cent of Cambodia was forest; now it's less than 30 per cent - an ecological crime fuelled by greed and war. Every once in a while, a stretch of the countryside is staked out by a vivid red sign, on it a scribble in Khmer, indecipherable, and a skull with deep white eye sockets, crossed bones and the words in English: 'Danger! Mines!!' A walk on the wild side in this part of Cambodia will most probably end with you hobbling on a stump. Cambodia is mined to tears.

The 'border' was marked by nothing so sophisticated as a crossing or a frontier. Just a skull and some leg bones, sitting in their own look-out position, on a pole, shaded from the heat of the day by a sheet of corrugated iron to make a little roof. The skull marks the last outpost of Royal Cambodian government authority. From here on in, the countryside gets emptier and emptier, creepier and creepier, as we drove deeper into Cambodia's Wild West. It's always a bad sign when there are no cars on the road coming the other way, no cows in the fields, no kids playing in the near distance. Just an empty road, the ashes of forests thousands of years old, and a primeval silence.

Pailin turned out to be bursting with its own queasy charm. It is a rat's nest of holes in the ground, dirt-floored casinos and whorehouses, set in a bowl of purple, corrugated hills. The heat suffocates, the sky a weird brown from the dust thrown up by the gem miners, who make the holes in the ground. There are two types of miners: the rich ones and the poor, both prospecting for rubies and sapphires. The poor miners buy plots of land for $50, and dig deep wells which can collapse at any moment. The rich use state-of-the-art digging machines which throb and roar through the night, raping the earth. During the day, the gem miners trade their wares with the dealers, a street of well-fed entrepreneurs who stare at rubies, emeralds, amber and passing humanity, assessing their worth down to the last dollar with the coldest of eyes.

And the miners themselves? The town is peopled by Khmer Rouge killers. Warriors with the thousand-mile stare. Most, but not all, of them have switched uniforms. I saw one ex-KR fighter drive by on his motorbike, balancing his stump from an exploded mine beautifully over the potholes, his telltale lime-green KR Mao cap firmly on his head. Intellectuals, doctors, teachers, anyone 'corrupted' by the modern world, was shot. City dwellers were dubbed 'new people'; they were discriminated against by the 'base people'. The KR killed close to 100 per cent of Cambodia's ethnic Vietnamese population, a huge percentage of the Cham people, ethnic Muslims, a fifth of the Khmers and a tiny handful of Westerners, pitiful wretches who were photographed shortly before they were killed. A fraction of the killing took place at an old lycée in Phnom Penh called Tuol Sleng. There, 20,000 people were processed. Only six survived.

Across Cambodia families were torn apart, children encouraged to spy and disown their parents, and city dwellers forced out of their homes to a countryside in the name of a mindless Communism that would have had Karl Marx howling with despair, then shot. The KR was a moronocracy. Survivors recall being lectured by illiterate 14-year-old KR troopers, armed with all powers, about 'Max-Leninism'. Anyone who laughed at them was a dead man. The catchphrase mockingly addressed by the KR cadres to their victims was: 'Keeping you is no gain. Losing you is no loss.'

The photographs of him in his years of power, from 1975 to 1979, show a man with the tapioca-pudding-smooth skin and soft plumpness of a fleshy buddha. Even after the Vietnamese invaded Democratic Kampuchea on Christmas Day 1978, and drove out Pol Pot from Phnom Penh, and pushed him into the jungle where he lived to kill plenty more in a dirty civil war, the Dear Leader ate handsomely.

The cook of Pailin recalled the eating habits of Pol Pot and his friends: 'I used to cook for them. They ate simple country food. But for hygiene's sake, we used to wash the vegetables in potassium permanganate.' This was an item few of Pol Pot's countrymen could afford when a dead rat was a luxury. What did they eat?

The cook chewed that one over: 'Deer, wild pig, snake. For dessert, apples, grapes.' They drank brandy, Thai potcheen, and Chinese wine in big, brown pitchers. Cooking for the KR leadership required diplomatic skills. Ta Mok hated stinky fish sauce. Nuon Chea (another KR boss, still at liberty) 'wouldn't eat soup without stinky fish sauce.' She stirred her pot some more.

Did he like company, having people, children, around him?

'No, he liked quiet, so he didn't like children.' She fussed over pots while, outside the café, a crew of miners piled up on the back of a lorry, their faces covered in red scarves to prevent them being choked by the dust.

How did she protect herself in the jungle? She turned to the subject of guns. Pol Pot himself carried a small gun in his holster. The smaller the gun, the higher the rank. She went on: 'I can fire a B-40.' That's a Chinese-made, shoulder-mounted, rocket- propelled grenade with the kick of a mule. Really? 'Yes. I can fire a B-40.' What did she think about the changes to Pailin? 'I'd like to have the B-40, and start with the casino over there. These people are bad. They bring thievery into our area.' They were only gambling, not mass murdering.

The Blue Dragon is the best joint in town. It's where it jumps in Pailin. You can feast on Frog Deep Fried Pepper, Spicy Fish Cat, Spicy Frog Mango and Beef Grille Oil, and wash it down with the very best Scottish whisky malts (made in Thailand) and Tiger beer, in the company of Pol Pot's old propaganda apparatchik, Kong Deung, while listening to - what else? - The Spice Girls' 'Wannabe'.

Kong used to broadcast the crudest, most bilious hate on Radio LNADK (National Army Radio of Democratic Kampuchea) and is an important accessory to the extinction of 1.5 million people. He articulated the frenzy that led to the mass murder. For example, the Vietnamese were never called the Vietnamese but the 'contemptible savages'. Brutality, torture, murder are easy once the killing is legitimised.

At the head table at the Blue Dragon, Kong seems very much at ease with himself, a fit man, in his fifties, comfortable in a pair of black pyjamas. His ring finger is weighed down by a life buoy encrusted with rubies. He takes a swig of beer, grins warmly at a girl with a slit skirt and nods along to the beat. Kong takes to the stage, microphone in hand. He opens his mouth and the metamorphosis is complete. Goodbye KR, hello Charles Aznavour. The KR crooner makes loooooove to his microphone cable, and warbles on. After the first solo number, he is accompanied by a gang of slit-skirted whores - sorry, dancers - strutting their stuff. He has switched from a Khmer version of the French chanteur to, put your hands together please, Disco Tex and the Sex-o-lettes.

Earlier, Kong showed us around his radio station, sited on the top of the denuded purple hills, just up the road from the gutted ruins of a burnt-out tank. Kong's still the propaganda chief of the Pailin District, only these days he broadcasts 'reconciliation', not murder. 'I worked from 1980 till 1994.' (The significance of the 1980 start date is simple. That was when Pol Pol was pushed out of Phnom Penh. Odd that he only got the job in 1980, though, specially since he joined the KR in 1974. Very odd.) 'There were six staff. We received the international news, and wrote a short report. Pol Pot was difficult to work with, to follow his ideology' - though, to be fair to Kong, he managed that feat for 14 years, by his own admittance.

Everyone suffered during Pol Pot's terror. Kong himself lost six members of his family, his father, two brothers and three sisters. Two died of starvation; the rest during forced labour. And yet he survived, and lived to croon.

Also at the high table at the Blue Dragon was Pol Pot's interpreter for eight years, Mea Makk, an elliptical and enigmatic creep who picked his teeth whenever he was asked a difficult question about the bad old days. At first, he'd fought shy of a chat with The Observer.

'Can we have lunch?'

'No, I am too busy putting up propaganda for International Women's Day'

But later he joined our table at the Blue Dragon. Ask him about what he did when Pol Pot was in power, and you are treated to some industrial-strength lying. 'I was just a clerk we had no freedom to express ourselves we just wanted to find the formula to unite.'

Mea Makk was there when Pol Pot met His Excellency the President of the People's Republic of China. To say that he was suffering from selective amnesia would be something of an understatement.

The crooner who murdered with his mouth and the creep who interpreted for Brother Number One ate and drank their way through the Blue Dragon's menu, $65 for food and $105 for drink. One has to remember that the KR, at the height of its power, was thumpingly puritan. Even as late as March 1997, visitors to Pailin were greeted with the following admonishment: 'Welcome, new people - the following things are not allowed in this zone: thievery, prostitution and gambling.'

At the end of Kong's crooning session, one of the dancers, sporting enough lipstick to paint the Forth Bridge, anointed him with a garland of paper chains. The crowd of ex-KR killers, gem miners, illegal loggers, whores and drunks were ecstatic. And the murdered 1.5 million? Dead men don't clap.

So how come the crooner and the interpreter live in liberty and comparative luxury, given what they did, who they worked for? They are small fry. Bigger fish are at liberty, too.

To understand why, one must realise that Cambodia is one of the most damaged societies on earth. The physical damage is easy to recognise - the burnt forests, the mined countryside, the lunar roads, the broken bodies. Ta Mok, now in jail awaiting his show trial, has only one leg. Hun Sen, a dodgy crook with a hint of viciousness, who happens to be Cambodia's prime minister, has only one eye. Prum Sou, a former KR junior commander, has only one arm. Duol Sareoun, another commander, has one eye.

The psychological damage is much harder to recognise but more profound. People live in the present tense. A whole generation of people from their late twenties upwards have no proper sense of society, or the future. They have lived through a time when you had to survive from minute to minute. The English manager of the Foreign Correspondents' Club in Phnom Penh - easily the best bar in the world - told me that he had to sack a Cambodian just the day before, a man, an excellent worker, who had been with him for four years. He had been stealing, big time, and thrown away the chances of a good income for years to come. A wire-agency chief told an almost identical story: 'This country looks so beautiful, so lovely. The people have real grace. But get to know them a little, spend time here a little, and you begin to realise that every adult has been through appalling traumas. A whole generation is crazy. They're all fucked.'

Justice would help, but justice for the KR killers has been denied all the way long the line, for pernicious and unnecessary reasons.

The KR mind-fuck was intensified one appalling day in 1997 when news broke that Pol Pot had died of a heart attack, cheating his people of the trial he so richly deserved. Nevertheless, Pol Pot suffered a pretty miserable end. The people who did for Pol Pot were not the forces of law and order, still less the diplomats of the international community. They were the tree detectives of Global Witness and freelance journalist called Nate Thayer, whose state of mind has never quite been the same since a car he was travelling in went over an anti-tank mine.

Global Witness closed down the illegal logging trade between western Cambodia, the area around Pailin controlled by the KR, and Thailand, thanks to its detailed and accurate reporting. The KR slowly began to run out of money to fund its grisly guerrilla campaign against the Phnom Penh government. In 1997, Ta Mok arrested Pol Pol and revealed the prisoner to Nate Thayer. The journalist ran the story on Voice of America, a station which the ex-Brother Number One used to listen to. He died of a heart attack that night. Thayer, over a drink in a bar in Thailand, said: 'I killed Pot Pot, you know.' You don't argue with anyone who has survived an anti-tank mine.

From 1996 onwards, senior KR commanders had started to defect. The first to go was Ieng Sary, or Brother 81 - the numbers are a poor guide to proximity to power - who decamped from the Khmer Rouge, taking his troops with him. The soldiers voted with their feet. The last to successfully switch sides was Brother Number Two, ideologist Nuon Chea, and Pol Pot's foreign minister, Khieu Samphan. They came over at Christmas 1998. That left Ta Mok, who was the last to jump and is to be punished by a trial, of sorts.

The insult to humanity is a simple one: if 1.5 million people were killed by the Khmer Rouge, how come three surviving KR leaders - Ieng Sary, Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea - are still at liberty? In Nazi terms, it is as if Goering, Goebbels and Himmler were wandering around Bavaria at liberty, while only Franz Stangl was charged for war crimes.

The evidence against Ieng Sary, Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea is compelling. The Documentation Centre of Cambodia has compiled a stack of smoking-gun documents from the paperwork the KR left behind, showing that the top three knew all about torture and murder.

For Brother Nuon? File 734, 'confession of Sieng Pauy alias Sean', two notes sent to Brother Nuon, document dated 9 November 1977: 'Concerning the four questions above, although I pressed him to answer, he did not answer, but he did once tortured.'

For Ieng Sary? File N0001158, 'telegram 21, report by comrade Chhon to Brother Pol [Pot], on the arrest and killing of the Vietnamese who spied and hid themselves in the forest, and on the arrest and torture of those who opposed Angkar's [another name for the KR leadership] dam-building plan.' This report was copied to Ieng Sary.

For Khieu Samphan? File upon file, some of the paperwork originating from Comrade Duch, the master of the torture centre at Tuol Sleng. One of the exhibits at Tuol Sleng is a 3D map of Cambodia, vaguely reminiscent of the maps made of shells at seaside resorts. Only this map is made of skulls.

It would be an insult to Cambodia's dignity if international judges had the final say over Cambodians, he said. The prime minister is a crook, and a nasty one, too. Those who cross the path of Hun Sen should take care. On 9 July 1998, Reuters carried the following story about someone who did so. His name was Thong Sophal, and he worked for the opposition grouping, FUNCINPEC, opposed to Hun Sen's party. The wire story detailed what had happened to Thong Sophal: 'His eyes had been gouged out, his head smashed in, the skin had been stripped from his lower legs and all his fingers and one ear had been cut off.' Police said they suspected Sophal had killed himself. By gouging out his own eyes? Then smashing his own head in? Then skinning his groin? His fingers? And then chopping off his ear? That's how you commit suicide, Cambodian style. You challenge the Hun Sen regime.

One of Hun Sen's closest financial backers is Theng Bunma. He may appear a hero to all air passengers. When Royal Air Cambodge lost his baggage on a flight from Hong Kong, 'Wild Theng' lost his temper. He told reporters after the incident: 'The airline staff were insolent. Had they worked for me, I would have shot them in the head. I sent my bodyguard out for the 9mm Biretta. I could have ordered the.44 Magnum, but I only wanted the tyre, not the whole plane.' And then Wild Theng shot the plane's tyre out.

The Chinese government, which bankrolled the KR from 1979 until embarrassingly recently, in particular did not want an international war crimes tribunal. The gossip in Phnom Penh is that they gave Hun Sen $200 million in soft loans, the going rate for not having a war crimes tribunal. They deny this, of course.

There's no doubt about the loan and a further $18 million provided to Chinese companies to invest in joint ventures. The Phnom Penh daily reported: 'Work on the cement plant, a joint venture with local entrepreneur Theng Bunma had already begun.' It's that name again.

Professor Stephen Hedler, a Cambodian scholar at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, said: 'It's highly unlikely that Hun Sen can be turned around. He's been prepared to have a trial or not have trial depending on the highest bid, and China and its friends are willing to give him economic benefits, security guarantees and diplomatic support that the US can't offer.'

There's more, and it's worse. The real push for a proper international trial of the KR killers has to come from the governments of the United States and Britain. But both were horribly compromised because of their enmity towards the Vietnamese. When the Vietnamese took Phnom Penh in 1979, America and Britain sided with the opposition, the KR. America and Britain left the KR squatting in its seat at the United Nations for years. They even gave money and weapons training to the KR's allies, effectively helping the KR itself. If they raise the ante too much, then this sorry episode of realpolitik will be exposed to the full glare of daylight for the first time, and there are few officials in the State Department and the Foreign Office who would welcome that.

So no one important wants a war crimes trial in Cambodia. The KR killers have bought out Hun Sen. The Chinese government has helped out, too. The Americans and the British have reasons not to try very hard. And the Cambodians? These beautiful people, raped and scarred by one of the worst regimes since Hitler? They're not important.

Ieng Sary and Khieu Samphan spend much of their time in a compound to the west of Pailin. It's a quiet place with more than a hint of menace. We dillied and dallied a little too long, and then - mindful of the guidebook - we got in a car and started to hurry away. A big 4x4 swung out of the compound gates and followed us down the road, through the minefields. The 4x4 overtook us, and moved on, but for a sliver of time we felt something of the terror, and the utter powerlessness, of the ordinary Cambodian faced with something out of their dark past.

The crooner of Pailin can croon on.

Hun Sen, a dodgy crook with a hint of viciousness, who happens to be Cambodia's prime minister, has only one eye. Prum Sou, a former KR junior commander, has only one arm. Duol Sareoun, another commander, has one eye. The psychological damage is much harder to recognise but more profound. People live in the present tense. A whole generation of people from their late twenties upwards have no proper sense of society, or the future. They have lived through a time when you had to survive from minute to minute. The English manager of the Foreign Correspondents' Club in Phnom Penh - easily the best bar in the world - told me that he had to sack a Cambodian just the day before, a man, an excellent worker, who had been with him for four years. He had been stealing, big time, and thrown away the chances of a good income for years to come. A wire-agency chief told an almost identical story: 'This country looks so beautiful, so lovely. The people have real grace. But get to know them a little, spend time here a little, and you begin to realise that every adult has been through appalling traumas. A whole generation is crazy. They're all fucked.' Justice would help, but justice for the KR killers has been denied all the way long the line, for pernicious and unnecessary reasons. The KR mind-fuck was intensified one appalling day in 1997 when news broke that Pol Pot had died of a heart attack, cheating his people of the trial he so richly deserved. Nevertheless, Pol Pot suffered a pretty miserable end. The people who did for Pol Pot were not the forces of law and order, still less the diplomats of the international community. They were the tree detectives of Global Witness and freelance journalist called Nate Thayer, whose state of mind has never quite been the same since a car he was travelling in went over an anti-tank mine. Global Witness closed down the illegal logging trade between western Cambodia, the area around Pailin controlled by the KR, and Thailand, thanks to its detailed and accurate reporting. The KR slowly began to run out of money to fund its grisly guerrilla campaign against the Phnom Penh government. In 1997, Ta Mok arrested Pol Pol and revealed the prisoner to Nate Thayer. The journalist ran the story on Voice of America, a station which the ex-Brother Number One used to listen to. He died of a heart attack that night. Thayer, over a drink in a bar in Thailand, said: 'I killed Pot Pot, you know.' You don't argue with anyone who has survived an anti-tank mine. From 1996 onwards, senior KR commanders had started to defect. The first to go was Ieng Sary, or Brother 81 - the numbers are a poor guide to proximity to power - who decamped from the Khmer Rouge, taking his troops with him. The soldiers voted with their feet. The last to successfully switch sides was Brother Number Two, ideologist Nuon Chea, and Pol Pot's foreign minister, Khieu Samphan. They came over at Christmas 1998. That left Ta Mok, who was the last to jump and is to be punished by a trial, of sorts. The insult to humanity is a simple one: if 1.5 million people were killed by the Khmer Rouge, how come three surviving KR leaders - Ieng Sary, Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea - are still at liberty? In Nazi terms, it is as if Goering, Goebbels and Himmler were wandering around Bavaria at liberty, while only Franz Stangl was charged for war crimes. The evidence against Ieng Sary, Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea is compelling. The Documentation Centre of Cambodia has compiled a stack of smoking-gun documents from the paperwork the KR left behind, showing that the top three knew all about torture and murder. For Brother Nuon? File 734, 'confession of Sieng Pauy alias Sean', two notes sent to Brother Nuon, document dated 9 November 1977: 'Concerning the four questions above, although I pressed him to answer, he did not answer, but he did once tortured.' For Ieng Sary? File N0001158, 'telegram 21, report by comrade Chhon to Brother Pol [Pot], on the arrest and killing of the Vietnamese who spied and hid themselves in the forest, and on the arrest and torture of those who opposed Angkar's [another name for the KR leadership] dam-building plan.' This report was copied to Ieng Sary. For Khieu Samphan? File upon file, some of the paperwork originating from Comrade Duch, the master of the torture centre at Tuol Sleng. One of the exhibits at Tuol Sleng is a 3D map of Cambodia, vaguely reminiscent of the maps made of shells at seaside resorts. Only this map is made of skulls. So why no trial? The KR three have bought out their crimes with dirty money raised from racketeering, illegal logging, the ruby and sapphire trade. They could do so thanks to the grotesque corruption of the Hun Sen government. Prime Minister Hun Sen has stated that he seeks a Cambodian solution to the war crimes problem. It would be an insult to Cambodia's dignity if international judges had the final say over Cambodians, he said. The prime minister is a crook, and a nasty one, too. Those who cross the path of Hun Sen should take care. On 9 July 1998, Reuters carried the following story about someone who did so. His name was Thong Sophal, and he worked for the opposition grouping, FUNCINPEC, opposed to Hun Sen's party. The wire story detailed what had happened to Thong Sophal: 'His eyes had been gouged out, his head smashed in, the skin had been stripped from his lower legs and all his fingers and one ear had been cut off.' Police said they suspected Sophal had killed himself. By gouging out his own eyes? Then smashing his own head in? Then skinning his groin? His fingers? And then chopping off his ear? That's how you commit suicide, Cambodian style. You challenge the Hun Sen regime. One of Hun Sen's closest financial backers is Theng Bunma. He may appear a hero to all air passengers. When Royal Air Cambodge lost his baggage on a flight from Hong Kong, 'Wild Theng' lost his temper. He told reporters after the incident: 'The airline staff were insolent. Had they worked for me, I would have shot them in the head. I sent my bodyguard out for the 9mm Biretta. I could have ordered the.44 Magnum, but I only wanted the tyre, not the whole plane.' And then Wild Theng shot the plane's tyre out. The Chinese government, which bankrolled the KR from 1979 until embarrassingly recently, in particular did not want an international war crimes tribunal. The gossip in Phnom Penh is that they gave Hun Sen $200 million in soft loans, the going rate for not having a war crimes tribunal. They deny this, of course. There's no doubt about the loan and a further $18 million provided to Chinese companies to invest in joint ventures. The Phnom Penh daily reported: 'Work on the cement plant, a joint venture with local entrepreneur Theng Bunma had already begun.' It's that name again. Professor Stephen Hedler, a Cambodian scholar at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, said: 'It's highly unlikely that Hun Sen can be turned around. He's been prepared to have a trial or not have trial depending on the highest bid, and China and its friends are willing to give him economic benefits, security guarantees and diplomatic support that the US can't offer.' There's more, and it's worse. The real push for a proper international trial of the KR killers has to come from the governments of the United States and Britain. But both were horribly compromised because of their enmity towards the Vietnamese. When the Vietnamese took Phnom Penh in 1979, America and Britain sided with the opposition, the KR. America and Britain left the KR squatting in its seat at the United Nations for years. They even gave money and weapons training to the KR's allies, effectively helping the KR itself. If they raise the ante too much, then this sorry episode of realpolitik will be exposed to the full glare of daylight for the first time, and there are few officials in the State Department and the Foreign Office who would welcome that. So no one important wants a war crimes trial in Cambodia. The KR killers have bought out Hun Sen. The Chinese government has helped out, too. The Americans and the British have reasons not to try very hard. And the Cambodians? These beautiful people, raped and scarred by one of the worst regimes since Hitler? They're not important. Ieng Sary and Khieu Samphan spend much of their time in a compound to the west of Pailin. It's a quiet place with more than a hint of menace. We dillied and dallied a little too long, and then - mindful of the guidebook - we got in a car and started to hurry away. A big 4x4 swung out of the compound gates and followed us down the road, through the minefields. The 4x4 overtook us, and moved on, but for a sliver of time we felt something of the terror, and the utter powerlessness, of the ordinary Cambodian faced with something out of their dark past. The crooner of Pailin can croon on.

fields.headline: The longest weekend
fields.standfirst: Few can resist a two-for-one offer. But who wants to spend more than a night in a service station? Michael Bywater checks into Clacket Lane Road Chef for an unwelcome break
fields.trailText: Few can resist a two-for-one offer. But who wants to spend more than a night in a service station? Michael Bywater checks into Clacket Lane Road Chef for an unwelcome break
fields.body:
It's not the Dome. Nothing is the Dome. Nor is it the Ayling Wheel, British Airways London Eye, going nowhere slowly and annoying the Queen. It's Clacket Lane. More than a motorway service area, Clacket Lane is the epitome of Mr Tony's New Britain. You can tell from the name itself, quivering with resonance. Clacket Lane. Say it. Clacket Lane. Hear the tappet-click of an aged slackjaw in NHS dentures munching through a microwaved service-station pie: adipocere pastry, centrifuged meat slurry, cloacal hogo, 'Good enough for the likes of us, can't be bothered with that mucked-about foreign stuff.'

Clacket Lane Road Chef. The Wigan Pier of our time, stuck like a salesman on the M25, straddling the route of an old Roman road, a bit of hump-and-fossa heritage lying somewhere beneath the lorry park and the fuel pumps, obliterated now by landscaped banks and yawning truck drivers but still commemorated in the Clacket Lane shopping what? Mall, area, outlet, bit?

Never mind; there's the Travelling Through Time display - squint at the pot shards, see the Samian ware, chumble on your burga while you peer at the Artist's reconstruction: clean-limbed Roman soldiers marching by a thatched village while cheery Saxons (plaits, cross-garters) smile and wave. In reality, they'd have been bunging rocks, or lurking out of sight, in the midden, sharpening sticks and dipping them in pig shit - but this isn't reality; this is Clacket Lane.

At least the Romans were going somewhere. The M25 is the greatest non-road in Britain, a vaporous hell of HGVs and sticky-arsed salesmen, of burping geezers in dodgy Transits, of circulating bailiffs up to no good, bewildered wholesale newsagents, cashiered conveyancers, gynaecologists' molls, you, me, us. Clacket Lane hunches over the least-anywhere section on this nowhere road; double-nowhere, a modern Erewhon; the Channel Tunnel at one end, Heathrow and Gatwick at the other: places you only go to to get to other places.

But it's an Erewhon with toilets, a Nowhere in which (although you can't get a simple cup of espresso without it being filtered through the reeking kidney of some marketing idiot's 'branding' process, in this case the 'Café Continental') you might possibly find what you need - a lavatory, a tank of unleaded, some edible calories - to give you the endurance to get the hell out of there and on to somewhere with a point.

But look: here, in the car park - the big sign: Weekend Breaks: Two Nights for the Price of One, £49.95 a double room. You thought a night in a motorway service station was a distress-purchase, something you did when you were knackered and still had 500 miles to go, when the Dexedrine ran out, the weather closed in, the options vanished: somewhere sad, cheap bastards spent Christmas Eve when nobody wanted to be with them.

See, though: you were wrong. Clacket Lane wants you not just to use it but to want it; it wants it to be your real; it wants to wake up with you. But who would go? What kind of degenerate would say to some poor blameless wife or giggling high-buttocked popsie, 'Hey, honey, fancy a two-night, double-room weekend break at the Clacket Lane Road Chef Lodge? Come on - you know you want it'? And what kind of a person would agree?

There, on the car-park banner, is a clarion call to an anthropological extravaganza. Love among the Mondeo folk, surreptitious venery with a Barclaycard and an itch; a grim mosaic of Rennies and Trevira, in-car accessories and petrol-station bonus points, of Vodafone and Classic FM: unfathomable courtship rituals and unwholesome sexual mannerisms brought to bear on some purse-lipped office person with a special acrylic Office Cardigan and a snap-shut handbag but nevertheless with thighs, with breasts, with nobody else at home and nowhere to go at the weekend and so off they go, £49.95, the All-Day Brunch only £4.99 and the competing allure of the Wimpy Classic King Size: Good Things in Life Are Worth Waiting For.

They're there. They must be. See: at 10 o'clock at night, there's condensation on some of the car windows in the sodium-lit car park. Their bonnets are cool. People are staying here. The receptionist is playing solitaire on the computer - Seahaven Towers. I've got that one. How are you doing? - I don't know. I just play; don't bother with the score. Can I help you? - What's the two-nights-for-the-price-of-one deal? - You get two nights for the price of one. Ooh look; you've stayed before.

My name comes up on the screen, but not my address, which is somewhere on the southern edge of the commuter badlands. Why would anyone who lived so close by stay in Clacket Lane? Mondeo Man. Cardie Woman. Must be. It must be true: my avatar, my doppelgänger, here with Sheila from Small Claims (Processing).

But there's no trace of them in the room. You'd think you could detect it: a vibration of guilt, a faint nose-twitch of the sadness pheromone, a sensibility of bed-wrestling and then the morning's retreat, 'We mustn't do this again' and 'No it was lovely but we've too much to lose' and 'Well cheers then, um, see you at the' and 'Yes, at the, yes, office, right' and 'But I don't regret it' and 'No nor do I, no, I'm glad we' but they do regret it. And they're not glad.

The beds are curiously high: twins beds, an immovable 'unit' bolted to the wall, obstruere perfugia improborum. A white, faintly clinical towel rail in the bathroom, and squeezy-bottles of Lux liquid soap; anything else ('Shampoo, Conditioner, Combs, Toothpaste, Toothbrush, Razors, Shaving Foam, Paracetamol, Tampon Towel, Pens, Writing paper, Hairspray, Flannel, Deodorant, Soap, Tights') is available for sale at Reception 'For your convenience', though it would be hard to imagine anything less convenient than putting one's strides to cook in the Corby 4400 then - oops! - having to stumble down to Reception, dirty, greasy-haired, foul-mouthed, migrainous, bleeding, unshaven and aching to write home.

Better, instead, to hose down with squeezy Lux then read the Literature while the car-crumpled trousers flatten in the Corby. Clacket Lane couches its delights in that constipated, Sta-Prest, massage-parlour register peculiar to the 'hospitality industry'. Things offer a 'full range' and are staffed '24 hours a day', as though there's some other possibility ('24 hours a fruit gum'). Has any human being apart from a strangulated-at-birth 'hospitality' executive ever used the word 'beverage' even in their deepest fantasies? Do actual people ever say: 'Oh look, Maureen, the bedroom telephone offers a self dial; we must request the line to be activated'? Is there anywhere outside Hospitality World where people require facilities, consume items, refer to adjacent instructions, prefer a light snack, visit the foyer area? Where 'a lot more' - as in 'The main shop has a comprehensive range of newspapers, magazines, toiletries, sweets, tobacco, gifts and a lot more' - means 'not much else unless you fancy a model steam locomotive carved out of coal'?

Out across the cold brick walkway, the night-time main building (called 'the Main Building') is already deserted, except for the ghost of motorway food and a dozen shouting, boisterous Essex teenagers on a spree. PhoneBitz is closed; the Wimpy Bar is closed (the best things in life are worth waiting for, but not until morning); the Bocca della Verita, a creepy fibreglass mouth with a slot, yabbers away insanely to itself and eats my coin.

I sense Sheila, my ghostly popsie, sliding into the deserted restaurant beside me for a romantic dinner: no wine (we're British; we can't be trusted; how would it be if everyone did it?), but a rosy-cheeked innocent beaming behind the empty hot-trays. 'Chef, can do you a lovely Mixed Grill' - and 'lovely' must be another word with a special Hosp. Ind. meaning because the lamb chop is like an old sheepskin slipper, the dead sausage has soft insides like a Marmite-flavoured dog turd, its skin not an actual skin but a dried, split version of the interior, only to be rendered edible by a thick slathering of Kiehl's No 1 Lip Balm. The food is so terrible that one wonders who the hell is in charge of the buying policy, and whether they go home at the end of the day pleased with what they've done.

And then you realise it's probably the same 'executive' who chooses the piped music. Perhaps the chefs never wanted, really, to be chefs. Perhaps it's just a living. But the music: to play even this drool requires skill, acquired by people who have spent a long time training, while the other children were out having fun, smoking, getting laid. People who were their parents' pride and hope.

Like the food, this is music stripped of all affect (unlike techno, dance, trance, jungle, D&B, whatever, which is affect stripped of all music) and it's almost a relief when, at just gone midnight, the music goes insane: a ghostly Tyrolean fish-slapping dance played on the weasel by someone who has heard about music but never actually heard any. For me and my imaginary mistress, it's like the final shuddering of a dutiful coitus ('We're here now so we might as well'): not an occasion of pleasure, merely an excuse to stop striving and go to sleep.

In the lorry park, they are all asleep, too, undisturbed by the corporate advertising blasting out of the petrol forecourt television sets in between fatuous burps of falsely urgent news. HH Young Transport Ltd, Southampton, Huddersfield; Hungarocamion, Budapest; the irascible Read Boardall Transport, sticker-laden ('Fair Play on Fuel!' 'Why Tax Our Transport Industry to Death!' 'Warning! Steering Rear Axle!'); Ideal Standard; Meachers of Southampton: all the curtains are drawn in the cabs, the bunks down, the portable televisions flickering, the lorry men settling down to uneasy dreams of home and breakfast, the road unrolling before them as they sleep.

In my room, sleep comes less easily, despite the soothing knowledge that either this, or tomorrow, night is free. Sheila the Avatar rusts in the next bed, waiting like a revenant for me to creep past the Unit and make her incarnate. Eventually I fall asleep, only to wake an hour later aware of an odd dampness about the sheets, something faintly feverish, an emanation of tormented salesmen which turns out to be a plastic mattress-protector, installed as a barrier against the bodily fluids of night inhabitants, frotted or fretted out in the nervous small hours. You know you've passed through some sort of taste barrier (heading in the wrong direction) when you find yourself in a room where it assumed that, one way or another, you are going to wet the bed.

At 6am, the lorry park is waking up. Drivers yawn and stretch in the grey, scudding drizzle; curtains are drawn back; scratching men line up for cups of tea or lean against their cabs, chatting. Bit by bit, the loads move off: meat, lavatories, fastenings, biscuits, parts. Commerce gives way to eager tourism. In the breakfasting restaurant, a chirpy six-pack of respectable middle-aged women chatter and giggle over their Full English Breakfasts, on their way to Leeds Castle. A sour-faced Belgian family purse their lips over their sausages and scan, hopelessly, the wad of brochures of Things To Do: BowlPlex Brighton, The Pantiles, Tunbridge Wells, Bosham Walk Craft Centre, The South Coast Museum of Shops, Eastbourne ('How We Lived Then'), Howletts and Lympne Wild Animal Parks ('There is always something new at Howletts and Lympne').

Clacket Lane comes to life like a numb limb. PhoneBitz opens its doors and I flirt briefly with a Champ (Hands Free into Battery: Best for Driver, Wonderful to combine mobile phone battery with hands free and charger function). Things are cranking up in the Shop, a clog-voiced American singing, ' If I say the right words/At the right time ' (in homage to Mr Tony, perhaps) while the women at the tills start on another day of shifting fags, tabloids, Shirt's £3.99, Beanie Baby luminous-green teddies (I imagine buying my ghostly Sheila a copy of BeanBag World and watching her face light up), Mrs Bridges' Afternoon Treats, Macallan marmalade, novelty jam, wristwatches, dusters, smutty novels ( Kiss the Lash and Domination Inc, just the thing for those lonely traffic jams) and Thermos flasks. A fiftysomething man (long, greasy grey hair, paunch, basketball jacket) is buying an egg sandwich and a Bruce Springsteen tape: man, food and music in perfect harmony.

I force down a Full English to the accompaniment of 'Pussycat Pussycat' played by Bulgarina microtonal bagpipes, Alpenhorn and expiring rhino. If this were the morning after, how would it be? It would be like this. It would be a total lack of style, it would be nothing done without an eye on profit, it would be abandonment dressed up as hospitality; it would be transience, tat, low cloud, the dispossessed in fleeces and bewildered expressions; it would be children shouting 'fuck' at the Time Bomb Jaw Breaker bubble-gum machine, Miller's Cornish Pasties TWO for £2.49, 'Customer's Own Food and Drink May Not be Consumed in the Restaurant', everything in little packets, sugar with a bad cartoon of Winston Churchill on the packet. It would be procurement executives, brochures, corporate identity meetings, branding, notices. It would be Britain 2000.

For me and my imaginary mistress, it's like the final shuddering of a dutiful coitus ('We're here now so we might as well'): not an occasion of pleasure, merely an excuse to stop striving and go to sleep. In the lorry park, they are all asleep, too, undisturbed by the corporate advertising blasting out of the petrol forecourt television sets in between fatuous burps of falsely urgent news. HH Young Transport Ltd, Southampton, Huddersfield; Hungarocamion, Budapest; the irascible Read Boardall Transport, sticker-laden ('Fair Play on Fuel!' 'Why Tax Our Transport Industry to Death!' 'Warning! Steering Rear Axle!'); Ideal Standard; Meachers of Southampton: all the curtains are drawn in the cabs, the bunks down, the portable televisions flickering, the lorry men settling down to uneasy dreams of home and breakfast, the road unrolling before them as they sleep. In my room, sleep comes less easily, despite the soothing knowledge that either this, or tomorrow, night is free. Sheila the Avatar rusts in the next bed, waiting like a revenant for me to creep past the Unit and make her incarnate. Eventually I fall asleep, only to wake an hour later aware of an odd dampness about the sheets, something faintly feverish, an emanation of tormented salesmen which turns out to be a plastic mattress-protector, installed as a barrier against the bodily fluids of night inhabitants, frotted or fretted out in the nervous small hours. You know you've passed through some sort of taste barrier (heading in the wrong direction) when you find yourself in a room where it assumed that, one way or another, you are going to wet the bed. At 6am, the lorry park is waking up. Drivers yawn and stretch in the grey, scudding drizzle; curtains are drawn back; scratching men line up for cups of tea or lean against their cabs, chatting. Bit by bit, the loads move off: meat, lavatories, fastenings, biscuits, parts. Commerce gives way to eager tourism. In the breakfasting restaurant, a chirpy six-pack of respectable middle-aged women chatter and giggle over their Full English Breakfasts, on their way to Leeds Castle. A sour-faced Belgian family purse their lips over their sausages and scan, hopelessly, the wad of brochures of Things To Do: BowlPlex Brighton, The Pantiles, Tunbridge Wells, Bosham Walk Craft Centre, The South Coast Museum of Shops, Eastbourne ('How We Lived Then'), Howletts and Lympne Wild Animal Parks ('There is always something new at Howletts and Lympne'). Clacket Lane comes to life like a numb limb. PhoneBitz opens its doors and I flirt briefly with a Champ (Hands Free into Battery: Best for Driver, Wonderful to combine mobile phone battery with hands free and charger function). Things are cranking up in the Shop, a clog-voiced American singing, ' If I say the right words/At the right time ' (in homage to Mr Tony, perhaps) while the women at the tills start on another day of shifting fags, tabloids, Shirt's £3.99, Beanie Baby luminous-green teddies (I imagine buying my ghostly Sheila a copy of BeanBag World and watching her face light up), Mrs Bridges' Afternoon Treats, Macallan marmalade, novelty jam, wristwatches, dusters, smutty novels ( Kiss the Lash and Domination Inc, just the thing for those lonely traffic jams) and Thermos flasks. A fiftysomething man (long, greasy grey hair, paunch, basketball jacket) is buying an egg sandwich and a Bruce Springsteen tape: man, food and music in perfect harmony. I force down a Full English to the accompaniment of 'Pussycat Pussycat' played by Bulgarina microtonal bagpipes, Alpenhorn and expiring rhino. If this were the morning after, how would it be? It would be like this. It would be a total lack of style, it would be nothing done without an eye on profit, it would be abandonment dressed up as hospitality; it would be transience, tat, low cloud, the dispossessed in fleeces and bewildered expressions; it would be children shouting 'fuck' at the Time Bomb Jaw Breaker bubble-gum machine, Miller's Cornish Pasties TWO for £2.49, 'Customer's Own Food and Drink May Not be Consumed in the Restaurant', everything in little packets, sugar with a bad cartoon of Winston Churchill on the packet. It would be procurement executives, brochures, corporate identity meetings, branding, notices. It would be Britain 2000.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: A year ago, the political broadcaster Sheena McDonald almost died after being hit by a police van. With the help of Gail Robinson, a neuropsychologist, she has miraculously recovered enough to be working again
fields.trailText: A year ago, the political broadcaster Sheena McDonald almost died after being hit by a police van. With the help of Gail Robinson, a neuropsychologist, she has miraculously recovered enough to be working again
fields.body:
Sheena McDonald
I don't remember anything about the accident last February. I've been told that I went to a lecture at BAFTA in Piccadilly. I presume I got a bus home to Islington, as that's what I usually do. I was crossing the road, and the van was on the wrong side of the road [answering an emergency call], so I can only assume I wasn't expecting anything from that direction. I was in a coma for three days and I'm told I was so badly bruised I was unrecognisable. I didn't take part in the court case which followed because I didn't have anything to say. I'm filled with incomprehension at the result [the driver was cleared of careless driving], and I'm now bringing a civil suit against the Met. It is unfinished business.

My first memory of Gail is a long time after she started working with me. I suffered post-traumatic amnesia (PTA) for weeks after the accident, and even after my memory began to come back it was very fragmentary, so the first time I remember meeting Gail is as an outpatient 12 weeks after the crash. She came across as a very open, informative and intelligent woman.

When you have PTA you are conscious, but you're not aware that you're conscious. Allan, my partner, says that I first met Gail a few weeks after the injury. Apparently, she would show me everyday objects and I had to name them, and she showed me 30 and I scored three. At first, I couldn't remember anything of the 15 years before the accident. I didn't remember that my grandmother had died, or that Princess Diana had died. I didn't even know who Allan was - I thought he was a doctor.

Gail ran a series of tests to identify which cognitive functions were impaired by the accident. A brain injury can wipe out parts of the brain. Some people in recovery can look at a chair and know it's called a chair, but they don't know what it's for, whereas others understand that it's for sitting on but they can't find the word 'chair'.

Gail's tests showed I could understand everything my family was saying, even though I couldn't respond, so they were able to keep me informed about what they were doing, tell me what was going on in the world, and treat me as a grown-up human being instead of an invalid.

What Gail is able to do is bring the example of others to bear so that I can see my condition in a wider context. So she'll say, 'Don't set yourself deadlines, because they're purely arbitrary, and you'll fail.'

I'm still seeing Gail. I'm still in recovery, but I can work again now, which is great. We meet up every four to six weeks and she gives me advice. She says, 'Don't do too much; don't exceed your capabilities.' But I did from quite early on. The first broadcast I did was in November in Durban, a panel discussion. There were five Commonwealth country foreign ministers with a live audience. I sent Gail a tape of it, and she said she had been nervous about me doing this in case I had language problems.

My most immediate problem is fatigue, but I can work around it. I'm creeping back into radio and television and writing a book about the impact of a life-changing experience. I can't work the 16-hour days I used to, but I don't think anyone should.

Gail Robinson
I first saw Sheena at the National Hospital for Neurology about two weeks after the accident, and she was in a bad way. At that point she still had PTA. There are islands of memory, but no continuous memory - you don't know where you are or who you are. Sheena was just living in the moment for five to six weeks, so she doesn't even remember people she saw on a daily basis. I was only vaguely familiar to her.

I saw her every few days, but was seeing her family more than her, as she was asleep for most of the day. My job was to assess the impairment of her cognitive skills - memory, language, concentration, visual perception - everything was severely impaired, and I was not optimistic, which is why Sheena is quite a miracle.

At the beginning of April, Sheena went to Edinburgh as an inpatient at a rehabilitation unit. When she left here, she was still having difficulty finding single words, let alone stringing sentences together. But in August, when I saw her again, that had more or less resolved itself. I was floored; everything had improved to the point where she was almost at ceiling on formal tests.

One of the things that definitely went in Sheena's favour is that she is intelligent, with a lot of resources and skills. She is also very motivated, organised and determined. She's got a very supportive family, and her partner would give her daily exercises and structures. Sheena would sometimes get a little frustrated, but she's never been really depressed. Anxiety and depression can undermine your progress.

I trained in Canberra, Australia, which is where I'm from. I was working as a research assistant in cognitive neuropsychology, which triggered my interest, so during the last three years of training I decided to specialise. I liked the combination of the clinical and the theoretical, applying the knowledge we have of the behaviour of the brain to real people.

I moved here four years ago, as London is really the centre of research in this field, and my job is a combination of clinical and research and teaching, my speciality being case studies in cognitive neuropsychology. My job is partly educational. So with Sheena, who is now getting back to her life, it is really listening to what problems she might be having. Sheena is very focused, which is her personality as well as what she's trained herself to be, and that's such a strength in somebody who's recovering.

My role is to give her strategies for how to get round problems. For example, if she's about to do a programme, we might talk about how to prepare in terms of having her memory at its best and all the words she needs at the tip of her tongue. Once she gets the skills and knows all the tricks of the trade, then she won't need me. I get a lot of job satisfaction seeing her doing so well. Sometimes you really enjoy patients, and that's the case with Sheena.

 Sheena McDonald's story will feature in Dispatches: Deadly Pursuit on Channel 4 on Thursday

fields.headline: Dying for a drink
fields.standfirst: Like a lot of journalists, Tom Hibbert liked a drink. Then things turned ugly...
fields.trailText: Like a lot of journalists, Tom Hibbert liked a drink. Then things turned ugly...
fields.body:
The pain was excruciating. My lower abdomen felt as though it was possessed by demons armed with chainsaws, and performing acts of savagery upon my internal organs. I knew what the matter was, of course. The Return of Pancreatitis. Sweating profusely and agony-wracked, I cursed myself, hated myself, for ignoring the strict instructions of the medical profession. I had been warned years before, and on several occasions, to give up drinking. But I had ignored this. I seemed unable to settle down to a day's writing without the 'tender counselling' offered by the whisky bottle. I had arrived, pathetically dishevelled, upon the sorry shores of alcoholism. I was a shame and disgrace to friends, family, my darling wife - even to my cat. I was an alcoholic (I am an alcoholic, as Elizabeth Taylor would say). I was an alcoholic - and I was about to die.

Pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, an elongated, tapered gland located behind the stomach. This secretes digestive enzymes and the hormones insulin and glucagon. With the onset of the disease, it is thought, enzymes normally secreted by the pancreas in an inactive form become activated and start to digest the pancreatic tissue. This process is called 'autodigestion' and causes swelling, haemorrhage and damage to the blood vessels. In other words, the pancreas eats itself. The death rate among pancreatitis sufferers is extremely high.

My recollections of what happened to me as a patient in London's Charing Cross Hospital are vague and hazy. But there I was, dosed to the gills on industrial-strength morphine and whatnot, in a coma. Things looked bleak. I was in intensive care, with my wife and sister building defences around my bed to prevent the Australian nurses from snagging their tights on one of the many tubes inserted into my weedy body. (The nurses from Sweden were more gentle.) My parents were there, too. Because of their inclination to soothe themselves with whisky and vodka while the four horsemen galloped towards me, we were nicknamed 'The Pancreatitis Family'.

Such is the state of the National Health Service that the hospital was forced to throw its doors open to almost anyone prepared to pay for the use of the surroundings. Apparently, while I lay there unaware of anything happening around me, there was a television crew stationed just outside my ward creating scenes for a small-screen item called The New Professionals. This has just started on Sky, so if you have satellite access and are completely bonkers, you might just catch a glimpse of me at death's door as Edward Woodward, and 'Bodie' and 'Doyle' tear around the corridors shooting their fake guns and growling.

It gets worse. The medical staff didn't know whether my brain had suffered from my unpleasant brush at the scythe of the Reaper. There seemed to be more than a chance that Tom Hibbert, that bloke that used to be able to answer all the questions on University Challenge and to interview people like Margaret Thatcher and Dennis Potter and Melvyn Bragg, might lose his marbles. People would come to visit me, and I would lie there spouting monstrous nonsense, or uttering nothing at all. One day Kevin Keegan, then manager of Fulham FC (whose ground, Craven Cottage, is just down the road from the hospital), dropped by on some 'caring sharing' PR visit. There he was at my bedside, and God only knows what I said to him, but when friends came to visit shortly after, I told them about my cosy meeting with the once be-permed wonder. They left the ward somewhat distressed and told my wife, 'Poor old Tom. He's got delusions that Kevin Keegan has mysteriously appeared by his bedside.'

I was in a bed with a sign reading 'Nil by Mouth' attached to it - not that I felt much like eating or drinking. My weight had fallen from 8.5 stone (at 5ft 10in, that's pretty weedy anyway, but I like being thin) to around five. I must have looked magnificent. And then it was all over. Thanks to the wonders of modern medicine (and thanks to the people who sat beside me in my hours of need), I am ALIVE.

And, do you know, being alive isn't too ghastly after all. It took months to recuperate and to walk properly again, after weeks of inactivity. The doctors have told me I can never drink again. Just one more Bells could kill me. I feel guilty for the expense I have been to the National Health Service and for the distress I have caused my family. Besides, not drinking can be a hoot. I don't miss the collection of bores in the pub at all, and at parties when everybody else starts to spout nonsense and act the giddy goat, I stand there basking in a warm glow of superiority. I am back to my normal (skimpy) weight, eat 'sensibly', and no longer bang my head falling down the stairs. My one concern now is that I will lose my hair. At 47, I have a full head of the stuff and have long laboured under the illusion that this was thanks to the follicle stimulation of demon alcohol. Oh well, I shall live to be 90, probably, a chrome-dome OAP. Hurrah. In celebration, I shall now light another life-enhancing cigarette.

fields.headline: Private Problem
fields.trailText: Your front-page lead (News, last week) failed to mention the nub of the problem - that is that the doctor informing the patient that their condition is serious enough to need hospital treatment for which there is, say, a two-year wait in the NHS will be the same person that will treat that patient in a private hospital within a few days providing the patient can pay several thousand pounds.

Tom Richardson
