webTitle: Phil Hogan limbers up for the school run

fields.headline: Phil Hogan limbers up for the school run
fields.trailText: My wife has decided to put my day's holiday to good use by driving off at the crack of eight o'clock to buy the contents of Lakeside Shopping Heaven with the money she has saved by not letting me use the internet to finish downloading an A-Z of common medical conditions from the Virtual Hypochondria Hospital of Iowa, even though I've barely got as far   as colonic irrigation and combat fatigue.
fields.body:
My wife has decided to put my day's holiday to good use by driving off at the crack of eight o'clock to buy the contents of Lakeside Shopping Heaven with the money she has saved by not letting me use the internet to finish downloading an A-Z of common medical conditions from the Virtual Hypochondria Hospital of Iowa, even though I've barely got as far as colonic irrigation and combat fatigue.

Needless to say, she thinks I am incapable of getting the three eldest to school and looking after the little one without the intervention of a more responsible being, and has written out an indecipherable list of instructions regarding the correct way to clean plates in the dishwasher, how to cut bread, which shoe goes on which foot and so on. But then I am just happily putting ill-shaped sandwiches in the wrong lunchboxes at 10 past eight when it occurs to me that - hang on - shouldn't someone be waking the children up?

Half an hour later we're careering up a country lane on two wheels, the four of them in the back trying to get their vests on while I run through my monologue on the subject of why people with the smallest cars are least able to keep on their own side of the white line. 'I WANT MY MILK!' says the little one, who is just going through the phase of not being able to speak in letters less than a foot high, though it is amazing how easily he is silenced by the chance discovery of a Chewitt in the map pocket while I'm looking for the 'magic' demisting cloth I bought from a former young offender who appeared on the doorstep last summer insisting that my purchase would enable him to fully discharge his debt to society in a way that, owing to the pressure of my not really wanting to know his life story, was never adequately explained. I've only just about got my seatbelt fastened when suddenly we're at the school, leaving scarcely five minutes to wrestle someone to the ground over the last of the parking spaces, which have been drastically reduced in availability since the headmaster issued his annual memo pointing out that the yellow zigzag lines outside the gates are not a secret Masonic invitation to parents with 4x4s the size of bungalows to reverse their vehicles up on the kerb and into crowds of milling infants.

We drop the three eldest off and get back in the car. 'I WANT MY MILK!' cries the little one all the way home, but luckily when we get back I remember it's the season for counting squashed frogs that have hopped out of the woods and on to the road, which as a means of sedation by repetition of a meaningless activity can hardly be bettered, and sure enough the little chap is soon lying on the couch for a pre-lunch double helping of Teletubbies, hence giving me an unmolested half-hour to catch up with my paperwork (or the crossword, as my wife insists on calling it) until such time as his fish fingers set the fire alarm off. I wait till he is safely re-stippling the kitchen walls with tomato ketchup before returning to my timetable of events, which lists replacing a lightbulb (was there one in particular?) and attempting to set the video following my wife's simple 15-part, step-by-step guidelines, to which I notice she has appended the ominous word 'Voila!', thus guaranteeing instant failure.

At last it's time to go off to the school and bring them all back again, but in the meantime Jose the gardener has been out mowing the communal lawns, and I don't know what gets into me, but I suddenly find myself having a quite breathless grass fight with the four of them still in their school uniforms, which doesn't go down fantastically well with my wife, who suddenly arrives back tutting from a hard day looking at things through shop windows. 'Have you any idea how to get grass stains out of a white shirt?' she asks, not really in a humour to entertain jocular responses involving the words 'Do I look like Danny Baker?'

An hour later I'm tucking the little one into bed ('I WANT MY MILK!') while my wife unloads toys out of the car for his third birthday, which I knew perfectly well was tomorrow, but had slightly forgotten in all the excitement of trying to keep my eyes open. Blimey, I can hardly believe it's three-and-a-half years since I had my vasectomy! How time flies whether you're enjoying yourself or not.

 childminding offers tophil.hogan@observer.co.uk
fields.bodyText: My wife has decided to put my day's holiday to good use by driving off at the crack of eight o'clock to buy the contents of Lakeside Shopping Heaven with the money she has saved by not letting me use the internet to finish downloading an A-Z of common medical conditions from the Virtual Hypochondria Hospital of Iowa, even though I've barely got as far as colonic irrigation and combat fatigue. Needless to say, she thinks I am incapable of getting the three eldest to school and looking after the little one without the intervention of a more responsible being, and has written out an indecipherable list of instructions regarding the correct way to clean plates in the dishwasher, how to cut bread, which shoe goes on which foot and so on. But then I am just happily putting ill-shaped sandwiches in the wrong lunchboxes at 10 past eight when it occurs to me that - hang on - shouldn't someone be waking the children up? Half an hour later we're careering up a country lane on two wheels, the four of them in the back trying to get their vests on while I run through my monologue on the subject of why people with the smallest cars are least able to keep on their own side of the white line. 'I WANT MY MILK!' says the little one, who is just going through the phase of not being able to speak in letters less than a foot high, though it is amazing how easily he is silenced by the chance discovery of a Chewitt in the map pocket while I'm looking for the 'magic' demisting cloth I bought from a former young offender who appeared on the doorstep last summer insisting that my purchase would enable him to fully discharge his debt to society in a way that, owing to the pressure of my not really wanting to know his life story, was never adequately explained. I've only just about got my seatbelt fastened when suddenly we're at the school, leaving scarcely five minutes to wrestle someone to the ground over the last of the parking spaces, which have been drastically reduced in availability since the headmaster issued his annual memo pointing out that the yellow zigzag lines outside the gates are not a secret Masonic invitation to parents with 4x4s the size of bungalows to reverse their vehicles up on the kerb and into crowds of milling infants. We drop the three eldest off and get back in the car. 'I WANT MY MILK!' cries the little one all the way home, but luckily when we get back I remember it's the season for counting squashed frogs that have hopped out of the woods and on to the road, which as a means of sedation by repetition of a meaningless activity can hardly be bettered, and sure enough the little chap is soon lying on the couch for a pre-lunch double helping of Teletubbies, hence giving me an unmolested half-hour to catch up with my paperwork (or the crossword, as my wife insists on calling it) until such time as his fish fingers set the fire alarm off. I wait till he is safely re-stippling the kitchen walls with tomato ketchup before returning to my timetable of events, which lists replacing a lightbulb (was there one in particular?) and attempting to set the video following my wife's simple 15-part, step-by-step guidelines, to which I notice she has appended the ominous word 'Voila!', thus guaranteeing instant failure. At last it's time to go off to the school and bring them all back again, but in the meantime Jose the gardener has been out mowing the communal lawns, and I don't know what gets into me, but I suddenly find myself having a quite breathless grass fight with the four of them still in their school uniforms, which doesn't go down fantastically well with my wife, who suddenly arrives back tutting from a hard day looking at things through shop windows. 'Have you any idea how to get grass stains out of a white shirt?' she asks, not really in a humour to entertain jocular responses involving the words 'Do I look like Danny Baker?' An hour later I'm tucking the little one into bed ('I WANT MY MILK!') while my wife unloads toys out of the car for his third birthday, which I knew perfectly well was tomorrow, but had slightly forgotten in all the excitement of trying to keep my eyes open. Blimey, I can hardly believe it's three-and-a-half years since I had my vasectomy! How time flies whether you're enjoying yourself or not.  childminding offers tophil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: American beauties
fields.standfirst: There is more to eating stateside than burgers, fries and apple pie
fields.trailText: There is more to eating stateside than burgers, fries and apple pie
fields.body:
I've never understood where we get off sneering at the Americans for their food so. Doesn't everyone know that their cooking is, well, maybe better than ours? I understand that now we're in the full flush of culinary smuggery it doesn't quite do to suggest any nation might be superior to us in the kitchen. Good God, even the French don't get a look-in these days, so why should we even be polite about the Yanks?

But it's not quite like that. A league table of gastronomic achievement is not to the point; this whole eating thing is not some examination compare-and-contrast exercise. It isn't about who's better, who's worse. We all have the foods that we love, and not always for culinary reasons. Is a shepherd's pie really better than a meatloaf? So much of what we feel about food is really about what we feel about our memories of eating it - and I don't say that's wrong. But it's better not to confuse the issue.

And just as we get annoyed when foreigners think our cooking is on the watery-stew and soggy-crumble level, so Americans must get incensed at our unworried assumption that their native fare extends little beyond hamburger and chiffon pies. I've eaten better in America, admittedly in the cities, than anywhere else in the world. You know that modern British Italianate thing - I first came by it in San Francisco and then New York more than 10 years ago. And it's not surprising that America is so interesting as an eating place. There is something inevitably gastronomically rewarding about a country that bases its identity on the cultural melting pot. This is the land of fusion cooking avant la lettre.

I don't mean to preach, not least because my weakness here is not for the modern, evolved and savvy food hot off the transatlantic menu, but for a certain sort of down-home cooking, best described as culinary-kitsch Americana. Perhaps here is the place for me to make this public confession: yes, I do own a copy of a book called Mazeltov Y'all: the Heritage of Southern Jewish Cooking. And there are many more with titles not so dissimilar on my bookshelves. Food That Really Schmecks - a Mennonite cookbook - is another of my favourites. And I'm not making fun here: I like these books because they are driven by a passionate, territorial culinary pride. You can't read them without wanting to cook their food.

And what many different American culinary cultures seem to share, apart from the obsessive need to chronicle, is an understanding of excellent simplicity: Maine lobsters, Florida stone crabs, New Orleans pompano - no one believes it has to be messed around with to be good. I'm not saying there aren't excesses or that there aren't catastrophes - but a gastronomic tour of the United States is not the joke we make out it might be. The recipes that follow are a scant introduction to the best of culinary Americana, from the simplest to the alluringly kitsch.

New England boiled dinner
We feel a bollito misto is chic, so why not the Bostonian version? You do, traditionally, need salt beef for it, but that shouldn't be beyond a proper butcher. Just ask. I'm not suggesting you salt and spice it yourself. Or use ordinary beef. The Scottish mail-order butcher, Donald Russell (01467 629 666), does a very good Germanic cut called tafelspitz which works well. This recipe comes by way of Evan Jones's great book, American Food: the Gastronomic Story, first published in New York in 1974. Serves 4.

1.5 kilos salt beef
6 turns of the mill of freshly ground pepper
1 bay leaf
1 parsnip
½ a swede
3 large carrots
4 medium potatoes
½ a cabbage
6 small beetroots, pre-boiled and peeled
3 tbsps horseradish sauce
6 tbsps sour cream
4 or 5 dashes of Tabasco

Cover the salt beef with water, add the pepper and bay leaf and bring to a simmer over medium heat. Let simmer for a total of 4 hours. (If you're using ordinary brisket or the Tafelspitz, I'd halve this time.) Before the last 40 minutes, add the parsnip, swede, carrots and potatoes, peeled and cut into large chunks. Before the last 15 minutes, add the cabbage, roughly chopped, and before the last 5 minutes, the beetroots.

Remove the beef and slice thinly. Arrange it on a large heated plate and then fish out the vegetables with a slotted spoon and dot around the meat. Make a sauce to eat with it by mixing together the horseradish, sour cream and Tabasco in a small bowl.

This makes enough for four with, as Evan Jones remarks, enough left over to make a red flannel hash. To make this, fry some chopped-up bacon and onion in a frying pan, then add the left-over beef, also chopped, along with diced boiled potato and beetroot. Cook it until you have a piping-hot, rubbly red cake - and eat with the corn breads below.

Corn bread
Since corn is the indigenous American ingredient, I couldn't help but include a recipe using it here. You can make corn bread in loaf, square or muffin tins, but I love the corn bread that comes in cornsticks, made in moulds that resemble folk art themselves, fashioned out of cast iron to give the nubbly form of corn in the cob. You can buy these sorts of moulds, though not usually in cast iron, over here now, but I've got some a friend devotedly schlepped over for me all the way from the Broadway Panhandler in New York, which I understandably cherish.

Get some if you can, especially if you've got children, to whom (though not exclusively) they appeal. And eat these golden miniature maize breads with soup, stews, the hash above or just as they are, even for breakfast (add an extra teaspoon of baking powder if you are making muffins). Makes 18 cornsticks, 12 muffins or one batch of corn bread.

175g fine cornmeal (or polenta - same difference, really)
125g plain flour
45g sugar
1 fat pinch salt
1 tbsp baking powder
250ml milk
1 egg
45g melted, cooled, unsalted butter
vegetable shortening for greasing cornsticks

Preheat the oven to 200º/gas mark 6, then grease the cornstick moulds with melted vegetable shortening. If you're not using the cornstick moulds, you should grease a 20cm square tin (5cm deep) or 12-bun muffin tin with butter (if you're not using paper cases).

Mix the cornmeal, flour, sugar, salt and baking powder in a large bowl. In a measuring jug, beat together the milk, egg and cooled, melted butter. Then pour the wet ingredients into the dry, stirring with a wooden spoon until just combined. Don't worry in the slightest about the odd lump. Pour into the greased moulds and bake for

12-15 minutes for the cornsticks, or 20-25 minutes for the square or muffin tins. When ready, the corn bread should be just pulling away from the sides. Cut the square into smaller squares or tip out the cornsticks or muffins and eat warm. The cornsticks, swabbed with butter, are God's way of telling you that greed is good.

S'mores
The original s'more - if the term can be accurately used for a vernacular foodstuff such as this - was a toasted marshmallow sandwiched between Graham crackers (digestive biscuits) and dunked into melted chocolate: campfire food, and so named because you eat one, you gotta eat s'more. Variations have developed to accommodate less impromptu modes of cooking and the one that follows is really a batch of brownies with a sandy covering of crumbled digestives under a topping of grilled mini-marshmallows. The name is well earned: this is the sort of food that you airily declare disgusting after the first, but then find, unaccountably, you've eaten half the tin.

250g good-quality dark chocolate
75g unsalted butter
100g plain flour
º tsp baking powder
50g caster sugar
2 large eggs
4 tbsps golden syrup
75g digestives, razed to crumbs in the processor
125g mini-marshmallows

Preheat the oven to 160º/gas mark 3, and line a 22cm square brownie tin with baking parchment. Melt the chocolate and butter together; I find the easiest way is to give them 2 or so minutes on medium in the microwave. In a large bowl, combine the flour, baking powder and sugar, and beat in the eggs and then the golden syrup, followed by the melted chocolate and butter mixture.

Pour or scrape into the prepared tin. Scatter the crumbled biscuits on top and cook for 35 minutes.

Remove from the oven, switch on the grill and cover the baked mixture with the mini-marshmallows. Toast under the grill for the merest minute - watching over it all the time - until it's toasted. Leave for 20 minutes, then cut into large or small squares, as you like, with a wet knife. And then pretend you've made them for your children.

 Nigella Lawson is cookery writer for Vogue; Nigel Slater returns next week

webTitle: Violence is a sign of class war

fields.headline: Violence is a sign of class war
fields.trailText: Although Barbara Ellen (Comment, last week) is quite right to point out the distinction between the doers and the watchers of male violence, her depiction of the composition of these groups and the relationship between them is shaky.
fields.body:
Although Barbara Ellen (Comment, last week) is quite right to point out the distinction between the doers and the watchers of male violence, her depiction of the composition of these groups and the relationship between them is shaky.

However, the class relationship that she hints might exist between these two groups is a much more fecund field of exploration. Self-protection is not the only reason why the 'educated and the privileged' have steered clear of violence and allocated it to the male constituents of the lower orders. Until the recent arrival of computers, robots and 'smart' distance weapons, hard physical labour in material production and military expansion was absolutely essential to the reproduction of the territorial and cultural power of the privileged classes.
Steve Hall
Project Director, ESRC Violence Research Programme
Newcastle upon Tyne

 In any evaluation of human behaviour a rule which must be adhered to is to leave the apes out of it as they for one, as most other members of species on this planet, don't organise violence as entertainment. In that it has become a medium of 'entertainment' is surely an ascent of person rather than a descent of man as it keeps us off the streets, out of the army and away from guns.
Richard Tunaley
Tokyo, Japan

fields.headline: Mo replies
fields.trailText: Antony Barnett (News, 12 March) suggests that companies deliberately arrange for employees to work in government departments in order to win contracts or to influence policy changes.
fields.body:
Antony Barnett (News, 12 March) suggests that companies deliberately arrange for employees to work in government departments in order to win contracts or to influence policy changes.

We are careful to ensure that proper safeguards exist. We are committed to modernising the Civil Service and I am confident that interchange with other sectors, backed up by adequate checks and controls, has a key part to play in delivering that more efficient and effective Civil Service.
Marjorie Mowlam
Cabinet Office, London SW1

fields.headline: What makes a Nazi-lover tick?
fields.trailText: Gerald Posner's interview with David Irving (News, last week) was certainly interesting, but what is it makes the man, and his fellow revisionists, tick? What driving force, or what psychological quirk, makes people who claim to be serious historians resist the current of so much evidence?
fields.body:
Gerald Posner's interview with David Irving (News, last week) was certainly interesting, but what is it makes the man, and his fellow revisionists, tick? What driving force, or what psychological quirk, makes people who claim to be serious historians resist the current of so much evidence? What seeker after historical truth can credit any Nazi-defensive statement when the system was so largely based on Goebbels' principle that the bigger the lie the more it would be believed?

If such people have a nostalgic admiration for the Nazis, then they should celebrate what the Nazis did to the Jews rather than deny it. Let them be consistent. Then we would really know with whom we are dealing.
John Hale
Nice, France

 David Irving is wrong about the eagerness of 'everyone' in wartime to hand over the Jews. The Italians evaded this by various stratagems; Denmark resisted, with considerable success; Bulgaria refused; the Greeks were tricked; and even the Romanians and Hungarians, despite strong anti-semitism, fluctuated in response. When a suspicious Admiral Horthy asked in 1943 what exactly would happen to deported Jews, however, Hitler told the Hungarian leader that the Jews would be forced to work, those who resisted would be killed, and those unable to work would succumb like animals who have to be put down.
Camile Watson
Gobernuisgach, NW Highlands

webTitle: Marriage is not the only answer

fields.headline: Marriage is not the only answer
fields.trailText: Marianne Talbot cannot seriously believe that David Blunkett will take up her challenge (Comment, last week) and expend monies from an already heavily overloaded education budget on a campaign to promote marriage throughout state schools. Indeed she answers her own rhetorical call by intimating that many teachers themselves do not believe in the efficacy of a state- or church-sanctioned heterosexual partnership after the best part of three decades of serious doubt among middle-class opinion-formers in this most contentious area of potential social engineering.
fields.body:
Marianne Talbot cannot seriously believe that David Blunkett will take up her challenge (Comment, last week) and expend monies from an already heavily overloaded education budget on a campaign to promote marriage throughout state schools. Indeed she answers her own rhetorical call by intimating that many teachers themselves do not believe in the efficacy of a state- or church-sanctioned heterosexual partnership after the best part of three decades of serious doubt among middle-class opinion-formers in this most contentious area of potential social engineering. If New Labour is minded to take up Ms Talbot's gauntlet then they must realise it must be part of a wider economic package aimed at helping parents to put in the time with their offspring rather than being compelled by financial necessity to neglect the needs of the next generation.
Bill Jackson
Nottingham

 As a former Relate counsellor and now a part-time vicar, I think that the Government and the churches are getting there. The church, however, didn't get it right for all time in the 1950s. For example, as a priest, I prepare some people, who have previously been divorced, for a second marriage, which then takes place in our church. That would have been virtually impossible, at least in the Church of England, in the Fifties. As a Relate counsellor, I helped some couples through divorce as well as others towards reconciliation. Many of those who have been divorced and have usually been through the mill psychologically, spiritually and sometimes physically, still regard marriage as the best basis for bringing up children. The difference between marriage and living together is that marriage explicitly acknowledges that the relationship is a social as well as a purely private arrangement between two people. It is out of kilter with fanatical individualism. A church wedding has the further dimension of a public covenant and commitment to God as well as before other people.

I hope that we do end up with Clause 28 being repealed and also with marriage being valued and treasured, while being equally clear that it is not the best arrangement for many people. We all have to make choices from the various alternatives that may be available to us. Marriage should not return to its oppressive status in the past whereby anyone not married (or in a monastery) was made to feel a second-class human being. It's a fine balance we need in which mutual respect has to be the keynote.
David Charles-Edwards
Priest-in-charge, Clifton and Newton
Rugby, Warwickshire

 Marianne Talbot should take comfort that the sex-as-recreation without responsibility which she describes as a 'very long-term, massively far-reaching and generally welcomed social trend' is, in fact, nothing of the sort. In a 3,000-year philosophical and religious Western culture, present trends are a mere blip of some three or four generations. They clearly sit very uncomfortably, even miserably, for much of society and there is every reason to suppose that, barring those who make themselves very rich out of these trends, most would like to see a better state of affairs.

We cannot, and should not, turn back the clock - but we should also have the humility to ask why, for example, all cultures have evolved a courageous recognition by individuals of their willingness to commitment in some form of marriage. Our temporal vanity and parochialism is worrying to say the least.
Ian Flintoff
London SW6

For example, as a priest, I prepare some people, who have previously been divorced, for a second marriage, which then takes place in our church. That would have been virtually impossible, at least in the Church of England, in the Fifties. As a Relate counsellor, I helped some couples through divorce as well as others towards reconciliation. Many of those who have been divorced and have usually been through the mill psychologically, spiritually and sometimes physically, still regard marriage as the best basis for bringing up children. The difference between marriage and living together is that marriage explicitly acknowledges that the relationship is a social as well as a purely private arrangement between two people. It is out of kilter with fanatical individualism. A church wedding has the further dimension of a public covenant and commitment to God as well as before other people. I hope that we do end up with Clause 28 being repealed and also with marriage being valued and treasured, while being equally clear that it is not the best arrangement for many people. We all have to make choices from the various alternatives that may be available to us. Marriage should not return to its oppressive status in the past whereby anyone not married (or in a monastery) was made to feel a second-class human being. It's a fine balance we need in which mutual respect has to be the keynote. In a 3,000-year philosophical and religious Western culture, present trends are a mere blip of some three or four generations. They clearly sit very uncomfortably, even miserably, for much of society and there is every reason to suppose that, barring those who make themselves very rich out of these trends, most would like to see a better state of affairs. We cannot, and should not, turn back the clock - but we should also have the humility to ask why, for example, all cultures have evolved a courageous recognition by individuals of their willingness to commitment in some form of marriage. Our temporal vanity and parochialism is worrying to say the least. Ian Flintoff London SW6

While all decent people accept that freedom of speech does not extend to the publishing of paedophile material, the make-up of the Internet makes censorship far harder than you imply (News, last week). Internet censorship is possible, and in this context desirable, but much less easy to achieve than people believe. A system designed by the US military to withstand nuclear war will not have much trouble dealing with the half baked solutions of Patricia Hewitt et al.

London E17

fields.headline: Reading lesson
fields.trailText: You asked: Can men read? (Leader comment, last week). That depends if 'reading' is an activity confined to a certain type of contemporary English fiction.
fields.body:
You asked: Can men read? (Leader comment, last week). That depends if 'reading' is an activity confined to a certain type of contemporary English fiction. A person who attempts other varieties of fiction, or History, or Biography, or even Classics, may also be reading. It takes a typically English literary provincialism to assume that readers (men or women) who prefer the likes of James Ellroy, William Gibson, Gore Vidal, Peter Ackroyd, Eric Hobsbawm and Simon Schama to the excitements of Anita Brookner are 'narrow minded when it comes to choosing books'.
John Medhurst
Hove, E Sussex

fields.headline: Trimble's gambit must triumph
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: So where now, David Trimble? Politics is littered with examples of leaders who issued 'come on then, have a go if you think you're big enough' invitations to dissidents and found they were fatally weakened as a result. Margaret Thatcher, for one, must have viewed yesterday's events in Belfast's King's Hall with a certain weary sense of  déjà vu. She's been stalked by donkeys, too.
fields.body:
So where now, David Trimble? Politics is littered with examples of leaders who issued 'come on then, have a go if you think you're big enough' invitations to dissidents and found they were fatally weakened as a result. Margaret Thatcher, for one, must have viewed yesterday's events in Belfast's King's Hall with a certain weary sense of déjà vu. She's been stalked by donkeys, too.

Certainly, Martin Smyth's 348 votes was an ominously large warning to his courageous and more far-sighted leader. No politician in Britain or Ireland has risked more than Trimble in the past year, and the 56 to 43 per cent margin by which he keeps his job against a decent but uncharismatic challenger shows that he has been taking risks, and serious ones, with the Ulster Unionist Party as well.

But we knew this already. So did he. His turning round of the decommissioning challenge, effectively asking the IRA to tell the world what it can do, and will do, was a clever gambit. He played the British Government with cold brilliance before the Assembly was suspended. He has been doing a better job for 'his people' than they seem to have the wit to understand. And for the rest of us, his value is his sinewy determination to come back to the negotiations time and time again, even if only to 'fail better'.

One difference between Trimble and Smyth is the difference between taking responsibility, taking risks and simply crouching in your dug-out. Another is that they represent different visions of Unionism: Trimble's is progressive, not cutting itself from its ancestral roots, but acknowledging that the world must change. It is more liberal, more bourgeois perhaps. Smyth stands for the rock-like loyalism on which his followers wish to dash themselves. But it is based on a vision of the United Kingdom which is disintegrating elsewhere in Britain and on a religious fundamentalism which sits uneasily in a secular age. Smyth represents a future where there is no such thing as a change for the better.

So it is desirable, perhaps, to flush out the 'no compromise at any price' people now. Before long, Unionist politics must be reshaped or there will be no settlement. Until the Assembly is up and running again, the danger of a long slither back to war is real. Trimble understands it. And now, having won his vote, however narrowly, he must push his worried, divided party further forward. Yes, it was 'too close for comfort'. But where was the comfort in any of this anyway?

fields.headline: Back-biting art
fields.trailText: I was shocked and very saddened to read the callous and mean-spirited comments Gilbert and George directed at Anthony d'Offay   (Life, last week).
fields.body:
I was shocked and very saddened to read the callous and mean-spirited comments Gilbert and George directed at Anthony d'Offay (Life, last week). It is a sad and somewhat pathetic commentary on the artists that they would choose to so openly disparage someone who for over 20 years did nothing but support and nurture their career.
Glenn Fuhrman
New York

fields.headline: Real charity
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) is surely wrong to use giving or not giving to beggars as a sign of our attitudes to poor people and   countries.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) is surely wrong to use giving or not giving to beggars as a sign of our attitudes to poor people and countries. If we really want to reduce inequality and increase inclusion, we will do these things: cut, immediately and substantially, our personal consumption of fossil fuels, buy fair-traded goods, give large sums to campaigning and charitable organisations, and devote a proportion of our own time to campaigning for a juster world.
E. K. Mandeville
Lewes, E Sussex

fields.headline: Plane speaking
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters outlined the runway crises facing Britain if passenger numbers rise as predicted (Business, last week). But the market is also being distorted by the amount of subsidy received by the aviation industry.
fields.body:
Joanna Walters outlined the runway crises facing Britain if passenger numbers rise as predicted (Business, last week). But the market is also being distorted by the amount of subsidy received by the aviation industry. There is no tax on aircraft fuel, for example. Nor is VAT charged on the purchase of new aircraft. And the taxpayer picks up the bill for the pollution, noise and health impacts of aviation. If these subsidies were removed, the predicted growth in passenger numbers would be far less.
John Stewart
Vice Chair, Transport 2000, London SW9

fields.headline: Grow up, Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's ambassador to Germany, Sir Paul Lever, has stirred up a vipers' nest with his unguarded comments in  Die Welt about anti-German prejudice in the British press. He has had to issue apologies and is now to be sued by  Telegraph proprietor Conrad Black. He is, of course, being punished for speaking the truth, a sin which only the most naïve diplomat is caught committing in public. As John Major noted some years ago, the Scots define their nationalism with reference to the English, but the English do so with reference to the French and the Germans. Hence the petty anglophobia which occasionally disfigures Scottish life; hence the sneering jokes which accompany many British references to France and Germany.
fields.body:
Britain's ambassador to Germany, Sir Paul Lever, has stirred up a vipers' nest with his unguarded comments in Die Welt about anti-German prejudice in the British press. He has had to issue apologies and is now to be sued by Telegraph proprietor Conrad Black. He is, of course, being punished for speaking the truth, a sin which only the most naïve diplomat is caught committing in public. As John Major noted some years ago, the Scots define their nationalism with reference to the English, but the English do so with reference to the French and the Germans. Hence the petty anglophobia which occasionally disfigures Scottish life; hence the sneering jokes which accompany many British references to France and Germany.

It is easy enough to dismiss such jibes as harmless humour. But for Germans, particularly those living in Britain, this is a Catch-22. If their children are taunted at school, they are expected to treat it as a joke; if they don't, it confirms everything people say about the Germans not having a sense of humour. Wrapped up in the jokes are jealousy and not a little ignorance. Eurosceptics perceive Germany, rather than France, as the chief threat in a European hegemony.

They see it as controlling the currency they have sworn to shun forever. Worse, Germans are perfectly comfortable with the F-word - federalism. Yet modern Germany, if a trifle smug, is far removed from the lampoon of British popular perception. Ninety-eight per cent of its people are committed to liberal democracy. Its press, though not free of unpleasantness, does not indulge in the whining xenophobia which characterises even some of our most respectable newspapers.

Diplomats with experience of both countries believe that the British prejudice is worse than 30 years ago. Paradoxically, the more the Second World War retreats into the past, the more its legacy seems to poison modern attitudes. We live in an age of historical self-abasement but, in the case of Germany, the time has surely come to move on.

fields.headline: First-class male
fields.trailText: Comfort for those who worry about men. After years of reading that males lag behind females in just about everything but earning power, we learn today that an Oxford psychiatrist claims to have located the origins of speech in the Y-chromosome. In other words, men spoke first.
fields.body:
Comfort for those who worry about men. After years of reading that males lag behind females in just about everything but earning power, we learn today that an Oxford psychiatrist claims to have located the origins of speech in the Y-chromosome. In other words, men spoke first.

Women may dismiss this as trivially true, pointing out that the finding merely underlines a well-established social truth, that nothing can be considered said until said by a man. But Professor Tim Crow is claiming rather more. He believes the transition from grunting to language was first made by the male of the species and that the reason for his clever noises was that they conferred sexual advantage.

Coincidentally, last week another psychiatrist claimed to have discovered that men find women with a richer vocabulary more sexually appealing. This is so counter-intuitive as to leave us wondering whether something went awry with the research.

Still, the two taken together generate interesting speculation about that Original Conversation. Clearly not: 'There's a bison down by the lake', still less: 'Don't eat the apple, Eve.' More a case of: 'Look at the phonemes on her.'

fields.headline: Battle rages for Saro-Wiwa's bones
fields.standfirst: Five years after the brutal execution of the Nigerian playwright and eight fellow activists their reburial has fuelled a series of bitter feuds that threaten further unrest, reports  Jason Burke
fields.trailText: His death sentence prompted thousands to hold candlelit vigils around the world. Ken Saro-Wiwa, a campaigner against Western oil interests in his native Nigeria, became an international martyr when his country's ruling dictator ordered him to be hanged.
fields.body:
His death sentence prompted thousands to hold candlelit vigils around the world. Ken Saro-Wiwa, a campaigner against Western oil interests in his native Nigeria, became an international martyr when his country's ruling dictator ordered him to be hanged.

The planned execution five years ago almost led to Britain expelling the populous West African state from the Commonwealth, as his then London-based son launched a poignant plea for clemency. It was to no avail. Saro-Wiwa was led to the gallows and his body dumped in a shallow grave.

Now, however, the bones of Saro-Wiwa are stirring again. A row over what should happen to his remains is causing a conflict stretching from London to Lagos that could once again tear Nigeria apart.

With a new democratically elected government installed in Nigeria, there have been suggestions that Saro-Wiwa should receive a traditional funeral next month in an attempt to show that the dark chapters of Nigeria's murderous past can finally be closed. The funeral would aid 'reconciliation', said Olusegun Obasanjo, the country's new President.

The remains of the eight other activists executed alongside him - who had, like Saro- Wiwa, fought for better treatment for the country's Ogoni tribal minority in the oil-rich delta region where they live - were buried close by.

However, the prospect of a funeral has split the political representatives of the Ogoni and set the relatives of the executed men against each other.

A key figure is Saro-Wiwa's eldest son, Ken Wiwa, who fled Nigeria's dictatorship for London, along with thousands of his countrymen, and now lives in Toronto. He wants his father buried according to his last wishes: in a simple grave if his beloved Ogoni people - of whom there about 500,000 - had still not been granted independent rule.

'We have to follow Ken's orders,' said Owens Wiwa, the hanged activist's younger brother. 'It is the family's duty to follow his last wishes. After everything he gave during his life, and after our failure to prevent his death, that is the least we can do.'

Saro-Wiwa's family contacted the Physicians for Human Rights (PHR) in Toronto who agreed to send a forensic expert to Port Harcourt, the southern city where he was hanged, to locate and examine the remains of the 'Ogoni Nine' - the other men hanged with him.

But the expert, who travelled to Nigeria last month, immediately ran into difficulties when relatives of the slain blocked his visit to the burial site.

'It was a fiasco,' said one PHR source. 'He walked slap into the middle of a million different agendas.'

The affair exploded across Nigerian newspapers as the various parties rushed to defend themselves in print. The argument is fundamentally over the form of the funeral.

Though Saro-Wiwa's family want the simple ceremony outlined in his will, many Ogoni politicians - even those of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop) that Saro-Wiwa founded - hope to use the occasion to rally their demoralised supporters and boost their political presence.

They have formed a 'burial committee' and have made calls for all nine of the executed men to be buried together in a huge public ceremony. The Wiwas have refused to recognise the committee, prompting accusations by some senior Mosop figures that the family are acting like 'dynastic rulers'.

Others criticise both sides. The widow of Barinem Kiobel, who died alongside Saro-Wiwa, claims that his family have never asked for her permission and that Mosop have just tried to make 'cheap political profit' out of the affair.

'The gimmicks, tricks, manipulation and dehumanisation of some elements in Mosop leave much to be desired,' Esther Kiobel said.

Lucky Dobee, whose elder brother was hanged, also says that her family was not consulted. Though the newly elected President of Nigeria, himself a former dissident, has been supportive of the reburial plan, other government figures are thought to oppose it for fear that it could spark a new round of blood-letting and violence in the country.

'Any funeral would be a huge occasion and the local authorities might have difficulty maintaining order,' said a Nigerian journalist based in London. 'They might have to resort to force and then things could very quickly spiral out of control. Not only would a funeral be a public relations disaster but it could be very inflammatory nationwide.'

The family hints that sinister interests are orchestrating the row. 'The confusion is organised. There are many people who still think Ken is a threat even if he is dead,' one of Saro-Wiwa's six surviving children told The Observer last week. 'This is a way to muddy his memory.'

But the authorities' concern may be justified. For a decade, Nigeria has teetered on the brink of total collapse. Thousands have been killed in communal violence in the past year, despite the country's return to civilian rule, and last month several hundred more died in riots following the imposition of Islamic law on large parts of the country.

Recently, youths attacked and killed 12 police officers. In response the President ordered the destruction of their home town, Odi, not far from the grim and steamy Port Harcourt.

Though the general situation has improved since General Sani Abacha - the military ruler who ordered Saro-Wiwa's execution - died of a sudden heart attack in 1998, many Nigerians still live in appalling poverty.

The benefits received by local people from the massive oil business are still minimal and no one doubts the ease with which the country - Africa's most populous state - could slip into chaos. The Niger delta is still racked with violence and sabotage and the kidnapping of oil company employees is common.

Though almost unanimously lauded in the West - at least posthumously - Saro-Wiwa has always been a controversial figure at home. Though few doubt that he was innocent of the charges for which he was executed - ordering the deaths of four pro-government chiefs - he has nevertheless been accused of creating a climate of violence that facilitated the murders.

A liberal man - and a talented satirist and playwright - Saro-Wiwa was also a ruthless and effective political player who knew how to work a crowd.

His campaign against the multinational oil companies who run massive operations in Nigeria and in the Ogoni heartlands was not universally admired. He undoubtedly had many enemies.

Last week his brother made a heartfelt appeal for those enemies to be reconciled. 'Ken was a man of peace and his burial should be peaceful. It should not be a cause for strife. The storm will pass and then we will all see a brighter future,' he said.

Though the general situation has improved since General Sani Abacha - the military ruler who ordered Saro-Wiwa's execution - died of a sudden heart attack in 1998, many Nigerians still live in appalling poverty. The benefits received by local people from the massive oil business are still minimal and no one doubts the ease with which the country - Africa's most populous state - could slip into chaos. The Niger delta is still racked with violence and sabotage and the kidnapping of oil company employees is common. Though almost unanimously lauded in the West - at least posthumously - Saro-Wiwa has always been a controversial figure at home. Though few doubt that he was innocent of the charges for which he was executed - ordering the deaths of four pro-government chiefs - he has nevertheless been accused of creating a climate of violence that facilitated the murders. A liberal man - and a talented satirist and playwright - Saro-Wiwa was also a ruthless and effective political player who knew how to work a crowd. His campaign against the multinational oil companies who run massive operations in Nigeria and in the Ogoni heartlands was not universally admired. He undoubtedly had many enemies. Last week his brother made a heartfelt appeal for those enemies to be reconciled. 'Ken was a man of peace and his burial should be peaceful. It should not be a cause for strife. The storm will pass and then we will all see a brighter future,' he said. jason.burke@observer.co.uk

webTitle: If this is art, then I'm an elephant

fields.headline: If this is art, then I'm an elephant
fields.standfirst: After losing their jobs as lowly loggers they were catapulted into a new life. Now as Abstract Expressionists, their paintings fetch thousands.  Ed Vulliamy reports from Manhattan on the school of Asian elephants
fields.trailText: The guests at the world's most respected auction house were enthralled. Over canapés and cocktails at Christie's in midtown Manhattan, they admired new works by Ganesh, Nom Chok and others.
fields.body:
The guests at the world's most respected auction house were enthralled. Over canapés and cocktails at Christie's in midtown Manhattan, they admired new works by Ganesh, Nom Chok and others.

One of the artists was described as a 'major force' because of his 'distinctive style', another as a 'savant' of the school. An expert likened one work to that of the 'Abstract Expressionists' who were 'always trying to discover the beasts within'.

But last week's show was different in one crucial respect: the paintings were by elephants. And when the sale started, bidding wars broke out: 50 paintings by seven Asian elephants raised more than $30,000 (£19,000).

A deep blue painting by 16-year-old Indian elephant Ganesh fetched the highest bid of $2,100. 'I love the colour selection. I love the lines. I just had to have it,' said John Tunney, an entrepreneur who also paid $900 for a painting by Lukkang, a 20-year-old elephant from Thailand.

Lynne Merrett of Connecticut thought the paintings 'so beautiful and innocent' and bid more than $1,200 for a work by Arum, whose style was compared by the organisers 'to that of Abstract Expressionism and Jackson Pollock'.

The latest fad to hit the art world is the brainchild of two emigré Russian artists renowned for their eccentricity - Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid. They were dissidents in the Soviet Union who first came to attention in the 1970s satirising 'official' Soviet art by getting dogs to paint. Since arriving in the US in 1976 they have continued to explore animal paintings as a means of questioning accepted values of art, beauty and financial worth.

But last week's auction was also intended to raise awareness and generate funds for Asian elephants, whose numbers have dwindled after a ban on the logging of teak left the animals and their life-long companions and trainers without a livelihood. The elephants had been used to haul logs.

The project began when Komar and Melamid found out that elephants in American zoos have been taught to paint for two decades. 'It clicked right away,' says Komar. 'Here were 3,000 elephants without a job. Our goal became to have thousands of elephants producing thousands of paintings.'

Five years ago they started working with an elephant named Renee at a zoo in Toledo, Ohio. Three years later they went to Thailand, where they have set up three elephant academies.

Painting, they said, came naturally to the elephants. 'For thousands of years, elephants have been making mysterious characters on the ground with stones or sticks. Elephant art is only new to people, but it's not new to the elephants,' said Komar, 56.

Mia Fineman, a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, wrote in the catalogue that there were 'three major regional styles' in Thai elephant art. One tended to be lyrical and expressive, another preferred darker, cool colours, while the third 'tend towards saturated, tertiary colours like mustard and plum'.

Researchers exploring the possibility of communicating with elephants in 1994 carried out a series of experiments in northern Thailand. The researchers drew pictures on paper; the elephants made images in trunk-tip moisture that were then dusted with paint powder to develop contrast.

The report concluded: 'We drew realistic images, surreal images or abstract designs. The elephants drew images that we understood as abstract. If they had realistic meaning to the elephants, we were unable to grasp it.'

Last week at Christie's, Andrew Ross, who teaches contemporary culture at New York University, said elephant art came from a school called senilism - 'as in senile,' he explained. 'It began at the Museum of Modern Art when people realised the abstract painter Willem De Kooning's paintings could have been done by any geriatric, so why not elephants?' His face broke into a knowing grin.

Komar, who compared the style of many of his elephants to that of De Kooning, dismissed criticism that some of the paintings looked like the work of small children. 'Everyone is an artist and can put paint to a canvas, but quality is a different thing. Some of the elephants are more talented than others.'

Are you laughing at us, Mr Komar ? 'It is not a joke,' he says adamantly. 'This is not a jest, it is a collaboration with the animal kingdom.'

Yet for all their protestations, Komar and Melamid's first intentions may have been satirical. But Komar insisted: 'What started as travesty has become treasure. We started in the Seventies with dog art, but later we changed our perspective. We fell in love with the elephants.'

The team has also exhibited photographs taken by a chimpanzee and aims to work with beavers using processed wooden boards on an architectural project.

While animal art is unusual for Christie's, the auction house said it wanted to support a worthy cause and offer a new perspective on modern art. 'Of course you think at first you may be criticised,' said Christie's chairman, Stephen Lash, 'but this is interesting stuff. Art has always been controversial.'

The support for elephant conservation drew bidders who remained sceptical about the paintings' merit. One, Catherine Stein, said: 'It's a way of contributing to the well-being of these animals, under threat from the ivory trade and other pressures.'

But she added: 'It just goes to show how easy it is to get Americans to part with their money.'

fields.headline: Cult that can't stop killing
fields.standfirst: As the Uganda mass suicide is relabelled murder, police are hunting surviving sect leaders.  Anna Borzello reports
fields.trailText: The death toll in the horrific relgious cult massacre in Uganda reached more than 480 last night after 153 bodies were uncovered in three mass graves. These finds intensified a police search for surviving members of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God who may know what happened.
fields.body:
The death toll in the horrific relgious cult massacre in Uganda reached more than 480 last night after 153 bodies were uncovered in three mass graves. These finds intensified a police search for surviving members of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God who may know what happened.

The graves containing the slashed and strangled bodies - including those of 59 children - were discovered in a building used as a transit camp by the group of former Roman Catholics in Rukingeri District, in the West of the country.

The fresh discoveries were made one week after at least 330 members of the cult burnt to death in a fire at their headquarters at Kanungu, 30 miles from the transit camp.

The sect members were initially thought to have entered the church on 17 March, doused themselves in petrol and set themselves alight. They were reported to have believed that the Virgin Mary was coming to take them to heaven. Police say they are now treating the deaths as murder and not mass suicide.

Shocked Ugandans are struggling to make sense of the killings, particularly as the sect was barely known before it so dramatically seized the headlines.

The cult was founded in the late Eighties by a former Roman Catholic teacher and opposition politician, Joseph Kibwetere. He claimed to have regular visions of Jesus and Mary. Kibwetere built a following and gained credibility when a learned Catholic churchman, Father Dominic Katarabaabo, joined.

In 1993, the group registered as an non-governmental organisation, a status given to charities, and set up a community near Kanungu on 10 acres of land donated by one of its principal 'prophets', Credonia Mwerinde.

By the late Nineties, the community was thriving, growing bananas, pineapples and sugar cane. Members lived in dormitores, ate together and sent their children to the sect's own school.

Converts were told to sell their property when they joined, and give the proceeds to the leaders. Once in the commune they lived in dormitories and were instructed not to have sex. They wore green and white robes, and were given cult identity cards.

They prayed and sang for hours, but had to communicate in sign language for the rest of the time for fear of breaking one of the the commandments by bearing false witness. They were discouraged from mixing with locals, who described the followers as polite and disciplined. By the time of the fire, the sect had about 4,000 members.

Jane Kyomakama, a roadside food seller, was approached by the cult last year, and agreed to attend a course in the capital, Kampala. 'Credonia Mwerinda told us the world was coming to end. She said if we joined we would not die in a fire,' Kyomakama said.

Credonia asked her to donate about £130 - a huge sum in Uganda. Kyomakama decided something was amiss, and left.

The sect had believed the world would end at the beginning of this year. When this proved false, some members are reported to have doubted their leaders - who promptly rescheduled it for 16 March.

At the beginning of March, Credonia Mwerinda told Kyomakama that the Virgin Mary was coming to take the cult members to heaven.

Another sect leader, Father Dominic, also turned up in Kampala saying Mary was on her way. He paid off his debts, and bought two jerry cans of car battery acid - a substance found on some of the bodies.

Sect members from across Uganda also began to put their affairs in order. In the second week of March, neighbours of the sect's small Kampala branch were offered followers' personal property at giveaway prices.

'They sold off their chickens. They sold off sofas and sideboards,' said John Ntwatawa, who looked after the branch's house. 'They left it completely empty.'

What happened next is not clear. On 13 March followers from sect branches convered on Kanungu.

The following day, there were baptisms for all those who had not been through the ceremony before. As thousands of people gathered in the community church, their leaders allayed any suspicions of what was to happen by inviting the local authorities to a party to inaugurate the church on 18 March.

On 17 March cult members feasted before delivering the deeds of any property they owned to the police.

The following morning they gathered in the sect's old church - known as their 'ark' - to find the doors and windows boarded up. Their leaders apparently said this to keep out sinners who might storm the building.

A woman visiting her mother nearby saw the leaders usher children into the church amid singing inside. Then she heard an explosion, ran to the building to peer in, and saw people 'in agony'.

Police found bodies still smouldering two days after the fire. They were burnt, twisted and charred. Some were in attitudes of terror, heads thrown back and arms shielding their bodies from the flames. Around 330 bodies were counted, but police believe nearly 500 people died.

The initial suspicion of mass suicide altered when officers found six bodies, burnt with battery acid in a latrine inside a building used by the sect leaders.

The discovery of mass graves at the transit camp last Friday further reinforced the view that the members had been murdered, perhaps as part of a ritual or because of a dispute with their leaders.

In the week after the fire, police became increasingly convinced that the sect leaders could be alive, but Father Katarabaabo's charred body was found by the church entrance, his dog-collar seared into his flesh. Mwerinda and Kibwetere were seen leaving Kanungu on the day of the fire.

Ugandans are struggling to understand how the sect survived for so long without the the police shutting it. Two others were banned last year.

President Yoweri Museveni, who has ordered an inquiry into the killings, blames the country's poverty and rampant Aids epidemic.

'People start looking for answers in the realm of metaphysics because there is no answer in real life,' he said.

webTitle: Oscar's walk on the wild side

fields.headline: Oscar's walk on the wild side
fields.standfirst:
The tarnished awards

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The plot is a familiar one: the hero is the little guy. He's under attack from all sides. It looks like he's had it. But then, in the last reel, it all works out fine. Or does it?
fields.body:
The plot is a familiar one: the hero is the little guy. He's under attack from all sides. It looks like he's had it. But then, in the last reel, it all works out fine. Or does it?

The little guy in question this time is aged 72 and weighs just over 8lb - and he's under the cosh from all sides. Litigation, accusations of racism, exploitation, obscenity, cultural colonialism, deceit and mockery of the afflicted have all been placed at his gilded little feet over the past few days. Poor Oscar.

Any awards ceremony thri-ves on controversy and, over the years, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science has had its share: from George C. Scott's refusal to accept the award for his role in Patton in 1971, to the refusal by members of the audience to stand for the award to veteran director Elia Kazan at last year's ceremony because he had given evidence to the House Un-American Activities Committee about alleged Communists.

But the controversies this year seem almost to deserve their own list of nominations. Leading the attack has been the Wall Street Journal . On Friday, it published an 'exit poll' of academy members in a bid to pre-empt the ceremony and spoil the fun on awards night.

This upset the academy, but what will cut deeper were mocking accusations in the paper the previous day suggesting its claims for the cultural significance of the event were a patronising conceit. The academy voters, wrote Edward Jay Epstein, believe 'their choices will, like Archimedes's lever, somehow influence the universe of entertainment'.

Epstein quoted this year's co-producer of the show as saying 800 million people would be watching around the globe. But there were only 78 million people watching in the US last year which means that 'some 722 million foreigners, many without television sets, would have to stay up through the wee hours of the morning and the next working day to watch a show in a foreign language - an extraordinary conceit.'

This year three of the films with chances of winning Oscars are based on true stories. All three will arrive at the Shrine auditorium trailing writs or attacks on their credibility. The latest writ was issued last week by Lucretia Nimocks, the wife of Jeffrey Wigand, on whose true story as a tobacco industry whistleblower The Insider , nominated as best film, was based. Russell Crowe, who plays Wigand, is a nominee for best actor.

Nimocks claims she has been falsely portrayed as an unsupportive wife who quit when the going got tough.

Boys Don't Cry , whose star Hilary Swank is co-favourite with Annette Bening for the best actress award, was the subject of a similar writ which has been settled just before the ceremony. Lara Tisdel, played by Chloe Sevingy (nominated as best supporting actress), had sued the producers for what she claimed was a damaging portrayal of her as someone who had failed to prevent a murder. She has settled for an undislosed sum.

The Hurricane, based on the true story of boxer Rubin Carter, is the subject of angry websites and newspaper articles that accuse the filmmakers of distorting the facts.

The controversy that received most publicity was the theft of the 55 Oscar statuettes and their subsequent discovery in LA's Koreatown by salvage worker Willie Fulgear. He has since been given the $50,000 reward offered by the transport firm responsible for delivering them and has been invited to the ceremony. Fulgear is black, which prompted Karen Grigsby Bates in the Los Angeles Times to refer to a joke about his find: 'That's about the only way a brother's gonna get an Oscar in Hollywood.' In the Oscars' history there have been but five black winners, since Hattie McDaniel won a best supporting role as Scarlett O'Hara's slave in Gone With The Wind . Sidney Poitier won one in 1963 for best actor in Lilies of the Field ; Louis Gossett Jr won as best supporting actor in 1982 for An Officer and a Gentleman ; Denzel Washington was best supporting actor for Glory in 1989; Whoopi Goldberg best supporting actress for Ghost in 1990; and Cuba Gooding Jnr best supporting actor for Jerry Maguire in 1996.

By failing to invite Fulgear immediately, wrote Bates, the academy had failed to show class. 'Class, like Oscars for black actors, seems to be in short supply,' she said. Whether this influenced the academy voters in deciding whether Denzel Washington takes a best actor prize for The Hurricane or Michael Clarke Duncan wins supporting actor for The Green Mile , we shall know tonight.

The academy says it would have invited Fulgear right away but was asked to wait until the police had completed investigations: one of the transport firm's drivers has now been charged with grand theft.

The academy also faces a free speech dilemma. 'Blame Canada', a song from the cartoon South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut, is nominated in the best song category. This seems to be the first time that a song containing the words 'fuck,' 'fart' and 'bitch' has been nominated. Robin Williams has been asked to sing it in a medley of the nominated songs.

American Beauty, directed by British director Sam Mendes, is expected to carry off a bundle of awards.

So will the little guy survive? Consider two figures. In 1999, the show pulled in more than $40 million in broadcast rights and a similar figure is anticipated this year. And this year a 30-second commercial during the show costs $1.5m. So will he survive? You will, Oscar, you will.

Whether this influenced the academy voters in deciding whether Denzel Washington takes a best actor prize for The Hurricane or Michael Clarke Duncan wins supporting actor for The Green Mile , we shall know tonight. The academy says it would have invited Fulgear right away but was asked to wait until the police had completed investigations: one of the transport firm's drivers has now been charged with grand theft. The academy also faces a free speech dilemma. 'Blame Canada', a song from the cartoon South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut, is nominated in the best song category. This seems to be the first time that a song containing the words 'fuck,' 'fart' and 'bitch' has been nominated. Robin Williams has been asked to sing it in a medley of the nominated songs. American Beauty, directed by British director Sam Mendes, is expected to carry off a bundle of awards. So will the little guy survive? Consider two figures. In 1999, the show pulled in more than $40 million in broadcast rights and a similar figure is anticipated this year. And this year a 30-second commercial during the show costs $1.5m. So will he survive? You will, Oscar, you will.

webTitle: Bullet that tore a hole in America

fields.headline: Bullet that tore a hole in America
fields.standfirst:
The killing of another black man by the NYPD opens old wounds and inflames political war. Ed Vulliamy reports

US gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: The bullet that killed Patrick Dorismond in midtown Manhattan had big-time politics written all over it as soon as it left the barrel of Detective Tony Vasquez's gun. It was the loudest shot in America for a long time, and it will echo well beyond Dorismond's funeral mass, which took place yesterday.
fields.body:
The bullet that killed Patrick Dorismond in midtown Manhattan had big-time politics written all over it as soon as it left the barrel of Detective Tony Vasquez's gun. It was the loudest shot in America for a long time, and it will echo well beyond Dorismond's funeral mass, which took place yesterday.

The bullet shot another hole through the reputation of a New York Police Department that appears out of control; it was fired only days after the Bronx narrowly escaped full-scale rioting when four officers were acquitted of murdering West African street vendor Amadou Diallo.

That bullet also cut Dorismond's wounded Haitian community in New York, only just recovering from the string of trials that followed the torture and sodomy by broomstick of another of their own - Abner Louima.

That bullet then ripped into what is fast becoming the nastiest election campaign in living memory, between New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and First Lady Hillary Clinton. And finally, it ricocheted into the climax of an epic gun control saga, its volley heard across the nation.

Giuliani opted to inflame the already febrile resentment of New York's black community by smearing the character of the dead man and refusing to visit his bereaved family, lest such a call give the impression that the killing, which happened during an undercover drugs operation, was 'unjustified'.

The mayor instead authorised the release - now itself a matter of legal contention - of Dorismond's police record to reveal a background of trouble. He was, as Giuliani said, 'no altar boy'. But Giuliani exaggerated, claiming 'possession of a gun' and 'robbery' in Dorismond's past.

It was not a pretty story: a couple of disorderly conduct charges in 1993 and 1996 and a 'buy-and-bust' arrest for marijuana possession and more seriously, a complaint from his girlfriend filed last March, saying that Dorismond had beaten her while she held their one-year-old daughter.

But no guns or robbery. And there were skeletons in Detective Vasquez's closet. His wife too, had filed a complaint of domestic abuse, and there had been numerous incidents over the past four years when Vasquez pulled his gun for no reason. In 1997, he was arrested for quick-drawing his weapon to break up a fight in Philadelphia. The following year, he shot a neighbour's dog.

Accounts of Dorismond's background depict a street-wise, serious lad who lived hard and worked hard as a security officer to provide for his children - one called Infinity by ex-girlfriend Dwana Sobers and one-year-old Destiny by the woman he intended to marry, Karen Sturkey. The women insist that their lover 'didn't deserve to die'. One neighbour described him to The Observer as 'just a very quiet guy, a very nice man'.

Mayor Giuliani's brazen demonisation of the victim sharpened the already-jagged Senate election battle with Clinton.

For her, the shooting provided a welcome chance to take the offensive after the two candidates turned the St Patrick's Day parade into political theatre - Clinton coming off the worst, jeered by crowds as a 'Carpetbagger'. Now, she chose a raucous rally at Harlem town hall to accuse her opponent of 'writing off' a community, and of 'dividing the city'.

She was inevitably joined by the self-appointed leader of New York's black community, Al Sharpton, who now adds the killing to his collection of just causes and who has organised witnesses to the shooting to come forward and testify to Dorismond's innocence in the incident.

This Giuliani can take. But after the Dorismond killing, even some of the Mayor's own Republican team are baffled and dismayed by his reaction to the latest NYPD outrage. 'I don't think she can beat him,' said Giuliani's former aide and one-time chairman of the Republican National Committee, 'but he can beat himself.'

New York's Republican governor George Pataki has publicly said he is 'perplexed' by the mayor's attitude.

Behind the scenes at a fragmented City Hall - The Observer has learnt - the mayor has come under bitter attack from senior officials. Officials in his own Cabinet worry privately that Giuliani's response will 'finally rupture' - as one put it - a trust between City Hall and the black community only built by the fall in crime rates.

Giuliani's own City Comptroller Alan Hevesi said the mayor's actions were 'very wrong'. Hevesi himself made a swift visit of condolence to the dead man's mother, Marie Dorismond, by way of sharp contrast to his boss. The mayor is also under attack from so-called 'Giuliani Democrats' whose support he needs in the battle for the middle ground. But his aides insist 'there are still more votes to be won than lost in being tough on crime'.

The war of words and bullets raging in New York dove tails into a second gunfight this week: between arms manufacturers and the Clinton administration, and within the arms industry.

Glock, America's biggest domestic gunmaker and supplier of the guns fired by Vasquez, declared war by refusing to join British-owned Smith & Wesson in its historic treaty with the US government.

Faced with legal action by several states and cities, Smith & Wesson agreed to restrictions on sale and distribution, plus child-proof safety locks on handguns.

Glock, based in Georgia, rejected this, and the authority of the embryonic Oversight Commission, created to supervise such agreements. 'The commission is an absurd concept,' said Glock vice-president Paul Januzzo.

Such defiance, with the apparent blessing of the formidable National Rifle Association, sets the scene for a mighty conflict in the courts. It could also cause political fallout: gun control is of extreme concern to women voters, deemed capable of deciding the forthcoming presidential election. George Bush is committed to only limited gun reforms, unlike his opponent Al Gore, who seems determined to push the Clinton administration's Smith & Wesson breakthrough much further.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Strike over pay paralyses Spain's rail network
fields.body:
Strike over pay paralyses Spain's rail network

Commuter and long-distance train journeys were severely disrupted in Spain for a third consecutive day as drivers yesterday stayed off work in a pay dispute. Worst hit was Madrid where all commuter services were cancelled.

Iraq shoots down spy drone

Iraq has shot down a second pilotless Iranian reconnaissance plane, the second this month. Iraqi-Iranian relations, never healed since their 1980-88 war, have been particularly tense in recent weeks.

French Ministers face sack

French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said he would make changes to his beleaguered government team but did not say when a Cabinet shuffle might take place. Finance Minister Christian Sautter and Education Minister Claude Allegre are expected to lose their jobs after the failure of reforms.

China blocks Internet sales

In its latest effort to impose control over electronic commerce, China has announced rules banning online sales of imported music and videos and excluding foreign-invested Internet companies from selling audiovisual products.

Maids resent porn frenzy

A group of Swedish chambermaids is seeking protection from male hotel customers who become 'over-excited' after watching pornography on television.

The group, members of the Swedish Hotel Workers Federation, called for the maids to be given alarms to use in case of attack.

'Chambermaids are always having to come face to face with over-excited guests watching porn movies,' they said, demanding the maids be allowed to work in pairs.

They said that since porn was allowed in hotels, 'We have to dry off sticky television screens and clean stained sheets as well as picking up used tissues.'

fields.headline: Bonn 'faked' hijack to free killers
fields.trailText: Black September, the Palestinian terror group that killed 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics, was allowed by the German government to hijack a passenger jet two months later to provide a 'cover story' for the release of the three gunmen captured at the scene.
fields.body:
Black September, the Palestinian terror group that killed 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics, was allowed by the German government to hijack a passenger jet two months later to provide a 'cover story' for the release of the three gunmen captured at the scene.

According to One Day in September - an Oscar-nominated documentary which is to be released in Britain in May - Bonn indicated to the terrorist group that it would give in to their demands should a certain aircraft - carrying no women and children - be hijacked. The Germans were keen to release the three jailed terrorists to avoid Black September fulfilling threats to carry out a series of bombings and hijackings.

On 29 October, 1972 - not even eight weeks after the Munich attack - a Lufthansa Boeing 727 on its way from Damascus, Syria, to Frankfurt was hijacked by two terrorists as it left Beirut airport. There were only 11 passengers on board, all male. The pilot was told to fly to Munich and the terrorists' demands were relayed to Bonn. Within hours the German Chancellor, Willy Brandt, gave in and the three men were handed over. The Israelis were not consulted.

All three Black September men had been arrested during a botched attempt by German authorities to rescue the Israeli athletes taken hostage in the Olympic Village. Nine hostages and five terrorists died in the shoot-out. Two of the surviving terrorists were later killed by Mossad - the Israeli secret service - but Jamal Al-Gashey, the third, has survived in hiding. He gave his first, and only, interview to the One Day in September team. 'An agreement had been made with the German government for our release after the hijacking of a Lufthansa plane,' Al-Gashey told researchers. 'I found out later.'

Though Brandt himself denied any deal, Al-Gashey's allegations are supported by a range of senior German, Palestinian and Israeli intelligence and political sources. Ulrich Wegener, then a key aide of the Interior Minister and the founder of GSG-9, the Germans' crack counter-terrorist unit, said Bonn did not want to risk confronting the Palestinians after the attack on the Olympics.

Earlier in the year Lufthansa had allegedly paid a ransom of $5million (£3.2m) after the hijack of a jet flying to Yemen. 'At this time the German government thought they could negotiate with terrorists, and [that] they could give them money [or] something else to get rid of them,' Wegener said.

The return of the hostages was celebrated in the Middle East. But the Israelis were stunned. Golda Meir, the Prime Minister, decided that their release - and the conciliatory attitude of Bonn - had to be answered. Within hours of hearing the news that Al-Gashey and his comrades were free, she authorised Mossad to launch 'Operation Wrath of God'. For the next 20 years, Israeli agents tracked down those connected with the Munich attack and killed them.

Many relatives are bitter about Bonn's acts. 'Of course I blame the terrorists,' Ankie Spitzer, widow of the Israeli fencing coach who died, said. 'But most of all I blame the German authorities.'
