fields.headline: Pester power
fields.standfirst: Pokemon, junior Gucci ... is there no end to the growth in the pre-teen market, asks  Andrew Smith
fields.trailText: The global launch next month of a new monster-like character for the Japanese Pokemon computer game will be one of the most hyped events of this new century. And, perhaps more significantly (or worryingly - for parents at least), it will offer another opportunity to witness a growing phenomenon: pester power.
fields.body:
The global launch next month of a new monster-like character for the Japanese Pokemon computer game will be one of the most hyped events of this new century. And, perhaps more significantly (or worryingly - for parents at least), it will offer another opportunity to witness a growing phenomenon: pester power.

Ever since the Spice Girls shot to fame in the mid-Nineties pester power has been on the marketing agenda - but that, it seems, was an accident. 'We were expecting them to appeal to a teen audience,' says Robert Sandall of Virgin Records, who fought a fierce battle to sign the quintet in 1995. 'I'm not aware that anyone here was intending or expecting them to catch on with pre-teens. Once that started, we suddenly found ourselves in uncharted waters.'

The public debate over child marketing began at that point. The standard liberal line was that the young girls who bought, or persuaded their parents to buy, records like 'Wannabe' were empowered by exposure to strong role models. Discomfort at the sound of five-year-olds singing lines like 'If you wanna be my lover' could be dismissed in the knowledge that they didn't understand what they were saying. Anxiety over the sight of six-year-olds stalking playgrounds in hot pants and halter tops could be assuaged by pointing out that little girls have always liked dressing up.

Now every record company has an expanding roster of acts aimed at this newly discovered pre-teen market, with names like Aqua (makers of the infamous 'Barbie Girl') and Cartoons. Taken on their own, they are harmless and part of a forgotten line reaching back to the Monkees and Banana Splits. But as so often in this country, the Spice Girls unwittingly reflected changes that were far wider reaching. The under-10s, and increasingly the under-fives, have been thrust, blinking, into the economic limelight.

They are significant players in the economy. Fashion houses, including Paul Smith, Armani, Calvin Klein and even Gucci have introduced lines designed for pre-teens, and next month's Pokemon launch will be one of the most hyped events of the new century. Already the associated playing cards have been banned from infants schools across Britain.

Advertising and marketing of products ranging from food to holidays and cars is being aimed directly at pre-teens. Initially, all this looks to be linked to economic and demographic shifts. The baby boom generations of the Fifties and Sixties have been having children, and there are more of them. They are also having children later in life, and these older parents have more money to spend on their children.

According to Wall's Monitor, which specialises in research into the five to 16 age group, there was a 38 per cent rise in pocket money between 1993 and 1998 - with 28 per cent of that rise from 1997 to 1998.In describing the ramifications of this increased affluence, Mark Ritson of the London Business School draws a distinction between customers and consumers. He uses the example of dog food to illustrate what he means. Dogs eat the food, but the marketing pitch is aimed at their owners.

'The real key, the holy grail, is getting kids to pester parents to buy something for the whole family, like a holiday or car. In this sense, they can be a very powerful marketing tool and the trick is to split a message in two, with one part for adults and another for children,' he says.

'The difficulty with small children is that their fashion cycle is even shorter than it has become for grown-ups, and thus much more difficult to follow and predict. The other thing is that the children's market is the most socially orientated of all, being almost entirely based on social networks.

'Like flu, fashion spreads more quickly in schools. It can be hard to tap into, but when you do, the rewards are very great.'

This explains why there are appalling shortages of one particular toy every Christmas (past examples are Buzz Lightyear dolls, Cabbage Patch dolls and beany babies), while other likely contenders gather dust on the shelves.

According to Dr Alexandra Lamont of the Psychology Department at Leicester University small children can be sophisticated consumers of advertising, being able to understand 'complex ideas like false belief, and complex forms of pretence'. They are, in other words, easily instilled with an innate feel for advertising.

All of which seemed perfectly innocent until, a few weeks ago, the august Journal of the American Medical Association produced a report which described a threefold rise in prescriptions of medical drugs for children under five, with toddlers being fed stimulants, anti-depressants and other substances in sharply increased number for perceived psychiatric problems.

Included in the findings was the contention that between 1991 and 1995 doctors' prescriptions of stimulants (mainly Ritalin, for supposed Attention Deficit Disorder, previously known as hyperactivity) shot up from 4.1 per 1,000 pre-school children, to 12.3. The researchers expected the trend to have continued between 1995 and the present.

Steven Hyman, director of the US National Institute for Mental Health, told the New York Times that he was 'more than shocked' by the findings. More disturbingly for us, five years ago there were only 2,000 prescriptions written for Ritalin in the UK. By 1997 doctors were writing 92,000 prescriptions.

What has this got to do with Gucci bags for kids? In the music industry, pester pop, like boy bands and girl groups, is a response to a profound financial crisis. The acts who provide it are cheap to develop and run, and easy to replace once they've had a few hits.

The same is true outside music. The one feature of our economy which Karl Marx and Gordon Brown agree on is that it needs to keep expanding and finding new markets in order to avoid stagnation and recession. Traditionally, new markets have been out there somewhere but now they're running out. So we've looked inward and found an untapped and constantly renewable supply of... kids.

At a glance, all the attention we and the marketeers are paying them looks like respect, as though our children are finally being given their place at the consumer table. What we're actually doing is controlling them more rigorously than we have for three generations, turning them into little versions of ourselves.

We give them Paul Smith jeans so they'll look l!ike us, Ritalin or Prozac when they don't behave like us. We load them up with homework so they'll feel like us.

Pester power is not what it seems. Kids should be kids. It's what they do best.

'At 10 I don't need a mobile, says Dad'

Martin O'Dea, eight, from Holland Park, London

For Christmas we got a digital TV so I can watch programmes on Cartoon Network and Sky One. My favourite is Pokémon. I would like Windows 2000 because it's the latest system and MagicArtist which I hope to get in America. I prefer to play with games on consoles rather than on a computer because they are easier to control.

I have Sega Megadrive, Sega Master Drive and Super Nintendo and lots of games for them. They all came from car boot sales because children sell their old stuff that they don't want any more.

I have 173 Pokémon cards but a lot of them are doubles. I would like a Sega Dreamcast but my parents say it's too expensive.

I am going to Florida next month with my family. I think I will be able to buy some of the things I want in America.

Maija Marsh, 10, from Finsbury Park, London

Everyone used to want yo-yos and Tamagotchis. Now it's Pokémon cards and Gameboy colours.

The things I pester my parents for are: a new bike, books, chocolate, smoked salmon, clothes and a mobile phone.

I think asking for most of these things is reasonable but asking for some, like more books when my shelf is about to crack through the middle, is a bit silly.

Dad says I'll get the bike when I leave primary school, there's no need for a mobile phone, new books are always arriving in the house, modelling clay will be bought when I have caught up on my writing and painting and we'll get more chocolate tonight when we do the shopping!

This research was produced by 'Children's Express', which lets young people report for themselves.

He uses the example of dog food to illustrate what he means. Dogs eat the food, but the marketing pitch is aimed at their owners. In this sense, they can be a very powerful marketing tool and the trick is to split a message in two, with one part for adults and another for children,' he says. 'The difficulty with small children is that their fashion cycle is even shorter than it has become for grown-ups, and thus much more difficult to follow and predict. The other thing is that the children's market is the most socially orientated of all, being almost entirely based on social networks. 'Like flu, fashion spreads more quickly in schools. It can be hard to tap into, but when you do, the rewards are very great.' This explains why there are appalling shortages of one particular toy every Christmas (past examples are Buzz Lightyear dolls, Cabbage Patch dolls and beany babies), while other likely contenders gather dust on the shelves. According to Dr Alexandra Lamont of the Psychology Department at Leicester University small children can be sophisticated consumers of advertising, being able to understand 'complex ideas like false belief, and complex forms of pretence'. They are, in other words, easily instilled with an innate feel for advertising. All of which seemed perfectly innocent until, a few weeks ago, the august Journal of the American Medical Association produced a report which described a threefold rise in prescriptions of medical drugs for children under five, with toddlers being fed stimulants, anti-depressants and other substances in sharply increased number for perceived psychiatric problems. Included in the findings was the contention that between 1991 and 1995 doctors' prescriptions of stimulants (mainly Ritalin, for supposed Attention Deficit Disorder, previously known as hyperactivity) shot up from 4.1 per 1,000 pre-school children, to 12.3. The researchers expected the trend to have continued between 1995 and the present. The acts who provide it are cheap to develop and run, and easy to replace once they've had a few hits. The same is true outside music. Traditionally, new markets have been out there somewhere but now they're running out. So we've looked inward and found an untapped and constantly renewable supply of... kids. At a glance, all the attention we and the marketeers are paying them looks like respect, as though our children are finally being given their place at the consumer table. What we're actually doing is controlling them more rigorously than we have for three generations, turning them into little versions of ourselves. We give them Paul Smith jeans so they'll look l!ike us, Ritalin or Prozac when they don't behave like us. We load them up with homework so they'll feel like us. Pester power is not what it seems. Kids should be kids. It's what they do best. 'At 10 I don't need a mobile, says Dad' Martin O'Dea, eight, from Holland Park, London For Christmas we got a digital TV so I can watch programmes on Cartoon Network and Sky One. My favourite is Pokémon. I would like Windows 2000 because it's the latest system and MagicArtist which I hope to get in America. I prefer to play with games on consoles rather than on a computer because they are easier to control. I have Sega Megadrive, Sega Master Drive and Super Nintendo and lots of games for them. They all came from car boot sales because children sell their old stuff that they don't want any more. I have 173 Pokémon cards but a lot of them are doubles. I would like a Sega Dreamcast but my parents say it's too expensive. I am going to Florida next month with my family. I think I will be able to buy some of the things I want in America. I think asking for most of these things is reasonable but asking for some, like more books when my shelf is about to crack through the middle, is a bit silly. Dad says I'll get the bike when I leave primary school, there's no need for a mobile phone, new books are always arriving in the house, modelling clay will be bought when I have caught up on my writing and painting and we'll get more chocolate tonight when we do the shopping! This research was produced by 'Children's Express', which lets young people report for themselves.

fields.headline: Yours, mine - and ours
fields.standfirst: New partner, new home, new life... Choosing to have a second family can mean a rewarding second chance at parenthood - but it can also mean a bigger drain on your finances than you've ever faced.  Alexander Garrett  reports
fields.trailText: Society in San Francisco was aghast to discover last year that one of its leading lights, Gordon Getty, son of the oil magnate J Paul Getty, had been secretly keeping a second family for many years.
fields.body:
Society in San Francisco was aghast to discover last year that one of its leading lights, Gordon Getty, son of the oil magnate J Paul Getty, had been secretly keeping a second family for many years.

The younger Getty had three daughters by his mistress, Cynthia Beck, who took him to court to change their name to his, and claim a share of the family fortune.

As one of the richest men in the world Gordon Getty was able to view this with a degree of equanimity. For most people , having a second family can be laden with financial implications that will radically affect their lifestyles for years to come.

More than 50 per cent of parents who become divorced or separated find a new partner within five years, in many cases marrying for a second time. As a result, thousands of second families are created each year, as mothers and fathers with one set of financial dependents add another set to their responsibilities, either by starting a new family or by becoming a step-parent.

The permutations are endless: fathers supporting their natural children who don't live with them, and their step-children who do, for example, or fathers supporting their own children from a second relationship, and those from a first who don't. And, of course, there are mothers in all of these situations - they may be far less common, but there are 50,000 women who have been assessed by the Child Support Agency over maintenance for their children.

Whatever the precise scenario, the decision to embark on a second family involves a huge financial commitment, even if it is one that is not always consciously acknowledged.

The implications are not just whether you have enough to take on a second family, in terms of the income you will need to earn and the amount you will have left to spend. For the nature of broken relationships creates a potential minefield in which the division of resources between two - or even three - families can be extremely complicated to work out, and can lead to tensions between all the parties involved that may even put second marriages and relationships at risk.

Cheryl Walters, head of policy and research at Parentline Plus, an organisation which incorporates the National Association of Stepfamilies, believes that many parents do not even consider the financial implications before starting a second family. 'There are people who just meet someone, feel absolutely right and decide to go for it,' she says. 'Others consider the pros and cons more seriously. What is clear is that those who do consider all the angles have a better outcome in the long-term.'

For any putative second-family parent, affordability is clearly a key issue, if not the only one. According to Loughborough University's Centre for Research in Social Policy, the average child costs £54,000 at today's prices to raise to the age of 17 - or £3,200 each year. If you already had three children by your ex-partner, and you took on responsibility for a couple more, that would leave you with a dent of £16,000 in your net income, an amount that somebody on an average income would find impossible to support.

This assumes, of course, that the parent in question is supporting the children in their first family. In reality, of course, most don't. Liz Sewell, chief executive of the lone parent families' organisation Gingerbread, says: 'The single most important statistic is that only a third of lone-parent families receive any maintenance from the father. If you become a lone parent, your income will almost certainly fall, but if you become an absent parent, your income is quite likely to rise.'

Up until now, many parents who don't have custody of their children - which usually means fathers - have been able to start a second family fairly confident that they can avoid supporting their first one. That may be about to change, with a new Child Support Act that promises much tougher sanctions to make parents pay. The amount they have to pay is clearly much more simply defined in the planned reform of the Child Support Agency.

But statutory child maintenance is only one part of the financial liability you have to consider when you start a second family. For a start, if you have been married, you may have to pay spousal maintenance to your ex-wife (or, less commonly, your husband). As far as your children are concerned, you will inevitably be asked to stump up for extras, whether it is a pair of trainers, piano lessons or a school exchange trip. And you may find yourself having to contribute to two mortgages, two life insurance policies and even two pensions, either as part of a divorce settlement or to provide the security that you want for your children. Inevitably, in some cases, that means deciding not to have any more children, or limiting the size of a second family.

Ian MacKay, a spokesman for Families Need Fathers, says: 'It is certainly true that absent fathers who keep in touch with their first family end up worse off than those who have less contact. A father who walks away and merely meets his CSA liability spares himself the cost of looking after his children when he has access, and also the cost of travel. For example, one chap I've been helping is in the RAF. His ex-wife is in Scotland, but he's been posted to Wiltshire, and it's obviously expensive for him to go and see his children there. But the judge has told him that the important thing is for him to maintain his children, not for him to see them.'

Absent parents who try to keep up the best relationship with their 'first family' children, in addition to supporting them, must certainly be prepared for the fact that it will cost them. In cases where one parent has custody, and the other only has contact, if the 'absent' parent looks after the children for less than 104 nights a year - equivalent to two nights every week - there is no reduction in the maintenance that many are liable to pay.

Equally, if they look after the children full-time for any period, say half the summer holidays, they are unlikely to receive any of the Child Benefit that is paid to the parent with custody. And the one tax concession towards supporting a second family - income tax relief on maintenance payments worth around £4 a week for standard rate taxpayers - is being abolished from April.

Resolving financial issues with your ex-partner is going to be stressful in many cases, especially if the parting was somewhat acrimonious.

Sewell says: 'Money becomes used as a bargaining tool.' In spite of her earnest wish that parents should not use funding for children to push other issues, Sewell acknowledges that maintenance is frequently used as a lever for the absent parent to obtain access.

But financial issues can also take a toll on the second family. It may be resentment at maintenance payments made to the first family, or something as simple as a father buying more expensive presents for his first set of children when they come to stay. If both partners in the second family have children of their own, the tensions and resentments can become even more inflamed.

Parentline Plus' Walters says: 'If things don't get talked about, you can end up with each parent fighting for their own. But although these issues are messy, if you can bear to tackle them at the outset, then it doesn't have to become a war. With the new couple it's absolutely vital to face up to these issues.'

Too often, Walters says, money becomes the repository for many of the disputes that surface around a second family. Anyone embarking on such a course must be prepared to separate the financial matters from the underlying issues, and to discuss both in an adult fashion.

Sorting out the finances to everyone's satisfaction may not assuage all the feelings of hurt and resentment that accompany divorce and separation, but it can provide the basis for a more civilised relationship between all the parties involved.

Supporting roles: The issues

1. Child maintenance

Can you afford to support your existing children? Under the new CSA rules, which should come into force within the next two years, you will be expected to pay 15 per cent of your net income for one child, 20 per cent for two, and 25 per cent for three. It is possible to come to an agreement independent of the CSA in court.

2. Spousal maintenance

If you weren't married to your ex-, you don't have to worry about this. Maintenance usually forms part of a divorce settlement, principally in cases where one partner has little or no earnings of their own, and has been dependent upon the other for a considerable period. But if the supported partner remarries or co-habits, the maintenance stops for good.

3. Access

Unless joint custody is granted, you must depend on access to see your children. If they spend more than 104 nights a year under your roof, you may be entitled to a reduction in maintenance. Parents with custody therefore have a vested interest in keeping access to less than two nights a week.

4. Stepchildren

Who is going to support your stepchildren? Under the law, their natural parents are jointly responsible for their upkeep, which means that won't earn you any reduction in the amount of maintenance you pay for your own children. However, if their other parent has left the country, or simply refuses to pay, it may be down to you and your new partner.

5. Mortgage

Usually in the case of divorce, the house is sold and the proceeds shared, taking account of the division of other assets. In a minority of cases, though, a parent may find that their name remains on the mortgage, and they could find they have difficulty in obtaining a new mortgage.

6. Benefits

Child-related benefits are all paid to the parent who has custody. So if you are the 'absent' parent, you're entitled to nothing, even if you frequently look after your children during access visits.

7. School/university fees

A court can order you to pay school fees for the children from your first family, particularly if they had already started in private school when your relationship ended, or if it had been your agreed intention for them to have private schooling. Your liability may not end at 18 - your offspring could get a court order to make you contribute towards their upkeep at university.

8. Life insurance

If you die, would all of your children be provided for? You may want to take out a life insurance policy for each set of children.

9. Pension

Unless it is offset against other assets at the time of a divorce settlement, part of your pension may be earmarked for your former spouse, or it may be split so he or she receives part of the fund in their own right.

10. Inheritance

If you have a second family, it is important to make a will so that your intentions are absolutely clear. Your step-children have no claim on your estate if you die intestate, unless they can prove they were dependent on you.

webTitle: Tightening the trap for runaway fathers

fields.headline: Tightening the trap for runaway fathers
fields.trailText: The reform of the Child Support Agency, outlined in a White Paper late last year, is designed to simplify the rules for calculating maintenance and increase compliance by getting a higher proportion of non-resident parents to support their offspring. The Bill will shortly receive its second reading and should become law by April 2002.
fields.body:
The reform of the Child Support Agency, outlined in a White Paper late last year, is designed to simplify the rules for calculating maintenance and increase compliance by getting a higher proportion of non-resident parents to support their offspring. The Bill will shortly receive its second reading and should become law by April 2002.

Arguably the most important change is the replacement of the hideously complicated formula for calculating maintenance. Currently, the parent's 'assessable' income is calculated after 'exempt' income, such as housing costs for their second family, has been deducted, along with tax, National Insurance and pension contributions. The income of their former partner is taken into account, as well as the income of their new partner if they have a child together.

Under the proposed system, neither the incomes of the former or new partner are involved. Nor is there any exemption for housing, travel or other costs. Instead, as the absent parent, you pay 15 per cent of your net income for one child; 20 per cent for two children; and 25 per cent for three children. If you have other dependent children in your second family, this can earn you a modest reduction.

So will second families, and parents with second families, be better or worse off under the new arrangements? Karen Randall, of Families Need Fathers, says: 'It's a step forward in that stepchildren and those born to the second family will be recognised. But they won't be treated equally: for example, if there is one child in the first family and one in the second family, you would expect that 20 per cent of the parent's income would be divided between them, in other words 10 per cent each. In practice, the child in the first family will get 12.5 per cent, because the Government has admitted that it is protecting the first family first.'

Second families with high housing costs will also be worse off, she says, because those housing costs are no longer taken into account when calculating 'assessable income'. And FNF also believes it is unfair that the income of the ex-partner who now has custody of children in the first family will no longer be taken into account at all. 'If you take Tony and Cherie Blair; if they split up tomorrow, because they have three children he'd have to pay 25 per cent of his net income to her, irrespective of the fact that she earns twice as much as him,' points out Randall.

According to Liz Sewell of Gingerbread, the fact that the calculation of maintenance will be so much more straightforward, together with the harsher measures proposed for the CSA to impose maintenance payments, should make it harder for absent parents to evade paying for their children from their first family.

But a less positive view comes from the Family Policy Studies Centre research organisation, which believes that the new legislation will still favour second families in favour of first families.

For any parent considering a second family, one thing is for sure: whether they are better or worse off it should be much easier, in theory, to work out how much it is likely to cost.

fields.headline: The mortgage dilemma
fields.standfirst: Should Phil and Jane pay off a chunk of their home loan? Helen Pridham  asks around
fields.trailText: Phil and Jane are facing an all too familiar conundrum. Should they use their savings to pay off part of their mortgage or not? With low inflation and tax relief on mortgage interest payments about to disappear having a mortgage no longer holds much attraction.
fields.body:
Phil and Jane are facing an all too familiar conundrum. Should they use their savings to pay off part of their mortgage or not? With low inflation and tax relief on mortgage interest payments about to disappear having a mortgage no longer holds much attraction.

The couple bought their current home with a £31,000 endowment mortgage in 1989. Rather than move again they increased their mortgage with the Halifax by £12,000 to pay for a loft extension.

They also switched their mortgage on to a two-year fixed rate which has just ended. When they took out the loan they were careful to ensure there was no extended lock-in after the end of the fixed-rate period so their options are now open again.

Phil and Jane have Tessas of approximately £14,000. They are strongly considering whether to use this money together with other savings to pay off £15,000 of their mortgage and also whether to move their remaining loan from the Halifax to Egg to get a better mortgage rate.

Phil still hankers after a larger property more like the one in Essex in which he grew up. However, Phil acknowledges that his parents were able to trade up because of inflation and rapidly rising house prices in the 1960s and Seventies.

Nowadays that is not happening in the area where Phil and Jane lives. Their house, bought in the Eighties boom, is barely worth more than they paid for it and moving to a larger property would mean even higher outgoings.

Phil's other area of concern is his Halifax and Norwich Union shares, worth around £8,000, held in self-select Peps. Jane has been saving £50 a month in a Fidelity Moneybuilder Pep/Isa and this is now worth around £4,000.

On the pensions front, Jane has been a member of the Local Government Pension Scheme throughout her working life. Phil has been a member of the teacher's scheme for the past 15 years. Twelve years ago he also started paying FSAVCs to Colonial Mutual but when he later considered increasing them and found out how expensive they were he decided to leave his savings at £30 a month.

Vital statistics: PHIL AND JANE HARKER

Age: 39 and 41

Live in: Preston

Occupation: Lecturer and probation officer

Earn: £24,000 and £23,000

Mortgage: £43,000

Debts: None

Investments: £6,500 in bank account; £14,000 in Tessas, £8,000 in self select Pep; £4,000 in unit trust Pep/ISA

Pension: Members of occupational schemes

Aims: To find out whether it is a good idea to pay off part of their mortgage, remortgage and sell Halifax shares

Adviser 1: Martin Jones

It can make sense to use investments to repay debt where the return on the investments after tax is less than the cost of the interest on the debt. However, Phil and Jane may prefer the flexibility of having money to hand. Also, as Tessas, Peps and Isas are not taxable, it probably makes sense to invest in these first before considering mortgage repayment.

Phil and Jane are currently paying a variable mortgage rate to the Halifax, which is 1 per cent more than Egg. This costs £430 a year, so it may make sense to consider switching, although they should bear in mind the costs of doing so.

Incidentally, if Phil is keen to 'trade up', it should not be difficult to find a lender willing to advance 2.5 times their joint income, or £117,500.

Phil could consider selling his Halifax shares. If they are in a general Pep, the proceeds could be transferred to a unit trust Pep. If they are in a single company Pep (SCP) he will need either to sell or transfer to another single share SCP. Generally, it is advisable to keep Peps. However, as basic-rate taxpayers do not normally use up their annual exemptions from capital gains tax, it may make sense to consider a sale.

Phil may have been misadvised to start his FSAVCs, and I suggest he take this up with Colonial and/or the Financial Services Authority. The teachers' pension scheme offers 'added years' as an alternative to AVCs and in any event has in-house AVCs, which are usually cheaper than FSAVCs.

 Martin Jones works for chartered accountants Blick Rothenberg

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

With a joint income of around £47,000 per annum, Phil and Jane have a mortgage well within their means and there is a good level of equity in their property. If the priority was to own a larger property then the mortgage could be increased substantially. This loan combined with the liquid funds available could secure a much larger home. I would not dissuade them though from reducing their mortgage debt. I would first use the £6,500 currently invested with the Halifax, as this is likely to be attracting only a modest rate of interest which is taxable. I would then use the interest from the Tessas and roll over the capital into a Tessa-only ISA. This would still leave Phil and Jane with safe tax-free funds available instantly.

I would endorse remortgaging. However, there are more competitive rates than those offered by Egg so it could pay to shop around. Alternatively Phil and Jane could consult a mortgage broker.

Self-select Peps are the higher-risk option and to hold two shares within them is higher risk still. We would advocate selling the Norwich Union and Halifax shares at current levels. The Fidelity Money Builder fund held by Jane has outperformed Phil's self-select option by around 22 per cent in the last year. At a time of radical change with key growth in the value of technology companies, diversification is a must. Unit trusts are one vehicle that can provide the required spread of risk.

 Gordon Wilson works for financial advisers Aitchison & Colegrave

fields.headline: A tale of two families
fields.trailText: Carolyn Walker and her husband Guy have both been married before. Carolyn's son, Harry, lives with them most of the time, and Guy pays maintenance to support his daughter, Judy, who lives with her mother and stepfather. There is a marked contrast between the arrangements for the two children. Harry spends school holidays with his father in Italy, and Carolyn does not press him to pay maintenance. Guy has a less amicable relationship with Judy's mother. He paid for Judy's school fees, clothes and other expenses until his ex-wife insisted on a CSA assessment that resulted in him paying less.
fields.body:
Carolyn Walker and her husband Guy have both been married before. Carolyn's son, Harry, lives with them most of the time, and Guy pays maintenance to support his daughter, Judy, who lives with her mother and stepfather. There is a marked contrast between the arrangements for the two children. Harry spends school holidays with his father in Italy, and Carolyn does not press him to pay maintenance. Guy has a less amicable relationship with Judy's mother. He paid for Judy's school fees, clothes and other expenses until his ex-wife insisted on a CSA assessment that resulted in him paying less.

Carolyn says: "Although we are supposed to have Judy half the time, my husband still has to pay for her - even though her mother earns almost as much as he does. And even when Judy's not here, her bedroom is still there. She has a complete wardrobe here, her bicycle and toys. So you still have many of the expenses."

Guy pays £27 a week in maintenance, which includes a reduction for the nights Judy spends at his home. But under the new CSA regime, he expects to pay £65 a week - a figure that takes no account of the Walkers' high mortgage. "That will seriously jeopardise our situation, especially as we would like to have another baby, which would involve me giving up work for a time," says Carolyn. Nevertheless, she has few regrets. "Perhaps I'm lucky to have the luxury of looking at it this way, but I regard supporting my son as a privilege, and not something I expect to be paid for."

Names have been changed

fields.headline: When the car is indispensable
fields.trailText: Peter westrip, 63, and his wife Jean, 60, are retired but Peter still works two days a week arranging finance for people who want to buy pubs. He is self-employed and uses his own car to visit clients: 'At the moment I drive a 2.3 Scorpio but we are thinking we might have to change to a smaller car. My wife has a Nissan Micra and we might have to consider just having one.'
fields.body:
Peter westrip, 63, and his wife Jean, 60, are retired but Peter still works two days a week arranging finance for people who want to buy pubs. He is self-employed and uses his own car to visit clients: 'At the moment I drive a 2.3 Scorpio but we are thinking we might have to change to a smaller car. My wife has a Nissan Micra and we might have to consider just having one.'

They live in a rural area, in West Sussex, and will always depend on a car: 'Although I can walk to the village, we have to use the car for major shopping. Public transport is not very good and you can't lug bags of shopping on buses.'

He is in favour of encouraging people to drive cars with lower CO2 emissions.

Their house cost just below the £250,000 threshold for higher stamp duty when they bought it but stamp duty would be a big item if they moved again: 'The way property prices are going, we would be in a new bracket.'

They have no intention of moving, though, and have committed themselves to improving their house with an unexpected boost from the Budget.

'We are having new central heating put in in June. It is very good news to hear that the VAT on central heating controls is coming down to 5 per cent. Every little helps.'

He will put the maximum into Isas again next year.

webTitle: That second car will have to go

fields.headline: That second car will have to go
fields.trailText: Tim Griffin and his wife, Nichola, have one daughter, Emily, and a baby due in July. Tim welcomed the Budget help for families, although this was only for low-paid and lone parents with an indication that radical changes to maternity pay might happen in future.
fields.body:
Tim Griffin and his wife, Nichola, have one daughter, Emily, and a baby due in July. Tim welcomed the Budget help for families, although this was only for low-paid and lone parents with an indication that radical changes to maternity pay might happen in future.

Nichola works part time but has no employer-funded child care and both of them rely on cars. Tim sells electronic connectors and has a company car - 'a gas-guzzler'. The company pays for his private fuel as well. He is pleased that the Chancellor is removing the discount for high mileage: 'I do 30,000 miles a year anyway, but some of my colleagues do only 12,000 in truth but make sure they get to 18,000 to save tax - and that is the opposite of what Mr Brown is trying to achieve.' He leaves his employer to work out the tax changes that affect him but is seriously considering switching to a cheaper car: 'The Ford Galaxy costs a lot to run but with the increases, I am without doubt having to consider switching to a smaller car.'

Their private car is a 1102 cc car which will fall within the lower vehicle excise duty band from next March. But, even with this saving, they are wondering whether to sell the car altogether. They live on the outskirts of Hinckley in Leicestershire and Nichola needs transport to take Emily around: 'We are thinking of selling our private car and trying to arrange a yearly rate with a local taxi firm. We do so few miles but the price of petrol is incredible. Tim knows that this won't achieve what the government wants, for people to use public transport, but for them there's no alternative.'

webTitle: Minimising the risk of holding shares direct

fields.headline: Minimising the risk of holding shares direct
fields.standfirst: Rachel Fixsen meets a retired lecturer moving into investment funds
fields.trailText: Unless you have a really large portfolio, holding shares directly can be risky. All it takes is for one of your companies to report a fall in profits, and you can wave goodbye to a large chunk of your invested assets.
fields.body:
Unless you have a really large portfolio, holding shares directly can be risky. All it takes is for one of your companies to report a fall in profits, and you can wave goodbye to a large chunk of your invested assets.

This is why 54-year-old Richard White, a retired lecturer from Nottingham, has decided gradually to shift his direct shareholdings into investment funds.

Apart from shares, he already holds a number of personal equity plans. In September he put £3,000 into an individual savings account run by asset manager Gartmore.

'I have got some individual shares, but I'm looking to move my investments into different areas,' he says. His Isa with Gartmore is split between two of its unit trusts, with £1,500 in Gartmore's European Selected Opportunities fund and the rest in the Gartmore UK Smaller Companies unit trust.

Both funds have performed very well since White bought them. In the last three months alone, an investment in the European trust has grown by 32 per cent, while units in the smaller companies trust have risen by 37 per cent, according to financial data provider Moneyfacts.

The next ISA he takes out would probably be in a different sector to increase the diversification in his portfolio. 'I was looking at the area of technology, although I have some doubts about it,' he says. He shares the fears of many market strategists that the whole sector has become overheated in the wake of recent frenzied buying.

Holding individual shares can be a bit of a lottery, White says. A big advantage of putting your money into a fund within an ISA is having a professional manage the investments. 'They've got people who have information, who can get the rumours and know exactly what is going on,' he says. A newspaper article had prompted Mr White to choose the two Gartmore funds. He had been about to buy a Fidelity fund, but the article highlighted current performance of various funds, rather than using the more traditional yardsticks of two-year and five-year performance. The smaller companies fund in particular was shown to have performed well in the past few months.

His ISA may have performed well since he bought it, but Mr White regards his existing ISA and future plans as long term investments that will help top up his pension.

webTitle: Old economy in the new paradigm

fields.headline: Old economy in the new paradigm
fields.trailText: You could call it the curse of the FTSE 100. No sooner has a company been promoted to its hallowed ranks than its shares start to slide. Tony Jackson, equity strategist with Charterhouse Securities, calculates that three-quarters of new members over the past 18 months have done just that - and by an average of 17 per cent.
fields.body:
You could call it the curse of the FTSE 100. No sooner has a company been promoted to its hallowed ranks than its shares start to slide. Tony Jackson, equity strategist with Charterhouse Securities, calculates that three-quarters of new members over the past 18 months have done just that - and by an average of 17 per cent.

The recent promotions were no exception. New economy stars such as Freeserve, Baltimore Technologies and Psion have plunged since their promotions - by as much as 50 per cent in Freeserve's case. Previously, the fallers have quickly bounced back. This time round, however, there is a feeling that the declines could represent a more permanent reassessment of the proper value of the new economy and, more importantly, of the worth of the old.

The fallout in technology shares has been accompanied by a re-rating of old-fashioned businesses such as brewers and food manufacturers - not before time.

Some sectors are undoubtedly suffering. Banks, even without a critical report accusing them of making excessive profits, are dogged by overcapacity and are extremely vulnerable to online competition.

In retailing, there are too many shops selling things most of us no longer want to buy. Indeed, many of our engineering companies are being squeezed by their customers who, in turn, are being forced by their own customers to cut prices.

Other sectors will be less affected. We will never be able to buy a beer or a restaurant meal over the Internet; many of us will prefer to see the whites of a pension adviser's eyes; and can you imagine water and electricity being delivered over the web?

The recent sell-off of old-economy stocks has been indiscriminate - and many have been unfairly lumped with the losers.

Virtually every retailer has been dumped, yet there are some that stand out as having decent prospects. Next has been winning disaffected M&S shoppers,and missing out on the high street malaise; Boots has no competitors with its range and value offering; Great Universal Stores looks ridiculously cheap yet finally shows sign of using its enviable database and distribution systems to prosper from e-commerce.

Food manufacturers such as Associated British Foods - one of those ejected from the FTSE 100 - and Northern Foods simply look too cheap, never mind the maturity of their market. Similarly some of the utilities - Scottish & Southern Energy and Thames Water spring to mind. Whitbread and Bass, long-time favourites of this column, still look good.

Housebuilders and materials suppliers - Hanson, Wilson Connelly, CRH - also look cheap, but have been for so long that many question whether they will ever recover, along with engineers such as GKN and BAe. Even in banking there are signs that the sell-off has been overdone. Egg is doing well, but so are many high street banks, and with their existing customer bases, they stand a good chance of overtaking the newcomers. Look for low-cost players which are not saddled with many costly branches: Northern Rock, say, or Bank of Scotland.

webTitle: Mother takes a flutter on shares and boosts the family fortunes

fields.headline: Mother takes a flutter on shares and boosts the family fortunes
fields.standfirst: Sanchia uses City knowledge to take risks that pay, she tells David Hunt
fields.trailText: Sanchia Treacher has decided that she likes a bit of a flutter. A 34-year-old Essex housewife and mother of two, Sanchia has only recently started dabbling in equities, but definitely enjoys taking a bit of a risk.
fields.body:
Sanchia Treacher has decided that she likes a bit of a flutter. A 34-year-old Essex housewife and mother of two, Sanchia has only recently started dabbling in equities, but definitely enjoys taking a bit of a risk.

At the beginning of last year, she invested £1,000 in the Manek Growth unit trust, which has since doubled, and in October she invested £1,500 into the Fidelity Technology fund and opened a regular £50 per month savings scheme into the same group's Telecoms fund. The regular savings scheme is ear marked for the kids and she uses part of her child benefit allowance to pay for it. 'I felt I should do something positive with it, rather than it just disappearing into the building society,' she says.

Her Isa investment is also pitched at the upper end of the risk spectrum - £1,500 into a maxi Isa invested in Fidelity's Japan Special Situations fund.

Sanchia used to work for a major bank in the City, but never really got involved with equities, and although her husband is employed as a fund manager, he works with hedge funds so hasn't any tips, or advice, to offer her. 'Anyway, I'm fiercely independent so I'm more than happy to do my own thing,' she says.

'I am really enjoying it. I've started following what's going on in the markets generally and read the FT to keep in touch. They are riskier investments but if I lose the money it's not a complete disaster.'

Sanchia aims to use up the rest of her Isa allowance before the end of the tax year but not necessarily by investing in the same fund. 'I might put something into America,' she says. 'I didn't take out any Peps but I will certainly be doing Isas on a regular basis. It's silly really not to take advantage. I am not saving for a specific purpose; I just wanted to get rather more than I was earning on the money while it was just sitting in a building society account.'

Sanchia spoke to The Observer just before heading off to the Cheltenham, but laughed off any suggestion that she was an inveterate gambler. However, she did confess that she went into the bank the other day with a copy of the FT under one arm and the Racing Post under the other. 'Lord knows what they thought!'

Her Isa investment is also pitched at the upper end of the risk spectrum - £1,500 into a maxi Isa invested in Fidelity's Japan Special Situations fund. Sanchia used to work for a major bank in the City, but never really got involved with equities, and although her husband is employed as a fund manager, he works with hedge funds so hasn't any tips, or advice, to offer her. 'Anyway, I'm fiercely independent so I'm more than happy to do my own thing,' she says. 'I am really enjoying it. I've started following what's going on in the markets generally and read the FT to keep in touch. They are riskier investments but if I lose the money it's not a complete disaster.' Sanchia aims to use up the rest of her Isa allowance before the end of the tax year but not necessarily by investing in the same fund. 'I might put something into America,' she says. 'I didn't take out any Peps but I will certainly be doing Isas on a regular basis. It's silly really not to take advantage. I am not saving for a specific purpose; I just wanted to get rather more than I was earning on the money while it was just sitting in a building society account.' Sanchia spoke to The Observer just before heading off to the Cheltenham, but laughed off any suggestion that she was an inveterate gambler. However, she did confess that she went into the bank the other day with a copy of the FT under one arm and the Racing Post under the other. 'Lord knows what they thought!'

webTitle: A new house - and a hoard of treasure

fields.headline: A new house - and a hoard of treasure
fields.standfirst: Brownfield sites can yield rich secrets, reports  Christine Webb
fields.trailText: Should you hope to snap up one of the 2 million brand new homes due to be built on brownfield sites in the next 20 years, a slice of the ancient past could come as an unexpected extra.
fields.body:
Should you hope to snap up one of the 2 million brand new homes due to be built on brownfield sites in the next 20 years, a slice of the ancient past could come as an unexpected extra.

Most brown sites are in the centre of old towns and cities, and are more likely than greenfield plots to yield treasures. Brooches, Roman coins, and even a set of Georgian false teeth have been uncovered.

Environment Minister John Prescott this week announced that more than 800,000 new homes would be built in the South East in the next five years. Recycled land will be used for at least 60 per cent of all new homes.

Before housebuilders start digging out foundations on these old sites, archaeologists are brought in to check for historic remains. If they find signs of important settlements, major excavations will begin. Finds are being meticulously recorded on building sites all over the country. For example, mediaeval bottles, musket balls, and a thirteenth-century iron arrowhead have been found on the site of a development being built by Countryside Residential at Llangattock, near Crickhowell. Archaeologists think fairs and markets were held around the enclosed church.

Channel 4's Time Team has prompted greater interest in archaeology, thanks partly to the programme's affable Phil Harding. He has just finished an exciting excavation of an important Saxon settlement at Bicester, near Oxford. This has uncovered eight Saxon buildings - and re-written local history.

The site, soon to disappear under a modern retirement development, is in a former frontier zone between the kingdoms of Wessex and Mercia. The dig exposed buildings and shards of pottery. Local guidebooks suggest Bicester was found by St Birinus in the eighth century, but the dig reveals it was founded around 410.

"This is a damned good site: it's textbook stuff," said Harding. "St Birinus is said to have converted many to Christianity and may have visited the area. The royal families of Mercia and Wessex wanted their children to marry to create an alliance, but the Christians refused to unite with pagans. So the pagans converted in a mass baptism in the Thames."

Building has just started on the land, which will become a retirement development.

Turning up signs of ancient life unexpectedly when a site is cleared is dreaded by many builders, as it can cause expensive delays. For example, plans by Alfred McAlpine Homes to build 47 new homes at The Paddocks in Thursby, Cumbria, were held up for about four weeks after the discovery of mediaeval pottery.

Usually, unexpected delays are avoided because planning applications for new homes are monitored by county archaeologists, and a site likely to hold historic secrets can be investigated to establish whether a full-scale excavation is needed. If so, it can start long before building work gets under way, and be budgeted into a scheme.

For example, a limestone ridge running between Oxford and Swindon is littered with ancient burial grounds, prompting a trench evaluation of Bryant Homes' forthcoming development in Faringdon, Oxford. Here, a host of interesting artefacts were unearthed, and a full-scale dig took place between July and October last year. Brooches and clothes pins were found, plus the circular drainage ditches of a substantial early Iron Age settlement dating from around 800BC. There was also evidence of Roman activity from the second century AD.

Bob Williams, assistant director of Oxford Archaeological Unit, which carried out the work, said a striking aspect of the site was the thousands of grain storage pits that were found. "These were below-ground silos up to two metres deep into which harvested grain was poured, before the pit was sealed with clay and dung, providing an airtight storage area until the next harvest."

After a circular Roman building believed to have been a religious shrine was found, Bryant homes agreed to adapt the layout of the development.

Archaeologists also got an early look at Charter Quay in Kingston upon Thames, a St George development of 219 apartments that have sold ahead of schedule. This extensive site revealed that Kingston was a planned mediaeval market town laid out around 1170, which was probably tacked on to an Anglo-Saxon settlement to the north.

Duncan Hawkins, who oversaw the excavations, said: "In the twelfth century, the Thames was much wider than it is now, and ran within 50 metred of merchants' houses, shops and craft stalls. Several alleys connected the river with the market place, which allowed goods to be brought to Kingston by river on small, flat-bottomed barges, and unloaded directly."

Finds included a cache of leather shoes from a mediaeval shoe shop, a seventeenth-century glass brandy bottle, and a set of early nineteenth-century false teeth, made from gold and porcelain.

If you find a historic fragment in your back garden, or on land you own, it's a case of finders keepers. Developers usually donate finds, and the archive of written records, to local museums.

The exception is articles containing gold or silver, or coins more than 300 years old, which are deemed treasure trove and must be reported to the coroner within 14 days.

webTitle: Check out your freebie car insurance

fields.headline: Check out your freebie car insurance
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I recently bought a new car and received 12 months' free comprehensive insurance from Privilege Insurance. Having previously built up many years' no-claims discount, I contacted Privilege requesting to pay a supplement to protect my no-claims bonus in case I had an accident. To my astonishment, I was told that I could not do so. In future, this could result in me having to pay hundreds of pounds extra in premiums.

I was told not to worry because my normal insurer would discount this free year's insurance when I resumed with it and I need not inform it of any accident in this free 12 months. My previous insurer was amazed at this.
DT, Runcorn

It is outrageous to suggest you can keep quiet about an accident. Privilege admits that it misinformed you and has e-mailed its operators to ensure no one makes this mistake again because, of course, all accidents must be declared.

Free car insurance certainly complicates things, though. They are bulk policies agreed with car manufacturers to insure new owners at a set price, regardless of individual experiences. You cannot pay extra to protect your no claims discount, although Privilege reckons your previous insurer should ringfence the free year so any accident does not affect your discount. The company compares it to owning two cars with two different motor policies: an accident in one would not affect the no-claims discount on the other. However, you cannot assume that your insurer will take this approach.

Subscription: No stopping it

I tried to stop my subscription to First Prize magazine but it says my standing order payment went through before it received my letter to cancel. I paid £16.20 for the first year's subscription in November 1998 and did not realise that I had signed a standing order. Usually I send a cheque for any first payment to see if it is to my liking. First Prize is not the sort of publication I was seeking and I did not wish to renew the subscription but last November I discovered that the magazine had taken £49 from my HSBC bank account.
BD-P, Seaton

HSBC has uncovered two forms from Chartsearch, which publishes First Prize. One is the chitty you signed and the other is the standing order instruction to the bank. The difference between the two is stark.

The printing on the bank's instruction is in large print, the words 'standing order' are 6mm high, and '£49' is repeated. If the bank staff were short-sighted idiots, they could not make a mistake. By contrast, you signed a form entirely in small print which nowhere said it was a standing order mandate although, separately from the £16.20 first year's payment, it does say that £49 is to be paid on the anniversary and thereafter until you cancel. Chartsearch says its forms have been cleared by the Advertising Standards Authority and legal experts and it has never been asked to make amendments.

But Chartsearch also agrees that there has been a mix-up here and that you have been badly treated. Normally, it says, customers who cancel are automatically sent a refund. A cheque for £49 is on its way to you.

House deeds: All fired up

When I bought my house in 1978, I obtained copies of my deeds because the history of the house is important to me. The deeds included impressive crests and seals. It had been an estate property of the local lord's until 1928 and I am in effect only the third owner.

In 1993, I paid off my mortgage with Bradford & Bingley but left the original deeds with them. These were lost in the fire that destroyed many Bradford & Bingley's borrowers' deeds. As these were so important to me, can I claim compensation?
ND, Northwich

Your rights to the property are not in doubt so it is difficult to judge what compensation would be appropriate. Instead, Bradford & Bingley has offered to get your deeds reconstituted on parchment paper, from the photocopies you hold, followed as closely as possible.

Credit Cards: Fraudulent use

Last December, we saw two unrecognised transactions for £947 and £264 on our Capital One credit card statement which took us over our credit limit.

We reported this but heard nothing more for a month, rang again and tried to call the fraud number but no one replied. We both work for the Inland Revenue and it is important that our financial affairs are run correctly.
SS, Nottingham

By 7 January, Capital One knew that these transactions were fraudulent but the details were not removed from your account until 6 March. The company admits that this was an undue delay and that it should have kept you informed. It is crediting your account with £35; £15 of this is a refund of the overlimit fee you were charged in December and £20 is a goodwill gesture.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Gambler who bets on helping addicts

fields.headline: Gambler who bets on helping addicts
fields.standfirst: GP Robert Lefever lost alomost everything. He tells Neasa MacErlean how he rebuilt his life
fields.trailText: Just over 20 years ago, GP Robert Lefever lost his home and everything else he possessed as a result of his gambling. Now he has made a business out of his own diagnosis, helping addicts contain the life-threatening elements of their addictions.
fields.body:
Just over 20 years ago, GP Robert Lefever lost his home and everything else he possessed as a result of his gambling. Now he has made a business out of his own diagnosis, helping addicts contain the life-threatening elements of their addictions.

As well as running his general practice, he has established the Promis - Problem Oriented Medical Information System - treatment centre in Kent.

'I am a compulsive risk-taker and gambler,' says the 'eternally young' Lefever. ('What is on my birth certificate suggests that I am about 62, but I see that as fiction').

'Once I start taking risks I can't stop. I gambled on property, thinking that I was looking after the future of my children. But gamblers lose. And the end result was that, far from protecting my children, we lost the lot, and they had to leave their schools.

'It was very stressful, but it was also necessary for me to come to terms with my addiction.'

He is proud that he did not go bankrupt, and that no one else had to pick up his bills. But the experience made him realise that his compulsive property speculation was a form of gambling.

He rebuilt his life using the 12-step formula he outlines in a new book, Kick the Habit. He learnt to become less egotistical, and to make his wife's happiness his priority.

More than 2,000 sexaholics, druggies, binge eaters, smokers, compulsive helpers and other addicts have passed through his clinic as in-patients since it opened in 1985.

One of them is Clarissa Dickson Wright, the remaining television Fat Lady, who praises his methods in the foreword to the book: 'I owe to Promis my life, but to Robert the fact that I enjoy it.'

When Lefever changed his behaviour, he had to put new safeguards in place, just as other recovering addicts do. He is no longer a signatory to his own bank account. He can spend money but is allowed to have it only with the agreement of his wife and son.

He also continues to attend Addictions Anonymous, in the way that alcoholics continue at Alcoholics Anonymous years after they have given up the bottle.

He estimates that 10 per cent of the population have addiction problems, largely due to their genes. Unless they can grasp the issues, the results can be disastrous. About 40 per cent of the people who commit suicide are alcoholics, he says.

He prescribes a tough love treatment to concerned family members and friends. 'If you have someone who is causing you problems, don't bail them out.

'When I paid off my son's debts, I perpetrated his drug addiction. I would have been better off letting him continue taking cocaine.'

This is the same son who, also recovered from his addiction, now also works for Promis at Nonington.

 'Kick the Habit' is published by Carlton at £7.99. The Promis centre is on 01304 841700.

Next week: prospective Olympic rower Fred Scarlett

fields.headline: Goodyear unions fear 2,500 job cuts
fields.trailText: Unions fear that Goodyear's Wolverhampton tyre plant will close, killing 2,500 jobs and intensifying the Midlands manufacturing crisis.
fields.body:
Unions fear that Goodyear's Wolverhampton tyre plant will close, killing 2,500 jobs and intensifying the Midlands manufacturing crisis.

Staff at the plant, the town's largest employer, were put on short-time working last week. Goodyear blamed the strong pound and industry overcapacity, but refused to give trade unions any assurance of the factory's future.

'We're hitting a blank wall in terms of information,' said Jim Hunt, regional secretary of the Transport & General Workers Union. 'There's a genuine fear of closure. To Wolverhampton, it's like closing Longbridge.'

A shutdown would be another huge blow for the area's tyre industry. In January Sumitomo, the Japanese tyremaker now owned by Goodyear, cut 650 of the 1,700 jobs at its Dunlop factory in Birmingham. At the start of the year, Michelin announced 473 redundancies at its huge plant in Stoke-on-Trent, cutting the workforce to 2,300.

Goodyear declined to comment this weekend.

fields.headline: How Scots invaded France
fields.standfirst: As most British brewers quit the beer business, one is emerging as a European leader, reports  Ben Laurance
fields.trailText: As most British brewers quit the beer business, one is emerging as a European leader, reports Ben Laurance
fields.body:
Little more than a decade ago, Scottish & Newcastle was one of British brewing's also-rans. The company was virtually at the bottom of the league table of Britain's 'big six' beer producers. The company was saved from having to fend off a hostile takeover bid only by the intervention of the Monopolies Commission. In an industry dominated by big bruisers, it was seen as the weakling in the (Scottish) corner.

Look at S&N now. It is by far the biggest brewer in the UK. Of the six companies which dominated the industry at the end of the Eighties, it is the only group to have both remained in brewing and committed itself to doing so in the future. And S&N's planned £1.7 billion takeover of Kronenbourg of France, announced last week, will propel the Edinburgh-based company into the superleague of European brewing - putting it second only to the mighty Heineken of the Netherlands.

The scale of change that has taken place in the British brewing industry over the past decade is breathtaking. Consider the upheavals that brewing has undergone:

 Grand Metropolitan - now part of Diageo - handed its breweries over to Courage;

 Allied Lyons, as it then was, pooled its breweries with those of Carlsberg and later pulled out of brewing altogether;

 Scottish & Newcastle - which in 1988 had been on the receiving end of a bid from Elders of Australia, owner of Courage - extracted the sweetest revenge in 1995 when it bought Courage from a then enfeebled Elders;

 Whitbread admitted last year that brewing, the business on which the empire had been built for centuries, was no longer seen as a core part of the operation;

 Bass, which was overtaken as the largest brewer in Britain only when Scottish bought Courage, said that it, too, was putting its beer business up for sale.

The outcome of the auction of the Bass breweries could be complete within weeks. The City's favourite frontrunners are South African Breweries (SAB) and Heineken. (Heineken executives were in London last week trying to convince investors of their case.) But there are other contenders. Carlsberg should not be written off.

Conventional wisdom has it that Carlsberg would find it hard to raise the £1.5bn-plus necessary to secure a deal because the group is controlled by a charitable trust; the company cannot issue new equity to pay for an acquisition because to do so would dilute the trust's holding. But it is thought that Carlsberg is testing the idea that the trust could give up control without sacrificing influence: that might make a bid possible. Belgium's Interbrew is also thought still to be in the running.

A further outsider is Kirin of Japan. Two years ago, the company employed advisers in London to look at the opportunities for investment in Europe.

The auction of Whitbread's breweries will not start in earnest until a Bass sale has been tied up. Only when it is clear who has secured Bass Breweries will the contenders for Whitbread's assets be clear.

Interbrew of Belgium will be interested in Whitbread's beer operation. Whitbread already produces Interbrew's Stella under licence in the UK. Whitbread's other big lager brand is Heineken. If Heineken fails to secure Bass, then the Dutch company may wish to take control of Whitbread. A further possibility is a buyout by management, led by Miles Templeman who runs the breweries. Whitbread's beer operation could fetch upwards of £300 million.

For Whitbread Plc the outcome of the Bass sale is clearly of huge importance. If SAB triumphs - and the company is desperate to increase its European presence and thus reduce its dependence on earnings within South Africa - the strategic implications for Heineken and Interbrew are profound.

Their brands clearly compete with one another. Whitbread, as brewer of both companies' products in Britain, has had to try to perform a delicate juggling act: to be promoting Heineken's products could be taken badly by Interbrew and vice versa.

If neither Heineken nor Interbrew secures Bass's breweries, each will fight hard to ensure that the Whitbread operation does not end up in the hands of its rival. If, on the other hand, Bass does go to either of the continental rivals the winner would seek to extricate itself from its licensing deal with Whitbread which would have an effect on the latter's valuation.

With both the Bass and Whitbread sales, there are complex problems to be addressed. The key issue is distribution. With the exception of Guinness, there is no substantial brewer in Britain that does not have a 'supply agreement' with a large pub operator - a long-term deal guaranteeing its ales and lagers a place on the bar. There is little point in buying a large beer producer if there are no pubs which are obliged to stock your products. Indeed, during the Nineties, the wholesale price of beer net of tax fell steadily as brewers competed ever more fiercely to persuade pub companies to sign supply deals.

This means that the publicly-stated price for any Whitbread or Bass brewing sale could be way adrift from the figures that have been suggested. Breweries which have supply agreements giving them a market for their products - agreements guaranteeing high prices and large volumes over a long period - will be worth a great deal. With little or no guarantee of distribution, the breweries will be worth far less. It is thought that Britain's competition authorities would be willing to accept a supply agreement which obliged pubs to sell a particular brewer's beers for up to three years.

Scottish & Newcastle is clearly not in the running for any of the British brewing assets now on offer. The company's share of the UK market is at least 26 per cent. On some measures, it is nudging dangerously close to the 30 per cent mark at which a range of European competition rules kick in to force a brewer to give up exclusive distribution deals.

The company can certainly expand further in the UK by buying more hotels, for example. But to become a larger player in brewing, it has been clear for some time that S&N's only avenue has been to look overseas - hence the Kronenbourg deal. The pressure on the company's finances is being eased by the structure of the agreement with Kronenbourg's current owner, Danone. S&N is paying 2.5 billion francs (about £230m) initially. Danone is also given warrants to buy 25 million S&N shares. At a later stage, Danone will be able to demand a further FFr13 billion (£1.2bn), giving S&N full control.

Also, S&N has the prospect of bolstering its balance sheet further when it sells its Center Parcs and Pontins holidays division for an expected £950m.

In any case, S&N has emerged as a force to be reckoned with. Alick Rankin, who as patrician head of S&N fought off Elders in 1988 and saw his company buy Courage in 1995, would have been proud. In the early Eighties, the company had just 7 per cent of the UK beer market. It will soon be the second largest brewer in Europe. webTitle: Kingfisher widens its net - and its Net credibility

fields.headline: Kingfisher widens its net - and its Net credibility
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
The City cannot make up its mind about Kingfisher. One minute it frets about margin pressure and worries that the group's Comet and B&Q chains will end up struggling under the same strictures as its depressed high street colleagues, the next it salivates over its international expansion and e-commerce potential.

Last week, chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy attempted to repair the damage caused by the mere mention of margin pressure in its Christmas trading statement with a detailed explanation of how Woolworths is dealing with the problem in electronic games and videos, while highlighting its ability to deal with margin pressure elsewhere.

Central to that is its move to what it describes as 'global sourcing', which effectively means buying the same things for Comet and for French electrical business Darty, for B&Q and for French chain Castorama. Savings in the DIY chains alone amounted to £15 million last year, and are expected to grow by a similar amount each year for at least the next three years.

It plans a number of portals, covering areas such as home, health and beauty, and DIY, and will also take stakes in promising e-ventures. One such is ThinkNatural.com, the health and beauty company in which it has just taken a minority stake.

Establishing a portal is easy enough; making it pay is rather harder: even Mulcahy does not expect many people to buy lipstick, tissues or screws over the web, and there is no guarantee that promoting these things on the web will actually drum up more business for its stores. As e-euphoria subsides, Mulcahy will be expected to justify its spending, £50m last year rising to £60m this. The £1 billion value of LibertySurf, the French ISP in which it has a stake, is a good buffer, but who would bet on it retaining that value indefinitely?

Elsewhere, Kingfisher's strengths and weaknesses are already familiar. It is by far the most advanced of any British retailer in developing an international brand. While it has a significant presence only in Britain, France and Germany, its developing markets, Poland and the Far East, for example, are growing fast and - if its interests in Italy are included - are actually turning in a profit.

It is the leading 'do-it-yourself' retailer by miles; its sales grew a fifth faster than the market; and it is adept at profitably expanding its electrical retailing business.

Woolworths and Superdrug continue to look lacklustre though. New formats such as Big W, a kind of Woolies superstore, and the new Woolworths General Store - which, despite the name, has more in common with Superdrug - may make them shine, but it will be years before we know. Weaknesses notwithstanding, Kingfisher is a shining success in a sector littered with dismal failures and deserves a higher premium still. Buy.

Land for grabs
Donald Gordon, the property brains behind Liberty International and Capital Shopping Centres, clearly thinks there is value in property shares: he has taken a 3 per cent stake in Land Securities, the establishment company, to prove it. So should other shareholders follow?

On the face of it, property shares are screamingly cheap. LandSecs price is 35 per cent below the value of its assets; other companies, such as British Land and Hammerson, trade at even higher discounts. If shareholders do not start buying them, surely predators will. Don't hold your breath.

Property shares have been trading at abnormally high discounts for months - indeed, in recent weeks, they have been narrowing. Yet neither investors nor predators have yet been tempted into the market.

The companies are now so desperate to kick-start their shares that some are even contemplating buy-backs: up to £1bn is proposed by Hammerson, Great Portland and LandSecs. If implemented, these buy-backs would have a big impact on the supply of property shares - LandSecs' capital, for example, would fall by 15 per cent.

Trouble is, it could also have a big effect on the supply of property. LandSecs and Great Portland Estates have said they will sell property to finance the buy-backs, Burford, Hammerson and MEPC could also be sellers.

In total, Merrill Lynch estimates that as much as £2bn of property could be on the market, a sharp reversal from the £1bn of purchases by property companies in the past six months. The broker estimates that much of this will be in retail - LandSecs, for example, wants to get rid of some secondary shopping centres. Direct investors, such as pension funds, have been keen on property, but their interest is mainly in retail and industrial. Will they be able, never mind willing, to absorb such a large slug of sales?

Nick Leslau, the entrepreneur behind Prestbury, is one of those who doubts it. And he points out that even those quoted companies who are not buying back shares will find little encouragement to buy properties when the wide discounts instantly undermine their value.

But what will be the catalyst to a change in the market? Leslau wants more disclosure by property com- panies, whose accounts are infamously opaque, to make it easier for bidders to see what they are getting. However, given that big boys such as LandSecs are as unloved as their smaller brethren, would mergers and takeovers make that much difference?

Property companies need to concentrate on giving investors what they cannot do themselves. That means specialising - like Slough Estates with its enviable industrial portfolio, or Freeport, with its retail outlet parks - or being entrepreneurial, like Prestbury.

Christmas turkey?
John Hancock, chief executive of MFI, dismisses the 3 per cent rise in sales for the 36 weeks to end December as irrelevant and points instead to the 23 per cent rise since Boxing Day. This has some justification: the post-Christmas sale is the group's most important trading period.

Unfortunately, MFI has to trade all year, not just for its six spectacular sales weeks. Before Hancock was parachuted in, sales had been falling consistently. He has strengthened its balance sheet with sales and leasebacks, and given it a coherent management structure. For that, he deserves credit - and has earned the doubling of its share price in the past six months. Further outperformance will depend on further results.
