fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Morgan's Mafia mayhem | Foxwatch
fields.body:
Morgan's Mafia mayhem
And so to the British Press Awards, a glittering night for journalists to pass a pleasant evening in self-congratulation and mutual bonhomie. Or not. Reinvigorated Mirror editor Piers 'Soprano' Morgan showed his Sicilian side in a series of encounters with the senior management from News International. Unimpressed with the Murdoch stable's coverage of the Mirror' s 'Slickergate' scandal, Mr Soprano refused an olive branch in the shape of a hand extended by NI chief executive Les Hinton, saying: 'You better finish me off, Hinton, or I'm coming after you. You, your family, EVERYONE.'

Not taking the hint, this was followed by a visit to Mr Soprano's table by Peter Stothard, editor of the Times, who made the small but obvious mistake of attempting to put his arm round Piers. 'I'm gonna whack you!' was the response - and he didn't mean a quick slap. This was followed by Simon 'Gotti' Kelner, editor of the Independent, threatening to have Kelvin MacKenzie 'rubbed out' by his driver for a series of unfortunate jokes about Indy on Sunday editor Janet Street-Porter.

Amazing, given the circumstances, that no contract was taken out on the presenter of the prizes, John Humphrys, who extended his carping about the media beyond his current employer, the BBC, to give his own heavy-handed 'awards' to newspapers, including one to the Express, 'sponsored by the Titanic'. Perhaps 'Rizla Rosie' Boycott is already calling her relatives in southern Italy to sort him out - strictly in the spirit of the event, of course.

Poll's hand in Glover absence
For those wondering why Stephen Glover, the acclaimed press commentator, was not at the awards, there is a simple explanation.

Regular readers of Media Diary will know that Glover is standing for the mayoralty of the tiny Scottish island of Talentfree. Last Tuesday a public engagement prevented him making it back to the awards. He was opening an exclusive new sanitorium on the island. 'The Liary' offers a rest cure for the terminally confused, who are unable to tell the difference between fact and fantasy. Its first block booking is a party of executives from BMW anxious to try the cure.

Fox's record brushes
The Martha Lane Fox count of media mentions was at an all-time high last week, despite the shares in lastminute.com hitting an all-time low. You had to wait until page 2 of the Times' T2 section before spotting a picture of Lane Fox on Friday. The Telegraph was more thoughtful, putting her on the masthead, and Trinny and Suzanna were promising a Lane Fox makeover. Unofficial count: 435.

webTitle: Racing's big 12 stack odds in TV chase

fields.headline: Racing's big 12 stack odds in TV chase
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward  on how a bitter battle over bringing bookies into the living room is splitting Britain's courses
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward on how a bitter battle over bringing bookies into the living room is splitting Britain's courses
fields.body:
British horse racing is in a state of civil war which is threatening to tear the industry apart. At the heart of the conflict is a battle over media rights and an ambitious plan to bring bookmaking into Britain's front rooms. The behind the scenes machinations involving the courses and the broadcasters make the skulduggery of a Dick Francis novel look decidely tame.

The 12 biggest racecourses are currently in an exclusive period of negotiation with a media consortium spearheaded by Channel 4 and which also includes the BBC and cable operator NTL. The 47 other racecourses are terrified of the implications and fear that the gap between them and the so called Super 12 tracks is about to be blown wide open.

'The smaller tracks are very worried that the big boys are going to do their own thing. It's the same as Premier League Football, you've got 20 big clubs and then the rest,' said Chris Curran, chief executive of Towcester racecourse in Northamptonshire.

The media consortium has offered the 12 racecourses £200 million over a 10-year period in return for handing over worldwide television rights. The media partners will also spend £25m on promoting the new service which will see the creation of a new dedicated television channel allowing viewers to bet through their screens. An online Internet betting service will be offered in tandem with racing coverage from both the BBC and Channel 4.

There are suggestions in the industry that the deal may fall apart but Sky, which had been looking to break up the agreement, has walked away from the fight. 'We've got an agreement in principle. We're in church and we're walking down the aisle. The marriage isn't consummated yet but it is going to happen,' said Kim Deshayes, acting chief executive of the Super 12 racecourses.

Some sceptics have questioned whether a consortium which features both Channel 4 and the BBC can work. 'C4 are brokering the deal but you can't see the two of them working together,' one source said.

However, the consortium members stress they have already sorted out which races will be shown on which channel and have ruled out the possibility of big name events like the Grand National ending up on Channel 4 or vice versa.

The news that the three media partners and the Super 12 are in advanced talks has sent shockwaves through some of the smaller courses which have so far been excluded from discussions. 'There is concern because there's uncertainty,' said Malcolm Armstrong, finance director with the Racecourse Association.

Currently all 59 courses receive revenues from the Racing Channel, a dedicated television service owned and operated by Satellite Information Services, a consortium made up of Ladbrokes, William Hill, the Press Association, Racal and United News and Media.

The smaller courses fear their slice of the broadcasting cake is about to get smaller.

To compound the smaller courses' problems the Government has signalled that the the levy - the money which is handed back to the race tracks from off-course betting revenues (which total around £5 billion a year, and which makes the levy worth around £60m) - is to be abolished within the next four years.

'Removing the statutory levy mechanism which effectively subsidises the less viable tracks will mean a radical shake-up with several of the second-tier courses likely to go to the wall. Meanwhile, of course, the big name tracks with the most attractive betting races will prosper,' John O Reilly, managing director of the offshore betting firm Ladbrokes International.

'The days of subsidies are over. Those tracks that have volume will be OK. They've got the products people want to buy. But it doesn't bode so well for courses like Ludlow or Newton Abbot,' said another bookmaker.

But the smaller courses do still have one weapon in their armoury. The betting industry relies on the fact that there are race events every day of the year. Thus, argue the smaller courses, the Super 12 needs to cut a deal with them if racing is to have a strong future. The Super 12 does not have the resources to stage events every day, runs the argument. 'They haven't got a product without us,' Curran said.

Channel 4, the BBC and NTL know this, which is why this week the three media partners will attempt to woo the disgruntled 47 courses through a series of presentations. Much will be made of the share these courses will receive from interactive betting revenues, although the smaller courses remain extremely suspicious. 'We're being offered the crumbs from the rich man's table,' was the view of one racecourse executive.

Worryingly for the smaller tracks the betting revenues won't be pooled and distributed across all the courses. So the high-profile Super 12 courses stand to make much more money from the new betting services than their smaller counterparts.

But the three media partners believe they can offer a knock-out package to the remaining 47 courses. 'There are very strong reasons for the smaller courses to join up. We're opening up new revenue streams through interactive services,' said David Brook, director of strategy at Channel 4.

'Between 90 and 95 per cent of people don't ever go into a betting shops. Imagine what can happen if you make the market simple and allow people to bet in their living rooms,' Deshayes said.

But the media consortium should not become too complacent. Sky may have walked away but another player is starting to emerge. TVG, a subsidiary of Television Guide, the big-selling US magazine backed by the likes of AT&T and News Corp, has started talks with the 47 courses outside the Super 12.

TVG already operates an interactive television betting service in the US and has global ambitions. Feedback from the courses suggests they like what they are hearing.

'This is an important market for TVG. We had hoped from the outset that we could be invited to work with the consortium but we've not had an invitation to do so.'

Amid all this uncertainty one thing seems assured: the gap between rich and poor courses looks set to grow, that much seems a safe bet.

It's the same as Premier League Football, you've got 20 big clubs and then the rest,' said Chris Curran, chief executive of Towcester racecourse in Northamptonshire. The media consortium has offered the 12 racecourses £200 million over a 10-year period in return for handing over worldwide television rights. The media partners will also spend £25m on promoting the new service which will see the creation of a new dedicated television channel allowing viewers to bet through their screens. An online Internet betting service will be offered in tandem with racing coverage from both the BBC and Channel 4. There are suggestions in the industry that the deal may fall apart but Sky, which had been looking to break up the agreement, has walked away from the fight. 'We've got an agreement in principle. We're in church and we're walking down the aisle. The marriage isn't consummated yet but it is going to happen,' said Kim Deshayes, acting chief executive of the Super 12 racecourses. Some sceptics have questioned whether a consortium which features both Channel 4 and the BBC can work. 'C4 are brokering the deal but you can't see the two of them working together,' one source said. However, the consortium members stress they have already sorted out which races will be shown on which channel and have ruled out the possibility of big name events like the Grand National ending up on Channel 4 or vice versa. The news that the three media partners and the Super 12 are in advanced talks has sent shockwaves through some of the smaller courses which have so far been excluded from discussions. 'There is concern because there's uncertainty,' said Malcolm Armstrong, finance director with the Racecourse Association. Currently all 59 courses receive revenues from the Racing Channel, a dedicated television service owned and operated by Satellite Information Services, a consortium made up of Ladbrokes, William Hill, the Press Association, Racal and United News and Media. The smaller courses fear their slice of the broadcasting cake is about to get smaller. To compound the smaller courses' problems the Government has signalled that the the levy - the money which is handed back to the race tracks from off-course betting revenues (which total around £5 billion a year, and which makes the levy worth around £60m) - is to be abolished within the next four years. 'Removing the statutory levy mechanism which effectively subsidises the less viable tracks will mean a radical shake-up with several of the second-tier courses likely to go to the wall. Meanwhile, of course, the big name tracks with the most attractive betting races will prosper,' John O Reilly, managing director of the offshore betting firm Ladbrokes International. 'The days of subsidies are over. Those tracks that have volume will be OK. They've got the products people want to buy. But it doesn't bode so well for courses like Ludlow or Newton Abbot,' said another bookmaker. But the smaller courses do still have one weapon in their armoury. The betting industry relies on the fact that there are race events every day of the year. Thus, argue the smaller courses, the Super 12 needs to cut a deal with them if racing is to have a strong future. The Super 12 does not have the resources to stage events every day, runs the argument. 'They haven't got a product without us,' Curran said. Channel 4, the BBC and NTL know this, which is why this week the three media partners will attempt to woo the disgruntled 47 courses through a series of presentations. Much will be made of the share these courses will receive from interactive betting revenues, although the smaller courses remain extremely suspicious. 'We're being offered the crumbs from the rich man's table,' was the view of one racecourse executive. Worryingly for the smaller tracks the betting revenues won't be pooled and distributed across all the courses. So the high-profile Super 12 courses stand to make much more money from the new betting services than their smaller counterparts. But the three media partners believe they can offer a knock-out package to the remaining 47 courses. 'There are very strong reasons for the smaller courses to join up. We're opening up new revenue streams through interactive services,' said David Brook, director of strategy at Channel 4. 'Between 90 and 95 per cent of people don't ever go into a betting shops. Imagine what can happen if you make the market simple and allow people to bet in their living rooms,' Deshayes said. But the media consortium should not become too complacent. Sky may have walked away but another player is starting to emerge. TVG, a subsidiary of Television Guide, the big-selling US magazine backed by the likes of AT&T and News Corp, has started talks with the 47 courses outside the Super 12. TVG already operates an interactive television betting service in the US and has global ambitions. Feedback from the courses suggests they like what they are hearing. 'This is an important market for TVG. We had hoped from the outset that we could be invited to work with the consortium but we've not had an invitation to do so.' Amid all this uncertainty one thing seems assured: the gap between rich and poor courses looks set to grow, that much seems a safe bet.

webTitle: Lastminute: the first flaw nerves prevail

fields.headline: Lastminute: the first flaw nerves prevail
fields.standfirst: Figures suggest the e-tailer has a very big mountain to climb, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Figures suggest the e-tailer has a very big mountain to climb, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Apparently, Martha Lane Fox, co-founder and chief operating officer of www.Lastminute.com, is prone to the occasional bout of verbal pyrotechnics when things go wrong. Events of last week must have tested her temper to the utmost. As she and co-founder Brent Hoberman spent much of their time looking at new premises to house more staff, Lastminute's share price - and with it their own personal £150 million fortune - was fast diminishing.

There must have been times when both wondered whether looking for more office space was really going to be necessary. The share price, which had risen to a first day high of 555p from an issue price of 380p, crashed down to the 270p mark. The drop created alarm among the 190,000 small investors who had managed to subscribe for shares in a placing that was 25 times oversubscribed at the retail level and considerably more at the institutional level.

At one stage the company, which had temporarily reached a value of nearly £850m on the day of its flotation, saw its worth sink below £400m.

Lane Fox, 27, and Hoberman, 31, were seen to be heading for very public ignominy. There was much talk of tulips and bubbles. Would the duo become icons of the Internet boom and bust theory? The fact that both came from wealthy backgrounds - Lane Fox is descended from the Marquess of Anglesey and Hoberman is an old Etonian - served only to heighten the pedestal from which they were falling.

Accusations that the company was a triumph of style over substance and that the float had been mishandled came throughout the week. 'Overpriced, oversold and over-optimistic,' said Simon Moores of the Research Group, a consultancy that advises firms on their Internet strategy. Some were more cutting. 'If Lastminute was run by a 51-year-old man with a toupee it wouldn't have been valued at £570m,' was the blithe assessment of one analyst.

The company's share price slumped to its nadir last Wednesday and subsequently started to head back up again, finishing the week at 332p, still some way below its issue price. However, it is clear investors continue to be nervous. Should they be?

Supporters of the company stress several things. First, they point out that in the past few days the Nasdaq and the FTSE's Techmark 100 index have dropped considerably, factors that have conspired to drag down Lastminute's share price.

Indeed Lycos Europe, floated in Frankfurt earlier last week, also saw its share price hammered. The company floated at 24 euros per share on Tuesday but fell to 22.8 euros the next day.

Second, they say volumes - the quantity of Lastminute's shares being sold - are very low. They argue that of the 190,000 small investors only 15,000 were selling last week and that several institutions are now buying back in.

Third, the share price of many technology companies - Colt, Freeserve and Orange - slumped after flotation only to bring very large smiles to investors' faces in subsequent months.

But sceptics insist that Lastminute's share price should have been more stable. The fact that smaller investors ended up with only 35 shares each - making it difficult for them to make a quick profit because of the high dealing charges - should have locked punters in.

Things might have seemed difficult for Lastminute over the past few days. But the real test will come next month when the company makes the first of its quarterly reports to the market. A month later, it will issue interim results. If the company's growth rates appear to be faltering, the slide in Lastminute's share price could turn into a collapse: smaller investors may end up feeling grateful they were limited to buying so few shares.

Lastminute's supporters maintain that the figures should earn the Internet's two most visible entrepreneurs at least a temporary respite. The number of subscribers doubled from around 600,000 in December to about 1.1 million by early February. The rumours are this will be sustained over March.

And, according to the most recent information available, the business has a 'conversion' rate of around 5 per cent: one in 20 subscribers - those people who have asked to receive information from Lastminute - have bought something from the company.

The fact that Lastminute has banked £120m from the flotation will give the company the financial firepower to continue its expensive marketing campaign to boost its flock and increase enthusiasm for using its services. The Lastminute brand is the second most widely identified UK Internet retailer after Amazon.

But a brand does not a company make. Lastminute is all too aware of this, which is why it is developing software to overhaul its service. By the end of June, it will offer a personalised service that knows what its users like and alerts them to late bargains.

The company is also attempting to develop its business as it starts to roll the brand out across Europe and, ultimately, the US. On the one side it offers bargains; on the other there will be a premium service for people who simply must be on a flight or holiday on a particular date no matter what the cost. Expanding its range of gifts and other services is also key.

These are all laudable aims if Lastminute is to justify its market capitalisation. But turning such dreams into reality is another matter. One problem investors have in working out whether Lastminute's goals are achievable is that, because it makes no profits, conventional financial analysis, the sort which ascribes values to traditional companies, goes out the window.

So instead some analysts use discounted cash flow to try to arrive at a value. Essentially this method looks ahead to a time when the company is expected to be profitable and ascribes a current value to its future cash flows.

'Let's assume that the company's valuation on the day it floated - £570m - is correct. So then you have to ask if that's the case what must the company look like in 10 years' time to justify that current value,' said Brett Christophers, of Informed Sources, a new-media strategy company.

According to his calculations, Lastminute will need '30 million subscribers and a conversion rate of around 20 per cent' by 2010 to have created the cash flow necessary to justify today's £570m price tag. Furthermore, this assumes that profit margins hit 15 per cent and average spend per customer will rise to £1,500 a year. And there is the small matter of sustaining earnings growth after 2010.

Obviously these figures are flexible. Higher conversion rates would allow for lower subscriber numbers for example. But these sort of numbers highlight just how big Lastminute needs to become to justify its original value. Put another way, there are roughly 600 million people in Western Europe and the US. One per cent of them - and that's including the children - need to spend £1,500 each. This is a huge challenge.

Lastminute's first mover advantage is cited by its supporters as a reason that its dreams of global hegemony are not misplaced. But some analysts say supporters would do well to heed the example of CDnow, the online music retailer that took the US and Europe by storm. Like Lastminute, its business plan is based on harnessing the power of the Internet to give customers more choice and cheaper goods. It was and is a fundamentally clever idea, say its supporters. And, like Lastminute, it has spent a fortune on establishing its brand.to build a massive subscriber base across the globe at jaw-dropping speed. Its shares soared. as a result.

But CDnow has failed to extract sufficient revenues from subscribers. It has only around $11m left in its war chest and is about to run out of money, according to reports in the US.

Its share price is now plummeting. 'It will be difficult to call on the market if the company goes back for more money [by issuing more shares]. When you can't sustain the rating, you get into a real financial problem,' one analyst said.

Sooner or later, the fundamentals have to kick in.

webTitle: An unhappy birthday for regional aid

fields.headline: An unhappy birthday for regional aid
fields.standfirst: Rover crisis highlights the unresolved political controversy over Government assistance, writes  Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: Rover crisis highlights the unresolved political controversy over Government assistance, writes Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
Advantage West Midlands is a name you can hardly miss. The Regional Development Agency's monicker screams at you from the landmark 1920s factory that is the gateway to the troubled West Midlands. Until a year ago, it was the English Partnerships' banner that was slung across the seventh storey of Birmingham's old Fort Dunlop. And all the time, while it served as the biggest quango billboard in the land, the building was derelict - a symbol of the failure of regional aid for millions of drivers on the M6 to see.

Now 'The Fort' will undergo a spectacular £42 million transformation. Loft living is coming to Brum - complete with a fourth-floor glass swimming pool, duplex penthouses, restaurants, shops and an art gallery or three.

It is a real achievement in regeneration that Advantage West Midlands is hoping to repeat with Longbridge, the UK's biggest car factory now being dumped by BMW. But new uses for the sprawling site - most of which will be surplus to the requirements of the new venture capital-backed MG Car Company - are hardly the main headache of the Advantage task force. The 50,000 livelihoods that depend directly and indirectly on Rover, and the knock-on effects on the regional economy, are the main concerns of Alex Stephenson, Advantage's energetic and - unusually for a quango - respected chairman.

This time, at least, Stephenson has £152m of aid, granted by the Government last weekend, to deal with the problem. And it far exceeds Advantage's £115m budget for the year, which had been frozen despite the manufacturing problems and escalating job losses across the region, exacerbated by a strong pound.

This Friday, the Regional Development Agencies - eight of them covering England - are one year old. Conceived by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott as the forerunners of full-blown devolution to the regions, they have suffered sniping as toothless tigers trapped in a jungle of bureaucracy. No fewer than three departments - Environment, Transport & the Regions, Trade and Industry and Education & Employment - fund them. They are shadowed by Regional Chambers, representing local councils, business and voluntary bodies, including trades unions.

'There's a real tension. The Government has set them up to placate pressure from the regions but has no idea what they are for,' said Dr Jamie Gough, lecturer in industrial geography at the University of Northumbria. 'They are being asked to come up with strategies for crucial industries, which is all well and good. But they have very few resources and the Government has no national industrial strategy in the traditional sense.'

However, as the £153m grant over Rover shows, much of the criticism - of Prescott initially and Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers more recently - has been directed at the wrong targets. The reason the grant was so forthcoming was that the money had already been earmarked, after much wrangling, for BMW to help Rover develop new models. So it had already cleared the Treasury, which holds the purse strings but rarely receives the flak for not loosening them.

All the RDAs, including Advantage West Midlands, will have their final budgets for the year set this week. So far, the Government has agreed an extra £46m overall, a rise of 4.4 per cent to take the total to £912m, excluding the Longbridge grant. But within that, some of the hardest pressed regions - the North East and the South West - face cuts, while wealthier areas such as East Anglia and the South East will enjoy gains.

'We are still pushing for an increase. We don't really understand, with the problems we faced before Rover, why our core money has been frozen at all,' one Advantage West Midlands source said.

In Britain, the whole issue of regional aid remains politically controversial. Archie Norman, the former Asda boss who shadows Byers for the Conservatives, would scrap the RDAs. The Right's continental counterparts, such as Bavaria's Christian Socialists, on the other hand, have long taken every pfennig of state aid for their industries. And even unreconstructed free-marketeers recognise the need to help areas through body blows such as the Rover crisis.

'I'm against aid as a systematic approach, as it is terribly undermining of regional entrepreneurialism and buttresses the old failing order,' said Patrick Minford, Professor of Applied Economics at Cardiff Business School. 'Except for real emergencies, when you need to give a shot in the arm to places on their uppers. The Welsh Development Agency has done a great job for Cardiff. No doubt the same applies at Longbridge, but we need to look carefully at the impact.'

Prescott's ideal for the English RDAs was the autonomy and considerable powers enjoyed by the WDA and its counterpart Scottish Enterprise. However, as the Government cooled on the whole concept of English devolution, Prescott's wings were clipped before the RDAs came into being on 1 April last year.

The teething problems experienced by Advantage West Midlands have been typical of all its seven sisters. For starters, the body grouped together staff from four bodies used to making their own decisions: English Partnerships in property development, the Rural Development Commission, the West Midlands Government Office and the old West Midlands agency responsible for attracting inward investment. Whitehall also still insists on approving all spending over £5m.

The Regional Chambers, the embryonic devolved assemblies, saw their task as to monitor and second guess the RDAs. And the business people who comprise the majority on RDA boards are used to getting things done without the niceties of dealing with local politicians or unions.

'There have been some misunderstandings of roles, resentment by local authorities of unelected quangos, feathers ruffled and frustrations by government offices which are used to acting like local commissars,' said one member of Advantage West Midlands' 12-strong board. 'But what we have here is a kernel of something good for the future. We are setting up a civil service for the regions. Eventually unelected RDAs will go and we will have local government for the regions.'

Under Stephenson - an engineer, who once headed Rover's engine and components division - Advantage topped the league tables last year for attracting inward investment into an English region. Its 10-year plan, delivered in December, aims to foster growth industries such as engineering design and medical technology, as well as support traditional sectors: cars, ceramics and engineering.

This weekend, however, with doubts over the future of another major factory - tyre-maker Goodyear, which employs 2,000 in Wolverhampton - the danger is that the plight of manufacturing will leave it and the other RDAs as little more than firefighters. And unless the Government adopts a more coherent industrial approach, the private sector will just cherry pick the most lucrative subsidies, no matter what the quality of the jobs and skills created.

'The RDAs will get into competitive bidding for any piece of inward investment. Public money will be wasted like before and all talk of strategy will go out of the window,' said Gough.

fields.headline: Governance is its own reward
fields.standfirst: UK company law is the best in the world - says an American.
fields.trailText: Bob Monks is used to being a gadfly. But on the question of company law reform, the veteran US corporate governance expert and shareholder activist, founder of investment company Lens Inc, shocks professional pessimists not by criticism but by his determined emollience. 'This is a place where the UK has got it right,' he affirms.
fields.body:
Bob Monks is used to being a gadfly. But on the question of company law reform, the veteran US corporate governance expert and shareholder activist, founder of investment company Lens Inc, shocks professional pessimists not by criticism but by his determined emollience. 'This is a place where the UK has got it right,' he affirms.

Accordingly, the lanky Anglophile Monks (who was consulted) is pleased that reform plans announced recently by the DTI leave shareholder value as the driving principle for company management, and back away from the stakeholder emphasis put forward by the Labour Party in opposition.

However, his pleasure is conditional on it being understood that 'most shareholders are not nano-second arbitrageurs nor computer indexers, but rather the long-term beneficiaries of pension funds. These shareholders want their companies run so as to provide retirement income in a clean, safe and civil society.' Making sure companies are run like that is what, for Monks, corporate governance is all about.

In this context, although professing respect for the position of stakeholder advocates such as John Kay, late of Oxford Business School, and the FT's John Plender, Monks maintains that the shareholders versus stakeholders struggle is a fight only for someone determined to have it, since in the long term a company's profitability (and shareholder return) is indivisible from the health of the society it operates in. Knowing at first hand how hard it is to make a profit in the first place, Monks believes that to insist on multiple goals risks a fatal dissipation of management concentration.

If Monks has no hesitation in asserting that the UK is the most favourable country in the world for the exercise of corporate governance, however, that is little comfort for the errant corporations that Lens and its UK partnership, Hermes Lens Asset Management, invest in. Unlike in the US, UK shareholders have the power to call an extraordinary general meeting and hold directors to account.

Monks is also skilled in using less formal channels. He says that in the UK, 'you can talk privately and discreetly with the chief executive and directors and get things done'. In the US, that can only be done in a blaze of publicity through the press - an institution with which Monks maintains cordial and reciprocally profitable relations.

The Internet has given Lens another potent instrument. Its website (www.lens-inc.com) is a huge corporate governance resource, currently waging an entertaining battle to persuade top US companies to disclose details of CEOs' contracts.

Yet although the environment is relatively favourable, UK corporate governance is by no means a done deal. On the contrary: one worry is the constant increase in the sway of global executives, now more powerful (partly because less accountable) than any political leader. So the need to insist on accountability is ever-growing.

The issue of executive pay is less pressing in the UK than the US, where the efforts of headhunters, compensation consultants and lawyers have made extraordinary perks routine. (As well as use of the corporate jet for his own commuting, one US CEO had first-class airfares for his mother written into his deal.) But it still needs to be impressed on executives that with their seven-digit pay packets, they accept 'both a job going beyond the custodial and the need to demonstrate that they are growing the savings entrusted to them safely and well'.

A further priority - and an important part of Monks' life's work - is persuading shareholders to face up to their responsibilities as company owners, and in particular to intervene where governance principles are being ignored or abused. In practice, this means pension and insurance funds, just 200 of which, he points out, own around 17 per cent of all world stocks for their ultimate beneficiaries.

There is already evidence to suggest that good governance pays. Lens itself is a good example: its portfolio has outperformed the S&P 500 index since its inception in 1992. And a McKinsey study found that investors will pay a premium of up to 16 per cent for companies with exemplary governance. To bolster support for the activism thesis, Monks is working on a theoretical investment model which he believes will show that companies that aggressively externalise their costs on to society (polluters, tobacco companies) do less well in the long term than those that are socially responsible.

Although Monks is not shy of making his presence felt (at 6ft 6ins he hardly fades into the crowd), not all his interventions are controversial. As the newly appointed president of the Centre for Board Effectiveness at Henley Management College, he credits his predecessor Sir Adrian Cadbury with almost singlehandedly creating concepts now recognised as corporate governance worldwide.

From this vantage point, and from his own experience, Monks has enormous sympathy for directors who have no direct power of their own, only as a team, and who are faced with a 'book of Genesis' of regulation but much less guidance as to how they should work in practice. 'Many decisions have to be taken with incomplete information under poor time conditions,' he says. 'We need outside directors comfortable with change and able to bring a vision of that to the people running the business.'

This, in fact, sums up the major challenge for corporate governance in the UK. 'The modality of business is change,' Monks says. But this poses severe problems for traditional industry, such as Rover. But whereas the US adores change and the volatility that goes with it, here there is more that people wish to preserve. At present that seems to give the US an advantage: but is adapting mindlessly to change the answer? Monks points to his alma mater, Cambridge, as proof that the old isn't incompatible with the new, and that venture capital can sit well with ancient portals as well as virtual ones.

'The UK is superbly positioned for this kind of future,' he says.

webTitle: A few grey hairs around the place

fields.headline: A few grey hairs around the place
fields.trailText: One of the resoundingly positive messages of redundancy in 2000 is that people who are laid off tend to find work again quickly, says research organisation IRS. About a third of people are employed again within three months, according to its Labour Force Survey.
fields.body:
One of the resoundingly positive messages of redundancy in 2000 is that people who are laid off tend to find work again quickly, says research organisation IRS. About a third of people are employed again within three months, according to its Labour Force Survey.

But the good news is mainly limited to the under-40s. 'Ageism is absolutely rife in this industry,' says Richard Lynch of banking union Unifi. 'If you're over 40, your chances aren't that good. If you're over 50, it can be hell.'

Even though employers are supposed to be following a voluntary, government-inspired code against ageism, they are not putting it into practice. Lloyds TSB, for instance, is deservedly hailed for its work on 'life/balance' issues but has done virtually nothing on ageism. Since everyone gets older, this is a spectacular instance of turkeys voting for Christmas.

Why does it happen? Outplacement consultant Jo Bond says: 'Younger managers don't feel confident managing older people. It's sometimes thought better, too, to see the future around you - that is to see younger people. And older people are sometimes seen as being less flexible and adaptable.'

In physical jobs, younger people are likely to have more stamina and fewer health problems. The best advice for older people is probably to consider going freelance or working on a temporary or casual basis. The notoriously ageist computer industry rarely puts 50-somethings on permanent employment contracts but is often happy to employ them on six-month or other temporary agreements.

Looking fit and young also helps. A shortage of 20-somethings over the next 20 years will ease the position of older workers - but, in the long run, legislation is probably the only satisfactory answer.

fields.headline: Isa guidelines at a glance
fields.trailText: • To invest in an Isa you must be resident in the UK for tax purposes and aged 18 and over.
fields.body:
 To invest in an Isa you must be resident in the UK for tax purposes and aged 18 and over.

 Investments held in an Isa are free of capital gains and income tax.

 You can invest up to £7,000 in the curent tax year (1999/2000) and the next tax year (2000/2001).

 Of this total, up to £3,000 can be invested in a mini cash Isa, up to £1,000 can be invested in a life insurance mini Isa and up to £3,000 in a stocks and shares mini Isa. Each mini Isa can be opened with a different Isa manager. You can open one of each type of mini ISA every tax year.

 Or you can invest up to £7,000 in a maxi Isa. This can hold a combination of cash, insurance or stocks and shares, subject to the £3,000 cash maximum and £1,000 insurance maximum, or you can invest entirely in stocks and shares.

 You may not open a maxi and mini Isa in the same tax year. Once you have opened a mini or maxi Isa, you cannot change it to the other type.

 You can transfer up to £9,000 capital from a maturing TESSA into a TESSA-only Isa to continue earning interest tax-free. This does not apply to interest from a maturing TESSA.

 The Government has introduced a set of standards - the CAT standards - which some product providers have chosen to adhere to on a voluntary basis. Isas that meet the CAT standards are deemed to have low charges, provide easy access and have reasonable terms.

 If you open too many mini Isas, or a mini Isa and a maxi Isa in the same tax year, you will be required to close the offending Isas on a last in, first out basis. For example, if you open a maxi Isa after opening a mini, the maxi will have to be closed and any returns earned in the interim are taxed at the relevant rate.

 From April 6, 2001, the investment limits will fall to £1,000 for cash, and £5,000 for a maxi ISA.

webTitle: Be first to grab the hidden bargains

fields.headline: Be first to grab the hidden bargains
fields.standfirst: Cash minis are big value, writes  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Why pay tax on your bank or building society account when you can have a cash mini-Isa and get the interest tax free? Cash Isas work like ordinary savings accounts. Yet many people seem to be ignoring them.
fields.body:
Why pay tax on your bank or building society account when you can have a cash mini-Isa and get the interest tax free? Cash Isas work like ordinary savings accounts. Yet many people seem to be ignoring them.

One leading providers, the Halifax, expects to have opened more than l million of the new accounts by the end of the tax year, but what are the rest of its 15 million savers doing? The Nationwide has 8 million savers, but so far only just over 500,000 have opened cash mini-Isas.

Sheltering your savings from tax is not the only reason these Isas make sense. The rates of interest on these accounts are much higher than on ordinary ones, even on quite small amounts of money. Rates of more than 7 per cent are available on deposits as low as £1.

All savers need some cash on deposit for short term needs and emergencies, so most people could profit from a cash mini-Isa.

Justin Modray of independent financial adviser Chase de Vere says: 'The only people who should not have a cash mini-Isa are those who want to invest more than £3,000 in a share Isa because if you have a cash mini-Isa, you are not allowed to have a maxi share Isa for £7,000.'

Most people do not have more than that to invest in a share Isa, and Modray believes the reason many savers have not opened cash Isas is that they are confused about the rules.

Fortunately, with these accounts there is little you need to know. The only real restriction is the amount that can be invested. In this tax year and next, it is is £3,000, but from 6 April 2001 this falls to £1,000.

Once you have opened an account, there is no fixed period for which you need to leave your money other than the individual terms of the account itself. Many have instant access.

Financial advisers point out that there are a variety of savers who could benefit from opening a cash Isa. They include:

 People in their twenties who are often saving for holidays, cars or the deposit on their first home. A cash Isa is ideal for these purposes.

 Thirty-somethings who find that saving is often difficult because of the other demands on their incomes, especially if they have children. They need to try to build up a sum of at least three to six months' earnings as a cash cushion for emergencies. Tucking it into a cash Isa means you may not be so tempted to spend it.

 The over fifty-fives. As people near retirement and then stop working, it often pays to adopt a more cautious investment strategy. A financial adviser may suggest keeping at least 20 per cent of your assets in cash, or even more if your resources are modest. Sheltering as much as you can from tax in a cash Isa will help improve your returns.

But don't take the first one offered by your bank or building society. Interest rates vary considerably so it is important to shop around.

Halifax, for example, has one of the lowest rates, of 4.15 per cent for amounts up to £1,000, compared with 7.05 per cent at the Coventry Building Society. If you invest the £3,000 maximum you might only get 5.55 per cent from a Royal Bank of Scotland account, when you could get 7.25 per cent from the Internet bank, Smile.

It is important, too, to consider the terms. Some of the top paying accounts are notice accounts, so they will not be suitable if you may need instant access to your money.

webTitle: Fast work can stamp on house tax rise

fields.headline: Fast work can stamp on house tax rise
fields.standfirst:
There's just one day left until the extra duty on the sales of dearer homes takes effect, says Rachel Fixsen
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Fast-moving solicitors could save their clients thousands of pounds tomorrow by completing home sales before the increases in stamp duty on more expensive homes takes effect.
fields.body:
Fast-moving solicitors could save their clients thousands of pounds tomorrow by completing home sales before the increases in stamp duty on more expensive homes takes effect.

The new rates will affect only sales completed on or after Tuesday. But as long as the contracts were exchanged before the end of Budget day, last Tuesday, you can still pay the old, lower, rates - even if your purchase is completed after that date.

Anticipating that the Chancellor would crank up stamp duty rates, buyers and sellers were still rushing to exchange contracts on their deals right up to Budget day, estate agents say.

However, even if contracts have not yet been exchanged, you could still get your sale through at the lower levy rates, as long as exchange and completion happen before Tuesday. This would mean these two normally separate stages in a house sale will have to be simultaneous.

'It is all do-able if you have the will,' says Paddington-based solicitor William Heath.

Local authority searches can be done within a day if the conveyancer does them directly rather than relying on the post, he says. For a same-day exchange and completion, the money for the transaction would have to be available instantly, and both parties would have to have agreed all terms.

'Apart from this, there is no real difficulty,' he says.

Someone buying a house for £600,000 could save £3,000 in stamp duty by completing the sale before Tuesday, though Heath doubts whether such savings are really important to a buyer spending over half a million pounds.

In his Budget, Gordon Brown announced that stamp duty on purchases of residential and commercial property would rise from 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent for transactions of £250,000, and from 3.5 per cent to 4 per cent for properties costing more than £500,000.

Stamp duty on purchases of homes priced at between £60,000 and £249,000 remains at 1 per cent, and there will still be no levy to pay on transactions involving less than £60,000.

But anyone hoping that the increases will cool the overheated property market, particularly in the South of England, may be disappointed.

On the contrary: they are likely to have a modest inflationary impact, argues John Gully of the Portman building society. He believes that vendors are likely to react by raising their asking price in an effort to cover the extra duty they will have to pay on their own next house purchase.

Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents, said he thought the tax rise was aimed at bringing the level of UK taxes closer to those elsewhere in the European Union.

'As it's having no effect on dampening house prices, our suspicion is it's a back-door way of harmonising taxes with the rest of Europe,' he said.

The sudden step up in the tax rate at the £250,000 level could cause distortions in house prices. Estate agents say it is already common for parties in the sale of a house with a price tag of just over the £250,000 or £500,000 thresholds to create complicated deals to stay in the lower tax band. In some cases, the official selling price is kept just below the threshold, but fixtures and fittings are sold for between £10,000 and £20,000.

The Inland Revenue says 95 per cent of residential property transactions are unaffected, as they involve less than £250,000.

Of those that are hit, Gully believes people in the South of England will be far harder hit than those in the North.

fields.headline: Gordon's oil secret
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Oil revenues could raise the projected UK budget surplus for 2000-2001 by £1 billion or more, Whitehall sources say.
fields.body:
Oil revenues could raise the projected UK budget surplus for 2000-2001 by £1 billion or more, Whitehall sources say.

Despite the recent rise in the oil price to between $25 and $30 a barrel, the cautious Chancellor has assumed it will fall to $21. This should mean that for every $1 above $21 that the price averages in the coming year, revenues will be £200m higher.

The Treasury's Economic and Fiscal Strategy report last week showed that, without the spending increases announced on Budget day, the current Budget surplus was expected to be £17bn in 2000-01, compared with £11bn forecast as recently as the November Pre-Budget report.

After public spending rises costing a net £3bn unveiled last week, the surplus was projected at £14 bn. But there is a widespread suspicion that Gordon Brown has been so cautious generally that this may be too gloomy.

fields.headline: New crisis hits car plants
fields.standfirst:
Whitehall pleads for Dagenham | Rolls-Royce under threat | BMW rejected Rover offers
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Desperate negotiations are under way between the Government and Ford to try to avert the end of car production at Dagenham. Such a move would cut 4,000 jobs and push the UK motor industry closer to disaster.
fields.body:
Desperate negotiations are under way between the Government and Ford to try to avert the end of car production at Dagenham. Such a move would cut 4,000 jobs and push the UK motor industry closer to disaster.

As the crisis deepened at Ford and Rover, it emerged that the future of Rolls-Royce Motors is also in jeopardy.

Fears are mounting that BMW will be forced by its financial predicament to abandon plans to take over production of the world's most famous car from Volkswagen in 2003.

Meanwhile, VW has been accused of starving the marque of investment while it concentrates on producing Bentleys.

The Rover row intensified when it emerged that Ford, General Motors and Volkswagen all offered separately to take control of the UK carmaker, but walked away after being refused a stake in BMW as part of the deal.

Government and motor industry sources told The Observer they were increasingly pessimistic about Rover's prospects, and expected bad news at Ford.

Whitehall officials are in 'daily contact' with Ford executives, and 'constantly' briefing Ministers, including Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers.

The main aim is to save carmaking at Dagenham, but the Government also wants to avoid being caught out if the worst happens. It was embarrassed at being wrong-footed when BMW sold Rover without warning 10 days ago.

Last month Ford announced a sweeping review of its European manufacturing operations aimed at cutting overcapacity.

A DTI source said: 'We have been in discussions with Ford and they have kept us in the picture as to what is happening. This is not going to be another Rover-BMW, where we were not in the picture.'

DTI sources refused to comment on whether a pre-emptive rescue package or plans for a task force similar to those for the Midlands had been drawn up, because Ford would not finalise its review until late April. One said: 'I can't rule anything in or out.'

Union chiefs are due to meet Ford's new European president, David Thursfield, in London on Tuesday, and are threatening industrial action if the Dagenham plant is closed or reduced to making only engines.

One senior industry observer said: 'Ford will say goodbye to Dagenham, that's the end of carmaking there. The next Fiesta will be produced solely in Cologne.'

Tony Woodley, national motor industry negotiator at the Transport & General Workers Union, said: 'We have got an agreement with Ford that when the Halewood factory was switched from producing the Escort to making Jaguars, Dagenham would have a new car and investment. If the company does not honour the agreement we will be in dispute.'

Woodley said that, contrary to earlier hopes, no mass car manufacturers had come forward to consider buying Rover since BMW broke up the company and agreed to dispose of the vast Longbridge car plant in Birmingham to venture capital group Alchemy and Land Rover to Ford.

At a meeting of 400 senior shop stewards last week, union leaders called on the Government to renationalise Rover.

Woodley said: 'There is no outside manufacturer looking to purchase the whole of Rover. Tens of thousands of people are going to be sacked. The chances of having an ongoing, credible car business with suppliers, dealerships, research and development... are nil.'

Industry sources say VW, Ford and GM were interested in Rover, but wanted a stake in BMW.

Their plans are believed to have had support from members of the BMW board, but were vetoed by the controlling Quandt family.

BMW will announce its annual results in Munich on Tuesday. It is expected to report a one-off cost of disposing of Rover of £1.8 billion on top of the UK group's 1999 losses of £760 million.

Thousands of people are due to march through Birmingham on Saturday to protest against the break-up of Rover.

webTitle: £2bn telecom plan fires up British Gas

fields.headline: £2bn telecom plan fires up British Gas
fields.trailText: The gas giant BG is planning to construct a nationwide broadband cable network within two years at a cost of up to £2 billion.
fields.body:
The gas giant BG is planning to construct a nationwide broadband cable network within two years at a cost of up to £2 billion.

The pipeline and exploration group is believed to favour BSkyB and Kingston Communications, the former Hull City Council telephone network floated last year, as partners in the venture.

Last week BG chairman Richard Giordano confirmed that the company was interested in telecoms when he announced a split of its Transco gas pipeline operation from its overseas operations.

The national fibre-optic network, to run alongside the firm's gas pipes, will be able to carry Internet, TV on demand, data and voice telephony services. It is key to BG's emerging telecoms strategy, which includes making its radio masts available to mobile phone operators.

A deal with BG could make sense for Sky, which has been looking for a chance to move its services from satellite to a network platform. It has been linked with BT before, but a BG network could also fit its strategy, and would provide a negotiating position.

BG has spelt out its plans at a round of City briefings. It said it was likely to reach a decision on the project soon.

One insider said BG believed it could rival Energis, the highly successful business telecoms and data provider spun out of National Grid in 1997. The BG network goes into more than 20 million households.

'If they had launched this three years ago, they would be in there rivalling Energis,' the insider said. 'But at that stage they were too involved in the demerger of British Gas into BG and Centrica [the gas sales company].'

Another said: 'They are serious about this. They are thinking both about big investment to build the network and about going in with a market leader. They are talking to lots of people but they favour BSkyB and Kingston.'

Executives at BG believe the company - whose shares closed at 346p on Friday - is undervalued, and should be worth up to 430p, without the telecoms venture.

fields.headline: The man in the middle
fields.trailText: Investors who think they will get a better deal by buying direct from the product provider will often be disappointed. Those who buy via the growing band of discount brokers, however, could save up to £350 or more on a £7,000 equity Isa.
fields.body:
Cutting out the middleman usually means lower prices, but not so in the investment industry.

Investors who think they will get a better deal by buying direct from the product provider will often be disappointed. Those who buy via the growing band of discount brokers, however, could save up to £350 or more on a £7,000 equity Isa.

An average unit trust has an initial charge of 5 per cent and annual charges of 1 per cent. Out of these charges, the groups will usually pay their main distribution channel, the IFAs who sell their products, a 3 per cent marketing allowance and a 0.5 per cent renewal commission to reward them for their ongoing service to the client over the term of the investment. Not all investors need advice however, and some are quite happy to make their own decisions. But for those who go direct to the company for the fund of their choice, the charges are exactly the same.

People can't understand why going direct isn't rewarded says Craig Wetton, chief executive officer of Bath independent financial adviser Chartwell. 'They think they are being smart and avoiding the commission structure, but companies can't afford to offend the independent financial advisers (IFAs) who support them by selling their products cheaper. So what would otherwise be paid to an IFA is kept by the company.'

This absurd situation is being taken advantage of by a growing number of execution-only discount brokers. They don't offer advice; they simply deliver your application form and cheque to the selected company and then rebate part or all of the initial charge (usually at least 3 per cent but often up to as much as 5 per cent or even more).

Chartwell, in fact, has ruffled a few feathers recently by announcing that it will rebate all initial commission plus half of any annual commission.

HCF Isa Partnership, based in Stanmore, takes the full renewal commission, although as a special offer it is effectively rebating half the first year's renewal on any Jupiter funds.

Don Clark, managing director of TQ Direct Choice reckons that the reason more people don't take the discount route is partly education. 'They don't know we exist; they don't understand how we can sell funds cheaper; or they are worried about security or being bombarded with junk mail.'

On the security angle, he points out that legitimate firms will never handle client's money. Investment cheques should always be made payable to the investment group itself rather than the discounter. He also guarantees that his firm will not junk mail clients.

All of the leading firms now have their own web sites and the general view is that it won't be long before on-screen dealing is widely available.

Selling Isas direct is big business for the investment groups. But as Darius McDermott of Chelsea Financial Services suggests, unless there are no initial charges and no commission payable, or the investor has left things until the very last minute, it would always pay to buy via a discount broker. 'Even the L&G tracker fund, with no initial charge pays 0.25 per cent commission which we can rebate,'

fields.headline: The choice of the experts
fields.standfirst: Four independent financial advisers penetrate the hype and tell  Alistair McArthur  which growth Isas they rate
fields.trailText: Investment firms desperate to attract new Isa business are bombarding potential investors with advertising on TV, in the press and even through the letter box.
fields.body:
Investment firms desperate to attract new Isa business are bombarding potential investors with advertising on TV, in the press and even through the letter box.

Each firm uses the statistical information which makes its own funds look best, making it hard for potential investors to compare funds on a like-for-like basis. To make the selection process easier for you, Cash asked four leading independent financial advisers for their recommendations for funds designed to generate capital growth.

David Aaron, of the Milton Keynes firm David Aaron Partnership, has chosen Gartmore European Selected Opportunities. Aaron says this fund has a five-star rating from Micropal and a AAA rating from Fund Research.

The fund, launched in 1984, is worth approximately £1.5 billion and is managed by Roger Guy, an economics graduate specialising in European financial analysis. He has 11 years of experience managing European funds, and now heads the Gartmore European Desk.

Aaron feels the economic outlook for Europe is brighter than for a decade, with growth expected to around 3 per cent. The euro is expected to increase in value against sterling and, in the meantime, its weakness will continue to boost exports, driving economic recovery further.

'We anticipate European interest rates to continue to remain low, providing further support for equities,' says Aaron. 'The fund's favourite shares are Nokia, Eriksson and Phillips, and the manager's philosophy allows for a minimum of 50 per cent in larger blue chip European companies, with a balance in smaller companies and shorter term selected opportunities, including technology.'

European Selected Opportunities has grown by 124.4 per cent over the last three years, 272.2 per cent over five and 442.1 per cent over 10 years. 'It very much remains among the top performers in Europe,' says Aaron.

Mark Dampier, the head of research at Hargreaves Lansdown, picks the Sarasin EquIsar Isa, a global fund that invests in five key themes, which can change. The present themes are e-commerce, technology, industrial deflation, world energy and corporate restructuring.

Fund manager Michael Jennings picks blue-chip companies that represent the themes. According to Dampier, the geographic split of the fund is 30 per cent in the UK, 20 per cent in the US and the balance split between Europe, Japan and the Far East.

The fund, which was launched over five years ago, has achieved an average return of 16 per cent a year.

'For people who want diversification, it is a good fund,' says Dampier. 'Its global spread means that investors are not betting all their money on one horse.'

Andy Cowan, a director at the Edinburgh office of Aitchison & Colegrave, picks two funds from Newton to achieve capital growth: the Continental European and the Higher Income .

Cowan says the Newton Continental European fund has an excellent record from investing in companies in mainland Europe.

He uses the Higher Income fund to achieve capital growth by reinvesting the income. 'By reinvesting the dividends in this way, it is possible to support the underlying value of the fund,' he says.

Cowan points out that the growth on both funds has been admirable. 'The Continental European fund has achieved a return of 26.5 per cent a year over five years and 14.1 per cent a year over 10 years,' he says. 'During 1999, it achieved a return of 44.2 per cent.'

The Higher Income fund has produced returns of 17.8 per cent a year over five years and 12.5 per cent a year over 10 years. It achieved a return of 18.2 per cent in 1999. Cowan believes these funds suit investors who can tolerate medium risk and want growth over a medium term.

Aberdeen Technology is the choice of Robert Reid, a director of North London firm Syndaxi.

The fund aims to provide above-average, long term capital growth from an international portfolio of shares in companies involved in high tech industries. Over the last year it has grown by 182.4 per cent, by 443.2 per cent over three years and 877.2 per cent over five years.

The fund, which was launched in February 1982 and is managed by John Pullar-Strecker, invests primarily in the US but Japanese and UK stocks also form an important part of the portfolio.

Reid likes Aberdeen Technology because it does not just invest in dot.com companies, but in the companies that support them. 'In a gold rush, it is sometimes best to invest in the companies that make the shovels,' he says.

 Further information: Gartmore 0800 289336; Sarasin 020 7246 0440; Newton 0171 332 9000

webTitle: Are high-tech shares too hot to handle?

fields.headline: Are high-tech shares too hot to handle?
fields.standfirst: Enjoy the thrills but beware the spills, warns  David Hunt
fields.trailText: As the boom in high-technology stocks continues, much of the talk is not if the bubble will eventually burst, but when...
fields.body:
As the boom in high-technology stocks continues, much of the talk is not if the bubble will eventually burst, but when...

Low risk investors who have avoided the thrills and spills of technology funds probably have mixed feelings. Some may be kicking themselves for having missed out on the massive gains. Others are probably thankful that they won't get caught up in the bloodletting when the crash comes.

But just because an investor hasn't taken the positive step of investing in a technology fund, doesn't necessarily mean that they aren't exposed to the sector. Managers of a whole range of UK and international funds have been piling into technology stocks in an effort to get a piece of the action.

And, because of the changes to stock market indices, investors in tracker funds, often sold on the basis of being a good first step into the stockmarket - now find themselves indirectly exposed to this sector.

Edinburgh Fund Managers, which is launching a technology fund in April, is already active in the area via its UK Smaller Companies, and UK Growth funds. 'Smaller Companies has around 50 per cent invested in technology stocks,' says Marianne Cantley, head of marketing, while the UK Growth fund has about the same amount in IT, media and telecoms stocks.

Christopher Clarke, chief investment officer of giant international general investment trust Witan, now has around 30 per cent in what he calls 'new growth' stocks. 'Clearly if we had not reacted at all we would have produced a much poorer performance than we did last year,' he says.

'We allocated £100 million from the mainstream UK to pure growth and that's been a good move. The trust is about as far up the risk spectrum now as I wish it to be.'

Clarke has taken a few profits along the way, but is watching the market carefully. 'There is bound to be a setback at some stage,' he says, but he doesn't believe there will be a crash. 'Some air will come out of the balloon, but it won't necessarily go pop.'

He also points out that one of the advantages of an investment trust over a unit trust is that, because the investment trust is structured as a company with a fixed number of shares, should a crash occur, he won't be forced to sell stocks to meet redemptions. In contrast if a large number of unit trust holders decide to sell their units, the fund manager may be forced to liquidate part of his portfolio at the worst possible time to realise the necessary cash.

Another of the big international general trusts, Alliance, has tended not to follow the herd. Investment director Alan Young says: 'We do have weightings in some of these areas although we give a miss to the dot coms. Alliance is a long-term investor and we don't tend to do well in frothy conditions when people go for growth at any price.'

Which approach is right? Only time will tell, but last year Alliance paid heavily for its more cautious stance. While the other giants of the sector all returned around 22 per cent, Alliance gained only 11 per cent.

Jason Hollands of Best Investment is more concerned about investors in tracker funds. 'For many years index trackers have been sold as low risk, low cost investments suitable for first time investors in the stockmarkets. But indices have changed so dramatically that you can no longer regard them as low risk,' says Hollands.

Hollands points to Vodafone which now represents over 10 per cent of the FTSE 100 index and the recent changes which have seen 'boring, profit making household names forced out by high tech, media and telecoms companies.'

webTitle: Take your pick of the income funds

fields.headline: Take your pick of the income funds
fields.standfirst: Top independent financial advisers tell  Alistair  McArthur about their favourites
fields.trailText: Investors who need an income from their Isa face a confusing choice. First you have to choose between funds investing in either corporate bonds or equities, or a combination of the two. Then you must sift through hundreds of them to select one which suits you.
fields.body:
Investors who need an income from their Isa face a confusing choice. First you have to choose between funds investing in either corporate bonds or equities, or a combination of the two. Then you must sift through hundreds of them to select one which suits you.

To make this quicker and easier, Cash has asked four independent financial advisers to name the funds they think are best.

Bish Limbu, a fund analyst at Best Investment, likes Fidelity Extra Income.

The fund, yielding 7.4 per cent, was launched in April 1999. Its aim is to invest between 45 per cent and 65 per cent in UK corporate bonds, between 20 per cent and 45 per cent in high yield bonds, between 5 and 15 per cent in European bonds, and up to 10 per cent in gilts.

The manager, Ian Spreadbury, aims to provide the best return without exposing investors' capital to too much risk.

'By investing at least half the assets in quality bonds, the manager has the flexibility to get these results,' says Limbu.

He feels people who need an income from their investments, but want to limit the risk to their capital should consider hybrid funds such as Fidelity Extra Income.

'Hybrid portfolios may be the way forward,' he says. 'Pure high yield bonds are not worth the risk for the extra income.'

Lynne Maltby, a manager at Willis National, favours Perpetual Monthly Income Plus. It invests mainly in high yielding bonds, with some of the assets invested in UK shares. The minimum investment is £500 as a lump sum, or £20 a month.

About 80 per cent of the fund is in high yield bonds, which could pose a threat to investors' capital because of the higher possibility of default by the bond issuers. In addition, capital could erode because the annual charge, 1.25 per cent, is taken from capital, not income.

However, the three fund managers, Neil Woodford, Paul Causer and Paul Read, aim to reduce this risk by investing up to 20 per cent of the portfolio in income-yielding equities to produce some capital growth.

The fund yields about 8 per cent, which can be taken quarterly or monthly.

The fund was launched in February 1999, and has achieved a return of 11.1 per cent since. It is second out of 81 similar funds in its sector during that period.

Ian Millward, of Chase de Vere Investments, likes the Aberdeen Fixed Interest fund. 'It has a large amount of its money in high yield bonds and provides an income of 8 per cent or more,' he says.

The fund's aim is to provide a high yield from a portfolio of preference and other fixed interest securities. Veteran Paul Reed manages the fund, which was launched in 1979. Millward says: 'It has been one of the best-performing funds for a long time.'

It has returned 4.7 per cent over one year, and 32.7 per cent over three years. Income is payable quarterly.

Robin McGowan, of Inter-Alliance, favours the Framlington UK Bond fund. 'Its aim is longer-term, rising income and capital growth with security to the underlying capital,' he says.

The fund, managed by Chris Murphy, provides a yield of 4.97 per cent, with the annual management charge deducted from income. McGowan says: 'It has none of the volatility associated with equities.'

Its assets are invested 90 per cent in UK bonds and 7 per cent in overseas bonds. The balance is invested in cash and other securities.

The fund has achieved a return of 8.53 per cent over one year and 76.5 per cent over five years.

 For more information: Aberdeen 0345 886660; Fidelity 0800 41416; Perpetual 01491 417000; Framlington 0845 777 5511

fields.headline: Another last-minute rush
fields.standfirst: Helen Pridham reports on how to get your Isa application in on time
fields.trailText: Managers of Individual Savings Accounts (Isas) are doing their utmost to encourage investors to make use of their annual investment allowance by the end of the tax year on 5 April. The frenzy of activity is not as hectic as last year when Personal Equity Plans (Peps) were about to disappear for good, but it is not far off.
fields.body:
Managers of Individual Savings Accounts (Isas) are doing their utmost to encourage investors to make use of their annual investment allowance by the end of the tax year on 5 April.

The frenzy of activity is not as hectic as last year when Personal Equity Plans (Peps) were about to disappear for good, but it is not far off. The fact that Chancellor Gordon Brown has extended the £7,000 Isa investment allowance for a further year is unlikely to calm investors or product providers.

Companies are urging people not to leave their decisions to the last moment but they know human nature means there will always be some who get round to it only just in time. To cater for latecomers, some companies will be keeping their offices open until midnight next Wednesday but many have also set earlier deadlines, so don't rely on your Isa provider being one of those which is open late.

Most companies have stories of people turning up at the last minute. At Virgin Direct, which has its head office in Norwich, Gordon Maw recounts: 'One chap drove up the A11 to deliver his Pep form just before midnight but he had forgotten his wallet and so we had to lend him £20 to buy petrol for the return journey.'

Roger Cornick of Perpetual, based in Henley-on-Thames, recalls one investor sending a last-minute application from Birmingham by motorcycle courier, while Don Clark of discount brokers TQ Direct, who hired a helicopter last year to bring late Pep applications from Wolverhampton to London, said one investor arrived just minutes before it took off.

This year it should be much easier for late applicants providing they have a Switch or Delta card (credit cards are not accepted). You can invest in an Isa using a debit card via the Internet or over the phone. Until recently, only Fidelity, M&G and Johnson Fry were accepting Internet applications but they are being joined by others including Aberdeen, Gartmore, Jupiter and Perpetual. Fidelity, M&G and Gartmore are among those which will accept your investment over the phone.

In theory, those organisations which offer Net and phone dealing will be able to accept your investment up to midnight on 5 April, although M&G is advising investors not to leave it any later than 11.30pm.

If you are reluctant about investing online, you can still use the Net to download the Isa application form. Virgin Direct, for example, offers this facility while discount brokers TQ Direct can provide Isa applications over the Net for around 600 funds.

Otherwise, you will have to allow a day for managers to send a form through the post. You will then have to be sure your cheque reaches them on time. If you want to take out an investment trust Isa, you may need to act particularly quickly. A number of IT managers are battening down the hatches as early as this Tuesday. They include Ballie Gifford, Dresdener RCM, Edinburgh Fund Managers and Templeton Investment Management.

However, most will be accepting investments at least until their usual close of business at 5pm on 5 April so you have until 4 April to send your application by post, although you are advised to send it by guaranteed next-day delivery.

A number of fund managers have arranged collection points in hotels. Invesco and Aberdeen, for example, are accepting personal applications at nine hotels on 3,4 and 5 April during normal office hours. Locations include Belfast, Birmingham, Cambridge, Leeds and Manchester. Other managers with hotel pick-up points include Fidelity and Jupiter, while Virgin Direct will accept applications at Virgin Megastores in London, Birmingham and Manchester until normal closing times.

The alternative is to take it direct or send a courier to a company head office. Those open until midnight on 5 April include Jupiter in London, Perpetual in Henley-on-Thames, M&G in Chelmsford, Gartmore in London & Brentwood, Virgin Direct in Norwich and Fidelity in Kent and Surrey.

If you do leave it until the last minute, don't forget to complete the form in full. Omitting the name of the fund you wish to invest in or forgetting to sign the form (both common mistakes) could make your application invalid.
