fields.headline: High fees, 'low performance'
fields.standfirst: A new study questions fund managers' claims that their upfront fees allow research that brings better returns, says  Bruce McWilliams.  And the new Cat standards are working for investors
fields.trailText: A new study questions fund managers' claims that their upfront fees allow research that brings better returns, says Bruce McWilliams.
fields.body:
Do charges for funds make a difference? Fund managers have traditionally justified the 5 per cent or so they charge up front on the grounds that the money is spent on detailed analysis to achieve superior returns. But a new study for Norwich Union shows that higher charges actually drag down performance.

A wide variation exists on the charges you pay for an investment fund held in an Individual Savings Account (Isa). First, there is the initial fee, which includes sales commission for your independent financial adviser and other expenses incurred by the fund manager in setting up your investment. Some funds charge 1 per cent or less as an initial charge, but the vast majority charge about 5 per cent.

The second charge is an annual management fee. This pays the fund manager to manage and administer the fund you have chosen, and may include a portion to cover the cost of renewal commission for your financial adviser. Again the annual management fees can vary widely, from 0.5 per cent to 1.5 per cent and even 2 per cent in some cases. Both initial and annual charges include an element of profit for the fund manager.

The cheapest funds tend to be index trackers, which passively invest in all shares included in a particular index, such as the FTSE All Share index, without regard to the outlook for those shares. These funds often have no initial charge, and an annual management fee of about 0.5 per cent. They are cheap because they do not require highly paid fund managers to pick stocks.

In contrast, 'actively managed' funds, where the fund manager aims to pick the winners and avoid the losers, charge as much as 6 per cent initially, and have annual management charges as high as 1.75 per cent a year. Active fund managers argue that the expertise and research necessary to produce good returns costs money, and that skimping on charges can prove a false economy.

However, a quick look at the performance tables shows that high charges are no guarantee of good performance. Figures from performance analyst WM show that only one in every four UK fund managers has beaten the market in any five year period, and over 20 years, only 15 per cent of managers out performed the market before charges were deducted. Schroder UK Enterprise and Perpetual UK Growth, which are both worth more than £1bn and have enough investors to fill Wembley Stadium, have initial charges of 5.25 per cent and annual charges of 1.5 per cent and 1.25 per cent respectively.

But their performance has done little to justify the costs - over three years Schroder UK Enterprise languishes in the 110th position out of 129 UK growth funds, while Perpetual UK Growth is just one off the bottom in 128th position.

A few actively managed funds have chosen to submit to voluntary Government Cat benchmark guidelines, which limit total expenses to less than 1 per cent a year. Fitzrovia Associates, which specialises in investment fund expenses research, undertook the study for Norwich Union to compare performance of these actively managed Cat funds with actively-managed funds not adhering to the Cat cost guidelines.

Over the last 11 months, actively managed Cat-standard funds grew by an average of 27.38 per cent, compared with 5.51 per cent for the non-Cat standard funds. Worse still, more than half the actively managed non-Cat funds have yet to make any money - they are still struggling to make up the cost of their initial charge.

Mark Skinner, sales and marketing director at Norwich Union Investment Funds, says the superior performance of the Cat standard funds is caused by having most, if not all, your money invested and earning for you from day one.

'Clearly it is low charges, as guaranteed by the Cat standard, which make a difference to the real returns to the investor. But very few fund managers are willing to cut their charges and sacrifice their profit margins. With these sorts of vested interests, it is no surprise that so few providers are willing to offer Cat standard value to their investors. However, as independent research continues to underline their importance, actively managed Cat standard funds cannot be dismissed as the poor relations. Far from it, in this financial year, their track record both has been considerably superior.'

Unfortunately, as few actively managed unit trusts and open ended investment companies (OEICs) offer such low charges, it is difficult to form a balanced and low cost portfolio. Graeme Currie of independent financial advisers Alan Steel Asset Management says that when selecting for clients, it is important to get the right mix of funds to meet their objectives: growth, income, capital preservation, and lower volatility.

'If you focus solely on low charges you may end up with a portfolio that does meet your overall goals,' he says.

By selecting only Cat standard funds, investors would exclude many smaller company funds, technology funds, and Far Eastern funds.

However, further research by Fitzrovia International has revealed that the size-weighted average total expenses of investment trusts are 60 per cent lower than that of retail equity-based unit trusts and OEICs. The average expense for investment trusts is 0.83 per cent, 0.55 per cent less than the average 1.38 per cent for unit trusts and OEICs.

Daniel Godfrey, director general of the Association of Investment Trust Companies, says: 'The study shows that large investment trusts are an exceptionally efficient way of managing money. Their lower charges give them a head start in the performance race. A 0.55 per cent difference in total expenses over ten years on a £10,000 investment between two funds would amount to over £1,300, assuming growth of 10 per cent. The cheaper fund would be worth £27,263, over 5 per cent more than the more expensive fund at £25,937.'

webTitle: Cheers of entrepreneurs are balanced by sole traders' fears

fields.headline: Cheers of entrepreneurs are balanced by sole traders' fears
fields.standfirst:
Andrew Bibby decodes mixed messages for small businesses
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The Budget came with a promise from Gordon Brown to reward enterprise. Small business people are only half convinced.
fields.body:
The Budget came with a promise from Gordon Brown to reward enterprise. Small business people are only half convinced.

Apart from the concessions on capital gains tax on business assets, small businesses have had a pledge that the 'temporary' 40 per cent first-year allowance on capital expenditure is to become permanent. Capital allowances are available to both incorporated businesses and the self-employed.

One hundred per cent capital allowances for information and communication technology mean that costs can be written off against tax in the year of purchase.

Smaller businesses are also benefiting from a fall in corporation tax. Companies which make no more than £10,000 will be taxed at 10 per cent, and there is a sliding rate up to 20 per cent on profits up to £50,000. The 20 per cent rate applies up to £300,000 profits when the standard 30 per cent rate cuts in. The corporation tax reduction may encourage some sole traders and partners to choose company incorporation rather than self-employment.

The Budget did its best to promote e-commerce. Software companies, often precluded by a quirk in the rules from accessing capital via the Enterprise Investment Scheme and Venture Capital Trusts, should benefit from changes in the two schemes. For investors, the main change is a reduction in the minimum holding period from five to three years. The Budget also introduced a Corporate Venturing Scheme, offering tax relief for firms investing in small high-risk businesses.

However, the Federation of Small Businesses is unhappy that the Budget has little for the four million self-employed. Though they benefit from the new capital allowance rules, there are some painful changes to the National Insurance regime announced in the 1999 Budget but operating from this April. These involve a reduction in the flat-rate NI Class 2 'stamp' from £6.35 to £2 but an increase in the profit-linked Class 4 contributions from 6 per cent to 7 per cent. Class 4 contributions will also be levied on a greater percentage of profits. While the changes will benefit the self-employed on low incomes, more profitable sole traders could face a net additional NI payment of more than £300.
fields.bodyText: The Budget came with a promise from Gordon Brown to reward enterprise. Small business people are only half convinced. Apart from the concessions on capital gains tax on business assets, small businesses have had a pledge that the 'temporary' 40 per cent first-year allowance on capital expenditure is to become permanent. Capital allowances are available to both incorporated businesses and the self-employed. One hundred per cent capital allowances for information and communication technology mean that costs can be written off against tax in the year of purchase. Smaller businesses are also benefiting from a fall in corporation tax. Companies which make no more than £10,000 will be taxed at 10 per cent, and there is a sliding rate up to 20 per cent on profits up to £50,000. The 20 per cent rate applies up to £300,000 profits when the standard 30 per cent rate cuts in. The corporation tax reduction may encourage some sole traders and partners to choose company incorporation rather than self-employment. The Budget did its best to promote e-commerce. Software companies, often precluded by a quirk in the rules from accessing capital via the Enterprise Investment Scheme and Venture Capital Trusts, should benefit from changes in the two schemes. For investors, the main change is a reduction in the minimum holding period from five to three years. The Budget also introduced a Corporate Venturing Scheme, offering tax relief for firms investing in small high-risk businesses. However, the Federation of Small Businesses is unhappy that the Budget has little for the four million self-employed. Though they benefit from the new capital allowance rules, there are some painful changes to the National Insurance regime announced in the 1999 Budget but operating from this April. These involve a reduction in the flat-rate NI Class 2 'stamp' from £6.35 to £2 but an increase in the profit-linked Class 4 contributions from 6 per cent to 7 per cent. Class 4 contributions will also be levied on a greater percentage of profits. While the changes will benefit the self-employed on low incomes, more profitable sole traders could face a net additional NI payment of more than £300.

webTitle: Time is ripe for income fund investments

fields.headline: Time is ripe for income fund investments
fields.standfirst: High returns can outweigh tax-free status, but this could still be the time to buy, says Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: High returns can outweigh tax-free status, but this could still be the time to buy, says Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
One of the major advantages of Isas is that they can provide a tax-free income. But unfortunately traditional equity income funds, which invest in shares, do not look so attractive now even within a tax-free environment.

Income yields are low compared with the rates from fixed-interest investments. The average for income funds is around 3.4 per cent, compared with 6.3 per cent from corporate bond funds.

More seriously, capital values have been falling. Over the last six months, the once high-flying Jupiter Income Fund has slumped nearly 15 per cent on a total return basis, and Perpetual High Income has fallen more.

Instead of seeing this as a bad sign, however, some advisers are arguing that now is an ideal time to invest in these funds. If you need to take an income from your savings, the main incentive for using them is their excellent long-term record of paying out bigger dividends each year. Although you may start off with less income than from a building society or corporate bond fund, historically equity funds have produced a higher return in the long run.

This is supported by past performance data from the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds, which shows that over the 10 years to 1 January the annual income on £1,000 invested in an income fund would have grown from £43 to £58 after 10 years, while the savings income on an average building society account fell from £98 to £22.

Naturally, some equity income fund managers have been better at growing their income than others. The latest survey from Principal Premier, independent financial advisers who specialise in income funds, shows that the best dozen income funds - including BWD Equity Income, Jupiter Income and Newton Higher Income - have increased their dividends by an average of 94 per cent in the past five years.

However, capital growth is also an important part of the equation with equity income funds. It is this which really sets the funds apart from building society accounts or bond funds, where growth is likely to be little or nothing.

AUTIF's figures say the capital invested in an average equity income fund would have grown 91 per cent over the ten years to 1 January, compared to 23 per cent in an average corporate bond fund.

Many income funds have been losing money recently, however, even though the stock market in general appears to be going up. The problem is that activity has concentrated on so-called growth stocks which pay little or no income, while the more type of stocks which income funds invest in have been out of favour.

Steve Glynn of Jupiter explains: 'Over the last six months growth stocks in the technology, media and telecommunications sectors have been propping up the index. Income funds can only have a limited exposure to growth stocks, and have therefore been hard pressed to make progress.'

Neil Woodford, manager of two of the industry's largest income funds, Perpetual Income and High Income, says: 'There has been a bear market in equity income shares but sooner or later they will recover.

'Many household name companies are looking ludicrously cheap. The share price of Next, for example, is languishing, even though the company is flourishing and growing its profits. It is a similar story with other companies.

'They are all growing nicely. Economic conditions are favourable. Their true value has obscured by the obsession with technology stocks, but there are signs that the tide is turning.'

Some equity income funds have managed to avoid losing too much ground by incorporating growth stocks in their portfolios. Several now have a concentration of smaller, high-yielding companies at one end of their portfolios to provide the bulk of the income. FTSE 100 holdings occupy the middle ground and growth stocks at the other end to keep the capital growing.

These funds include ABN Amro Equity Income and Invesco GT Income, which have all done well.

But equity income funds are still worthwhile, says Mark Dampier, head of research at independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown. 'The shares they hold are usually in sound companies making good profits. They may be deeply out of fashion but that is usually the best time to buy. When the tide turns, they could bounce back quickly.'

webTitle: With the world to choose from

fields.headline: With the world to choose from
fields.standfirst: Technology stocks are dominant everywhere, but geography still matters, says  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Technology stocks are dominant everywhere, but geography still matters, says Heather Connon.
fields.body:
Technology and telecom shares have been driving the performance of stock markets from Hong Kong to the US. Whether you should join them depends on your attitude to risk.

'There is a split between the old and the new economies wherever you look. It is a global theme; you could talk about the new economy being overvalued and the old economy being undervalued,' said Michael Hayden, managing director of Legal & General unit trusts.

That means investors need to be clear about what they want from their investments, regardless of the region they choose.

Hayden recommends that investors look carefully at how different funds approach their investments. And - not surprisingly, given that most of L&G's range of funds are designed to track the index - he says that investors should consider buying a tracker, where they can at least be certain about the level of exposure to technology.

Technology fever has been fuelling stock markets around the world, masking the poor performance of traditional shares, particularly in the UK and United States . In these two countries, some would say we are already perhaps 18 months into a full-blown bear market - and, some fund managers believe, that is throwing up opportunities.

Richard Scott, who manages Exeter Warrant and Global Opportunities Fund and Exeter Pacific Growth Fund, points out that while the US Standard & Poor's index is roughly flat so far this year, if you exclude technology and telecoms it has fallen around 15 per cent. But he warns that there are already signs that margins are contracting, limiting the scope for some companies to grow. That has already been demonstrated in the recent shock profit warning by Procter & Gamble. Scott warns that what happens in the US is often quickly followed by the rest of the world.

Richard Urwin of Gartmore agrees that there is already a bear market in some stocks and says that, in aggregate, the US does not look too expensive. But he cites the prospect of further rises in interest rates and warns that it is best to wait until rates seem close to their peak, which could be at least six months away, before putting money into the US.

Markets in Europe have been powering ahead: unfortunately, British investors have not enjoyed their share of the gains as the euro has continued to slide against the pound. However, this is the reason why, together with some attractive economic portents, most fund managers are positive about investing there.

Keith Wade of Schroders points out that, while the performance of the euro has eroded returns for British investors, it has 'helped support the recovery in Europe.'

Richard Urwin of Gartmore agrees Europe looks attractive, both for its robust growth and because of the pace of restructuring.

However, like Wade, he cites changes in German tax legislation, which will allow the unwinding of the web of cross-holdings which has characterised the local industry, as a positive feature. The successful bid for Mannesmann by Vodafone Airtouch, the first ever hostile takeover in Germany, suggests that things are changing.

For most fund managers, Europe takes second place to Japan - despite the recent statistic suggesting it had dropped back into recession. Wade says the statistics are not a good guide to the economy, and were expected anyway as the Japanese government has been gradually reducing the fiscal stimulus, through increased public spending, that it has been using to kick-start the economy. Most of Schroders' funds are overweight in Japan.

Again, the big corporations are restructuring and there is evidence that profit increases are coming through. L&G's Hayden agrees that makes Japan look attractive. 'On a five-year view, Japan looks attractive, almost regardless of what happens in the short-term.'

Emerging markets, both in Asia and Latin America , has come right back into

favour. Some have already performed well but most fund managers believe there is still some way to go.

Gartmore's Urwin is typical: 'These regions tend to do well if there is firm global economic growth and economies elsewhere are firm'.

Exeter's Scott is particularly enthusiastic about the Pacific Rim. These are recovering strongly but are largely being ignored by international investors.

Some trusts he sees as particularly good value - like Templeton Emerging Markets or Henderson Far East, both of which are trading on more than 20 per cent discounts.

None of the fund managers can get particularly excited about Britain. Interest rates are still rising, our economic growth will be less strong than in Europe and the markets do not look particularly cheap.'

More positive is M & G's Hughes. 'The UK has been an underperforming market of late and it now looks reasonable value.'

webTitle: Two-horse TV race could leave 47 also-rans

fields.headline: Two-horse TV race could leave 47 also-rans
fields.trailText: The battle to broadcast British racing on television and the Internet is set to become a two-horse race. A US company is mounting a challenge to a consortium made up of Channel 4, the BBC and cable firm NTL.
fields.body:
The battle to broadcast British racing on television and the Internet is set to become a two-horse race. A US company is mounting a challenge to a consortium made up of Channel 4, the BBC and cable firm NTL.

The consortium is in exclusive negotiations with Britain's top racecourses, the Super 12, and will start talks tomorrow with the 47 others.

But TVG, a subsidiary of US magazine giant TV Guide, a company whose sharehold ers include News Corporation and AT&T, wants to prise the 47 smaller tracks away from the Channel 4-led bid. TVG, which has secured media rights to some of the largest tracks in the US, is looking to build a global horseracing network, and is keen to put British races on its channel.

The news that it has been talking to some of the UK courses will shock Channel 4, which had been having discussions with TVG about swapping media rights.

However, Peter Burnand, TGV's UK representative, said it had now decided on a different strategy. 'We had hoped from the outset that we could be invited to work with the consortium, but we've not had an invitation to do so. We've moved to shore up our position, and the message that we have been putting across [to the courses] is that we are furlongs ahead. We are a player.'

At the heart of both media groups' strategies is a desire to turn racing into an interactive sport, with viewers able to bet on races through their television screens. The Channel 4 consortium plans to launch a dedicated racing channel on satellite and cable.

TVG is rumoured to be seeking an alliance with Sky.

Some observers suggest racing would suffer if the courses split into two groups. However Kim Deshayes, acting chief executive of the Super 12, said: 'We would very much like the other courses to come on board with us.'
